instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: LinkedIn Users Were Targeted in a Social Engineering Attack
LinkedIn users, located in Italy, and working in the aerospace and avionics sectors were targeted in a social-engineering attack. According to a report from Telsy, the attack began with users receiving private messages from an account that impersonated an HR recruiter.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: LinkedIn Users Were Targeted in a Social Engineering Attack
LinkedIn users, located in Italy, and working in the aerospace and avionics sectors were targeted in a social-engineering attack. According to a report from Telsy, the attack began with users receiving private messages from an account that impersonated an HR recruiter.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Social Engineering, APT




# Overview

A social-engineering attack that targeted LinkedIn users has been analyzed by Telsy. The analysis, that began in May 2020, led Telsy to conclude with medium confidence that the attack is linked to the APT group commonly known as MuddyWater (also known as Mercury and Static Kitten). The attribution is based on code and infrastructure overlap. The targets of the attack were LinkedIn users located in Italy and working in the aerospace and avionics sectors. The attack began with the victim receiving a private message that asked them to download an archive file containing information about a job. The private messages came from an account that impersonated an HR recruiter for a company dealing in satellite imagery. The archive contained a vCard file (.vcf) file and a folder named http, which contained another file. If the victim opened the vCard file the infection chain is kicked off. The file exploited a vulnerability identified as ZDI-CAN-6920. The vulnerability allows for the vCard file to execute the file contained in the http folder. The executed file, in turn, opened the victim's web browser while downloading a PowerShell script in the background. There are several further stages in the infection chain, which culminates with a RAT being installed. Persistence is achieved using a Registry key and a Startup folder item. Certain information is collected and forwarded to a C&C server. At this stage, if the infected host is not considered relevant to the operation, the C&C server will respond with a command that will put the malware in an infinite sleep loop. Further information, including a detailed analysis of the infection chain, is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.telsy.com/wp-content/uploads/Operation_Space_Race.pdf>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Ad Blocker Injecting Ads Into Legitimate Websites
Researchers at Imperva Research Labs have identified a false ad blocker extension that injects ads into legitimate pages. This extension is available on Chrome and Opera browsers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

Summary
=======



Attack Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Adware
* **Targets:** eCommerce
* **Malware Family/Families:**PBot, AllBlock
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Extension Download
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown

Overview
========

Imperva Research Labs recently uncovered a malicious browser extension that injects malicious adverts into links present on a web page. This particular extension is available on both Chrome and Opera browsers and is called AllBlock. This extension could be used to generate revenue for clicks, sabotage a competitor's site by making their website unusable, or redirect customers to a competitor's site. When a page is loaded, AllBlock sends a list of the links present to a remote server. This server then responds with a list of domains it wants to redirect the user to from those links. These links often have affiliate codes injected into them, allowing the attacker to earn money from the user's clicks. The extension also contains some anti-analysis techniques. Firstly, the extension contains a command to clear the debug console every 100 milliseconds. This conceals the communications between the extension and the remote server. AllBlock also has a built-in allowlist, to prevent it from replacing links from some major websites. This allowlist mainly contains search engines, with a focus on Russian engines. There is a sizeable impact to this kind of attack. It is estimated that 68% of shopping baskets are abandoned and a large part of this could be due to ad injection attempts. This extension has been traced back to another adware campaign known as PBot, which used some of the same back-end infrastructure. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
* Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
* Set a browser extension allow or deny list as appropriate for your security policy (M1038).
* Only install browser extensions from trusted sources that can be verified. Browser extensions for some browsers can be controlled through Group Policy. Change settings to prevent the browser from installing extensions without sufficient permissions (M1033).
* Ensure extensions that are installed are the intended ones as many malicious extensions will masquerade as legitimate ones (M1047).

References
==========

* <https://www.imperva.com/blog/the-ad-blocker-that-injects-ads/>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1176 - Browser Extensions  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
   T1070.003 - Clear Command History  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
   T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Ukrainians Targeted By Formbook Spam Campaign
The MalwareBytes Threat Intelligence Team has been monitoring a phishing campaign targeting Ukrainian citizens. The campaign delivers the commercial malware Formbook.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Target:** Ukrainian Citizens
  *  **Lure:** Offer of Money From Ukrainian Authorities
  *  **Payload:** Formbook
  *  **Compromised Data:** Unknown



# Overview

The MalwareBytes Threat Intelligence Team has been tracking a phishing campaign delivering Formbook to Ukrainian citizens. The malware is delivered as an excel file attachment on an email. The email is claiming to be from the authorities offering money to citizens, with the attachment pretending to be a letter of approval. If opened, the file uses an exploit to compromise the machine and download the Formbook payload. Formbook is commercial malware that is sold as a service on the dark web. It is designed to steal personal information and control infected devices remotely. Since this is a widely used piece of malware, attribution is difficult. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/82641067/Ukrainians%20Targeted%20By%20Formbook%20Spam%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1647271312299&api=v2)



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2022/03/formbook-spam-campaign-targets-citizens-of-ukraine%ef%b8%8f/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
T1112 - Modify Registry  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1012 - Query Registry  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Updates for Cisco Jabber Clients Address Critical Vulnerabilities
Cisco has published a Security Advisory that addresses five vulnerabilities that variously affect the Jabber clients for Windows, macOS, and mobile platforms. The advisory has been rated as Critical by Cisco.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
 The vulnerabilities have CVSS 3.1 Base Scores ranging between 4.3 and 9.9 and are caused a failure to properly handle input to the application's protocol handlers or a failure to properly validate the content of messages. The most serious of the vulnerabilities could be exploited by a remote attacker sending maliciously crafted XMPP messages to a victim. Successful exploitation could potentially result in the execution of arbitrary commands on the underlying operating system. Other potential impacts from successful exploitation of the vulnerabilities include allowing an attacker to obtain access to sensitive information or elevate privileges. The advisory notes that Cisco's PSIRT "is not aware of any public announcements or malicious use of the vulnerabilities that are described in this advisory." Further details, including affected versions and available updates, are available from the Cisco advisory linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-26085, CVE-2020-27127, CVE-2020-27132, CVE-2020-27133, and CVE-2020-27134




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-jabber-ZktzjpgO>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: PurpleFox Using WPAD to Target Indonesian Users
A weakness in WPAD exists that can allow a remote attacker to cause the execution of arbitrary code without user interaction. Trend Micro recently observed the Purple Fox exploit kit abusing this technique to infect victims.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Exploit Kit




# Overview

Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing a Purple Fox campaign targeting Indonesian users. This campaign was specifically designed to implement an old WPAD abuse tactic. The threat actors registered the domain wpad.id so that users on a network with the .id top-level domain may fall victim to a WPAD abuse attack. This occurs if WPAD services are enabled without a WPAD URL set up for the victim network, causing WPAD to iterate over the subdomains until it is able to resolve wpad.id. From that domain, a wpad.dat file is executed; in this case, it's a JavaScript exploit script. CVE-2019-1367 is exploited by this JavaScript file in order to execute shellcode. The shellcode then kicks off an attack chain with multiple stages involving PowerShell and MSI files hosted at remote URLs. Exploited vulnerabilities included CVE-2020-1054 and CVE-2018-8120, as well as an exploit for MS15-051. As with the previous campaign analyzed by Trend Micro, the threat actors once again leveraged Cloudflare proxies. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/g/purplefox-using-wpad-to-targent-indonesian-users.html>

A weakness in WPAD exists that can allow a remote attacker to cause the execution of arbitrary code without user interaction. Trend Micro recently observed the Purple Fox exploit kit abusing this technique to infect victims.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: RCE Possible via Microsoft Print Spooler
CERT/CC has issued a vulnerability note addressing a Microsoft Print Spooler Remote Code Execution flaw. Functional exploit code has been made available for this vulnerability.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

##  _Update July 2nd, 2021_

Microsoft is now tracking this vulnerability via [CVE-2021-34527](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2021-34527). Additionally, IBM Security QRadar published a blog post providing two rules that can be used to search Sysmon logs for signs of exploit activity. Guidance on these detection rules can be found here: <https://community.ibm.com/community/user/security/blogs/gladys-koskas1/2021/07/01/printnightmare-critical-windows-print-spooler-vuln>.

##  _Original Report_

CERT/CC's Vulnerability Note VU#383432 addresses a Microsoft Print Spooler Remote Code Execution flaw. The RpcAddPrinterDriveEx( ) function allows for unauthenticated attackers to execute code with system-level privileges. A parameter, DRIVER_CONTAINER, contains information about which driver a printer uses while another argument, dwFileCopyFlags, is used to detail how replacement drivers are copied. By utilizing a call to RpcAddPrinterDriverEx( ), any authenticated user can specify a driver that is hosted on a remote server. The resulting spoolsv.exe executes code in an arbitrary DLL with system-level privileges. An update from Microsoft addressed CVE-2021-1675, however, this update does not address the public exploit detailed above. Exploit code, called PrintNightmare, exists that targets Active Directory domain controllers. CERT/CC is not aware of a practical solution to the issue. They have issued a workaround which involves stopping and disabling the Print Spooler service. Additionally, a PowerShell script is available [here](https://blog.truesec.com/2021/06/30/fix-for-printnightmare-cve-2021-1675-exploit-to-keep-your-print-servers-running-while-a-patch-is-not-available/) that will implement ACL restrictions for the system print spooler. The aforementioned script was not developed by IBM X-Force and should be run at your own risk. Further information will be made available as it is disclosed.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-1675




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

  * Disable Microsoft Print Spooler service
  * Restrict the ACLs on the "C:\Windows\System32\spool\drivers" directory to prevent malicious DLLs from being introduced to the print spooler service (PowerShell Script available [here](https://blog.truesec.com/2021/06/30/fix-for-printnightmare-cve-2021-1675-exploit-to-keep-your-print-servers-running-while-a-patch-is-not-available/)).



# Reference

  * <https://kb.cert.org/vuls/id/383432>

  * <https://blog.truesec.com/2021/06/30/fix-for-printnightmare-cve-2021-1675-exploit-to-keep-your-print-servers-running-while-a-patch-is-not-available/>
  * <https://msandbu.org/printnightmare-cve-2021-1675/>
  * <https://community.ibm.com/community/user/security/blogs/gladys-koskas1/2021/07/01/printnightmare-critical-windows-print-spooler-vuln>

parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

##  _Update July 2nd, 2021_

Microsoft is now tracking this vulnerability via [CVE-2021-34527](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2021-34527). Additionally, IBM Security QRadar published a blog post providing two rules that can be used to search Sysmon logs for signs of exploit activity. Guidance on these detection rules can be found here: <https://community.ibm.com/community/user/security/blogs/gladys-koskas1/2021/07/01/printnightmare-critical-windows-print-spooler-vuln>.

##  _Original Report_

CERT/CC's Vulnerability Note VU#383432 addresses a Microsoft Print Spooler Remote Code Execution flaw. The RpcAddPrinterDriveEx( ) function allows for unauthenticated attackers to execute code with system-level privileges. A parameter, DRIVER_CONTAINER, contains information about which driver a printer uses while another argument, dwFileCopyFlags, is used to detail how replacement drivers are copied. By utilizing a call to RpcAddPrinterDriverEx( ), any authenticated user can specify a driver that is hosted on a remote server. The resulting spoolsv.exe executes code in an arbitrary DLL with system-level privileges. An update from Microsoft addressed CVE-2021-1675, however, this update does not address the public exploit detailed above. Exploit code, called PrintNightmare, exists that targets Active Directory domain controllers. CERT/CC is not aware of a practical solution to the issue. They have issued a workaround which involves stopping and disabling the Print Spooler service. Additionally, a PowerShell script is available [here](https://blog.truesec.com/2021/06/30/fix-for-printnightmare-cve-2021-1675-exploit-to-keep-your-print-servers-running-while-a-patch-is-not-available/) that will implement ACL restrictions for the system print spooler. The aforementioned script was not developed by IBM X-Force and should be run at your own risk. Further information will be made available as it is disclosed.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-1675




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

  * Disable Microsoft Print Spooler service
  * Restrict the ACLs on the "C:\Windows\System32\spool\drivers" directory to prevent malicious DLLs from being introduced to the print spooler service (PowerShell Script available [here](https://blog.truesec.com/2021/06/30/fix-for-printnightmare-cve-2021-1675-exploit-to-keep-your-print-servers-running-while-a-patch-is-not-available/)).

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Malicious Telegram Installer Spreading Purple Fox Rootkit
A new attack spreading the Purple Fox Rootkit has been discovered. What makes this attack special is that the attack is divided into many small files, which is effective in avoiding detection by antivirus tools. This has been detailed by Minerva Labs.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Rootkit
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Purple Fox Rootkit
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

Minerva labs has published a report on a new malicious installer that drops the Purple Fox Rootkit. In this example, the installer was pretending to be for Telegram. Upon execution, the installer creates a new folder and drops both the legitimate Telegram installer and a malicious downloader named 'TextInputh.exe'. The malicious downloader drops more small malicious files and executes them to continue the attack. The use of lots of small files means that this attack is fairly stealthy, as researchers found that these files had a very low detection rate. If the malware detects antivirus, it drops five more files which work together to shut down and block the antivirus processes, allowing the attack to continue without detection. Once the files have been dropped and executed, the malware sends all the host information including what security software is running to the C2 server. The researchers analyzed the C2 IP in the sample they were investigating and found that the last stage of the attack was the download and execution of the Purple Fox rootkit. The researchers speculate that the installer was likely being spread through both phishing emails and phishing websites. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056579/Malicious%20Telegram%20Installer%20Spreading%20Purple%20Fox%20Rootkit%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641377272095&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://blog.minerva-labs.com/malicious-telegram-installer-drops-purple-fox-rootkit>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1543 - Create or Modify System Process  
T1543.003 - Windows Service  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1546 - Event Triggered Execution  
T1546.015 - Component Object Model Hijacking  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1012 - Query Registry  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Bait Used in Instagram Profile Hacking Scheme
A new Instagram credential harvesting campaign has been discovered by Trend Micro. Although this campaign appears to be perpetrated by the same actors as their previously reported on campaign, the lure and tactics have changed.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Trend Micro has discovered a new Instagram credential harvesting campaign being carried out by the same actors as the campaign they previously reported on. This Turkish-speaking threat group is targeting celebrities, business owners, and other accounts with sizeable followings. Although an account verification phishing email was previously used as the initial lure, the attackers have moved away from that method in this new campaign. They are, instead, using Instagram's built-in messaging platform to send direct messages to potential victims. This message indicates that a copyright violation was filed and they need to fill out a form to prevent their account from being deleted. Clicking the link to the supposed form leads to a page requesting the account username. The next page then requests a "known name," password, and email username and password. Submitting the form exfiltrates the credentials to the attacker and redirects the victim to the legitimate Instagram website. With credentials of both the Instagram account and the associated email account, the attackers are able to change the email associated with the Instagram account to one they own and unlink the original cell phone number. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/vinfo/us/security/news/cybercrime-and-digital-threats/new-bait-used-in-instagram-profile-hacking-scheme>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: IBM Security Guardium Security Bulletins
IBM has published two security bulletins addressing vulnerabilities in IBM Security Guardium and Guardium Big Data Intelligence (SonarG)..

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

IBM has published two security bulletins addressing vulnerabilities in IBM Security Guardium and Guardium Big Data Intelligence (SonarG).

Security Bulletin 6348664 addresses eight vulnerabilities in DB2 which is used by IBM Security Guardium. If successfully exploited, the vulnerabilities could allow a local attacker to manipulate data, or a remote attacker to cause denial of service conditions or execute arbitrary code.

Security Bulletin 6348664 addresses one vulnerability in a third-party Cryptographic library which is used by IBM Security Guardium Big Data Intelligence (SonarG). A weaker than expected cryptographic algorithm could allow an attacker to decrypt highly sensitive information.

Further details, including affected versions and available updates which address the vulnerabilities, are available from the advisories linked below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/32146060/IBM%20Security%20Guardium%20Security%20Bulletins%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1603079492131&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/6349177>
  * <https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/6348664>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: CoinSpot-Themed Phishing Campaign
Unsurprisingly, the recent hype around cryptocurrency has led to Cofense observing an uptick in crypto-themed phishing campaigns. Their blog post details once such campaign targeting CoinSpot users.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: CoinSpot-Themed Phishing Campaign
Unsurprisingly, the recent hype around cryptocurrency has led to Cofense observing an uptick in crypto-themed phishing campaigns. Their blog post details once such campaign targeting CoinSpot users.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** CoinSpot users
  *  **Lure:** CoinSpot withdrawal confirmation
  *  **Payload:** Link to fake CoinSpot login page
  *  **Compromised Data:** CoinSpot account credentials, 2FA code



# Overview

Cofense published a blog post analyzing a crypto-themed phishing campaign using the CoinSpot cryptocurrency exchange as part of their lure. The email uses CoinSpot branding and purports to be a withdrawal confirmation. Buttons are provided to either confirm or cancel the transaction, but both lead to a Netlify link that ultimately redirects to the phishing page. The landing page is almost an exact copy of the legitimate CoinSpot login page and is hosted on a lookalike domain. Upon entering credentials, victims are further asked for a 2FA code. Finally, they are redirected to the official CoinSpot website in an attempt to allay suspicions. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the REference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056463/CoinSpot-Themed%20Phishing%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1640715302355&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/cryptocurrency-and-exchange-phish-used-to-steal-user-information/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1598 - Phishing for Information  
T1598.003 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Attackers Fight for Control of Sites Targeted in File Manager Vulnerability
Expanding on their analysis of attacks exploiting a vulnerability in the File Manager plugin, Wordfence has provided details regarding two key actors performing this activity.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Attackers Fight for Control of Sites Targeted in File Manager Vulnerability
Expanding on their analysis of attacks exploiting a vulnerability in the File Manager plugin, Wordfence has provided details regarding two key actors performing this activity.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor




# Overview

Wordfence previously reported on exploit activity targeting a vulnerability in the Wordpress File Manager plugin. After further monitoring of this activity, they discovered two key threat actors behind the attacks. The first actor, dubbed "bajatax," injects malicious code into multiple files in order to exfiltrate credentials of users logging into the victim site. Credentials are exfiltrated via the Telegram API and are likely either sold for profit or used to access other accounts using the same credentials. The second attacker is installing backdoors onto victim servers. This actor also leverages a different method of exploitation than bajatax. With backdoors installed on the system, the attacker injects additional malicious code into WordPress files. Possible final goals include cryptomining, SEO spam, or leasing access to a botnet. Both threat actors are adding password protection to the vulnerable file in order to prevent other attackers from infecting the server, allowing them to maintain control. Numerous additional threat actors have been observed, but these two actors are most prevalent and most successful. For more information, see the Wordfence blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.wordfence.com/blog/2020/09/attackers-fight-for-control-of-sites-targeted-in-file-manager-vulnerability/>

I have encountered the following information: Ranzy - Ransomware as a Service
The Ransomware as a Service, Ranzy, is derived from the ThunderX ransomware. Ranzy appeared after decryptors for ThunderX became freely available. A report from SentinelOne delves into Ranzy and its evolvement since ThunderX.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

The core of the Ranzy ransomware is a Ransomware as a Service (RaSS) system that is believed to have been an evolvement of the ThunderX ransomware. One of the primary changes made to Ranzy was the improvement of the encryption method as ThunderX's encryption method had failings which allowed decryptors to be created and made freely available. The methods used to exfiltrate victim data which could be used for extortion were improved and, in addition, a blog where the exfiltrated data could be published was established. According to SentinelOne, Ranzy is primarily delivered through emails though in some instances drive by download sites have been used. The initial versions of Ranzy appended a .RNZ extension to encrypted files but this has now been changed to the .ranzy extension. Ranzy contains an RSA-2048 key and Salsa20 is used for encryption. Ranzy will encrypt multiple file types while avoiding encrypting system files. Like many ransomware families, Ranzy will delete shadow copies and modifies boot options. It will attempt to terminate processes which may be holding files open, so they can be encrypted. Ransom notes are left in each directory where files have been encrypted. The latest Ranzy variant directs victims to a ToR site for payment, instead of email which prior versions used for communication with victims. Further details are available from the SentinelOne report which is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/ranzy-ransomware-better-encryption-among-new-features-of-thunderx-derivative/>

Tell me about the following threat: K-Electric in Pakistan Suffers Netwalker Ransomware Attack
Breach / Leak Notification: An electricity provider in Pakistan, K-Electric, has suffered a Netwalker ransomware attack. According to a media report the, the attack has impacted online services, including billing.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: K-Electric in Pakistan Suffers Netwalker Ransomware Attack
Breach / Leak Notification: An electricity provider in Pakistan, K-Electric, has suffered a Netwalker ransomware attack. According to a media report the, the attack has impacted online services, including billing.

# Threat Type

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

  
K-Electric, the sole electricity provider for Karachi, Pakistan, has suffered a Netwalker ransomware attack that led to the disruption of billing and online services. K-Electric is Pakistan's largest power supplier, serving 2.5 million customers and employing over 10 thousand people. Starting yesterday, K-Electric customers have been unable to access the online services for their account.

# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/netwalker-ransomware-hits-pakistans-largest-private-power-utility/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Remote Code Execution Vulnerabilities Affect Drupal Core
A Security Advisory for Drupal, SA-CORE-2020-013, addresses critical remote code execution vulnerabilities in the PEAR Archive_Tar library, which is used by the Drupal core.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
The Drupal Security Advisory, SA-CORE-2020-013, provides an update for various versions of Drupal core to address remotely exploitable code execution vulnerabilities in the Drupal core. The vulnerabilities are rated as critical by Drupal. The vulnerabilities exist in the PEAR Archive_Tar library and are caused by a failure to properly sanitize user provided input when processing URI handlers in filenames. A remote attacker who can upload maliciously crafted .tar, .tar.gz, .bz2, or .tlz files could potentially execute arbitrary PHP code on an affected system. The vulnerabilities are addressed in versions 7.75, 8.8.12, 8.9.10, 9.0.9. Further details are available from the advisory linked to in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [Remote Code Execution Vulnerability Affects Drupal Core CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33983867/Remote%20Code%20Execution%20Vulnerability%20Affects%20Drupal%20Core%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606446648437&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.drupal.org/sa-core-2020-013>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: XML Vulnerabilities in Go's Standard Library
Mattermost has responsibly disclosed three XML vulnerabilities in Go's standard library.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

Mattermost, working with Go's security team, has responsibly disclosed three XML vulnerabilities in Go's standard library. These include an XML attribute instability (CVE-2020-29509), an XML directive instability (CVE_2020-29510), and an XML element instability (CVE-2020-29511). In essence, if your application is processing information that has already gone through Go's decoder and encoder functions at least one time before, the application may be processing invalid data, since Go's decoder and encoder does not preserve the semantics of the data. The lack of integrity is a major issue in applications that require absolute semantic integrity in order to be secure, such as SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language). The notification indicates that the Go team cannot, at this time, reliably and reasonably address the issues. Only one of the issues is on the Go roadmap to be addressed in the foreseeable future. Mattermost is releasing an XML validation library that can be used as a workaround until a full patch can be released. For more details, please refer to the disclosure notification in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [XML Vulnerabilities in Gos Standard Library CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35718356/XML%20Vulnerabilities%20in%20Gos%20Standard%20Library%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1608064748127&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * https://mattermost.com/blog/coordinated-disclosure-go-xml-vulnerabilities/

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Bangladesh Organizations Being Targeted
The Dhaka Tribune has published an article on 6 Bangladeshi organizations being targeted by hackers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing, Botnet




# Overview

Kasablanca is a threat group that is targeting 6 Bangladeshi organizations in a campaign to intercept sensitive data from either Android or Windows devices. The group was said to have deployed a new RAT in a previous campaign; however, there has been signs of that RAT being used in this campaign. The e-Gov CIRT, Bangladesh's e-Government Computer Incident Response Team, has identified several phishing sites set up for the purposes of obtaining sensitive information from the targeted organizations. The CIRT has not found a specific reason for the targeting but, as previously stated, phishing sites have been set up. The group is using the organizations as the backbone of the phishing websites. Additionally, 8 other sites have been setup using other organizations for phishing. The group's typical motives for campaign's targeting is to spread a botnet to as many computers and mobile devices as possible. The victims could be targeted due to their collection of National ID card numbers, financial information, and other information. In each instance, the targeted organizations have taken extra security measures to mitigate any current or future threats or infiltrations. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.dhakatribune.com/business/2021/02/22/hackershave-eye-on-6-bangladeshi-organisations>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: ICS-CERT Advisories February 16 2021
ICS-CERT has published three advisories that affect Hamilton-T1, Open Design Alliance Drawings SDK, and Rockwell Automation Allen-Bradley Micrologix 1100.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: ICS-CERT Advisories February 16 2021
ICS-CERT has published three advisories that affect Hamilton-T1, Open Design Alliance Drawings SDK, and Rockwell Automation Allen-Bradley Micrologix 1100.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarised below.

 **ICS Medical Advisory ICSMA-21-047-01 - Hamilton-T1**  
CVE-2020-27278 - Hard-Coded credentials in the ventilator allow attackers with physical access to obtain admin privileges for the device’s configuration interface.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 3.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:P/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:N).

CVE-2020-27282 - An XML validation vulnerability in the ventilator allows privileged attackers with physical access to render the device persistently unusable by uploading specially crafted configuration files.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 4.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:P/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).

CVE-2020-27290 - An information disclosure vulnerability in the ventilator allows attackers with physical access to the configuration interface's logs to get valid checksums for tampered configuration files.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 2.1 - CVSS Vector String: AV:P/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsma-21-047-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-047-01 - Open Design Alliance Drawings SDK**  
CVE-2021-25178 - The affected product is vulnerable to a stack-based buffer overflow while processing malformed DXF and DWG files. This could allow an attacker to execute code or cause a denial-of-service condition.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-25177 - A type confusion issue exists when rendering malformed DXF and DWG files. This could allow an attacker to execute code or cause a denial-of-service condition.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-25176 - A NULL pointer dereference exists when rendering malformed DXF and DWG files. This could allow an attacker to execute code or cause a denial-of-service condition.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-25175 - A type conversion issue exists when rendering malformed DXF and DWG files. This could allow an attacker to execute code or cause a denial-of-service condition.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-25174 - A memory corruption issue exists when reading malformed DGN files. This could allow an attacker to execute code or cause a denial-of-service condition.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-25173 - A memory allocation with excessive size issue exists when reading malformed DGN files. This could allow an attacker to execute code or cause a denial-of-service condition.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H)  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-047-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-047-02 - Rockwell Automation Allen-Bradley Micrologix 1100**  
CVE-2020-6111 - A vulnerability exists with the processing of ICMP packets with an invalid IPv4 length in the MicroLogix 1100. This vulnerability could allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to send malformed packets and cause the controller to enter 8H Hard Fault. This event would lead to denial-of-service conditions. To recover from the condition, the controller must be power cycled and the project redownloaded.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-047-02>

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/40993499/ICS-CERT%20Advisories%20February%2016%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1613527393989&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: MuddyWater Targeting Turkey and Arabian Peninsula in Malware Campaign
According to Hacker News, the threat actor known as MuddyWater, tracked by X-Force as ITG17, is responsible for attacks targeting Turkey and the Arabian Peninsula. Purportedly, the goal in this latest campaign is to deploy remote access trojans (RATs) on compromised systems.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** RAT
  *  **Target:** Nation State
  *  **Lure: **Phishing
  *  **Payload:** SloughRAT (aka [Canopy](https://thehackernews.com/2022/02/irans-muddywater-hacker-group-using-new.html) by CISA)
  *  **Compromised Data:** Unknown
  *  **Post-compromise Actions:** Remote Access



# Overview

In a recent report from Hacker News, the Iranian state sponsored threat actor known as MuddyWater, tracked by X-Force as ITG17, is responsible for attacks targeting Turkey and the Arabian Peninsula. MuddyWater is believed to have been active since 2017 and is also believed to a "conglomerate of multiple teams operating independently rather than a single threat actor group." According to U.S. Cyber Command this is a state sponsored group and they have been attributed to the Iranian Ministry of Intelligence and Security. This latest campaign uses phishing in order to attempt to deliver malicious Microsoft Excel documents with the intent to deploy a remote access trojan called SloughRAT. Additionally, it also seems to pick up where a November 2021 campaign left off that targeted Turkish private organizations and government institutions with PowerShell-based backdoors. For additional details, see the full article linked in the references section below.

  


# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/82640928/MuddyWater%20Targeting%20Turkey%20and%20Arabian%20Peninsula%20in%20Malware%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1646941660328&api=v2)



# CVEs

  * N/A



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://thehackernews.com/2022/03/iranian-hackers-targeting-turkey-and.html>
  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2022/03/iranian-supergroup-muddywater.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

  
 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589.002 - Email Addresses  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583.006 - Web Services  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**

#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1055:** Do Not Mitigate - This category is to associate techniques that mitigation might increase risk of compromise and therefore mitigation is not recommended.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
MuddyWater Targeting Turkey and Arabian Peninsula in Malware Campaign
According to Hacker News, the threat actor known as MuddyWater, tracked by X-Force as ITG17, is responsible for attacks targeting Turkey and the Arabian Peninsula. Purportedly, the goal in this latest campaign is to deploy remote access trojans (RATs) on compromised systems.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** RAT
  *  **Target:** Nation State
  *  **Lure: **Phishing
  *  **Payload:** SloughRAT (aka [Canopy](https://thehackernews.com/2022/02/irans-muddywater-hacker-group-using-new.html) by CISA)
  *  **Compromised Data:** Unknown
  *  **Post-compromise Actions:** Remote Access



# Overview

In a recent report from Hacker News, the Iranian state sponsored threat actor known as MuddyWater, tracked by X-Force as ITG17, is responsible for attacks targeting Turkey and the Arabian Peninsula. MuddyWater is believed to have been active since 2017 and is also believed to a "conglomerate of multiple teams operating independently rather than a single threat actor group." According to U.S. Cyber Command this is a state sponsored group and they have been attributed to the Iranian Ministry of Intelligence and Security. This latest campaign uses phishing in order to attempt to deliver malicious Microsoft Excel documents with the intent to deploy a remote access trojan called SloughRAT. Additionally, it also seems to pick up where a November 2021 campaign left off that targeted Turkish private organizations and government institutions with PowerShell-based backdoors. For additional details, see the full article linked in the references section below.

  


# Indicators of Compromise

# CVEs

  * N/A



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Fake Flash Player with JavaScript Stealers
A new investigation has revealed a familiar pattern in malware being hidden within legitimate files. Sucuri reports on a steganography campaign in which malicious code is hidden within .css files.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Steganography




# Overview

A recent investigation in October by Sucuri found malicious code hidden within .css files. Previous steganography cases have seen legitimate .ico files containing malicious code. The change in delivery method has moved from the .ico format into a .css file. The script being used to deliver the malware is nearly identical to those used previously. A URL is in plain text and is clearly seen in the script. Using a lookalike URL from Facebook, the script tries to load through an XMLHttpRequest to a different URL. The original URL contains a .NET and a .COM extension and actually does not exist. Using specific characters within the script, the method constructs the malicious JavaScript function character by character and, once compiled and processed, is executed. More than 56,000 empty lines can be seen and bring a relatively small fonts.css file to about 150 Kilobytes. Normally ignored, these empty spaces actually contain tab, space, and line feed characters. Once viewed in hex, a piece of hidden code appears in which normal ASCII characters are represented using numeric character codes. Once decoded, an iframe is created and the user is presented with a fake Flash Player update iframe. The iframe window can only be closed by clicking the update button, which then downloads a malicious installer with an HTA file that uses PowerShell to download further malicious files. The malware is hosted on a site registered recently and is unprotected. Within one of the directories, attacked IP addresses are able to be observed. Further technical details can be found in the report within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/11/css-js-steganography-in-fake-flash-player-update-malware.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: SCADA Modbus Reconnaissance Increases
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence has observed an increase in reconnaissance activity targeting the port associated with SCADA Modbus, highlighting an increasing threat to ICS-based networks.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Reconnaissance, Information Leakage




# Overview

IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence analysts have identified a persistent trend within our data that points to a very large increase in reconnaissance activity targeting port 502. This port is commonly used by Supervisory Controls and Data Acquisition (SCADA) Modbus, an application layer messaging protocol used to provide client/server communication between connected Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) devices in an industrial network. Between January and April of 2021, IBM observed a 1,600 percent increase in this activity compared to the total volume of reconnaissance activity for all of 2020. This trend highlights the increasing threat to ICS-based networks, and we encourage clients to review risk mitigations for securing SCADA Modbus. The full report, including mitigation advice, is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# CVEs

  * Associated CVEs can be found in the full report, available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more and see the indicators at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/49ac3fb1-5414-4582-a5ab-1b0562be7a77>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New Versions of the Necro Botnet in the Wild
New versions of the Necro botnet have been reported by 360Netlab, A number of changes have been made to the new Necro versions, including the adoption of new propagation techniques, and a DGA for C2 domains.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Versions of the Necro Botnet in the Wild
New versions of the Necro botnet have been reported by 360Netlab, A number of changes have been made to the new Necro versions, including the adoption of new propagation techniques, and a DGA for C2 domains.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet, Cryptomining




# Overview

Since the beginning of 2021, 360Netlab has detected three new versions of the Necro botnet. Necro is also known as Python.IRCBot, and N3Cr0m0rPh. The three new versions incorporate a host of new features including propagation using weak Telnet passwords and a 1-day vulnerability (CVE-2020-35665) in TerraMaster TOS, exploitation of some n-day vulnerabilities, increased use of code obfuscation, a domain generation algorithm (DGA) for C&C server domain names, and payloads distributed as both Python scripts and ELF binaries. The compiled ELF binary is used in situations where the infected host does not provide Python 2 due to its EOL status. The exploit for TerraMaster TOS was introduced into the Necro code eight days are the vulnerability was made public. Other payloads downloaded include the xmrig and xmrig1 cryptominers. The same actors are believed to be behind all three of the new versions, and the download servers used for Necro have also been observed hosting Mirai variants and malicious Windows executables. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/necro/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Evolution of GADOLINIUM Attacks
Focusing on the group's activity over the last couple years, Microsoft reports on a threat actor they call GADOLINIUM.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

Microsoft has published a blog post analyzing the activities of GADOLINIUM, a nation-state threat actor. Most recently the group has shifted their focus away from the maritime and health industries and towards higher education and regional government organization in the Asia Pacific region. Before discussing recent activity, the researchers mention activity from 2016 and 2018 leveraging TechNet and GitHub, respectively, to issues C2 commands. Broken down by attack phase, the rest of the blog post focuses on their 2019 and 2020 campaigns. In both cases, spear-phishing emails were used for initial access. At first they leveraged Access 2013 databases to execute a VBA dropper that, in turn, loads a .NET DLL payload. This DLL payload leverages the Outlook Task API for C2 communication. In 2020, they instead used a PPT attachment to drop a .dotm file. In this case, the .dotm file runs a secondary payload that downloads and decrypts a PNG file. The PNG file is responsible for running PowerShell commands that interact with the Microsoft Graph API for further actions. Along with using the Microsoft Graph API to download additional modules, the OneDrive API is used to execute commands and exfiltrate results. After the infection chain is complete, the attacker performs a variety of post-compromise actions, such as credential dumping, lateral movement, and privilege escalation. Both the custom LazyCat malware and web shells were seen in use. Microsoft notes that the group's infrastructure included several Azure Active Directory applications that have since been suspended. For more information, see the Microsoft blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2020/09/24/gadolinium-detecting-empires-cloud/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Aggah Campaign Using Zendesk and GitHub to Host Malicious Files
Juniper Threat Labs has reported an Aggah malware campaign that, instead of using the likes of BlogSpot, Pastebin, and WordPress to host its malicious files, is using GitHub and Zendesk.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified ****
  * **Malware Family/Families:** Oski, Agent Tesla (S0331)
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious PowerPoint file, delivery vector not specified.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and Exfiltration of sensitive data.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Aggah malware campaigns have in the past been known to host malicious content on legitimate services such as BlogSpot, Pastebin, and WordPress. According to a report from Juniper Threat Labs, an Aggah campaign is now using Github and Zendesk to host malicious files. Juniper analyzed a malicious PowerPoint file that was downloaded from Zendesk. The file contained a macro that used mshta.exe to download and execute a malicious script from Blogspot. One of the operations the script carries out is to add a registry run key that is used to trigger the download of another PowerShell script that contains the Oski infostealer. Another PowerShell script that is downloaded from GitHub installs the Agent Tesla infostealer and RAT. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127356/Aggah%20Campaign%20Using%20Zendesk%20and%20GitHub%20to%20Host%20Malicious%20Files%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1631162647868&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://blogs.juniper.net/en-us/security/aggah-malware-campaign-expands-to-zendesk-and-github-to-host-its-malware>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1585 - Establish Accounts  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1546 - Event Triggered Execution  
T1546.003 - Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.005 - Mshta  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
T1115 - Clipboard Data  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel
