instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New NOBELIUM Backdoor - FoggyWeb
A report from Microsoft provides an analysis of a newly discovered backdoor used by NOBELIUM that Microsoft has named FoggyWeb.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New NOBELIUM Backdoor - FoggyWeb
A report from Microsoft provides an analysis of a newly discovered backdoor used by NOBELIUM that Microsoft has named FoggyWeb.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** NOBELIUM, ITG11
  *  **Associated Payloads:** FoggyWeb
  *  **Targets:** Compromised Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) servers.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** FoggyWeb is a post-exploitation tool.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Deploy FoggyWeb, Collect and Exfiltrate data.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

NOBELIUM is a threat actor known by many names including APT29, Cozy Bear, CozyDuke, Cozys, Dark Halo, Duke Group, Hammertoss, Minis, Office Monkeys, Pitty Tiger, Spikerrush, StellarParticle, TEMP.Monkey, TEMP.Noble, The Dukes, TG-4127, UNC2452, and Yttrium. IBM X-Force tracks NOBELIUM as Hive0099. A report from Microsoft provides an analysis of a new backdoor which Microsoft has named FoggyWeb that has been used by NOBELIUM since at least April 2021. It is a passive backdoor that is specifically targeted to Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) servers. FoggyWeb is installed deployed on compromised AD FS servers by dropping two files onto the system. One file, a DLL is a loader that is executed by Microsoft.IdentityServer.ServiceHost.exe through search order hijacking. In turn, the loader is responsible for decrypting and loading the second of the two files which is the FoggyWeb backdoor. Once active, FoggyWeb configures HTTP listeners that listen for specific URIs defined by the actor. These specific URIs are what provide instructions to the backdoor. FoggyWeb is used to collect and exfiltrate data from the infected server and can install additional payloads. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129463/New%20NOBELIUM%20Backdoor%20-%20FoggyWeb%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633403936443&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2021/09/27/foggyweb-targeted-nobelium-malware-leads-to-persistent-backdoor/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
T1574.001 - DLL Search Order Hijacking  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
T1574.001 - DLL Search Order Hijacking  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
T1560 - Archive Collected Data  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: TA505 and CL0P
A posting on the Deutsche Telekom blog looks at the relationships between TA505 and the operators of the CL0P ransomware, along with some of their activities throughout the past year.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, APT




# Overview

A posting on the Deutsche Telekom blog looks at some of the activities of TA505 and the operators of the CL0P ransomware throughout the past year. TA505 is also known as CHIMBORAZO, Evil Corp, GOLD TAHOE, Graceful Spider, Sector J04, and Temp.Warlock. The group known as FIN11 may also be TA505 or a subgroup of TA505. IBM X-Force tracks TA505 as ITG19. According to Deutsche Telekom, the operators of the CL0P ransomware may also be a subgroup of, or managed by, TA505. Another group known as Silence appears to have some form on relationship with TA505. These subgroups may also be simple clients of TA505 as TA505 tends to focus on gaining access to targets. They may then sell access to the victim's network or hand off to a subgroup or client who conducts further operations, such as the deployment of the CL0P ransomware. Deutsche Telekom noted three waves of spam from TA505 in 2020. The first wave ran January through February, the second June until September, and the last run in early December. TA505 spam is typically sent during weekdays, whereas the CL0P deployments more often occurred on a Friday or Saturday. The emails may contain a link or an HTML attachment, which lead the victim to a malicious document. If the document is opened and macros are enabled, the infection chain begins. CL0P ransoms tend to be based on the revenue of the victim company and a victim's sensitive data will have been exfiltrated prior to the ransomware being executed. The ransom notes are customized to the victim and the CL0P operators maintain a portal where victims can negotiate or pay ransoms. If a victim does not pay the ransom, their sensitive data will be made public on the portal. Further details are available from the Deutsche Telekom blog posting linked to in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.telekom.com/en/blog/group/article/inside-of-cl0p-s-ransomware-operation-615824>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: ICS-CERT Advisories February 11 2021
The ICS-CERT has published two advisories that affect Multiple Embedded TCP/IP stacks and Rockwell Automation DriveTools SP and Drives AOP.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarised below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-042-01 - Multiple Embedded TCP/IP stacks**  
CVE-2020-27213 - Nut/Net software relies on highly predictable source values and has consistent increments when generating initial sequence numbers (ISN), which may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27630 - uC/TCP-IP ISN generation relies on a linear congruential generator (LCG), which is reversible from observed output streams as the algorithm is seeded with publicly recoverable information. This defect may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27631 - CycloneTCP ISN generation relies on a linear congruential generator (LCG), which is reversible from observed output streams as the algorithm is seeded with publicly recoverable information. This defect may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27632 - NDKTCPIP software is initialized with a consistent value and has consistent increments when generating initial sequence numbers (ISN), which may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27633 - FNET software is initialized with a consistent value and has consistent increments when generating initial sequence numbers (ISN), which may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27634 - uIP, Contiki-OS, and Contiki-NG software is initialized with a consistent value and has consistent increments when generating initial sequence numbers (ISN), which may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27635 - PicoTCP PicoTCP-NG software ISN generation relies on a linear congruential generator (LCG), which is reversible from observed output streams as the algorithm is seeded with publicly recoverable information. This defect may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27636 - MPLAB software ISN generation relies on a linear congruential generator (LCG), which is reversible from observed output streams as the algorithm is seeded with publicly recoverable information. This defect may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-28388 - Nucleus NET and Nucleus ReadyStart software ISN generation relies on a combination of values that can be acquired from capturing network traffic, which may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:L).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-042-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-042-02 - Rockwell Automation DriveTools SP and Drives AOP**  
CVE-2021-22665 - DriveTools and Drives AOP both contain a vulnerability that a local attacker with limited privileges may be able to exploit resulting in privilege escalation and complete control of the system.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:H/PR:L/UI:R/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-042-02>

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/40993176/ICS-CERT%20Advisories%20February%2011%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1613097013087&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Amazon Price Tracker Keepa Abused
A web browser plug-in designed to track pricing on Amazon has been abused with a persistent Cross-site Scripting vulnerability. A blog post from Almost Secure details this latest development.
output:
# Overview

A Cross-site Scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the web browser plugin called Keepa allows third parties to track victims in the Amazon ecosystem. A second vulnerability exposed the scraping function of Keepa to third parties. Keepa uses a web extension to track pricing changes for particular Amazon products a shopper may be interested in. Keepa uses jQuery to power its Keepa Box. HTML code is compiled from strings within jQuery-based project. This leads to multiple injection points across the software. The attack uses Self-XSS, thus allowing the attacker to only attack themselves. If the attacker uses a session fixation attack, the attacker can force the victim to log into the malicious username. The attacker can extract the session token and open a pop-up window to allow the injection of JavaScript code, all instances of Keepa Box are installed and persistent. Even though the vulnerability was addressed by forcing a specific character, more vulnerabilities exist that have potentially exploitable HTML injection. This can allow for a third-party to spy on victims while on Amazon. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Vulnerability Details

### Type of Vulnerability (OS, Software, Hardware)

  * Cross-site Scripting
  * Keepa browser extension



### Seen in the Wild

  * Yes
  * Non-specific



### Proof of Concept

  * No PoC has been seen to this point



# Post-infection Actions

### Data Exfiltrated

  * Data has been exfiltrated
  * Shopping habits and information about the victim



### Pivoting/Lateral Movement?

  * No lateral movement has been seen



# Protection

  * Ensure that applications do not store sensitive data or credentials insecurely. (e.g. plaintext credentials in code, published credentials in repositories, or credentials in public cloud storage). (M1013)
  * Use application control where appropriate. (M1038)
  * Only install browser extensions from trusted sources that can be verified. Browser extensions for some browsers can be controlled through Group Policy. Change settings to prevent the browser from installing extensions without sufficient permissions. (M1033)
  * Configure browsers or tasks to regularly delete persistent cookies. (M1054)
  * Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. (M1031)

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Amazon Price Tracker Keepa Abused
A web browser plug-in designed to track pricing on Amazon has been abused with a persistent Cross-site Scripting vulnerability. A blog post from Almost Secure details this latest development.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Overview

A Cross-site Scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the web browser plugin called Keepa allows third parties to track victims in the Amazon ecosystem. A second vulnerability exposed the scraping function of Keepa to third parties. Keepa uses a web extension to track pricing changes for particular Amazon products a shopper may be interested in. Keepa uses jQuery to power its Keepa Box. HTML code is compiled from strings within jQuery-based project. This leads to multiple injection points across the software. The attack uses Self-XSS, thus allowing the attacker to only attack themselves. If the attacker uses a session fixation attack, the attacker can force the victim to log into the malicious username. The attacker can extract the session token and open a pop-up window to allow the injection of JavaScript code, all instances of Keepa Box are installed and persistent. Even though the vulnerability was addressed by forcing a specific character, more vulnerabilities exist that have potentially exploitable HTML injection. This can allow for a third-party to spy on victims while on Amazon. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Vulnerability Details

### Type of Vulnerability (OS, Software, Hardware)

  * Cross-site Scripting
  * Keepa browser extension



### Seen in the Wild

  * Yes
  * Non-specific



### Proof of Concept

  * No PoC has been seen to this point



# Post-infection Actions

### Data Exfiltrated

  * Data has been exfiltrated
  * Shopping habits and information about the victim



### Pivoting/Lateral Movement?

  * No lateral movement has been seen



# Protection

  * Ensure that applications do not store sensitive data or credentials insecurely. (e.g. plaintext credentials in code, published credentials in repositories, or credentials in public cloud storage). (M1013)
  * Use application control where appropriate. (M1038)
  * Only install browser extensions from trusted sources that can be verified. Browser extensions for some browsers can be controlled through Group Policy. Change settings to prevent the browser from installing extensions without sufficient permissions. (M1033)
  * Configure browsers or tasks to regularly delete persistent cookies. (M1054)
  * Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. (M1031)



# References

  * <https://palant.info/2021/10/05/abusing-keepa-price-tracker-to-track-users-on-amazon-pages/?_hsmi=167647589>

I have encountered the following information: ICS-CERT Security Advisories - October 20th, 2020
The ICS-CERT has released two security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in Rockwell Automation and Hitachi ABB Power Grids products.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  




ICSA-20-294-01 addresses three buffer overflow vulnerabilities in Rockwell Automation 1794-AENT Flex I/O Series B devices. These vulnerabilities exist in different device components but all could allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to cause a denial-of-service condition, if successfully exploited.

ICSA-20-294-02 addresses an improper authentication vulnerability in Hitachi ABB Power Grids XMC20 Multiservice-Multiplexer products that, if successfully exploited, could allow an attacker to remotely take control.

We recommend reviewing the advisories in the Reference section for patches and mitigation advice.

In an effort to intimidate customers of Austin Energy, scammers are using threatening phone calls to intimidate the customers into paying a non-existent bill with payment cards. Bleeping Computer and Austin Energy have both reported on these efforts.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

A Texas utility company's customers are being targeted by scammers in an effort to obtain money. The scammers telephone customers and warn them their utilities will be disconnected unless they make an immediate payment using reloadable debit cards or other non-traceable forms of payment. This type of request is common amongst scammers seeking quick financial gain. A large winter storm across the state seems to be the catalyst behind this scam. The Austin Energy company released a statement via Twitter advising customers on policy and protective measures. For more information, see the links located within the Reference section below.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Kimsuky Phishing Hard at Work
A series of attacks by what's suspected to be DPRK's Kimsuky group (aka Velvet Chollima), is underway. The phishing attack is being investigated by ThreatConnect. They provide analysis of this series of attacks in a report.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Targeting everything from journalism to civil society organization, the Kimsuky group is ramping up their phishing efforts. Initial hypothesis indicates the group is harvesting credentials for espionage but also other objectives not yet known. A malicious document discussing North Korean defectors is used to lure victims. The document contains a UPX packed binary. The binary attempts to contact a C2 server. The document closely matches past documents in that it uses the same obfuscation technique, the C2 matches, contains VBA code similarities, and the digital signature signer name is dropped into the file. By all appearances, it looks as though the IP responsible for hosting the domain is dedicated to a single user. A secondary technique is to pivot from similar subdomains using unique strings. According to VirusTotal, the malicious document serves a specific link which is believed to be the pivot point. This pivot point leads to several other domains with each ending in a .work URL. These .work domains lead to several subdomains used in the campaign. Two entries containing rya in the domain are believed to lead to Radio Free Asia - a potential target. Another contains ohchr, believed to be the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights. Additional targets can be gleaned from the list of domains uncovered. Analysis uncovered efforts dating back as far as December 2019 and continuing as recently as August of this year. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://threatconnect.com/blog/kimsuky-phishing-operations-putting-in-work/>

  * <https://www.virustotal.com/gui/url/4444c37c684a628be261cabf8736271e753d883b46f0123fabb753720a2c1a16/details?_ga=2.138046901.482920492.1601397835-577232906.1601397835>
  * <https://threatconnect.com/wp-content/uploads/ThreatConnect-Kimsuky-Phishing-Operations-Putting-In-Work-IoC.csv>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Adobe Document Cloud Phishing Campaign
Document sharing services are increasingly being impersonated in order to harvest credentials. In one such case analyzed by Cofense in a recent blog post, Adobe Document Cloud is the targeted service.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense has published a blog post analyzing a phishing email using an Adobe Document Cloud lure. The email originates from a Gmail account and claims to be from a government agency, providing legitimate contact details to support this. Attached, is what the body of the email states, is a purchase order that can be accessed via Adobe Document Cloud login or by downloading the latest version of Adobe Acrobat Reader, hoping they'll opt for the easier login choice. Opening the attachment results in an HTML page stored locally that gathers its resources from the legitimate Adobe website. After bypassing a popup stating that the document is electronically encrypted and requires the recipient to log in with their email to view, they are directed to a fake Adobe Document Cloud sign in page. Any submitted credentials are exfiltrated to a remote URL controlled by the attacker. Finally, the victim is redirected to the legitimate Adobe Acrobat webpage. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/document-sharing-services-represent-a-vector-for-phishing-campaigns/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Android Banking Trojan - MasterFred
Avast Threat Labs are reporting a new Android banking Trojan that has been named MasterFred.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Android banking Trojan.
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** MasterFred
  *  **Targets:** Polish and Turkish bank customers, Social media users.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Android app.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and exfiltration of credentials.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A new Android banking Trojan has been reported by Avast Threat Labs, it has been named MasterFred. It makes use of the default installed Application Accessibility toolkit. It uses fake login overlays to steal information from its victims. Currently, there are HTML overlays for Polish and Turkish banks as well as for Instagram, Netflix, and Twitter. The overlays are stored within the app's Asset folder. Information entered into the overlays is transmitted to the attack via an onion.ws URL. In at least one case, MasterFred was delivered bundled in an app that was available on the Google Play store, third party stores are also probably used to distribute MasterFred. Further details are available from the links in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222443/Android%20Banking%20Trojan%20-%20MasterFred%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636691296270&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1006).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to avoid potentially risky behaviors such as downloading apps from third-party stores. (M1011).



# References

  * <https://twitter.com/AvastThreatLabs/status/1458162278277156866>
  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/new-android-malware-targets-netflix-instagram-and-twitter-users/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1475 - Deliver Malicious App via Authorized App Store  
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0031**  
T1411 - Input Prompt  
  
 **Collection - TA0035**  
T1417 - Input Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0036**  
T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol  
T1532 - Data Encrypted

Tell me about the following threat: VMware Security Advisory - February 11th, 2021
VMWare published a security advisory, VMSA-2021-0001, addressing a command injection vulnerability in vSphere Replication.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: VMware Security Advisory - February 11th, 2021
VMWare published a security advisory, VMSA-2021-0001, addressing a command injection vulnerability in vSphere Replication.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

VMWare published a security advisory, VMSA-2021-0001, addressing a vulnerability in vSphere Replication. CVE-2021-21976 is a post-authentication command injection vulnerability in the "Startup Configuration" page of vSphere Replication. It has been rated with a CVSS v3 base score of 7.2. Successful exploitation requires administrative access, but would allow the authenticated admin user to perform remote code execution. A patch has been released to fix the issue. We recommend reviewing the advisories in the Reference section for patch details. 

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-21976




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2021-0001.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: TA505 Linked To Malicious Peer-to-Peer Networks
NCC Group have uncovered malware which they are attributing to TA505. The malware is in three stages and aims to set up a peer-to-peer network between compromised hosts.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Threat Group:** TA505, ITG19
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

NCC Group has been tracking the threat group TA505 (IBM tracks as ITG19) and has uncovered several different malicious programs related to a peer-to-peer network that communicates via UDP. In the report, the researchers provide an analysis of three tools, which are speculated to be developed by the same developers as 'Grace'. The first tool is a downloader, which runs as a service and is used to download the second stage from the command and control server. It does this by decrypting and executing a payload which, in turn, decrypts and runs a driver. The driver is used to inject the final payload into a new process (‘wmiprvse.exe’). The final payload is able to register the victim computer with the P2P network and communicate with other nodes via UDP. This has been attributed ITG19 due to similar naming conventions and programming styles to that seen in 'Grace' samples. The researchers found evidence that at least 3 separate P2P networks were running based on network IDs of the samples. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74055887/TA505%20Linked%20To%20Malicious%20Peer-to-Peer%20Networks%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638964785238&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries (M1031).
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038).
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious processes, files, and API calls, etc. behavior (M1040).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://research.nccgroup.com/2021/12/01/tracking-a-p2p-network-related-with-ta505/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1569 - System Services  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1040 - Network Sniffing  
T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Android Malware WAPDropper Signs Up For Premium Services
Check Point Research reports on a new Android malware package that, when installed, signs the victim up for premium services.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Android



# Overview

Check Point Research discloses details of a two stage malware package that runs on Android called WAPDropper. The first stage is the dropper module that retrieves and installs the second stage module. The second stage module's responsibility is to subscribe the victim device to premium services, thus causing the victim financial loss. Some of the services require that a CAPTCHA step be successfully passed for the subscription to succeed. WAPDropper uses a Chinese company known for its image recognition software, called "Super Eagle", to provide the solution for the CAPTCHA problem. After the malware is installed and running, it hides its icon to thwart the victim from uninstalling. If the infected device does not have a proxy or VPN configured, stage one will also download additional malware payloads. For more details, see the Check Point article in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/33983826/Android%20Malware%20WAPDropper%20Signs%20Up%20For%20Premimum%20Services%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606331014509&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2020/enter-wapdropper-subscribe-users-to-premium-services-by-telecom-companies/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Ransomware Adversaries Began Extortion Tactics Using Exfiltrated Data in Past Year
ReversingLabs has reported a trend they began seeing in early 2020 by most ransomware families where rather than only encrypting files and asking for a ransom so the victim can decrypt their data, threat actors began exfiltrating the data as well and use extortion to try to to get the victims to pay. In their blog, they review five similar ransomware samples that utilize data exfiltration and also implement an anti-analysis trick.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, Data Theft




# Overview

ReversingLabs has reported a trend they began seeing in early 2020 by most ransomware families. Rather than only encrypting files and asking for a ransom so the victim can decrypt their data, threat actors began exfiltrating the data as well. They will often use the exfiltrated data to reveal a sample to a leak site as proof that they have it, and then promise to destroy the data if they get paid by the victim. If the victim fails to pay, the threat actor may then sell the data to the highest bidder. ReversingLabs covers details regarding 5 like samples that conduct data exfiltration. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.reversinglabs.com/blog/data-exfiltrator>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Targeted Phishing Attack against Ukrainian Government Expands to Georgia
Following up on previous reporting from Fortinet and Malwarebytes, Intezer details updates to malware used in a campaign targeting government agencies in the Ukraine and Georgia.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Infostealer




# Overview

Intezer published a blog post analyzing updates to a targeted phishing attack against the Ukrainian and Georgian governments. Government-related topics are used in emails with shortened links to entice victims into downloading malware. The shortened URLs redirect to a C2 server hosting a ZIP archive. Inside the ZIP archive was either an RTF, DOC, PDF, JS, LNK or EXE. The methodology for dropping the final payload depended on the file type leveraged. For example, the PDF leveraged an action object alongside a Google redirect, while the Word documents used malicious macros in combination with PowerShell and a Batch script to download the final payload. Regardless of the intermediary step, ultimately an AutoIt payload is executed in memory. Its purpose is search for specific file types and exfiltrate discovered files to a C2 server. Analysis of the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) along with the targeting leads Intezer to assess with high confidence that the activity can be attributed to the Russian government. For more information, see the Intezer blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/malware-analysis/targeted-phishing-attack-against-ukrainian-government-expands-to-georgia/>

Intezer published a blog post analyzing updates to a targeted phishing attack against the Ukrainian and Georgian governments. Government-related topics are used in emails with shortened links to entice victims into downloading malware. The shortened URLs redirect to a C2 server hosting a ZIP archive. Inside the ZIP archive was either an RTF, DOC, PDF, JS, LNK or EXE. The methodology for dropping the final payload depended on the file type leveraged. For example, the PDF leveraged an action object alongside a Google redirect, while the Word documents used malicious macros in combination with PowerShell and a Batch script to download the final payload. Regardless of the intermediary step, ultimately an AutoIt payload is executed in memory. Its purpose is search for specific file types and exfiltrate discovered files to a C2 server. Analysis of the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) along with the targeting leads Intezer to assess with high confidence that the activity can be attributed to the Russian government. For more information, see the Intezer blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/malware-analysis/targeted-phishing-attack-against-ukrainian-government-expands-to-georgia/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: UNC2198 and IcedID
A report from FireEye looks at the tradecraft of a group FireEye refer to as UNC2198. The group are known to use IcedID to install ransomware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: UNC2198 and IcedID
A report from FireEye looks at the tradecraft of a group FireEye refer to as UNC2198. The group are known to use IcedID to install ransomware.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

A FireEye report looks at the tradecraft of a threat cluster they refer to as UNC2198 who have targeted organizations located in North America across a variety of industry sectors. The report notes that UNC2198 is the most prominent threat cluster they track that uses IcedID as their foothold in intrusions. UNC2198 are known to have obtained initial access to some systems from other groups such as UNC2420. Throughout 2020, UNC2198 were using the Maze ransomware, but around October or November began using Egregor. Once UNC2198 has a foothold in a system, other malware and tools such as Cobalt Strike, InnoSetup, Koadic, Metasploit Meterpreter, PowerShell Empire, SystemBC, and WINDARC, may be installed. Lateral movement between systems is known to have been carried out using RDP and Windows Remote Management. Further information, including the relationships between UNC2198 and other threat clusters, is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2021/02/melting-unc2198-icedid-to-ransomware-operations.html>

Tell me about the following threat: Similarities Between the ShadowPad and PlugX Backdoors
Using samples from attacks on systems located in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan, analysts from Doctor Web discovered relationships between the ShadowPad and PlugX backdoors.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Similarities Between the ShadowPad and PlugX Backdoors
Using samples from attacks on systems located in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan, analysts from Doctor Web discovered relationships between the ShadowPad and PlugX backdoors.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

According to a report from Doctor Web, the ShadowPad backdoor may be an evolution of the PlugX backdoor. The Winnti APT group are known to use modified versions of ShadowPad. Indicators from the malware involved in attacks on systems in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan suggest that Chinese APT groups may have been involved in the attacks. Based on similarities found in the code of the ShadowPad and PlugX backdoors, Doctor Web analysts conclude that both backdoors may have been created by the same developers and is a more advanced backdoor than PlugX. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Lazarus BTC Changer
Lazarus, a North Korean APT, has previously been observed using JavaScript skimmers on compromised websites to steal banking details. Group-IB recently discovered the threat actor using a new version of the JS sniffer capable of stealing cryptocurrency, which they have dubbed "BTC Changer."

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, JS Sniffer




# Overview

Group-IB published a blog post analyzing a new JS sniffer, dubbed "BTC Changer," being leveraged by the Lazarus APT. The sniffer appears to be related to previous sniffers used by the threat actor. These new versions, however, target cryptocurrency payment systems instead of banking details. Like before, the skimmers are hosted on a compromised website and injected into checkout pages on vulnerable retail sites where Bitcoin is accepted as a payment method. If a payment is submitted using this option, the wallet address owned by the store is replaced with the attacker's address, ensuring they recieve the funds instead. Additionally, the researchers discovered a fake web payment form embedded in an iframe that requests the user pay an invoice by sending Bitcoin to the specified wallet address. Analysis of the wallet transactions indicate that they have been receiving money from the identified wallets. For more information, see the Group-IB blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.group-ib.com/blog/btc_changer>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: IBM QRadar Security Advisories - December 15th, 2020
IBM has published two security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in IBM QRadar SIEM.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview



Security Bulletin 6382286 addresses a vulnerability in the PostgresSQL JDBC Driver, which is leveraged by IBM QRadar SIEM. CVE-2020-13692 is an information disclosure vulnerability in an XML external entity (XXE) that, if successfully exploited, could allow a remote authenticated attacker to obtain sensitive information.

Security Bulletin 6382282 addresses eight vulnerabilities in the IBM Java SDK and IBM Java Runtime that impact IBM QRadar SIEM. The vulnerabilities are unspecified but allow for potential impacts such as sensitive information disclosure and denial-of-service conditions.

Patches have been released to address these issues. We recommend reviewing the advisory in the Reference section for further details and applying any applicable updates as soon as possible.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35718483/IBM%20QRadar%20Security%20Advisories%20-%20December%2015th%2C%202020%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1608146870773&api=v2)

  * <https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/6382286>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: White Rabbit Evasion Techniques Analyzed
The new ransomware family White Rabbit was first seen in December of 2021. A report by Trend Micro explores some of the evasion tactics used by this new malware.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Fin8 (G0061)
  *  **Associated Payloads:** White Rabbit
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown **  
**
  * **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encryption, Double Extortion



# Overview

White Rabbit is a new ransomware family discovered by Trend Micro with a potential connection to the threat group Fin8. It looks like it could be loaded onto systems using systems already compromised and infected with Cobalt Strike. Trend Micro has published details of the evasion tactics used by the malware. The payload is a small file with no notable strings or activity. The way to activate the ransomware and decrypt the internal configuration is via a command-line password - a technique also used by the ransomware family Egregor. Upon execution, White Rabbit will terminate several processes, including processes related to antivirus. Once complete, the ransomware drops a ransom note which threatens to leak the victim's stolen data if the ransom is not paid. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057151/White%20Rabbit%20Evasion%20Techniques%20Analyzed%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642589352360&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/a/new-ransomware-spotted-white-rabbit-and-its-evasion-tactics.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Agent Tesla Malspam Campaign
Italy's CSIRT is reporting that beginning on June 23, a "massive" malspam campaign distributing Agent Tesla was detected.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Malspam




# Overview

 The samples provided in the CSIRT alert show Word documents used to exploit the Microsoft Office vulnerability, CVE-2017-8570. While this vulnerability is old, the CSIRT note that it ranked as the third most exploited vulnerability in the last thirty days. The malspam emails are written in English and purport to be from import-export companies and the attached documents relate to alleged purchase orders. If the documents are opened and exploitation is successful, a PowerShell command is used to download the payload. Data is exfiltrated using SMTP. While two malicious executables, with different hashes, have been observed in the campaign, both exfiltrate data to the same email address. Further details are available from the report in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Three Quarters of Infusion Pumps Vulnerable To Attack
Unit 42 has done a study of available data on over 200,000 infusion pumps on hospital networks. They found a large number of vulnerable devices, showing that the healthcare sector needs to have a focus on security as devices become more connected.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Three Quarters of Infusion Pumps Vulnerable To Attack
Unit 42 has done a study of available data on over 200,000 infusion pumps on hospital networks. They found a large number of vulnerable devices, showing that the healthcare sector needs to have a focus on security as devices become more connected.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Vulnerability
  *  **Targets:** Hospital Infusion Pumps
  *  **Vulnerability Type:** Denial of Service, Unauthorized Access



# Overview

Unit 42 has done an in-depth study on the state of security in the healthcare sector. Specifically, in connected devices that are accessible over the internet. The study looked at results from open-source scans of over 200,000 infusion pumps on hospital networks. They found that 75% of the infusion pumps that were scanned had known security issues. Together, the pumps represented almost 40 different known security vulnerabilities, as well as almost 70 other known security issues commonly found in IoT devices. A more alarming statistic was that over 50% of the pumps were vulnerable to two known vulnerabilities that were rated 'critical' and 'high' severity. The majority of vulnerabilities were found to be related to sensitive information leakage. There were also several vulnerabilities that would allow a malicious actor to take a device offline, or give them unauthorized access to the device. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [Three Quarter of Infusion Pumps Vulnerable To Attack CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/81134349/Three%20Quarter%20of%20Infusion%20Pumps%20Vulnerable%20To%20Attacl%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1646836892040&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).



# References

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/infusion-pump-vulnerabilities/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1195 - Supply Chain Compromise  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1489 - Service Stop  
T1495 - Firmware Corruption  
T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service  
T1565 - Data Manipulation

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: An Analysis of the Hazard Token Grabber
A report from Cyble Research Labs provides an analysis of the information-stealing malware named Hazard Token Grabber.  Analysis is provided on upgraded version available recently observed in the wild.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

Summary
=======



Attack Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Malware
* **Targets:** Discord users
* **Malware Family/Families:** Hazard Token Grabber
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data and credential collection, and exfiltration
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

Hazard Token Grabber is information-stealing malware that was first observed in the wild in 2021. A report from Cyble Research Labs notes that Python source code for both the original version and an updated version observed by Cyble, are available from Github. A builder script is provided with the source code which uses Pyinstaller to create an executable payload file. The payload contains anti-debugging routines and will terminate if it detects it is being debugged. The malware steals Discord tokens from more than twenty applications, cookies, login credentials from Chrome, and Roblox Studio cookies. A Discord authorization token is then used to obtain the account information associated with the token. Stolen data is compressed and exfiltrated to a webhook specified in the payload's configuration file. Cyble's report also notes they observed a significant increase in the number of samples related to Hazard Token Grabber over the last three months and located more than two thousand samples in total. For more information, please see the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://blog.cyble.com/2022/06/01/hazard-token-grabber/>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1204 - User Execution  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
   T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
   T1497.001 - System Checks  

**Credential Access - TA0006**  
 T1528 - Steal Application Access Token  
 T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
 T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1007 - System Service Discovery  
 T1057 - Process Discovery  
 T1087 - Account Discovery  
 T1124 - System Time Discovery  
 T1518 - Software Discovery  
 T1614 - System Location Discovery  

**Collection - TA0009**  
 T1113 - Screen Capture  

**Exfiltration - TA0010**  
 T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  

**Mitigations:**

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1025:**  Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1027:**  Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1032:**  Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1043:**  Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
**M1044:**  Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: DTPacker - A Commodity .NET Packer
A report from Proofpoint provides an analysis of a two-stage commodity .NET packer Proofpoint has named DTPacker.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Packer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Various APT and cybercrime actors.
  *  **Associated Payloads:** DTPacker, Agent Tesla, AsyncRAT, Ave Maria, and FormBook.
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Email with malicious attachments.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unspecified.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

DTPacker is a two-stage commodity .NET packer that Proofpoint analyzed and named. Since 2020, tt has been used in many campaigns conducted by APT actors such as TA2536 and TA2715 and other cybercriminals. Many of the campaigns used emails that typically had an attached document or an executable in a compressed form that are used to deploy DTPacker. When DTPacker is executed, it decodes data contained in the executable or downloads it from a remote host using HTTP requests. Once all the required data has been downloaded, the resulting DLL is used to extract and execute the payload. The payloads delivered in the campaigns are varied but are known to have included information stealers and RATs including Agent Tesla, AsyncRAT, Ave Maria, and FormBook. While the Proofpoint report is focused on the analysis of DTPacker rather than the campaigns it has been used in, it does provide some information on one campaign that used websites for soccer clubs and their fans and later used Liverpool football club themed download locations to host the final payloads. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057831/DTPacker%20-%20A%20Commodity%20.NET%20Packer%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1643597376176&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/dtpacker-net-packer-curious-password-1>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1584.001 - Domains  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.001 - Malware  
T1588.002 - Tool  
T1588.005 - Exploits  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Cisco Security Advisory - May 11 2021
Cisco has published one security advisory. The advisory is rated as Medium and deals with twelve vulnerabilities in the 802.11 standard, which were disclosed in the research paper "Fragment and Forge: Breaking Wi-Fi Through Frame Aggregation and Fragmentation."

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Cisco Security Advisory - May 11 2021
Cisco has published one security advisory. The advisory is rated as Medium and deals with twelve vulnerabilities in the 802.11 standard, which were disclosed in the research paper "Fragment and Forge: Breaking Wi-Fi Through Frame Aggregation and Fragmentation."

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Please note that the advisory summarized below has a warning about public disclosure or exploitation of the vulnerability covered in the advisory.

 **Multiple Vulnerabilities in Frame Aggregation and Fragmentation Implementations of 802.11 Specification Affecting Cisco Products: May 2021**  
cisco-sa-wifi-faf-22epcEWu  
On May 11, 2021, the research paper Fragment and Forge: Breaking Wi-Fi Through Frame Aggregation and Fragmentation was made public. This paper discusses 12 vulnerabilities in the 802.11 standard. One vulnerability is in the frame aggregation functionality, two vulnerabilities are in the frame fragmentation functionality, and the other nine are implementation vulnerabilities. These vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to forge encrypted frames, which could in turn enable the exfiltration of sensitive data from a targeted device.  
  
The Cisco Product Security Incident Response Team (PSIRT) is aware that proof-of-concept exploit code is available for the vulnerabilities that are described in this advisory. The Cisco PSIRT is not aware of any malicious use of the vulnerabilities that are described in this advisory.  
Base 6.5 CVSS:3.1/AV:A/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-wifi-faf-22epcEWu>

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/49185007/Cisco%20Security%20Advisory%20-%20May%2011%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1620880365080&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-wifi-faf-22epcEWu>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: VMware Security Advisory - November 19th, 2020
VMware has published security advisory VMSA-2020-0026 that addresses two vulnerabilities, one of them rated as Critical, in VMware ESXi, Workstation, and Fusion.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
VMware has published security advisory VMSA-2020-0026 that addresses two vulnerabilities in VMware ESXi, Workstation, and Fusion. Of the vulnerabilities, one is rated by VMware as Critical, the other as Important. One of the vulnerabilities (CVE-2020-4005) could allow a local attacker to elevate their privileges. The other vulnerability (CVE-2020-4004) could allow an attacker with local administrative privileges to execute code on the host system as the VMX process. instruction:
I have encountered the following information: XAMPP Servers Hosting Agent Tesla and Formbook
A report from RiskIQ provides information on the use of Internet-facing XAMPP servers to host malware such as Agent Tesla and Formbook.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Malware Family/Families:**[Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331/), Formbook
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Servers running XAMPP are being used to host malware.



# Overview

XAMPP is an Apache distribution containing MariaDB, PHP, and Perl that is intended to make installation simple but is not intended to be used for production deployments. A report from RiskIQ provides information on the use of Internet-facing XAMPP servers that are being used to host malware such as Agent Tesla and Formbook. It is not clear from the report if the XAMPP servers have been set up by the actors behind the malware, or whether the servers have been compromised by the actors. A number of the hosts observed distributing the malware used dynamic DNS names. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/59539651/XAMPP%20Servers%20Hosting%20Agent%20Tesla%20and%20Formbook%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1628643059745&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date ([M1049](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1049/)).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs ([M1031](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1031/), [M1035](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1035/), [M1037](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1037/)).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level ([M1051](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1051/)).



# References

  * <https://community.riskiq.com/article/40000d46/description>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Cring Ransomware Techniques
Cring is a ransomware family that appeared on the threat landscape in 2021. Trend Micro has published a blog post detailing the techniques used by threat actors to deploy this payload.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Finance, Transportation
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Cring
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** RDP, Vulnerability exploitation
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Steal credentials, move laterally, deploy ransomware payload
  *  **Additional TTPs** : Use of Mimikatz and Cobalt Strike



# Overview

Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing the techniques used in Cring ransomware infections. Initial access is obtained through either exposed RDP services or vulnerability exploits, such as those in Adobe ColdFusion and FortiGate VPN. When the threat actor has obtained access, they leverage Mimikatz to steal account credentials, which are used to move laterally via Cobalt Strike. Cobalt Strike is further leveraged to distribute batch scripts. These batch scripts are used to download, execute, and delete the Cring ransomware payload. Like many ransomware families, Cring disables services and processes, deletes backup files, and performs encryption. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64128862/Cring%20Ransomware%20Techniques%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632855232253&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/i/examining-the-cring-ransomware-techniques.html>

 **Initial Access - TA0001**

 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
T1078.002 - Domain Accounts

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools

 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials

 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery

 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer

 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1090 - Proxy  
T1090.003 - Multi-hop Proxy  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer

 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1489 - Service Stop  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: A New Malware Dropper Emerges with Key Functionality
A malware dropper has been targeting users in Spain, Portugal, Italy, and Norway. Lab52 has performed extensive analysis on the dropper and provided details on the malware.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing




# Overview

Using intercepted malicious mail, Lab52 has analyzed multiple samples being delivered to multiple targets in European countries including Spain, Portugal, Italy, and Norway. Using phishing emails containing attachments ranging from PPT to DOC to XLS, the attackers documents contain no actual content; however, upon closing the document viewer, users are presented with a file corrupt message which is generated by a macro within the On_Close function. This type of protective action is used to prevent execution in sandbox solutions. Code within the dropper points to a server where a script is hosted. The script executes several actions including creating persistence, rebooting the machine, and executing two other Pastebin mshta scripts. The dropper is separated into three functions: id1, id2, and id3. The first, id1, contains a string directed at any analyst who may be examining the dropper. The next part of the script downloads two other executables which were developed in .NET. The process then makes calls to the binary from PowerShell. Next, a third executable is downloaded from Pastebin, which is decoded and stored in a variable. This leads to a second executable that passes parameters and a variable containing the third executable. This creates a legitimate Notepad process and injects it into the binary. The final binary is a sample of LokiBot. This leads to the stealing of credentials from all mail clients, FTP, browsers, and other services. Finally, this acts as a bot and allows some remote control by the attacker. The second, id2, consists of a PowerShell script that runs on each reboot. This script runs a check clipboard loop. This loops checks for a Bitcoin address. If found, the attacker's bitcoin address is pasted in place of the victim's. This is done to make the user deposit funds into the attacker's account. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://lab52.io/blog/a-twisted-malware-infection-chain/>
