instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: PerSwaysion Campaign Uses Legitimate Services to Trick Users
Group-IB Threat Intelligence team has published a timeline of a phishing campaign using an up-trending technique whereby they use legitimate file-sharing sites to guide victims to the phishing site. After compromise, the attacker uses the email account to send out further phishing emails.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Targets:** Financial Services, Legal, Consulting
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Group-IB Threat Intelligence team has been tracking a new phishing campaign using a phishing technique that is becoming more common. The technique uses Microsoft file-sharing services, such as Sway, Sharepoint, and OneNote. This property is why the campaign is being called PerSwaysion. This campaign has been seen in multiple countries across North America, Europe, and Asia. Phishing emails in this campaign typically work in 3 phases. The first phase is an email with a PDF attachment claiming to be an Office 365 notification that a file has been shared with the victim. If the user clicks on the link in the PDF, they are then taken to a file hosted on a legitimate file-sharing site, such as Sway. The attacker abuses Sway's default borderless view and a specially crafted presentation page to make it seem as if the user has landed on a valid Office 365 login page. The link on this page directs the user to the final phase, which is a false login page on the attacker-controlled infrastructure. Once the user's details are entered, the attacker receives a notification email and the victim is served an 'access denied' page. After the credentials have been stolen, the attackers log into the compromised email account and dump all of the available emails. They then use the victim's details to generate new phishing PDFs that will seem legitimate, before sending them out to external targets on the victim's contact list. These targets are generally hand-picked to be high-profile members of businesses other than the victim's organization. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155151/PerSwaysion%20Campaign%20Uses%20Legitimate%20Services%20to%20Trick%20Users%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637762050748&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction (M1017).
  * Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc (M1021).
  * Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries (M1031).



# References

  * <https://blog.group-ib.com/perswaysion>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1591 - Gather Victim Org Information  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1586 - Compromise Accounts  
T1586.002 - Email Accounts  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: DarkRadiation Ransomware
DarkRadiation is a new Bash ransomware discovered by Trend Micro researchers. It appears to specifically be designed to target Red Hat and Debian-based Linux distributions. SentinelOne has also published their analysis of the payload.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: DarkRadiation Ransomware
DarkRadiation is a new Bash ransomware discovered by Trend Micro researchers. It appears to specifically be designed to target Red Hat and Debian-based Linux distributions. SentinelOne has also published their analysis of the payload.

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Trend Micro has published a blog post analyzing a new Bash ransomware, dubbed "DarkRadiation." This ransomware was discovered hosted in an attacker's hack tools directory alongside other Bash scripts used in the infection chain. Victims are initially compromised via SSH by a Bash script that operates as an SSH worm that uses compromised credentials or brute force tactics. Various tools from the hack tools URL are downloaded to the system, including rootkits, reconnaissance tools, obfuscators, exploits, and more. The attacker's ultimate goal is to execute a ransomware payload. Both the worm and the ransomware payload include Telegram C2 communication capabilities to notify the attacker of successful infections and encryption. The ransomware waits for the presence of a specified file on the hack tool server before beginning encryption. Once the file is observed, AES with CBC mode encryption is performed against various directories. A ransom note is left on the system requesting the victim contact the attackers by email. Based on the use of Yellowdog Updater, Modified (YUM) package manager to install prerequisite packages, the worm and ransomware are currently designed to target CentOS, RHEL, and Debian-based Linux distributions. Shortly after Trend Micro's publication, SentinelOne released their analysis of the payload, also noting indications of targeting of Docker containers. For more information, see the Trend Micro and SentinelOne blog posts in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/f/bash-ransomware-darkradiation-targets-red-hat--and-debian-based-linux-distributions.html>

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/blog/darkradiation-abusing-bash-for-linux-and-docker-container-ransomware/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Cisco Security Advisories April 28 2021
Cisco has published thirteen Security Advisories. Of the advisories, five are rated as High and eight are rated as Medium.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Cisco Security Advisories April 28 2021
Cisco has published thirteen Security Advisories. Of the advisories, five are rated as High and eight are rated as Medium.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 For all advisories listed below, it is noted that Cisco's Product Security Incident Response Team (PSIRT) is "not aware of any public announcements or malicious use of the vulnerabilities" that are described in the advisories.

## Advisories Rated High

 **Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Software and Firepower Threat Defense Software Web Services Buffer Overflow Denial of Service Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-memc-dos-fncTyYKG  
A vulnerability in the web services interface of CiscoAdaptive Security Appliance (ASA) Software and CiscoFirepower Threat Defense (FTD) Software could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to cause a buffer overflow on an affected system.  
CVE-2021-1493  
Base 8.5 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:C/C:L/I:N/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-memc-dos-fncTyYKG>

 **Cisco Firepower Threat Defense Software SSL Decryption Policy Denial of Service Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-ftd-ssl-decrypt-dos-DdyLuK6c  
A vulnerability in the software-based SSL/TLS message handler of CiscoFirepower Threat Defense (FTD) Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to trigger a reload of an affected device, resulting in a denial of service (DoS) condition.  
CVE-2021-1402  
Base 8.6 CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-ftd-ssl-decrypt-dos-DdyLuK6c>

 **Cisco Firepower Threat Defense Software Command Injection Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-ftd-cmdinj-vWY5wqZT  
A vulnerability in the CLI of CiscoFirepower Threat Defense (FTD) Software could allow an authenticated, local attacker to execute arbitrary commands with root privileges on the underlying operating system of an affected device that is running in multi-instance mode.  
CVE-2021-1448  
Base 7.8 CVSS:3.0/AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-ftd-cmdinj-vWY5wqZT>

 **Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Software and Firepower Threat Defense Software Web Services VPN Denial of Service Vulnerabilities**  
cisco-sa-asa-ftd-vpn-dos-fpBcpEcD  
Multiple vulnerabilities in CiscoAdaptive Security Appliance (ASA) Software and Firepower Threat Defense (FTD) Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition on an affected device.  
CVE-2021-1445 CVE-2021-1504  
Base 8.6 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-asa-ftd-vpn-dos-fpBcpEcD>

 **Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Software and Cisco Firepower Threat Defense Software SIP Denial of Service Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-asa-ftd-sipdos-GGwmMerC  
A vulnerability in the SIP inspection engine of CiscoAdaptive Security Appliance (ASA) Software and CiscoFirepower Threat Defense (FTD) Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a crash and reload of an affected device, resulting in a denial of service (DoS) condition.The vulnerability is due to a crash that occurs during a hash lookup for a SIP pinhole connection. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by sending crafted SIP traffic through an affected device. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to cause a crash and reload of the affected device.  
CVE-2021-1501  
Base 8.6 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-asa-ftd-sipdos-GGwmMerC>

## Advisories Rated Medium

 **Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance Software and Firepower Threat Defense Software for Firepower 1000 and 2100 Series Appliances Command Injection Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-asa-cmdinj-TKyQfDcU  
A vulnerability in the upgrade process of CiscoAdaptive Security Appliance (ASA) Software and CiscoFirepower Threat Defense (FTD) Software could allow an authenticated, local attacker to inject commands that could be executed with root privileges on the underlying operating system (OS).  
CVE-2021-1488  
Base 6.7 CVSS:3.1/AV:L/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-asa-cmdinj-TKyQfDcU>

 **Multiple Cisco Products Snort HTTP Detection Engine File Policy Bypass Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-http-fp-bp-KfDdcQhc

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Indeed Phishing Campaign
An ongoing phishing campaign detected by Bitdefender attempts to steal credentials for Indeed, an employment platform.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Bitdefender published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign targeting Indeed users. Indeed is an employment platform providing users with the ability to find and apply for jobs. The phishing email uses a spoofed sender to make it appear that the email is coming from an Indeed noreply email address. Attached to the email is an HTML file supposedly containing a login form required to confirm the user's email address. The file contains a fake login form that also includes single sign-on (SSO) options. Any submitted credentials are exfiltrated to the attacker. X-Force researchers uncovered 30 of these attachments submitted to VirusTotal between May 28th and June 25th, 2021. The hashes associated with these files are provided alongside this report. For more information, see the Bitdefender blog post in the Reference section.  


# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://hotforsecurity.bitdefender.com/blog/cyber-crooks-hunt-for-indeed-job-seekers-account-credentials-in-latest-phishing-campaign-26054.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: UNC1945 - Threat Actor that Targets Solaris and Telecommunications Companies
UNC1945 is a threat actor that Mandiant has been tracking since 2018. UNC1945 has primarily targeted exposed Solaris servers in the networks of telecommunications entities. Mandiant has published a report on the activities of UNC1945 throughout the time period they have been tracking the threat actor.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: UNC1945 - Threat Actor that Targets Solaris and Telecommunications Companies
UNC1945 is a threat actor that Mandiant has been tracking since 2018. UNC1945 has primarily targeted exposed Solaris servers in the networks of telecommunications entities. Mandiant has published a report on the activities of UNC1945 throughout the time period they have been tracking the threat actor.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

A report from Mandiant tracks the activities of a threat actor Mandiant has named UNC1945 that has been targeting telecommunications entities. To gain access to a network, UNC1945 has exploited vulnerabilities in the Solaris operating system. The first compromise of a Solaris host by UNC1945 which is noted in the report occurred in late 2018. A backdoor named SLAPSTICK was installed on the compromised host. In mid 2020, Mandiant observed a remote exploitation tool named EVILSUN being deployed by UNC1945. EVILSUN contained an exploit, for what at the time, was a 0-day vulnerability in Solaris, which is now identified as CVE-2020-14871. Oracle provided a patch for this vulnerability in its October 2020 Critical Patch Update. An exploit for the vulnerability had been advertised for sale on black-market website in April 2020. Once the initial foothold was established, UNC1945 installed a number of tools, including a QEMU Virtual Machine that contained a version of Tiny Core Linux. A number of techniques and tools were used to facilitate lateral movement to HP-UX, Linux, and Windows hosts, and to third-party environments. UNC1945 takes a number of steps to evade detection including the scrubbing of log files. No data exfiltration was detected in the UNC1945 attacks but in one case, ransomware was deployed. Mandiant does not attribute the ransomware to UNC1945 and instead suggests that access to the compromised system may have been sold to a third-party. Tools and malware associated with UNC1945 includes LEMONSTICK, OKSOLO, PUPYRAT, SLAPSTICK, TINYSHELL which all provide some level of backdoor capabilities, STEELCORGI which is a packer for Linux ELF programs, the reconnaissance tool OPENSHACKLE, LOGBLEACH which is used for scrubbing log files, and ProxyChains. Further details are available from Mandiant's report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2020/11/live-off-the-land-an-overview-of-unc1945.html>

Tell me about the following threat: An Analysis of APT29's Backdoor - MiniDuke
The newest variant of the backdoor known as MiniDuke has been analyzed by a researcher at CyberGeek.tech. This backdoor has been in use for a long time, but this is the first time this variant from 2019 has been fully analyzed publicly.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: An Analysis of APT29's Backdoor - MiniDuke
The newest variant of the backdoor known as MiniDuke has been analyzed by a researcher at CyberGeek.tech. This backdoor has been in use for a long time, but this is the first time this variant from 2019 has been fully analyzed publicly.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** APT29 (G0016), ITG11
  *  **Targets:** Government Entities
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** MiniDuke (S0051)
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

A researcher at Cybergeeks.tech has analyzed a new variant of the MiniDuke malware that is currently being used by APT29. APT29 is a threat actor known by many names including Cozy Bear, CozyDuke, Cozys, Dark Halo, Duke Group, Hammertoss, Minis, Office Monkeys, Pitty Tiger, Spikerrush, StellarParticle, TEMP.Monkey, TEMP.Noble, The Dukes, TG-4127, UNC2452, and Yttrium. IBM X-Force tracks NOBELIUM as ITG11. They are associated with Russia's Foreign Intelligence service and are believed to be behind the high-profile SolarWinds compromise in 2020. MiniDuke is a backdoor generally used by APT29 as a second-stage backdoor, with the newest version being seen in 2019. The analysis mainly focuses on the communications between the malware and the C2 server, and details three different modes of communication. If the machine does not have internet access, the malware will open a named pipe and use it to connect to another machine in the network which does have internet access and use this as a proxy to exfiltrate data. There is a command for an instance of MiniDuke to set up a named pipe and listen for connections if another machine in the network requires it. If it does have internet access, the malware can exfiltrate data via either POST or PUT requests. On top of exfiltration, the malware can receive commands to manipulate files and processes and has been used as a dropper in past campaigns. ATP 29 has previously used this malware in attacks on government entities in different countries in Europe and the United States. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129834/An%20Analysis%20of%20APT29%27s%20Backdoor%20-%20MiniDuke%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633695923433&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use application control where appropriate (M1038).



# References

  * <https://cybergeeks.tech/how-to-defeat-the-russian-dukes-a-step-by-step-analysis-of-miniduke-used-by-apt29-cozy-bear/>
  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/ESET_Operation_Ghost_Dukes.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.005 - Indicator Removal from Tools  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1012 - Query Registry  
T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1016.001 - Internet Connection Discovery  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1614 - System Location Discovery

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Torisma and LCPDot Malware
Operation Dream Job was a campaign carried out by Lazarus. In a recent article JPCERT/CC described two malware families discovered as part of this campaign, Torisma and LCPDot.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT, Downloader




# Overview

JPCERT/CC has published a blog post analyzing the Torisma and LCPDot downloaders used by Lazarus in Operation Dream Job. Torisma is spread through malicious Word files and are delivered to the system as DLL files. Its configuration information, such as the C2 server, is loaded from a separate file. Initial communication with its C2 involves sending the victim system's information. If the server returns an acceptance message as the response, a VEST-32-encrypted and Base64-encoded module is downloaded to the victim system. Modules observed during JPCERT/CC's analysis included the capability to send information about the infected host and to execute specific files. LCPDot is very similar Torisma and is believed to be used in combination with Torisma to move laterally on victim networks. In the case of LCPDot, the configuration is included within the payload. With successful C2 communication established, an RC4-encrypted module is downloaded. The researchers were unable to obtain samples of the modules downloaded by LCPDot so the next-stage functionality of this malware is unknown. For more information, see the JPCERT/CC blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.jpcert.or.jp/en/2021/01/Lazarus_malware2.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Hamas-Linked APT Group Using New Tools To Target Israeli Individuals
Cybereason has been tracking a new advanced persistent threat (APT) group that is targeting Israel. This group, known as APT-C-23, is linked to Hamas and has recently upgraded its malware arsenal, and is using dedicated infrastructure for its latest campaign.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Hamas-Linked APT Group Using New Tools To Target Israeli Individuals
Cybereason has been tracking a new advanced persistent threat (APT) group that is targeting Israel. This group, known as APT-C-23, is linked to Hamas and has recently upgraded its malware arsenal, and is using dedicated infrastructure for its latest campaign.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** APT-C-23 **  
**
  * **Associated Payloads:** Barbie Downloader, BarbWire, VolatileVenom
  *  **Targets:** Israeli Individuals
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Social Engineering
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Malware Installation, Data Theft



# Overview

The group APT-C-23 is undertaking a new campaign against individuals in Israel, as reported by Cybereason. This group is connected to Hamas and is using new malware and infrastructure to stage attacks against their targets. The attack starts with a fake profile on Facebook which is leveraged to trick individuals into downloading trojanized direct message applications. The accounts are months old and appear to be authentic. The victims are also tricked into downloading a .rar file that contains new malware, called Barbie Downloader. This will then download and install a new backdoor, called BarbWire. The file also contains a private video to distract the user from the malware installation. The attacker also attempts to infect the victim's phone with the malware VolatileVenom to ensure they can monitor all activity. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://www.cybereason.com/blog/operation-bearded-barbie-apt-c-23-campaign-targeting-israeli-officials>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1592 - Gather Victim Host Information  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1518.001 - Security Software Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1025 - Data from Removable Media  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
T1123 - Audio Capture  
T1560.001 - Archive via Utility  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1132.001 - Standard Encoding  
T1132.002 - Non-Standard Encoding  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1029:** Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Purple Fox Using New Initial Access Methods
Trend Micro has been tracking Purple Fox since it first was seen in 2018. They have analyzed the newest version, which uses a new arrival vector and early access loaders. Details have been published in a report.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Purple Fox Using New Initial Access Methods
Trend Micro has been tracking Purple Fox since it first was seen in 2018. They have analyzed the newest version, which uses a new arrival vector and early access loaders. Details have been published in a report.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Rootkit
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown **  
**
  * **Associated Payloads:** Purple Fox
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Software Installers 



# Overview

Purple Fox malware has been active since 2018. Trend Micro has been keeping track of the changes of this malware as it improves its infrastructure and adds capabilities. Recently, the researchers observed the malware using a new initial access vector and early access loaders. The malware is distributed using disguised software packages that contain the first-stage loader. The installer name contains a character that indicates which payloads are to be downloaded and installed from the C2 server. The second stage payloads can be tracked using upload times on the server and show that these payloads are being continually updated by the attackers. The payloads showed a range of capabilities for evading security software, including disabling agents and using stolen certificates. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/c/purple-fox-uses-new-arrival-vector-and-improves-malware-arsenal.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: MooBot Targeting UNIX CCTV DVR With Zero Day
CNCERT and Qthoo 360 have published a joint report regarding MooBot, a botnet discovered in September 2019, targeting UNIX CCTV DVR with a zero day vulnerability.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: MooBot Targeting UNIX CCTV DVR With Zero Day
CNCERT and Qthoo 360 have published a joint report regarding MooBot, a botnet discovered in September 2019, targeting UNIX CCTV DVR with a zero day vulnerability.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet, Zero Day



# Overview

CNCERT and Qthoo 360 have jointly published findings on a zero day being exploited by MooBot. The targeted device in question is UNIX CCTV DVR. The attack was first noticed in early June. By the end of June, a sample of the new version of MooBot had been captured and examined. A patch for UNIX CCTV DVR was released by the end of August. MooBot scans port 8000 for vulnerable devices and then attempts to exploit the remote command injection vulnerability. This port is used to update the system time with an NTP server, but the software does not validate the ntpdate parameters. Thus, an attacker could inject a command along the lines of "ntpdate -d -t 1 time.nist.gov & whoami", where "whoami" could be replaced with a malicious command. For vulnerable devices and more details, refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/33983073/MooBot%20Targeting%20UNIX%20CCTV%20DVR%20With%20Zero%20Day%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606165480671&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/moobot-0day-unixcctv-dvr-en/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Tmanger RAT
While investigating TA428 activity, NTT Security researchers identified a new RAT, dubbed "Tmanger", being used by the group.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Tmanger RAT
While investigating TA428 activity, NTT Security researchers identified a new RAT, dubbed "Tmanger", being used by the group.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

NTT Security has published a blog post detailing the , which was discovered in use by TA428, a Chinese APT. The attack chain began with the deployment of Poison Ivy and Cotx RAT to gain remote control of the victims host. The threat actor then moved laterally by exploiting the EternalBlue vulnerability. It was at this point they deployed the new . The payload is comprised of three components: SetUp, MloadDll, and Client. First, SetUp decodes various data to be used in later installation steps. The MloadDll is then inflated and saved in System32. To establish persistence the DLL uses either a service, if admin privileges are obtained, or via a Registry Run key otherwise. Either method leads to the execution of the DLL, which begins by generating the RC4 key that will be used to decrypt configuration data. The decoded configuration data is the C2 address and port number. The DLL also inflates and executes the final payload, named Client. The final payload gathers hosts information and sends the information to its C2 server. It can then receive C2 commands that allow for the attacker to perform file operations, start processes, keylog, screen capture, and more. For more information, see the NTT Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://insight-jp.nttsecurity.com/post/102gi9b/pandas-new-arsenal-part-1-tmanger>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Carbine Loader Cryptomining Campaign
A new loader script, dubbed "Carbine Loader" by Lacework, is spreading cryptominers to vulnerable, public-facing Nagios XI servers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining, Loader




# Overview

Lacework has published a blog post analyzing a campaign using a loader script, called "Carbine Loader," to distribute cryptominers. The initial infection vector is exploitation of remote code execution vulnerabilities on public-facing Nagios servers. The remote execution capabilities are used to to download the loader shell script. The loader performs a series of tasks including configuring Hugepages for mining efficiency, uninstalling monitoring agents, removing competing cryptominers, and killing processes with high CPU usage. Its main function, however, is to download and run the Avalonsaver mining software. With the mining operation running, the loader attempts to move laterally by looking for accessible SSH hosts. It also cleans up its tracks by overwriting various log files. Investigation into the wallet configured by the attacker reveals a relatively low profit at this time. For more information, see the Lacework blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.lacework.com/carbine-loader-cryptojacking-campaign/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Analysis of Kinsing Malware's Use of Rootkit
The Kinsing malware has been evolving with capabilities added to increase the difficulty of detection. Trend Micro reports on the use of a rootkit in recent samples to carry out these objectives.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Analysis of Kinsing Malware's Use of Rootkit
The Kinsing malware has been evolving with capabilities added to increase the difficulty of detection. Trend Micro reports on the use of a rootkit in recent samples to carry out these objectives.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Rootkit, Backdoor, Miner




# Overview

Trend Micro has published their analysis of a Kinsing malware sample using a rootkit to evade detection. As with most Kinsing infections, a series of shell scripts are used to install the malware. After downloading and installing the backdoor, miner, and rootkit payloads, along with disabling resource-intensive services and processes, the rootkit installation process begins. This process is only able to be performed if the malware has root privileges. First, the immutable file flag from /etc/ld.so.preload is removed. Then the rootkit is downloaded onto the system and a new /etc/[ld.so](http://ld.so).preload file is created with a link to the rootkit. Without root privileges, persistence is established via a system service. Additionally, a cron job is created so that the installation script is repeatedly downloaded and executed. The rootkit, once installed, provides a variety of functions to hide malicious activity, such as hiding files, running processes, and active network connections. With this in place, the attacker can carry out their backdoor and mining activities with a decreased risk of detection. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/20/k/analysis-of-kinsing-malwares-use-of-rootkit.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Mozilla Security Advisory 2021-02
Mozilla has released a security advisory addressing an issue with its Thunderbird Email software.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Mozilla Security Advisory 2021-02
Mozilla has released a security advisory addressing an issue with its Thunderbird Email software.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

The Mozilla Foundation has issued a security advisory, 2021-02, which addresses a use-after-free write when handling a malicious COOKIE-ECHO SCTP chunk (vulnerability CVE-2021-16044). If successfully exploited, the vulnerability could allow a maliciously crafted SCTP packet to be used in a use-after-free scenario. It is also speculated by Mozilla that this could be exploited to run arbitrary code. We recommend patching the affected software, version 78.6.1, as soon as possible. Advisory notes are located within the article linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-16044




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/security/advisories/mfsa2021-02/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: FFDroider Stealer Masquerading As Telegram To Avoid Detection
Zscaler has reported on a new windows-based infostealer called FFDroider. This is distributed through freeware and disguises itself as Telegram to avoid detection. This has been analyzed and the results have been published in a report.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Infostealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** FFDroider
  *  **Targets:** Windows Users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Freeware, Cracked Installers
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Zscaler ThreatLabz has discovered a new infostealer, which they have named FFDroider. This malware is being distributed online through freeware and cracked installers. These installers, once executed, download the stealer which checks for browsers. If it finds the browsers it has on a pre-defined list, it steals cookies and credentials and sends them to a C2 server. The malware creates a registry key and uses multiple threads to speed the theft of cookies and credentials whilst attempting to make analysis more difficult. The malware can use cookies for Facebook and Instagram to access the victim's social media accounts and gather intelligence. If the stolen account belongs to a business, it will fetch payment information from Facebook Adsmanager and other relevant information. Data sent to the C2 server is encrypted using modified base64 encoding. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/ffdroider-stealer-targeting-social-media-platform-users>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1055 - Process Injection  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Browser Hijacking Campaign Targets MacOS
Crowdstrike has published an article detailing a browser hijacking campaign targeting macOS. The campaign modifies the users' browsers to deliver ads to generate revenue.
output:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Adware
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
* **Associated Payloads:** Unnamed Chrome Extension
* **Targets:** macOS users using Chrome or Safari
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Ad Generation
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Crowdstrike has discovered a macOS browser hijacking campaign. The first stage of the campaign uses a DMG file that masquerades as a legitimate file. The user is tricked into mounting this and clicking on the icon to execute a malicious script. The script hides any terminal windows and checks for existing infections. The script then downloads a chrome extension and installs it. It gains persistence by using launch agents which are executed periodically. These are disguised as components of the Chrome browser. The extension contains a hardcoded C2 address and an ID. The extension is built to serve ads to the victims by redirecting a random proportion of user searches to a predetermined site. The extension contains the functionality to remove extensions with conflicting purposes. The researchers also found a variant of this targeting the Safari browser. For more information, please see the link in the references section. 

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/how-crowdstrike-uncovered-a-new-macos-browser-hijacking-campaign/>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1566 - Phishing  

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1204 - User Execution  
   T1204.002 - Malicious File  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1036 - Masquerading  
 T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

**Impact - TA0040**  
 T1565 - Data Manipulation  

**Mitigations:**

**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction. **M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1029:**  Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1039:**  Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1041:**  Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1053:**  Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Browser Hijacking Campaign Targets MacOS
Crowdstrike has published an article detailing a browser hijacking campaign targeting macOS. The campaign modifies the users' browsers to deliver ads to generate revenue.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Adware
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
* **Associated Payloads:** Unnamed Chrome Extension
* **Targets:** macOS users using Chrome or Safari
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Ad Generation
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Crowdstrike has discovered a macOS browser hijacking campaign. The first stage of the campaign uses a DMG file that masquerades as a legitimate file. The user is tricked into mounting this and clicking on the icon to execute a malicious script. The script hides any terminal windows and checks for existing infections. The script then downloads a chrome extension and installs it. It gains persistence by using launch agents which are executed periodically. These are disguised as components of the Chrome browser. The extension contains a hardcoded C2 address and an ID. The extension is built to serve ads to the victims by redirecting a random proportion of user searches to a predetermined site. The extension contains the functionality to remove extensions with conflicting purposes. The researchers also found a variant of this targeting the Safari browser. For more information, please see the link in the references section. 

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/how-crowdstrike-uncovered-a-new-macos-browser-hijacking-campaign/>

**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Cryptocurrency Account SMS Phishing
Cryptocurrency accounts provide immense financial value to attackers. EST Security observed an attempt at getting such credentials in a recent SMS phishing campaign.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

EST Security published a blog post analyzing a recent SMS phishing campaign aimed at stealing cryptocurrency account credentials. The service targeted, Coinone, is a Korean cryptocurrency service, indicating regional targeting. Targets receive a text message claiming that their Coinone account had an access attempt from a foreign IP and that they should verify the activity via a provided link. Visiting the link leads to a lookalike domain hosting a phishing page with a design similar to the legitimate website. If a user falls for the lure and enters their account credentials, the data is exfiltrated to the attacker's collection site. Victims see a progress bar as an attempt to lead them into believing the login is actually being performed. With access to these accounts, the attackers can inflict significant financial damage and turn a profit. For more information, see the EST Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.alyac.co.kr/3321>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: LogoKit Phishing Kit
Phishing kits provide an easy-to-use method of attackers to carry out phishing campaigns. RiskIQ has discovered a new phishing kit that they have dubbed "LogoKit."

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

RiskIQ has published their analysis of a new phishing kit dubbed "LogoKit." This phishing kit uses a unique methodology as compared to other phishing kits. It uses JavaScript functions that interact within the DOM to allow content and HTML form data to be dynamically altered without user interaction. It can either be used to integrate with existing HTML templates or to build fake forms. A victim is sent an email containing a customized URL. The content of the site is built using the company's logo, which is obtained from a third-party service. An AJAX request is used to exfiltrate entered credentials, at which point the victim is either redirected to the legitimate company site or is asked to provide their password again so that the attackers can perform new actions on the data. LogoKit is fully modularized and been used to target a variety of sectors with various templates, such as SharePoint, Adobe, and Microsoft login pages. By using legitimate services such as Google Firebase or Amazon's object storage to load page content, it is more difficult to block the phishing page content. Riskiq identified over 700 domains infected with LogoKit over the past month. For more information, see the RiskIQ blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.riskiq.com/blog/external-threat-management/logokit-phishing/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Agent Tesla Dropped via .daa Attachment
A recent diary on the SANS Internet Storm Center details an Agent Tesla campaign implementing the use of a .daa attachment and Telegram for C2 communication.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Stealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Agent Tesla ([S0331](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331/))
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious .daa email attachment ([T1566.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/001/))
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Steal data ([T1005](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1005/)), Exfiltrate data via Telegram ([T1567](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1567))
  *  **Additional TTPs:** User execution ([T1204.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204/002/))



# Overview

A researcher with the SANS Internet Storm Center uncovered an Agent Tesla campaign implementing a couple of new techniques. As with other Agent Tesla campaigns, the initial infection vector is a phishing email. In this recent campaign, however, the actors have changed to delivering the payload within a .daa file. Interestingly, this file type, Direct Access Archive, cannot be opened on default Windows installations and requires a special tool. If the file is able to be opened by the target, an executable file will be extracted. The executable file is an Agent Tesla payload. It operates as usual except for it now leverages the Telegram API to exfiltrate stolen data. For more information, see the SANS ISC diary in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/57312711/Agent%20Tesla%20Dropped%20via%20.daa%20Attachment%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1627413384425&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date. 
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in search results.



# References

  * <https://isc.sans.edu/diary/rss/27666>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Academic Fraud Websites Running Rampant During Pandemic
With remote learning necessitated by the COVID-19 pandemic, students are finding new and creative ways to commit academic fraud. Cisco Talos shows the correlation between remote learning and academic malfeasance.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Academic Fraud Websites Running Rampant During Pandemic
With remote learning necessitated by the COVID-19 pandemic, students are finding new and creative ways to commit academic fraud. Cisco Talos shows the correlation between remote learning and academic malfeasance.

# Threat Type

  * Fraud




# Overview

An observation by Cisco Talos shows a correlation between the beginning of the school year and visits to known academic fraud sites via DNS requests. According the their blog, Talos has observed a 4x increase in visits to these sites. While not the typical kind of fraud investigated by cybersecurity teams, this type of fraud targets a younger audience and is every bit as dangerous to good security hygiene. Students are logging into websites that could contain answers to tests, shared papers, assignments, and others. What's more, the sites could be run by threat actors looking to take advantage of younger individuals' gullibility. One such site, essayservice.com, offers an app on the Google Play store catering to students looking for a shortcut to academic success. The app has mostly positive reviews and some questionable reviews. One review suggests a student will submit an order, choose a writer, and wait for the requested paper. Another review contains the same information verbatim right down to the punctuation. This practice is common on this application as many other reviews copy seem to be carbon copies of others. The Talos team submitted a request for a four-page, PhD-level essay for about $50. The team selected a writer, who conspicuously shared nearly identical ratings and reviews as most of the other choices. The finished product was not PhD-level and was determined to only be on the high school level. Other domains offered services similar to the above. Clicking on these other domains leads to redirection networks of a malicious nature. This could have the user presented with a fake Flash installer, JavaScript, or other malicious objects. The level of sophistication for these threat actors is on par with the type of knowledge of other types of malicious sites. It appears that, even during a pandemic, there is always someone looking to take advantage of those looking for a shortcut. As long as the pandemic rages, these sites will continue to see increased traffic and with them, dangerous activity for victims to fall prey to. Further details can be found in the blog located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2020/09/the-internet-did-my-homework.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Toolset of Threat Actor IAmTheKing
A report from Kaspersky provides information on a threat actor they believe is state-sponsored and have named IAmTheKing. The report provides an outline of the malware families the actor is known to have been using, one of which is named SlothfulMedia.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

KingOfHearts, QueenOfHearts, QueenOfClubs (older variants of this malware family are known as SlothfulMedia), and JackOfHearts, are malware families used by the actor Kaspersky has named IAmTheKing. Kaspersky notes in their report that IAmTheKing has been active for some years and believes the actor to be state-sponsored. The KingOfHearts, which comes in DLL and EXE variants, is a backdoor with basic features. Traces of the malware can be found as far back as 2014. It is believed to have been distributed using malicious documents contained in spear-phishing emails. The KingOfHearts includes routines to detect debugging and virtualized environments. Communications with its C&C servers is carried out over HTTP(S). The QueenOfHearts probably appeared in 2014 and is more widespread than, but very similar to, the KingOfHearts; however, it does not include the anti-analysis routines. It is still being actively developed and communicates with its C&C server over HTTP. The QueenOfClubs is also similar to the KingOfHearts and has a number of links to the QueenOfHearts. The QueenOfClubs provides the ability to launch arbitrary PowerShell scripts. The JackOfHearts is a dropper and used to install the QueenOfHearts. Once a foothold has been attained inside a network, the attackers attempt to move laterally. In the past, IAmTheKing has targeted Russian entities including those in government, defence, development, education, and energy sectors to gather intelligence. Kaspersky more recently observed IAmTheKing involved in attacks on Central Asian and Eastern European countries, and the US DHS reported on IAmTheKing activity in Malaysia and Ukraine. It is not clear whether these are isolated instances, a shift in targeting, or perhaps that the malware has been shared with other groups. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/iamtheking-and-the-slothfulmedia-malware-family/99000/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: CISA Issues Alert on BlackMatter Ransomware
The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) issued alert AA21-291A on the BlackMatter ransomware, providing a brief analysis of the group and payload tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs).

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** U.S. Critical infrastructure, U.S. food and agriculture
  *  **Ransomware Family:** BlackMatter
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Yes
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Valid credentials
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data encryption, data theft
  *  **Leak Site:** hxxp://blackmax7su6mbwtcyo3xwtpfxpm356jjqrs34y4crcytpw7mifuedyd[.]onion



# Overview

The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) issued alert AA21-291A on the BlackMatter ransomware. BlackMatter is a ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) group, operating on an affiliate model where they profit from those who purchase the payload for use. The sample analyzed as part of the alert uses embedded, previously-compromised credentials to perform its operations. First, running processes and services are enumerated. Then network reconnaissance is performed using LDAP, SMB, and MSRPC. It has the capability to encrypt discovered remote shared over SMB. Additionally, a separate binary exists for the encryption of Linux and ESXi hosts. Backups are completely wiped or reformatted instead of being encrypted. Outside of the capabilities provided by the ransomware payload, tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) observed in BlackMatter incidents may vary depending on the affiliate carrying out the attack. For more information, see the CISA alert in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130635/CISA%20Issues%20Alert%20on%20BlackMatter%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634650769300&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use multi-factor authentication wherever possible. (M1032)



# References

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa21-291a>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1133 - External Remote Services  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1003.001 - LSASS Memory  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.002 - SMB/Windows Admin Shares  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1485 - Data Destruction  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1561 - Disk Wipe

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: CISA ICS Advisories September 17 2020
Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency has issued two advisories covering two products with varying degrees of severity.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerabilities




# Overview

Two advisories issued by CISA address vulnerabilities in product lines from two different vendors. 

## Philips Clinical Collaboration Platform (ICSMA-20-261-01)

A vulnerability in the Philips Clinical Collaboration Platform exists wherein an attacker could perform cross-site request forgery, improper neutralization of script attributes in a web page, protection mechanism failure, algorithm downgrade, and configuration. This exploit contains a CVSS score of 6.8. The vulnerability affects Clinical Collaboration Platform versions 12.2.1 and prior. Philips has released version 12.2.5 which addresses three of the vulnerabilities. One vulnerability requires manual intervention, details of which can be found in the link located within the Reference section below.

## Advantech WebAccess Node (ICSA-20-261-01)

A vulnerability in the Advantech WebAccess Node exists in which an attacker could escalate privileges. An incorrect permission assignment for critical resources allows for this particular vulnerability to be exploited. This vulnerability contains a CVSS score of 7.8. Affected versions of Advantech WebAccess Node prior to 9.0.1 are included. Advantech has issued version 9.0.1 which addresses the vulnerability. Further details can be found in the advisory located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A list of CVEs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/30769616/CISA%20ICS%20Advisories%20September%2017%202020%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1600732311953&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsma-20-261-01>

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-261-01>
  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: XSS Bug in Google Maps Identified
A security researcher has uncovered an XSS vulnerability in Google Maps. The researcher, Zohar Shachar, twice reported the bug to Google with the second attempt successful in the patching of the vulnerability.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: XSS Bug in Google Maps Identified
A security researcher has uncovered an XSS vulnerability in Google Maps. The researcher, Zohar Shachar, twice reported the bug to Google with the second attempt successful in the patching of the vulnerability.

# Threat Type

  * XSS, Vulnerability




# Overview

Under Google's bug hunter program, a security researcher discovered a bug in Google Maps. The bug starts with the create your own map functionality. Upon building the map, the user is able to export the map in KML. KML is similar to XML with some extra features. In his research, he created a map and exported with KML; however, upon submission of the exported file to the server, some XML responses were received. The culprit in the vulnerability is the inability to close the CDATA tag. Mr. Shachar was able to find a way to close the tag by using special characters at the beginning of the payload. In his case, he used the map name tag. It is at this point where the introduction of arbitrary XML code can be introduced. This leads to the XSS. This discovery and submission of this bug garnered Mr. Shachar a bounty and an email stating the bug had been addressed. In order to check the fix, the researcher performed the same steps and found the only way to close a CDATA tag was to add another CDATA tag. This allowed him to bypass the first fix. This information was passed to Google with the promise of another fix and, for Mr. Shachar, an additional bounty. Further information can be found in the article linked within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.ehpus.com/post/xss-fix-bypass-10000-bounty-in-google-maps>
