instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Bizarro Banking Trojan Expands to Europe
Bizarro is a banking Trojan that began by targeting victims in Brazil but has since spread to other countries in Europe and South America. Kaspersky has published their analysis of the campaign and payload.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Banking Trojan, Backdoor




# Overview

Kaspersky published a blog post analyzing the Bizarro banking Trojan, which has recently spread its campaign from Brazil to other countries in Europe and South America. The campaign begins with malicious emails directing users to a link hosting an MSI installer. If the installer is launched, a ZIP archive is retrieved from a compromised AWS, Azure, or WordPress server. The archive contains a malicious DLL, an AutoHotKey or AutoIt script runner, and a script to call an exported function from the DLL. The exported function contains heavily-obfuscated, malicious code to install Bizarro. All browser processes are killed to end any existing sessions on banking websites and autocomplete is disabled in the browser. Basic system information is gathered and exfiltrated to the attacker via an HTTP POST request. Screen recording begins at this point, allowing the attackers to view entered credentials. Furthermore, a clipboard monitor watches for and replaces cryptocurrency wallet addresses. Besides its credential stealing capabilities, Bizarro provides the attackers with extensive backdoor access. Its capabilities include file operations, remote control of mouse and keyboard, keystroke logging, and social engineering. As part of the social engineering capabilities the attackers attempt to obtain 2FA codes and bank transfers. For more information, see the Securelist blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/bizarro-banking-trojan-expands-its-attacks-to-europe/102258/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Android Spyware Targets Users in Pakistan
A number of malicious Android apps targeting Pakistani users were discovered and analyzed by Sophos.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Spyware




# Overview

Sophos published a blog post analyzing a series of Android applications distributing spyware to Pakistani users. Their initial finding was multiple applications masquerading as Pakistan Citizen Portal. In order to decrease chances of detection, the authors of the spyware simply Trojanized the legitimate application, ensuring that the intended application functionality would exist. Furthermore, at least one of the payloads was found being hosted on a domain mimicking the Pakistani government agency that created the Pakistan Citizen Portal application and even steals elements of the legitimate website. The malicious link was also found injected into other compromised Pakistani government websites. The initial payload simply profiles the phone and downloads the second-stage, which contains the main spyware functionality. Specifically, it is capable of exfiltrating sensitive data and the full contents of SMS messages to its C2 server. Other applications that appear to have been Trojanized as part of this campaign include a muslim prayer-clock app, a mobile plan price comparison tool, a SIM checker, and an insurance app, all of which are focused towards Pakistani users. For more information, see the Sophos blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/01/12/new-android-spyware-targets-users-in-pakistan/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Phishers Impersonate Pfizer in RFQ Scam
A report from INKY details the use of Pfizer look-alike domains and a request for quotation (RFQ) theme in an attempt to social engineer targets.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Unknown
  *  **Lure:** Fake request for quotation spoofing Pfizer
  *  **Payload:** PDF attachment
  *  **TTPs:** Spoofing Pfizer
  *  **Compromised Data:** Banking details



# Overview

INKY published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign spoofing Pfizer and using a request for quotation (RFQ) theme. A series of domains containing the word "pfizer" were registered via NameCheap leading up to the campaign starting. The body of the emails claim that Pfizer is requesting a quote for various expensive industrial engineering supplies. Attached is a PDF providing further fake details under the guise of a Pfizer RFQ. Recipients are requested to email a seperate Pfizer lookalike email address with their quote. It is likely the secondary stage of the campaign is to obtain banking details from those who fall victim to the lure. For more information, see the INKY blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Major Brands the Target of Cybersquatting Campaign
Cybersquatting campaigns have targeted major companies including Apple, Facebook, Amazon, and Netflix. Unit42 discuss these campaigns and the details of the TTPs actors employ in the scams.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Major Brands the Target of Cybersquatting Campaign
Cybersquatting campaigns have targeted major companies including Apple, Facebook, Amazon, and Netflix. Unit42 discuss these campaigns and the details of the TTPs actors employ in the scams.

# Threat Type

  * Cybersquatting




# Overview

Using domains altered to look like actual brand domains is nothing new in the world of cybercrime, threat actors are targeting large, brand name companies to perform this action in cybersquatting campaigns. Using domains that look like legitimate domains is a way for cyber criminals to entice victims to visit their sites. At present, Palo Alto has identified 13,857 squatting domains registered in December 2019. Of these, 2,595 were deemed to distribute malware or conduct phishing attacks via credential harvesting. Domains such as PayPal.com, apple.com, Facebook.com, Netflix.com, and others are prime targets, as these are some of the largest domains in terms of user visits. These cyber criminals choose a domain, PayPal.com for instance, and change the domain to something that is closely linked to the original domain like paypa1.com. Under scrutiny, this type of domain doesn't hold up; however, to the untrained user, this domain could be easily overlooked. In this instance, visiting this domain could lead to credential disclosure and, eventually, account takeover. A Samsung domain was mimicked to distribute Azorult malware in order to steal credit card information. Threat actors will also employ domains such as Microsoft-store-drm-server.com to conduct C2 attacks on entire networks. These examples are a small sample of the types of cybersquatting. Other techniques include typosquatting, combo squatting, homograph-squatting, soundsquatting, and others. Additional techniques employed to throw victims off is the use of legitimate certificates to provide a, seemingly, secure HTTPS connection. Cybersquatting domains serve a variety of purposes and have become more and more commonplace. The most common types of domains to be leveraged in cybersquatting campaigns are domain names that target financial, shopping, and banking domains, domains using frequently abused registrars, and domains that do not have validated SSL certificates. Further technical details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/cybersquatting/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New Version of APT-C-23 Android Spyware
APT-C-23 targeting Middle Eastern users with Android spyware. Sophos reports on recent updates to the group's payloads that enhance its evasiveness.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Version of APT-C-23 Android Spyware
APT-C-23 targeting Middle Eastern users with Android spyware. Sophos reports on recent updates to the group's payloads that enhance its evasiveness.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Android Spyware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** APT-C-23
  *  **Associated Payloads:** APT-C-23 Spyware
  *  **Targets:** Middle East
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Side-loaded malicious APK
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Remote command execution, data theft



# Overview

Sophos published a blog post analyzing a recent version of APT-C-23's Android spyware. The group operates in the Middle East, primarily targeting victims in the Palestinian territories. The infection vector of the most recent payloads is unknown, although Sophos suspects that SMS text message links are the source of the malicious download. Upon installation, the device checks in with a hardcoded C2 address. A new addition to the code allows this C2 address to be updated by the operators as needed. After obtaining the permissions required to carry out its functionality, the app attempts to hide itself from the user by changing its logo and name to that of a legitimate application, such as Google Play, Youtube, Google, or Botim. Opening the app from this point forward will open the legitimate version of the application it is masquerading as. The malware will continue to wait for commands received via Firebase messaging. Command capabilities include data collection, taking pictures and screenshots, recording audio, reading notifications, and more. Any collected data is ZIP archived and later uploaded to the C2 server. For more information, see the Sophos blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155158/New%20Version%20of%20APT-C-23%20Android%20Spyware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637766335569&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Install security updates (M1001).
  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).
  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.



# References

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/11/23/android-apt-spyware-targeting-middle-east-victims-improves-its-capabilities/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  
  
 **Execution - TA0041**  
T1575 - Native Code  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0030**  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
  
 **Discovery - TA0032**  
T1418 - Application Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0035**  
T1409 - Access Stored Application Data  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages  
T1429 - Capture Audio  
T1432 - Access Contact List  
T1433 - Access Call Log  
T1512 - Capture Camera  
T1513 - Screen Capture  
T1517 - Access Notifications  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0037**  
T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol  
T1481 - Web Service  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0036**  
T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Vulnerable WordPress Sites Used To DDoS Ukrainian Targets
BleepingComputer has reported on the discovery of several WordPress sites which contain a malicious script. When accessed by a user, the script is run and the browser is used to stage a DDoS attack. Details have been published in a report.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** DDoS
  *  **Targets:** Ukrainian Websites
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** WordPress Vulnerabilities
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** DDoS Attack



# Overview

Browsers are being used as part of an ongoing DDoS attack, BleepingComputer has reported. The attackers have compromised several WordPress sites using known vulnerabilities. With this, they have implanted a JavaScript file that runs when the site is loaded. The script forces the browser to make many connections to a hardcoded website, intending to degrade the service of the website. The sites targeted by the script include Ukrainian government agencies, think tanks, financial sites, and other pro-Ukrainian sites. Upon further analysis, the researchers found the same script being used by a pro-Ukrainian site to target Russian websites. The difference in this use of the script is that the website is transparent about the use of the script whereas on the compromised WordPress sites the user wouldn't know the script is running in the background. The script uses a random query string in the request to avoid anti-DDoS services and get to the actual target server. For more information please see the link in the reference section.

# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/hacked-wordpress-sites-force-visitors-to-ddos-ukrainian-targets/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1489 - Service Stop  
T1498 - Network Denial of Service  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: SPM55 - An Indonesian Phishing As A Service Operator
DomainTools has published a report that provides information on the activities of an Indonesian Phishing-as-a-Service operator they refer to as SPM55.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Users with accounts at financial institutions, services companies, and technology companies.
  *  **Lure:** Account disabled messages.
  *  **Payload:** Phishing page. ****
  * **Compromised Data:** Account credentials and other personal information.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

According to a report from DomainTools, SPM55 is an Indonesian Phishing-as-a-Service operator that has been increasing its customer base and activity. The report notes that the SPM55 offerings have a high rate of success in comparison to other phishing kits. Financial institutions, services companies, and technology companies are the typical targets. The operator also offer add-ons for credit card checkers, account validators, and what is described as an "antibot." The antibot is used to help evade detection by redirecting sessions to benign sites if they do not appear to be from a valid phishing target. SPM55 prefers Indonesian-speaking customers and payments from OVO and DANA, which are Indonesian payment services. Payments can also be made using Bitcoin and Ethereum. The typical lures used in target emails claim a recipient's account has been disabled. Aside from seeking a victim's credentials the phishing pages can also include fields to capture other personal information. The kit is written in PHP, some parts of which have been copied from other phishing kits. Interestingly, harvested credentials are sent not only to the SPM55 customer but also to the operators. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://www.domaintools.com/resources/blog/spm55-ascending-the-ranks-of-indonesian-phishing-as-a-service-offerings>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1589.002 - Email Addresses  
T1598 - Phishing for Information  
T1598.001 - Spearphishing Service  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.002 - Tool  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
SPM55 - An Indonesian Phishing As A Service Operator
DomainTools has published a report that provides information on the activities of an Indonesian Phishing-as-a-Service operator they refer to as SPM55.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Users with accounts at financial institutions, services companies, and technology companies.
  *  **Lure:** Account disabled messages.
  *  **Payload:** Phishing page. ****
  * **Compromised Data:** Account credentials and other personal information.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

According to a report from DomainTools, SPM55 is an Indonesian Phishing-as-a-Service operator that has been increasing its customer base and activity. The report notes that the SPM55 offerings have a high rate of success in comparison to other phishing kits. Financial institutions, services companies, and technology companies are the typical targets. The operator also offer add-ons for credit card checkers, account validators, and what is described as an "antibot." The antibot is used to help evade detection by redirecting sessions to benign sites if they do not appear to be from a valid phishing target. SPM55 prefers Indonesian-speaking customers and payments from OVO and DANA, which are Indonesian payment services. Payments can also be made using Bitcoin and Ethereum. The typical lures used in target emails claim a recipient's account has been disabled. Aside from seeking a victim's credentials the phishing pages can also include fields to capture other personal information. The kit is written in PHP, some parts of which have been copied from other phishing kits. Interestingly, harvested credentials are sent not only to the SPM55 customer but also to the operators. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://www.domaintools.com/resources/blog/spm55-ascending-the-ranks-of-indonesian-phishing-as-a-service-offerings>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1589.002 - Email Addresses  
T1598 - Phishing for Information  
T1598.001 - Spearphishing Service  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.002 - Tool  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Threat Actors Use Canva Templates for Credential Phishing
While not their first time seeing such activity, Cofense reports on a significant increase in the use of Canva in phishing campaigns.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Threat Actors Use Canva Templates for Credential Phishing
While not their first time seeing such activity, Cofense reports on a significant increase in the use of Canva in phishing campaigns.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense has published a blog post reporting on a recent increase in the use of Canva, a design platform, as part of a phishing campaign. They observed two variations in the initial stage of distribution of the phishing link. The first version delivered comes with a PDF attachment that contains a link to an image hosted on Canva. The second version includes the Canva link directly in the body of the email. Regardless of the method used to distribute this link, users are directed to an image on Canva. The image may use any number of lures, such as document sharing themes. Clicking on the image, as it requests, leads to a phishing page hosted on a compromised website. The fake login pages vary but all have the same goal of gathering victim credentials for email services. Cofense notes that one of the main reasons attackers likely began to use Canva, as opposed to more well known services such as Google Drive or Dropbox, is that the other services tend to take down the malicious files more quickly than Canva. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/threat-actors-use-canva-templates-for-credential-phishing/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Phishing After ProxyShell Exploitation
A report published by Cybereason provides their analysis of an attack that involved compromising an Exchange server by exploiting one of the ProxyShell vulnerabilities and then using email threads obtained from the server to send phishing emails that contained malicious links.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Phishing After ProxyShell Exploitation
A report published by Cybereason provides their analysis of an attack that involved compromising an Exchange server by exploiting one of the ProxyShell vulnerabilities and then using email threads obtained from the server to send phishing emails that contained malicious links.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Phishing
  *  **Targets:** Unpatched Exchange servers, Users whose email addresses are in threads in the Exchange server.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** DatopLoader, QBot, Cobalt Strike
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** ProxyShell vulnerability.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, Reconnaissance, Lateral Movement, Data collection.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

According to a report published by Cybereason, an attacker recently compromised an Exchange by exploiting one of the ProxyShell vulnerabilities, CVE-2021-34473. The attackers then sent phishing emails to internal and external addresses. The emails were replies to existing email threads the attackers obtained from the Exchange server. The links in the emails led to a .zip archive that contained a malicious DatopLoader Excel file. When executed, a macro in the DatopLoader Excel file was used to download three DLLs which were then executed using regsvr32.exe. The first DLL executed deployed the initial payload, QBot, which then took control and established persistence and began communicating with its C&C server. The attacker then conducted reconnaissance on the compromised system's environment and Cobalt Strike beacons were deployed on other hosts in the network. More information can be found in the Cybereason report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056850/Phishing%20After%20ProxyShell%20Exploitation%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641959299888&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017)



# References

  * <https://www.cybereason.com/blog/threat-analysis-report-datoploader-exploits-proxyshell-to-deliver-qbot-and-cobalt-strike>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1072 - Software Deployment Tools  
T1569 - System Services  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
T1505 - Server Software Component  
T1505.003 - Web Shell  
T1543 - Create or Modify System Process  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1211 - Exploitation for Defense Evasion  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1620 - Reflective Code Loading  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1212 - Exploitation for Credential Access  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1069 - Permission Groups Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1135 - Network Share Discovery  
T1482 - Domain Trust Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1072 - Software Deployment Tools  
T1534 - Internal Spearphishing  
T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1114 - Email Collection  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
T1219 - Remote Access Software

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Brazilian Bank Users Targeted in Phishing Operation
Clients of Banco Itau Empresas who use Itaú Internet Banking are being targeted by a phishing operation that is set up to take advantage of the new PIX payment method.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

PIX is a payment method implemented by Brazil's Central Bank that provides several benefits over the old systems, such as faster completion of transactions. A phishing operation is targeting business customers of Banco Itau Empresas online banking service, which uses an app. The lure is a fake diagnostic page for the app that informs the user their version of the app is out of date and provides a link to update the app. If the link is clicked, the victim is presented with a fake login page. The login page uses PHP sessions and AJAX calls to provide the attacker real time control over the responses and requests sent to the victim. While a victim awaits responses, the bank's legitimate loading GIF is presented to the victim. The aim of the attacker is to obtain the victim's credentials and QR code, which allows the attacker to then access and manipulate the victim's account. Further details, including a split screen animation showing the victim's screen and the attacker's dashboard, are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * None provided.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2021/01/real-time-phishing-kit-targets-brazilian-central-bank.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Chaes Banking Trojan Being Spread By Compromised WordPress Sites
The Chaes banking trojan was first seen in November 2020 and operates solely in Brazil. This article by Avast details the latest activities of this malware and explores the infection chain being used in the current campaign.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Chaes Banking Trojan Being Spread By Compromised WordPress Sites
The Chaes banking trojan was first seen in November 2020 and operates solely in Brazil. This article by Avast details the latest activities of this malware and explores the infection chain being used in the current campaign.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Banking Trojan **  
**
  *  **Targets:** Brazillian Bank Customers
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Chaes (S0631)
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Web Popup
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

The Chaes banking trojan has been targeting users in Brazil since November 2020. Avast has seen an uptick in infections from this malware, with over 66,000 infection attempts recorded from their Brazilian customers. The root of this appeared to be over 800 websites that have been infected by a malicious script being used to spread the trojan. The vast majority of these use Brazilian TLDs, and some of these websites are highly reputable. All websites compromised by the threat actor were WordPress sites, leading researchers to believe the initial infection vector was a vulnerability in the WordPress versions being used. The delivery mechanism is highly modular and uses multiple scripting frameworks including Python, JavaScript, and NodeJS. The user is first infected by visiting the compromised sites and installing a false version of Java which is recommended by a popup. Once the malware is installed, all web credentials, history, and user profiles are stolen and sent to the attackers, to monitor and steal any Brazilian banking credentials and activity. For more information about the delivery stages, please view the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057838/Chaes%20Banking%20Trojan%20Being%20Spread%20By%20Compromised%20WordPress%20Sites%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1643627739173&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Set a browser extension allow or deny list as appropriate for your security policy (M1038).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/anhho/chasing-chaes-kill-chain/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1059.006 - Python  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
T1574.001 - DLL Search Order Hijacking  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1112 - Modify Registry  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.004 - InstallUtil  
T1218.007 - Msiexec  
T1221 - Template Injection  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
T1185 - Browser Session Hijacking  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1132 - Data Encoding  
T1132.001 - Standard Encoding  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: SharkBot - An Android Banking Trojan
SharkBot is a newer Android banking Trojan that was initially discovered in the last quarter of 2021 and has been deployed through the Google Play store according to a report from the NCC Group.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Android banking Trojan.
  *  **Targets:** Various
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** SharkBot
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake anti-virus application downloaded from the Google Play store.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration, Fraudulent transactions.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A newer addition to the families of Android banking Trojans is SharkBot. It was originally discovered in October 2021 and has been updated since, with the last update occurring on 10 February 2022, according to a report from the NCC Group. The later version appears to be a dropper and uses the ‘Direct Reply‘ Android feature to download the full SharkBot version sometime after the dropper version is installed. It is distributed as an anti-virus application. SharkBot contains provides multiple methods to conduct fraudulent transactions including overlay injections, keylogging to obtain credentials, SMS interception, and remote control of an infected device using Android's Accessibility Services. One of the notable features of SharkBot is the use of Android's Automatic Transfer Systems (ATS) which allows the attackers to auto-fill fields in legitimate mobile banking apps and initiate money transfers while bypassing many security checks. It is also used by the dropper to download and install the full SharkBot version with Accessibility permissions. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/81134151/SharkBot%20-%20An%20Android%20Banking%20Trojan%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1646625110200&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://research.nccgroup.com/2022/03/03/sharkbot-a-new-generation-android-banking-trojan-being-distributed-on-google-play-store/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Metamorfo/Mekotio Banking Trojan Uses AutoHotKey Scripting
The Cofense Phishing Defense Center (PDC) takes a brief look at Mekotio, also known as Metamorfo, a banking Trojan with Latin American origins that is now expanding its reach to victims across Europe. This trojan is one that makes use of a little known scripting language known as AutoHotKey (AHK).
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing, Keylogger, Infostealer, Trojan




# Overview

 AHK was originally developed to create keyboard shortcuts (e.g. hot keys). Mekotio monitors browser activity looking for targeted banks. The targeted banks list include banks from Latin America, Spain, France, and Portugal. The malware captures the credentials with its keylogging capabilities. In addition to being a banking trojan, it can also monitor bitcoin addresses and replaces them with ones belonging to the attackers. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/autohotkey-banking-trojan/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Google Sweepstakes Phishing Campaign
A diary by a SANS Internet Storm Center researcher details a phishing email using a Google Sweepstakes theme to steal sensitive data.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Google Sweepstakes Phishing Campaign
A diary by a SANS Internet Storm Center researcher details a phishing email using a Google Sweepstakes theme to steal sensitive data.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

A SANS Internet Storm Center researcher has published a diary detailing a phishing campaign using a Google Sweepstakes theme. Targets are sent an email from a lookalike Google domain with a PDF attached. The email claims that the user has been selected by Google for something and to view the PDF for further information. Inside the PDF is a letter claiming that the recipient has won prize money and Google products. They are requested to respond with various personally identifiable information (PII) to receive their prize. If they respond to the sender, eventually the attacker will request the victim pay for shipping charges and bank fees. Inside the PDF is a suspicious domain. X-Force researchers investigated this domain and found PDFs with similar file names, such as "Official Notification" and "Official Winning Notification," submitted as far back as January 2021. The hashes of these PDFs are provided alongside this report. For more information, see the SANS Internet Storm Center diary in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://isc.sans.edu/diary/rss/27578>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New QRAT Spam Campaigns
QRAT is a Java-based RAT that has been sold under a software-as-a-service model since 2015. Trustwave reports on the infection process and payload of a recently observed campaign.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

Trustwave published an analysis of a recent QRAT campaign, providing details of both the infection process and the final payload. This campaign begins with a spam email containing either a download link to a JAR file or having a JAR file directly attached. Opening the associated JAR file, which is a first stage downloader, begins the infection process. The first stage is responsible for installing Node.js on the victim host. With Node.js installed, it then downloads and executes the second stage downloader, which comes in the form of a JS file. The JS file begins by establishing persistence on the system via a CMD file in combination with a Registry Run key. With persistence in place, the main QRAT payload is downloaded from a remote server and executed with a series of arguments. Initial communication with the C2 server is created via the Websocket connection protocol. Once the C2 communication is established, QRAT is able to receive commands allowing the attacker to obtain system information, perform file operations, and steal credentials from applications. For more information, see the Trustwave blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trustwave.com/en-us/resources/blogs/spiderlabs-blog/rats-and-spam-the-nodejs-qrat/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: TA505 and ServHelper RAT Activity
In mid-June, Cisco Talos observed an increase in ServHelper RAT activity which Talos attributes, with medium confidence, to the group they refer to as TA505.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** ServHelper (S0382), Amadey, and Raccoon
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Trojanized Software Installer
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Information Theft, Cryptomining



# Overview

In mid-June, Cisco Talos noted an increase in activity involving the ServHelper RAT. Other malware involved in the activity included Amadey, Raccoon, and cryptominers. Talos attributes the activity, with medium confidence, to the group they refer to as TA505. IBM X-Force tracks TA505 as Hive0065. One of the infection vectors observed is the use of Trojanized software installers that are served from compromised hosts. The installer will deliver Racoon, which in turn delivers a GoLang loader and a .NET dropper. These deliver a PowerShell loader that installs the ServHelper RAT. ServHelper has also been deployed onto systems that are already infected with Amadey. Post-compromise activities may include the installation of a cryptominer. Further details are available from the Talos report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/62357530/TA505%20and%20ServHelper%20RAT%20Activity%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1629347724003&api=v2)



# Mitre ATT&CK Framework

  * Execution (TA0002, T1059.001)
  * Persistence (TA0003, T1547.001)
  * Defense Evasion (TA0005, T1027, T1055, T1064)
  * Collection (TA0009, T1056)
  * Command and Control (TA0011, T1105, T1219, T1571)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2021/08/raccoon-and-amadey-install-servhelper.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Latest RATs Targeting macOS
SentinelOne notes continued trends of malware targeting macOS seen in 2022 after releasing their blog on Mac malware trends throughout 2021. They provide a brief overview of two new malware families, referred to as SysJoker and DazzleSpy.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  ** **Malware Family/Families:** **SysJoker, DazzleSpy
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, Collection, and Exfiltration of data.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Mac users are no longer considered safe from malware just by simply practicing "safe behavior". SentinelOne has recognized the trends they pointed out in 2021 continuing into 2022 in regards to the malware targeting macOS. In a recent blog, they provide a brief overview of two new malware families, referred to as SysJoker and DazzleSpy. MacOS is included in targeting by malware that crosses multiple platforms such as SysJoker which has Windows, Linux, and macOS variants and DazzleSpy is exploiting vulnerabilities within macOS. The primary purpose of SysJoker is to await commands from a C2. Capabilities of DazzleSpy are designed for espionage and include dumping the keychain, running a remote desktop, and running shell commands. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058208/Latest%20RATs%20Targeting%20macOS%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644011103642&api=v2)

Tell me about the following threat: Chrome Browser Update - March 2 2021 - Exploit in the Wild
Google has released an update to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for forty-eight vulnerabilities. An exploit for one of the vulnerabilities exists in the wild.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Chrome Browser Update - March 2 2021 - Exploit in the Wild
Google has released an update to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for forty-eight vulnerabilities. An exploit for one of the vulnerabilities exists in the wild.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Google has released an update, version 89.0.4389.72, to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for forty-eight vulnerabilities. An exploit for the one of the vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-21166) exists in the wild. Google has rated this vulnerability as High. The most serious potential impact from successful exploitation of the vulnerabilities is the remote execution of arbitrary code. Further information is available from the release notes which are linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/42434953/Chrome%20Browser%20Update%20-%20March%202%202021%20-%20Exploit%20in%20the%20Wild%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1614734328165&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://chromereleases.googleblog.com/2021/03/stable-channel-update-for-desktop.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Modular Backdoor - SideWalk
SideWalk is a new modular backdoor discovered by ESET. It was used in a recent campaign by the APT group ESET refer to as SparklingGoblin that targeted a US computer retailer.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** SparklingGoblin
  *  **Associated Payloads:** SideWalk
  *  **Targets:** Primarily, though not exclusively, targets East and Southeast Asia and entities involved in the academic, computer, e-commerce, education, electronics, media, religious, and retail sectors, and government organizations.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Gather system information, Elevate privileges
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the Mitre ATT&CK Framework identifiers below. 



# Overview

According to ESET, SparklingGoblin (also known as Earth Baku) is part of the Winnti Group family. The SideWalk (also known as ScrambleCross) back door shares many similarities with and is believed to have been written by the same authors who wrote, the CROSSWALK back door. SideWalk is modular, with modules being able to be loaded from its C&C server. It uses Google Docs for a dead drop resolver and can communicate with its C&C server from behind a proxy. The C&C servers are Cloudflare workers. Further information can be found from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/62358126/New%20Modular%20Backdoor%20-%20SideWalk%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1630284523746&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/08/24/sidewalk-may-be-as-dangerous-as-crosswalk/>

T1587.003 - Digital Certificates  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**

T1008 - Fallback Channels

T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Financial Spear-Phishing Campaigns Pushing RATs
Following a private industry notification from the FBI, Cyjax has published a blog post further analyzing associated financial spear-phishing campaigns delivering RATs.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT, Spear-phishing




# Overview

Cyjax published a blog post providing further research into the financial spear-phishing campaign recently reported on by the FBI. The initial infection vector is a phishing email supposedly from a financial institution with two PDF files attached, both of which were benign but contained related decoy content. Additionally, a link is provided with associated credentials to download an application. Regardless of the bank being mimicked in each specific sample, a similar login form requesting the recipient's email and the access code from the email is displayed. Entering the access code leads to the download of a fake Windows application. The installer executes the fake Windows application in order to distract the user while also opening a backdoor on the host. Based on analysis, it appears the Windows application was developed using an open-source project called "Squirrel" and the backdoor functionality is based off of TeamViewer, a legitimate remote admin tool. The researchers also found various domains with different banks being impersonated based on shared hosting infrastructure. There is no attribution to a known threat actor at this time, although this attack is highly sophisticated. For more information, see the Cyjax blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.cyjax.com/2021/05/27/financial-spear-phishing-campaigns-pushing-rats/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: JobCrypter Ransomware Analysis
Focusing on a smaller ransomware family still active amongst the largerm double extortion ransomware groups, Yoroi has published a blog post analyzing the JobCrypter ransomware.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Yoroi has recently observed the JobCrypter ransomware active in campaigns across Italy, despite its relative simplicity to the larger, double extortion ransomware groups widely discussed across the cyber landscape. This ransomware family often spreads via email attachments sent to victims enticing them to open the file in order to initiate the infection. The researchers' analysis begins with the JavaScript loader employed by the threat actors. Inside the script is a hex-obfuscated payload that is dropped into the user's %TEMP% folder and subsequently executed. The payload is packed using a .NET packers and employs anti-debugging checks before performing its primary malicious activities. If anti-debugging checks pass, a configuration file is decrypted for use by the malware. Persistence is then established via a JavaScript file in the Startup folder that simply launches the ransomware executable. Plaintext SMTP is used in order to send the decryption key to be used to the attacker's C2 server. This means that if an organization is capturing the contents of outbound emails, the decryption key could be obtained and used without paying the ransom. Finally, Triple DES encryption is performed and a ransom note requesting the victim email the attacker's to pay the ransomware is dropped on the system. For more information, see the Yoroi blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Protection

## Yara Rule
    
    
    rule JobCrypter_2104{  
      
    meta:   
    description = "Yara Rule for JobCrypter Ransomware - End of March 2021 "   
    author = "Yoroi Malware ZLab"   
    last_updated = "2021-04-13"   
    tlp = "white"   
    category = "informational"  
      
    strings:   
    $a1 = { 3B C2 8D A0 ?? 00 }   
    $a2 = { 2A 28 C5 00 00 06 20 03 }   
    $a3 = { 20 BC 01 00 00 FE 0E 04 00 38 }   
    $a4 = { AB 39 00 00 83 54 00 00 8C }   
    $a5 = { 69 44 F4 E8 B7 78 50 EF }   
    $a6 = { 0E 03 6F 4F 02 00 06 }   
    $a7 = { 71 70 F4 48 B9 68 18 65 }   
      
    condition:   
    uint16(0) == 0x5A4D and 4 of them  
      
    } 

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
  * Perform endpoint scans using the provided Yara Rule to detect existing infections.



# Reference

  * <https://yoroi.company/research/ransomware-micro-criminals-are-still-out-here-and-growing/>
