instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Threat Actors Using Open Travel After COVID To Lure Victims
Fortinet has published a report detailing how several types of malware are using travel-themed lures to trick victims. This is capitalizing on the reopening of the travel industry since the pandemic.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Threat Actors Using Open Travel After COVID To Lure Victims
Fortinet has published a report detailing how several types of malware are using travel-themed lures to trick victims. This is capitalizing on the reopening of the travel industry since the pandemic.

Summary
=======

 

Attack Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Phishing
* **Target:** Various, including Colombian Military Organization
* **Lure:** Travel Advice
* **Payload:** AsyncRAT, Netwire RAT, Quasar RAT
* **Compromised Data:** Unknown
* **Post-compromise Actions:** Unknown
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Fortinet has been tracking how various malware is using travel-themed lures to trick victims into becoming infected. In one example, researchers found a file that was masquerading as an example travel itinerary. The file was disguised as a pdf but used padding characters and a double file extension to hide that it is an executable. Running the file will install AsyncRAT onto the victim machine and allow attackers access. In a similar campaign, Netwire RAT was also found being spread using a fake itinerary. This time, the file was a javascript file that was found on Discord. Finally, the researchers discovered a spearphishing attack against a Colombian military organization. The email requests a reservation of rooms with an attached ISO file. The payload in this instance was Quasar RAT, which is stored as an executable that the user must click on when the attached ISO file is mounted and accessed. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/threat-actors-prey-on-eager-travelers>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1566 - Phishing  
   T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
   T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  

**Execution - TA0002**  
   T1059.007 - JavaScript  
   T1204.002 - Malicious File  

**Credential Access - TA0006**  
 T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
 T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
   T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1082 - System Information Discovery  

**Collection - TA0009**  
 T1056 - Input Capture  
 T1113 - Screen Capture  

**Exfiltration - TA0010**  
 T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  

#### Mitigations:

**M1015:**  Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1027:**  Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1030:**  Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1035:**  Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1041:**  Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Threat Actors Using Open Travel After COVID To Lure Victims
Fortinet has published a report detailing how several types of malware are using travel-themed lures to trick victims. This is capitalizing on the reopening of the travel industry since the pandemic.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
Summary
=======

 

Attack Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Phishing
* **Target:** Various, including Colombian Military Organization
* **Lure:** Travel Advice
* **Payload:** AsyncRAT, Netwire RAT, Quasar RAT
* **Compromised Data:** Unknown
* **Post-compromise Actions:** Unknown
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Fortinet has been tracking how various malware is using travel-themed lures to trick victims into becoming infected. In one example, researchers found a file that was masquerading as an example travel itinerary. The file was disguised as a pdf but used padding characters and a double file extension to hide that it is an executable. Running the file will install AsyncRAT onto the victim machine and allow attackers access. In a similar campaign, Netwire RAT was also found being spread using a fake itinerary. This time, the file was a javascript file that was found on Discord. Finally, the researchers discovered a spearphishing attack against a Colombian military organization. The email requests a reservation of rooms with an attached ISO file. The payload in this instance was Quasar RAT, which is stored as an executable that the user must click on when the attached ISO file is mounted and accessed. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/threat-actors-prey-on-eager-travelers>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1566 - Phishing  
   T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
   T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  

**Execution - TA0002**  
   T1059.007 - JavaScript  
   T1204.002 - Malicious File  

**Credential Access - TA0006**  
 T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
 T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
   T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1082 - System Information Discovery  

**Collection - TA0009**  
 T1056 - Input Capture  
 T1113 - Screen Capture  

**Exfiltration - TA0010**  
 T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  

#### Mitigations:

**M1015:**  Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1027:**  Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1030:**  Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1035:**  Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1041:**  Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Social Security Scam
A Social Security scam is circulating where the victim is walked through the process of acquiring funds in the form of various gift cards for the criminals.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Scam, Monetary Theft, Social Engineering



# Overview

Those of us that have been in the computing world for a number of years are aware of the "Microsoft Tech Support" and "Social Security" scams. But there are those who, either from lack of participation on Social Media or age, may not be aware of the evil people do to make money. If a potential victim is taken in by the social engineering techniques, the intimidation and threats from these scams, they can potentially lose a good portion, if not all, of their life savings they have set aside for their retirement years. The following is the result of an interview with such a victim.

She and her husband had moved back to their home town area into an assisted living facility, to be near their sons. The husband was a victim of dementia and died from the disease about a year later. The two of them were, by no means, "wealthy", but she still retained enough income to live on and to purchase the occasional birthday and Christmas gifts. There was even enough money for a bowl of chili from Wendy's when her sons weren't around to pay for it.

Then there was that faithful day, when the telephone rang with a number that appeared to be from Washington DC. The caller informed the lady that there had been an attempt by someone to take money out of her Social Security account and that her account had been frozen. Since the lady did not immediately hang up, the criminal on the line thought he may have just found a new victim. Using social engineering techniques, he was able to convince the lady that not only were there arrest warrants made out for her (after all, cocaine had been found in the trunk of her car), but that he might be able to assist her with getting the charges dropped if she paid the fine. He assured her that he would be right there to help her gather and transfer the money himself. The best way to transfer the money would be through gift cards that she would purchase in $200 increments. He warned her, not to tell anyone what was going on, because, after all, this was a federal investigation.

The next day, the caller once again contacted the lady and guided her through the steps she would be taking that day. First, she would go to the bank and withdraw $3,000 in cash, which would be used to purchase the gift cards. Then she would go to Kroger (a local grocery chain) for the first card purchases. Again she was warned not to tell anyone what she was doing or why. The staff at the assisted living facility, her family, her friends, no one was to be told of her secretive mission. And she must stay on the line with the criminal at all times so that he could walk her through what needed to be done.

She arrived at the bank just before noon and withdrew $3,000 from her account, money that otherwise would have been spent on her assisted living costs. Next she was to go to Kroger where she would purchase some E-Bay gift cards valued at $200 each. While keeping her line open at all times, she was to return to her car and scratch off the covering to the redemption code. For each card, she was to read off the thirteen digits found underneath to the criminal on the line. Next, she was to go to Walgreens for more purchases. This time the gift cards would be for Google Play, again for the same amount.

Meanwhile, back at the assisted facility, those in charge were becoming worried about the lady. She was only supposed to be going to the bank and should have returned a while ago. So they called the point of contact to inform him of the missing lady. He, in turn, called his brother and they both began calling the lady, trying to get her to answer. At the time, she was not answering any calls other than from the criminal, what few times she wasn't already on the line with him. The two brothers, not knowing about the calls, were fearful something had happened to her. They even had contacted the police regarding a possible traffic accident involving her, since they were unaware of the scam taking place.

Just as the brothers were about to reach the city limits, she finally called and told them she was at Walgreens and wanted to know if they were coming for a visit. Relieved that she appeared to be okay, they indicated that while the visit was not a planned one, yes, they were coming. She indicated she would be back at the facility shortly, then, for their visit. The brothers arrived first and waited. For thirty minutes. Since they had just passed Walgreens on the way to the facility and it was less than five minutes away, they returned to see what was wrong. The lady was acting strangely and was just getting into her car while trying to talk on the phone. They all drove back to the facility for a visit.

While the brothers were explaining how concerned they were about her being gone for so long and not answering her phone, her phone rang and she promptly answered it. Her side of the conversation sounded strange, subdued, almost secretive. The older brother picked up the phone and asked who was on the other end. Upon hearing a foreign accent, he became concerned and asked what this call was in regards to. Upon hearing the words "Social Security", combined the secretive actions of the lady, he immediately arrived at the correct conclusion that the lady was being scammed and may have said a few things that would have required soap to wash out of his mouth in his youth.

The facts and events of the previous twenty-four hours were slowly drawn out of the lady. Her reluctance to hand over the cards, so their balances could be checked, shed some light on the brain washing and social engineering techniques used on her. They assured they lady that her Social Security account was not frozen, that there were not warrants out for her arrest, and that cocaine had not been discovered in her car.

While this vile criminal may have gotten some money out of the lady's account, her inexperience in dealing with gift cards and her lack of knowledge of places of purchase the criminal was trying to lead her to at least allowed her to retain some of her purchased cards that day. An expensive lesson, but one hopefully her declining years will allow her to retain against another incident.

Tales such as these appear all the time on Social Media and often they are written off as slight exaggerations. When the "lady" is your own mother and you walk into the middle of what otherwise might have been a successful scam, it hits home and it hits deep.

# Recommendations

  * Warn your elderly parents, relatives, and friends of the dangers of these types of scam calls
  * Report attempts, especially successful attempts, to local law enforcement agencies
  * Review the Social Security document warnings on such incidents



# Reference

  * <https://www.ssa.gov/scam/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: The Chronicles of Bumblebee Malware
Current reporting indicates that a new malware has been discovered. The new malware called “BumbleBee” has been the subject of a detailed report on the tactics, techniques, and procedures utilized to deploy BumbleBee. This malware is currently being utilized with a spearphishing campaign with the goal of injecting Cobalt Strike shellcodes to compromise victims' environments.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: The Chronicles of Bumblebee Malware
Current reporting indicates that a new malware has been discovered. The new malware called “BumbleBee” has been the subject of a detailed report on the tactics, techniques, and procedures utilized to deploy BumbleBee. This malware is currently being utilized with a spearphishing campaign with the goal of injecting Cobalt Strike shellcodes to compromise victims' environments.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type: Loader**
  *  **Associated Threat Actors: Conti Group, Initial Access Brokers**
  *  **Associated Payloads: Cobalt Strike**
  *  **Initial Infection Vector: Spearphishing**



# Overview

Reporting indicates that a new loader called “BumbleBee” is currently being utilized by the Conti ransomware group. There is also reporting that indicates that initial access brokers (IAB) are utilizing BumbleBee as a way to obfuscate activities. IABs are groups of cyber threat actors that gain initial access to vulnerable networks and then offer that access on DarkWeb forums.

In the past, these groups have utilized well-known loaders such as Trickbot, Bazarloader, and Emotet. All of these variants of loaders have been utilized to deliver Cobalt Strike, but Bumblebee is using DLL files to deliver the payload. As part of the campaign, the threat actors create fake employee email addresses, and fake websites, and utilize public storage services to deliver the malicious ISO image file. The ISO image file is responsible for luring the victim to execute the BumbleBee malware. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://elis531989.medium.com/the-chronicles-of-bumblebee-the-hook-the-bee-and-the-trickbot-connection-686379311056>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

####  **Tactics and Techniques:**

####  **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation

####  **Mitigations:**

####  **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Cisco Security Advisories January 2021
Cisco has released four advisories that address vulnerabilities in several Cisco products for January 2021.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Cisco Security Advisories January 2021
Cisco has released four advisories that address vulnerabilities in several Cisco products for January 2021.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerabilities




# Overview

Cisco has released security advisories for several of its products. Listed below are the specific products affected and the subsequent patches addressing those vulnerabilities for each product. We recommend reviewing each of the advisories and implementing suggested patches as soon as possible.

## Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Client for Windows DLL Injection Vulnerability

A vulnerability exists which could allow for an authenticated, local attacker to perform a DLL injection attack. Insufficient validation of resources is the source of the vulnerability. Affected versions of the software are Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Client for Windows releases earlier than Release 4.9.04043. This vulnerability has a CVSS Score of 7.8.

 **CVEs**

  * CVE-2021-1237



 **Source**

<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-anyconnect-dll-injec-pQnryXLf>

## Cisco Small Business RV110W, RV130, RV130W, and RV215W Routers Management Interface Remote Command Execution and Denial of Service Vulnerabilities

Vulnerabilities in several Cisco Small Business routers could allow for an authenticated, remote attacker to execute arbitrary code or unexpected restart. Affected routers are listed below. This vulnerability has a CVSS Score of 7.2.

  * RV110W Wireless-N VPN Firewall
  * RV130 VPN Router
  * RV130W Wireless-N Multifunction VPN Router
  * RV215W Wireless-N VPN Router



 **CVEs**

  * CVE-2021-1159
  * CVE-2021-1160
  * CVE-2021-1161



 **Source**

<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-rv-overflow-WUnUgv4U>

## Cisco Small Business RV110W, RV130, RV130W, and RV215W Routers Management Interface Command Injection Vulnerabilities

Vulnerabilities in several Cisco Small Business routers could allow for an authenticated, remote attacker to inject arbitrary commands which are executed with root privileges. Affected routers are listed below. This vulnerability has a CVSS Score of 7.2.

  * RV110W Wireless-N VPN Firewall
  * RV130 VPN Router
  * RV130W Wireless-N Multifunction VPN Router
  * RV215W Wireless-N VPN Router



 **CVEs**

  * CVE-2021-1146
  * CVE-2021-1147
  * CVE-2021-1148



 **Source**

<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-rv-command-inject-LBdQ2KRN>

## Cisco Connected Mobile Experiences Privilege Escalation Vulnerability

A vulnerability exists in Cisco's Connected Mobile Experience (CMX), which, if successfully executed, could allow a remote, authenticated attacker without administrator privileges to change the password of any user on a vulnerable system. Affected versions of the software are Cisco CMX releases 10.6.0, 10.6.1, and 10.6.2. This vulnerability has a CVSS Score of 8.8.

 **CVEs**

  * CVE-2021-1144



 **Source**

<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-cmxpe-75Asy9k>

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35719997/Cisco%20Security%20Advisories%20January%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1610568305626&api=v2)

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Brazil Under Revenge RAT Attacks
Uptycs provides their research data indicating that users in Brazil are currently under attack from a campaign that is spreading Revenge RAT.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Brazil Under Revenge RAT Attacks
Uptycs provides their research data indicating that users in Brazil are currently under attack from a campaign that is spreading Revenge RAT.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT



# Overview

Uptycs has observed a campaign in Brazil that is utilizing multiple weaponized documents spreading Revenge RAT. Once the victim opens the document, another weaponized document is downloaded that executes internal, malicious macros that pull a PowerShell script down from the command and control servers. This, in turn, pulls a fake MP3 file down and saves it as a VBS file. This VBS pulls down "opera.ps1" (Revenge RAT) and executes it. When Revenge RAT first runs, it generates a unique ID for the victim, gathers information on the system, and sends the information back to its command and control server. It then begins waiting on commands to be executed. Capabilities include screen, key, video, audio capture, and credential dumping. For more details, check out the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35719111/Brazil%20Under%20Revenge%20RAT%20Attacks%20IoCs.txt?version=2&modificationDate=1609341135891&api=v2)



# Protection

## Yara Rule

  * A Yara rule for protection can be found here: [ Yara.txt](/download/attachments/35719111/Brazil%20Under%20Revenge%20RAT%20Attacks%20Yara.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1609340785624&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.uptycs.com/blog/revenge-rat-targeting-users-in-south-america>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Iranian Government-Sponsored APT Actor Exploiting Vulnerabilities
A joint alert (AA21-321A) from the United State's FBI and CISA, Australia's Cyber Security Centre (ACSC), and the United Kingdom’s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) has been published. The alert warns of ongoing attacks from an Iranian government-linked APT actor.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Other
  *  **Targets:** Vulnerable Fortinet devices and Microsoft Exchange servers.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Mimikatz, WinPEAS, SharpWMI, and possibly other malware.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fortinet vulnerabilities CVE-2018-13379, CVE-2019-5591, and CVE-2020-12812. Microsoft Exchange ProyShell vulnerability CVE-2021-34473.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration, Extortion, Ransomware.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A joint alert (AA21-321A) from Australia's Cyber Security Centre (ACSC), the United Kingdom’s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC), and the United State's FBI and CISA has been published. The alert warns of ongoing attacks from an Iranian government-sponsored APT actor that has a history of exploiting vulnerabilities in Fortinet devices ( CVE-2018-13379, CVE-2019-5591, and CVE-2020-12812) and a Microsoft Exchange server ProxyShell vulnerability (CVE-2021-34473). The alert notes that the actor is focused on exploiting vulnerable systems rather than targeting specific entities. To date, the actor has exploited systems in multiple U.S. and Australian critical infrastructure sectors. Post compromise activities conducted by the actor can include data exfiltration, extortion, or ransomware. Most recently, the actor has been exploiting the ProxyShell vulnerabilities to gain a foothold in systems for use in later operations. Further details, including CISA's list of mitigations, are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222695/Iranian%20Government-Sponsored%20APT%20Actor%20Exploiting%20Vulnerabilities%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637207733297&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa21-321a>
  * <https://www.cyber.gov.au/acsc/view-all-content/alerts/iranian-government-sponsored-apt-cyber-actors>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.001 - Malware  
T1588.002 - Tool  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1098 - Account Manipulation  
T1136 - Create Account  
T1136.001 - Local Account  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.005 - Security Support Provider  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1134 - Access Token Manipulation  
T1134.005 - SID-History Injection  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1207 - Rogue Domain Controller  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1003.001 - LSASS Memory  
T1003.002 - Security Account Manager  
T1003.004 - LSA Secrets  
T1003.006 - DCSync  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1552.004 - Private Keys  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
T1555.004 - Windows Credential Manager  
T1558 - Steal or Forge Kerberos Tickets  
T1558.001 - Golden Ticket  
T1558.002 - Silver Ticket  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1550 - Use Alternate Authentication Material  
T1550.002 - Pass the Hash  
T1550.003 - Pass the Ticket  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1560 - Archive Collected Data  
T1560.001 - Archive via Utility  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol  
T1048.001 - Exfiltration Over Symmetric Encrypted Non-C2 Protocol  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: AvosLocker Ransomware Group
AvosLocker is a new ransomware group operating an affiliate program. A blog post from Cyble details the group and its payload.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware

  *  **Ransomware Family** : AvosLocker

  *  **RaaS Operation** : Affiliate program advertised on hacking forums

  *  **Initial Infection Vector** : Phishing email ([T1566](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/)), Malvertising ([T1189](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1189/))

  *  **Post-Compromise Actions** : Data Exfiltration, Data Encryption ([T1486](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1486/))

  *  **Additional TTPs** : Encrypted files appended with .avos

  *  **Leak Site** : hxxp://avosqxh72b5ia23dl5fgwcpndkctuzqvh2iefk5imp3pi5gfhel5klad.onion/




# Overview

Cyble has discovered a new ransomware group named AvosLocker, as detailed in their blog post. The group has advertised an affiliate program on clear web hacking forums in order to recruit distributors for the payload. They leverage a double extortion model, stealing and threatening to release data if the ransom for decryption is not paid. Victim data is published on a leak site operated by the group. A portal for negotiating and paying the ransom also exists. In terms of the AvosLocker payload, files are encrypted using a custom AES-256 algorithm and are appended with a .avos extension. Advertisements detail the ransomware's functionality including multi-threaded encryption, encryption of all drives and network shares, shadow copy deletion, and more. For more information, see the Cyble blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2021/07/15/avoslocker-under-the-lens-a-new-sophisticated-ransomware-group/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: BlackCat Ransomware
A report from Kaspersky provides an analysis of the BlackCat ransomware and notes the use of an exfiltration tool that was previously associated with the BlackMatter ransomware group.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Typically businesses.
  *  **Ransomware Family:** BlackCat
  *  **Additional Payloads:** Fendr (ExMatter), Mimikatz, PsExec.
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Yes
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified in the report.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration, File encryption.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

BlackCat is a Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) group that began advertising its services in December 2021 using the name ALPHV. According to a report from Kaspersky, one of the notable differences between BlackCat and other ransomware operators is that the BlackCat ransomware is written in the Rust language and provides variants for Linux and Windows. BlackCat uses the double extortion technique in their attacks and the tool used to exfiltrate data from a victim system is named Fendr, also known as ExMatter. This tool was previously associated with the BlackMatter ransomware group. Kaspersky notes that the modification and reuse of Fendr, and telemetry, suggests that some members of BlackCat are linked to the BlackMatter group. The version of the BlackCat ransomware analyzed by Kaspersky is a command-line application that accepts several arguments at runtime. Many of the operations it carries out, such as privilege escalation, deleting Windows shadow copies, and killing processes, are similar to other ransomware. For lateral movement, a compressed version of PsExec is used. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://securelist.com/a-bad-luck-blackcat/106254/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.002 - Tool  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation  
T1134 - Access Token Manipulation  
T1134.003 - Make and Impersonate Token  
T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism  
T1548.002 - Bypass User Account Control  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1087.001 - Local Account  
T1087.002 - Domain Account  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1489 - Service Stop  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1019:** Threat Intelligence Program - A threat intelligence program helps an organization generate their own threat intelligence information and track trends to inform defensive priorities to mitigate risk.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
BlackCat Ransomware
A report from Kaspersky provides an analysis of the BlackCat ransomware and notes the use of an exfiltration tool that was previously associated with the BlackMatter ransomware group.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Typically businesses.
  *  **Ransomware Family:** BlackCat
  *  **Additional Payloads:** Fendr (ExMatter), Mimikatz, PsExec.
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Yes
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified in the report.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration, File encryption.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

BlackCat is a Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) group that began advertising its services in December 2021 using the name ALPHV. According to a report from Kaspersky, one of the notable differences between BlackCat and other ransomware operators is that the BlackCat ransomware is written in the Rust language and provides variants for Linux and Windows. BlackCat uses the double extortion technique in their attacks and the tool used to exfiltrate data from a victim system is named Fendr, also known as ExMatter. This tool was previously associated with the BlackMatter ransomware group. Kaspersky notes that the modification and reuse of Fendr, and telemetry, suggests that some members of BlackCat are linked to the BlackMatter group. The version of the BlackCat ransomware analyzed by Kaspersky is a command-line application that accepts several arguments at runtime. Many of the operations it carries out, such as privilege escalation, deleting Windows shadow copies, and killing processes, are similar to other ransomware. For lateral movement, a compressed version of PsExec is used. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Unknown Threat Group Using Hades Ransomware
Hades ransomware has been in operation since at least December 2020. Accenture reports on their analysis of the ransomware, which is known to have attacked at least three victims, all large multi-national organizations.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Unknown Threat Group Using Hades Ransomware
Hades ransomware has been in operation since at least December 2020. Accenture reports on their analysis of the ransomware, which is known to have attacked at least three victims, all large multi-national organizations.

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Accenture has published their analysis of the Hades ransomware, which they identified as part of attacks against three multi-national organizations since December 2020. It is unknown whether this ransomware is operated by a single threat actor or distributed under an affiliate model. During incidents involving Hades, Accenture observed highly targeted, "hands on keyboard" activity. Initial access appears to have been obtained via public-facing systems via RDP or VPN with legitimate credentials. Once on the network, the threat actors used Cobalt Strike and Empire for persistence and lateral movement. As with many ransomware families, it deletes shadow copies, traverses local directories and network shares to identify files to be encrypted, encrypts files and adds an extension, and leaves a ransom note. The ransom note includes a unique URL for a TOR site to pay the ransom. Hades also leverages the double-extortion model, which involves exfiltrating sensitive files as a secondary method of extortion, threatening to release these files publicly if the victim does not pay the ransom. For more information, see the Accenture blog post in the Reference section.

Around the same time as Accenture's report, Awake Security published a report outlining their analysis of an incident response engagement that also involved the Hades ransomware. During their incident, they observed additional activity linked to the Hafnium group, but they are unsure whether that threat actor was using Hades or if multiple compromises occurred in the same environment. The details of this incident and their findings on the Hades ransomware can be found in the Awake Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.accenture.com/us-en/blogs/cyber-defense/unknown-threat-group-using-hades-ransomware>

  * <https://awakesecurity.com/blog/incident-response-hades-ransomware-gang-or-hafnium/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Xen Security Advisory XSA-370
A security advisory have been published for Xen. The vulnerability addressed in the advisories could potentially allow for an attacker to carry out a Spectre v2 attack against Xen.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information, including a mitigation strategy, is available from the link in the advisory summary below.

 **Xen Security Advisory CVE-2021-28689 / XSA-370**  
x86: Speculative vulnerabilities with bare (non-shim) 32-bit PV guests  
Impact: A malicious 32-bit guest kernel may be able to mount a Spectre v2 attack against Xen, despite the presence hardware protections being active. It therefore might be able to infer the contents of arbitrary host memory, including memory assigned to other guests.  
<https://xenbits.xen.org/xsa/advisory-370.html>

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-28689




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://xenbits.xen.org/xsa/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Hancitor Downloader Still Installing Cobalt Strike
The DFIR Report has published an analysis of an intrusion which demonstrated that the Hancitor downloader continues to install Cobalt Strike.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Hancitor Downloader Still Installing Cobalt Strike
The DFIR Report has published an analysis of an intrusion which demonstrated that the Hancitor downloader continues to install Cobalt Strike.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

The Hancitor downloader has been around since at least 2014 and is provided to threat actors through a Malware-as-a-Service operation. Over the years, Hancitor has been used to install a range of malware through either spam or phishing emails that had weaponized documents attached or links within the emails. Hancitor has, for some time, been installing Cobalt Strike to facilitate lateral movement and has become involved in ransomware attacks. The DFIR Report has published an analysis of a recent intrusion which demonstrated that the Hancitor downloader continues to install Cobalt Strike. Typically, the intrusion began with a malicious Word document which dropped the first stage Hancitor downloader DLL. The DLL was injected into multiple instances of svchost.exe which, in turn, injected a Cobalt Strike beacon into multiple instances of rundll32.exe. Attempts were made to download further malware, including Ficker Stealer, which is commonly installed by Hancitor. The attacker did manage to compromise another system on the network by using the SMB protocol to copy a batch script and DLL to the system. The batch file was then executed by a remote service and executed the Cobalt Strike shellcode embedded in the DLL. The attacker was discovered and evicted from the systems before their objective became clear. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://thedfirreport.com/2021/06/28/hancitor-continues-to-push-cobalt-strike/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: The Klingon RAT
The Klingon RAT is written in Go and exhibits very little code reuse. According to a report from Intezer, the operators of the RAT are financially motivated.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

is written in Go and exhibits very little code reuse. According to a report from Intezer, the operators of the RAT are financially motivated.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

 is written in Go and exhibits very little code reuse, which Intezer notes is uncommon in a RAT. Of note is an extensive list of anti-virus processes (in excess of 650) that Klingon will terminate if it finds them running. Persistence is achieved using multiple registry entries and a scheduled task. Multiple methods to bypass UAC are used to achieve privilege escalation. Communications with Klingon's C&C servers are encrypted using TLS. The RAT functionality includes the ability to start a SOCKS proxy, a reverse shell, or an RDP server, execute a binary file, and run PowerShell commands. No information on the methods used to distribute Klingon is provided in the report. The purpose of the malware is to obtain a victim's financial data which can then be used by the operators. The technical details are available from Intezer's report which is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/malware-analysis/klingon-rat-holding-on-for-dear-life/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Squirrelwaffle Loader Delivers Cobalt Strike
A report from Zscaler ThreatLabz provides an analysis of a malspam campaign and a new loader named Squirrelwaffle that is being used to deliver Cobalt Strike.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Squirrelwaffle Loader Delivers Cobalt Strike
A report from Zscaler ThreatLabz provides an analysis of a malspam campaign and a new loader named Squirrelwaffle that is being used to deliver Cobalt Strike.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Squirrelwaffle loader, Cobalt Strike (S0154)
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious documents delivered via Malspam campaign.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions: Unspecified**
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A malspam campaign that has been running since mid-September is distributing a new loader named Squirrelwaffle, according to a report from Zscaler ThreatLabz. The payload delivered by Squirrelwaffle is Cobalt Strike. The infrastructure used to host Squirrelwaffle is known to have been used to distribute the Qakbot banking Trojan. The malspam is using an email thread hijacking technique that has been used in the distribution of Emotet and Qakbot. The spam emails contain a link that leads to an archive file that contains a malicious Word or Excel file. Macros in the documents either drop a VBS file used to download the Squirrelwaffle DLL or download the DLL directly. The DLL is executed by either rundll32.exe or regsvr.exe. Once executed Squirrelwaffle begins communicating with its C&C server and downloads a Cobalt Strike stager that in turn delivers a Cobalt Strike beacon. ThreatLabz notes that while Squirrelwaffle employs techniques similar to previous Emotet campaigns, it is unclear whether a known threat actor or a new group, has developed and is distributing Squirrelwaffle. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129072/Squirrelwaffle%20Loader%20Delivers%20Cobalt%20Strike%20IoCs.txt?version=2&modificationDate=1632981297383&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/squirrelwaffle-new-loader-delivering-cobalt-strike>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1592 - Gather Victim Host Information  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Squirrelwaffle Loader Delivers Cobalt Strike
A report from Zscaler ThreatLabz provides an analysis of a malspam campaign and a new loader named Squirrelwaffle that is being used to deliver Cobalt Strike.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Squirrelwaffle loader, Cobalt Strike (S0154)
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious documents delivered via Malspam campaign.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions: Unspecified**
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A malspam campaign that has been running since mid-September is distributing a new loader named Squirrelwaffle, according to a report from Zscaler ThreatLabz. The payload delivered by Squirrelwaffle is Cobalt Strike. The infrastructure used to host Squirrelwaffle is known to have been used to distribute the Qakbot banking Trojan. The malspam is using an email thread hijacking technique that has been used in the distribution of Emotet and Qakbot. The spam emails contain a link that leads to an archive file that contains a malicious Word or Excel file. Macros in the documents either drop a VBS file used to download the Squirrelwaffle DLL or download the DLL directly. The DLL is executed by either rundll32.exe or regsvr.exe. Once executed Squirrelwaffle begins communicating with its C&C server and downloads a Cobalt Strike stager that in turn delivers a Cobalt Strike beacon. ThreatLabz notes that while Squirrelwaffle employs techniques similar to previous Emotet campaigns, it is unclear whether a known threat actor or a new group, has developed and is distributing Squirrelwaffle. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129072/Squirrelwaffle%20Loader%20Delivers%20Cobalt%20Strike%20IoCs.txt?version=2&modificationDate=1632981297383&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/squirrelwaffle-new-loader-delivering-cobalt-strike>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Department of Veterans Affairs Breach
Breach/Leak Notification: A breach of a Financial Services Center online application has been disclosed by the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs Office of Management. The personal information of some 46,000 veterans may be have been exposed in the breach.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

  
"The Financial Services Center (FSC) determined one of its online applications was accessed by unauthorized users to divert payments to community health care providers for the medical treatment of Veterans. The FSC took the application offline and reported the breach to VA’s Privacy Office. A preliminary review indicates these unauthorized users gained access to the application to change financial information and divert payments from VA by using social engineering techniques and exploiting authentication protocols. To prevent any future improper access to and modification of information, system access will not be re-enabled until a comprehensive security review is completed by the VA Office of Information Technology."

# Reference

  * <https://www.va.gov/opa/pressrel/pressrelease.cfm?id=5519>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New Dridex Variant Delivered Via Phishing Emails
FortiGuard Labs has published a report that provides an analysis of a new variant of Dridex being delivered via phishing emails.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Dridex Variant Delivered Via Phishing Emails
FortiGuard Labs has published a report that provides an analysis of a new variant of Dridex being delivered via phishing emails.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Banking Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Dridex
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Excel file attached to a phishing email.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, Data Exfiltration
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A new variant of Dridex has been discovered by FortiGuard Labs. The new variant is delivered using phishing emails with a malicious Excel file attached. The sample email shown in the FortiGuard report purports to be about updated US Import Tariffs. If the recipient opens the attached Excel file, and macros are enabled, data from certain cells in the Excel sheet are written to a local file. This file is an .hta file. The Excel file contains both an auto-run VBA macro and an Excel 4.0 Macro. The macros call mshta.exe to execute the .hta file which downloads the actual Dridex payload and using wmic.exe creates a new Rundll32 process which loads the Dridex payload. The anti-analysis techniques and C&C communications protocols are similar to prior variants of Dridex. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127542/New%20Dridex%20Variant%20Delivered%20Via%20Phishing%20Emails%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1631510252409&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/new-dridex-variant-being-spread-by-crafted-excel-document>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1185 - Man in the Browser  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1090 - Proxy  
T1219 - Remote Access Software  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography  
T1573.002 - Asymmetric Cryptography

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Gallium Expands Targeting With New PingPull Tool
Palo Alto's Unit 42 has analyzed a new remote access Trojan named PingPull that is being utilized by a possibly state-sponsored APT group named Gallium.
output:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Malware, Espionage
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Gallium, aka Softcell
* **Associated Payloads:** PingPull RAT
* **Targets:** Organizations in the government, finance, and telecommunications sectors located in Africa, Europe, and Southeast Asia.
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and exfiltration of information
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Gallium is a threat group that has been targeting organizations in Africa, Europe, and Southeast Asia. Gallium has historically targeted the telecommunications sector but has expanded its targeting to include the finance and government sectors. According to a report from Palo Alto's Unit42, Gallium is likely to be a Chinese state-sponsored group. The new PingPull RAT used by Gallium comes in three main variants, each of which uses one of three protocols, HTTP(S), ICMP, or raw TCP, for C&C communications. The use of ICMP helps PingPull helps hide its connections to C2 servers as few organizations monitor ICMP traffic. PingPull malware is coded in C++ and gives the threat actor the ability to execute commands and access a reverse shell on compromised hosts. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* [https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/pingpull-gallium/](https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/pingpull-gallium/ "Follow link")

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Resource Development - TA0042**  
 T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
   T1583.004 - Server  
 T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
   T1588.002 - Tool  

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1078 - Valid Accounts  
 T1133 - External Remote Services  
 T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
 T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
   T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
   T1059.001 - PowerShell  
   T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1078 - Valid Accounts  
 T1136 - Create Account  
   T1136.002 - Domain Account  
 T1505 - Server Software Component  
   T1505.003 - Web Shell  
 T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
   T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
   T1027.002 - Software Packing  
   T1027.005 - Indicator Removal from Tools  
 T1036 - Masquerading  
   T1036.003 - Rename System Utilities  
 T1550 - Use Alternate Authentication Material  
   T1550.002 - Pass the Hash  
 T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
   T1553.002 - Code Signing  

**Credential Access - TA0006**  
 T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
   T1003.001 - LSASS Memory  
   T1003.002 - Security Account Manager  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
 T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
 T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
 T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  

**Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
 T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer  

**Collection - TA0009**  
 T1005 - Data from Local System  
 T1074 - Data Staged  
   T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
 T1560 - Archive Collected Data  
   T1560.001 - Archive via Utility  

**Exfiltration - TA0010**  
 T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
   T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
 T1090 - Proxy  
   T1090.002 - External Proxy  
 T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
 T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
   T1573.002 - Asymmetric Cryptography  

**Mitigations:**

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1015:**  Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
**M1016:**  Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1020:**  SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1025:**  Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1027:**  Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1030:**  Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1032:**  Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1035:**  Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1041:**  Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1043:**  Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
**M1044:**  Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1046:**  Boot Integrity - Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1048:**  Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1050:**  Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1052:**  User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.
