instruction:
I have encountered the following information: WhatsApp Pink Auto-Reply Worm
Earlier this year, researchers identified a worm spreading via WhatsApp messages on Android devices. ESET has discovered a new variant of this malware increasing its target applications.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Worm




# Overview

ESET published a blog post analyzing a new variant of an Android worm previously reported on. In this case, the messages circulating the malware claim that the provided link is to download a new color theme for WhatsApp, specifically via an application called "WhatsApp Pink." Visiting the link leads to the download and installation of the malicious payload. The user is requested to allow access to notifications, but as soon as they open the application it hides itself and claims it was never installed. From this point on, any time a user receives a message and replies to it, the recipient will also receive a link to download this same malware. Unlike previous versions of the worm, the auto-replies are sent not just via WhatsApp but also via WhatsApp Business, Signal, Skype, Viber, and Telegram. At this time the worm has no further capabilities outside its spreading mechanism. For more information, see the ESET blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in messages.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/04/20/whatsapp-pink-watch-out-fake-update/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Android Security Bulletin - January 4th, 2021
Android published a security bulletin regarding vulnerabilities in their operating system and its components.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Android Security Bulletin - January 4th, 2021
Android published a security bulletin regarding vulnerabilities in their operating system and its components.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 In total they disclosed 41 vulnerabilities including remote code execution, privilege escalation, information disclosure, and denial of service issues. Four of the vulnerabilities were rated as "Critical" severity, thirty-six as "High" severity, and one as "Moderate" severity. The most severe potential impact is arbitrary code execution by a remote attacker. Along with those in the Android software itself, vulnerabilities in its components, such as MediaTek and Qualcomm, are also addressed in this advisory. Patches have been released to fix these issues. We recommend reviewing the advisories in the Reference section for patches and mitigation advice.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35719477/Android%20Security%20Bulletin%20-%20January%204th%2C%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1609966411374&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://source.android.com/security/bulletin/2021-01-01>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: HMRC Phishing Scam Abuses Mail Service
A security researcher named TheAnalyst discovered and shared information about a continuous HMRC phishing campaign leveraging SendGrid’s features to support malicious attacks, according to BleepingComputer.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: HMRC Phishing Scam Abuses Mail Service
A security researcher named TheAnalyst discovered and shared information about a continuous HMRC phishing campaign leveraging SendGrid’s features to support malicious attacks, according to BleepingComputer.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Threat actors continue to abuse and exploit the legitimate email delivery service SendGrid to collect sensitive credentials. By utilizing some of SendGrid’s features, threat actors are able to bypass spam filters and email security products. The malicious webpages in a specific campaign analyzed by BleepingComputer mimic the HMRC and GOV.UK appearance, requesting information such as: UTR number, NINo number, passport number and expiry dates, driving license number, name, DOB and, address information. According to the information BleepingComputer received, what made this campaign so successful was the spoofed “From email” field with an outgoing address likely designed to trick the victim. For more information, see the BleepingComputer article in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/hmrc-phishing-scam-abuses-mail-service-to-bypass-spam-filters/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Chinese Threat Group Using Security Software To Load Malware
Sentinel Labs has been tracking a Chinese threat group named 'Moshen Dragon'. They have observed this group attempting to use antivirus software to sideload malicious DLLs. Details of these attempts have been published in an article.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Espionage
  *  **Targets:** Central Asia
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** PlugX, ShadowPad
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Sentinel Labs has observed a threat group known as 'Moshen Dragon' utilizing a trial-and-error process to sideload malicious DLLs. The group is operating in Central Asia and primarily operates as a cyberespionage group. The group attempted to use search-order hijacking to get security software to execute a malicious DLL rather than a legitimate one. This DLL would decrypt a malicious encrypted payload stored in the same folder. The researchers observed the actors attempting to exploit five different security products, showing that they were persistent when the technique did not work the first time, and were not put off by detections from security software. The payloads were variants of ShadowPad and PlugX malware. Once a foothold was established, the threat actors moved laterally using Impacket and installed a backdoor which was used to harvest credentials and exfiltrate data. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/moshen-dragons-triad-and-error-approach-abusing-security-software-to-sideload-plugx-and-shadowpad/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1574.001 - DLL Search Order Hijacking  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1574.001 - DLL Search Order Hijacking  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

Sentinel Labs has observed a threat group known as 'Moshen Dragon' utilizing a trial-and-error process to sideload malicious DLLs. The group is operating in Central Asia and primarily operates as a cyberespionage group. The group attempted to use search-order hijacking to get security software to execute a malicious DLL rather than a legitimate one. This DLL would decrypt a malicious encrypted payload stored in the same folder. The researchers observed the actors attempting to exploit five different security products, showing that they were persistent when the technique did not work the first time, and were not put off by detections from security software. The payloads were variants of ShadowPad and PlugX malware. Once a foothold was established, the threat actors moved laterally using Impacket and installed a backdoor which was used to harvest credentials and exfiltrate data. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/moshen-dragons-triad-and-error-approach-abusing-security-software-to-sideload-plugx-and-shadowpad/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1574.001 - DLL Search Order Hijacking  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1574.001 - DLL Search Order Hijacking  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Fake PoC Exploit Delivers Cobalt Strike Beacon
A report from Cyble provides an analysis of fake Proof-of-Concept exploits that deliver Cobal Strike beacons and may be part of a campaign targeting the Infosec community.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Fake PoC Exploit Delivers Cobalt Strike Beacon
A report from Cyble provides an analysis of fake Proof-of-Concept exploits that deliver Cobal Strike beacons and may be part of a campaign targeting the Infosec community.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Possibly the Infosec community.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Cobalt Strike
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake PoC exploit.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unspecified
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below



# Overview

Fake Proof-of-Concept exploits that have been available on Github may be part of a campaign that is targeting the Infosec community, according to a report from Cyble. The two PoCs mentioned in Cyble's report were both available from the same Github account. When executed, the fake PoCs deliver fake messages while in the background, PowerShell is used to deploy the payload, a Cobalt Strike Beacon. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2022/05/20/malware-campaign-targets-infosec-community-threat-actor-uses-fake-proof-of-concept-to-deliver-cobalt-strike-beacon/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: APT10 Uses Sophisticated Multi-Layered Loader in A41APT Campaign
The Kaspersky Global Research and Analysis Team (GReAT) has discovered the use of a sophisticated multi-layered loader within what's known as the A41APT campaign. They've named the loader malware, Ecipekac, based on the unique string found in the second layer of the loader. Kaspersky has high confidence that the APT10 group is behind the A41APT campaign.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT, RAT




# Overview

Since March 2019, Kaspersky observed an APT campaign targeting multiple industries, including the Japanese manufacturing industry and its overseas operations, that was designed to steal information. This campaign was named the A41APT campaign which is derived from the host name “DESKTOP-A41UVJV” from the attacker’s system used in the initial infection. APT10, which is also known as Red Apollo, POTASSIUM, MenuPass, CVNX, ChessMaster, Hogfish, Cicada, Snake Wine, and Stone Panda. IBM X-Force tracks the group as ITG01. The group has traditionally targeted organizations linked to Japan, and MSPs. In January 2021, Kaspersky discovered new activity from A41APT that utilized modified and updated payloads. These include a sophisticated multi-layered loader they have named "Ecipekac". There are four layers of loaders, and they observed three types of final payload. The payloads seen have been FYAnti loader for QuasarRAT, SodaMaster, and P8RAT. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/apt10-sophisticated-multi-layered-loader-ecipekac-discovered-in-a41apt-campaign/101519/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Adobe December Bulletins and Advisories
Adobe has issued three bulletins and a prenotification. The bulletins are for Adobe Prelude, Adobe Experience Manager, and Adobe Lightroom. The prenotification is for Adobe Acrobat and Reader.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

Adobe has issued three bulletins representing updates for Adobe Prelude, Adobe Experience Manager, and Adobe Lightroom. A prenotification for Adobe Acrobat and Reader was released indicating Adobe's intention of an upcoming update during the week of December 7. Issues corrected arbitrary code execution, arbitrary JavaScript execution, and sensitive information disclosure. We recommend reviewing each bulletin for affected versions and applying the updates to your installed base.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35717862/Adobe%20December%20Bulletins%20and%20Advisories%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1607454474035&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/prelude/apsb20-70.html>
  * <https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/experience-manager/apsb20-72.html>
  * <https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/lightroom/apsb20-74.html>
  * <https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/acrobat/apsb20-75.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Operation StealthyTrident
Operation StealthyTrident is the name given by ESET to a long running campaign that has been targeting agencies of the Mongolian government. The campaign delivered malware through a compromised software company.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

is the name given by ESET to a long running campaign that has been targeting agencies of the Mongolian government. The campaign delivered malware through a compromised software company.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Campaign, APT




# Overview

A messaging application named Able Desktop was, according to a report from ESET, used to deliver malware to victims. Able Desktop is widely used by Mongolian government agencies. Beginning around December in 2017, Trojanized installers were used to deliver the malware. The report further notes that Able's update system was probably compromised and also used to deliver malware. The malware included a backdoor named HyperBro and two RATs, Korplug (PlugX) and Tmanger. ESET named the campaign . In the early stages of the campaign, HyperBro was the installed malware, but in July 2020 the compromised update system began delivering Tmanger. The Trojanized installers were used to deliver HyperBro or Korplug. The group known as LuckyMouse appear to be behind the campaign. LuckyMouse is a Chinese threat group and is also known by several other names including APT27, Bronze Union, Emissary Panda, Hippo, Iodine, Iron Tiger, and TG-3390. IBM X-Force tracks LuckyMouse as Hive0006. ESET also discovered relationships between LuckyMouse and TA428 due to one of the Tmanger C&C server addresses also being used by the ShadowPad backdoor. Further information about the campaign and the malware involved can be found in ESET's report which is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2020/12/10/luckymouse-ta428-compromise-able-desktop/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Threat Actor Group Cloud Atlas Tracked by DomainTools Researchers
Researchers from DomainTools continue to see an APT group known as Cloud Atlas (also known as Inception) run campaigns which primarily focus on targeting countries formerly part of the Soviet Union with an emphasis on energy and political themes.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing, Data Theft, Trojan




# Overview

Researchers from DomainTools were able to identify new infrastructure used by Cloud Atlas, an APT, also known as Inception. A pattern of infrastructure creation used by Cloud Atlas shows that they have a reliance on European hosting providers such as Hostkey and OVH. The domains use consistent naming themes that include terms such as "office," update," or "ms," which are likely designed to spoof Microsoft-related items. When researchers discovered documents associated with the discovered infrastructure, they were further convinced of linking it to Cloud Atlas by the appearance of the same long numerical template string across the documents as they have previously used. The documents are Microsoft word documents, likely deployed as attachments in emails, and execute code that attempt to download additional payload files that are later called upon by powershell or vbscript. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.domaintools.com/resources/blog/the-continuous-conundrum-of-cloud-atlas>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: CISA Alert on Kimsuky APT
The Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has issued an alert on a North Korean Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) named Kimsuky.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: CISA Alert on Kimsuky APT
The Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has issued an alert on a North Korean Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) named Kimsuky.

# Threat Type

  * APT




# Overview

CISA, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and the U.S. Cyber Command Cyber National Mission Force (CNMF) have issued a joint report on a North Korean APT named Kimsuky. The group has most likely been active since 2012 with the primary mission being global intelligence gathering. Using social engineering, spearphishing, and watering holes, the group attempts to exfiltrate information from victims. Initial access is most likely to be through spearphishing attacks on hosts or networks. According to the alert, the target set includes South Korea, Japan, and the United States with the primary focus being foreign policy, national security as it relates to the Korean Peninsula, nuclear policy, and sanctions. The specific targets named within the alert are experts in various fields, think tanks, and South Korean government entities. The group uses the BabyShark malware delivered via links or attachments within emails and PowerShell or Command shell in order to execute their mission. The group has demonstrated persistence using malicious browser extensions, modification of system processes, autostart functions, and changing default file association. The group also employs privilege escalation, defensive evasion, credential access, and myriad other techniques, the details of which can be found in the alert located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa20-301a>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Lightning Stealer Targets Over 30 Browsers
Cyble Research Labs have written an analysis of a new infostealer malware. Named Lightning Stealer, this malware targets over 30 browsers to steal crypto wallets, telegram data, and discord tokens.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Infostealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Lightning Stealer
  *  **Targets:** Windows Users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Cyble Labs has discovered a new infostealer malware called Lightning Stealer. It is not said how the malware initially gets onto a victim machine, but the stealing process is well documented. The malware first hunts for any Firefox-based browsers and attempts to steal credentials and user data. Once the malware has done this, it moves onto any Chromium-based browsers, again looking for sensitive data. In both cases, it will attempt to steal cookies, credentials, and credit card payment data. It also will steal crypto wallets present in the victim system. The malware also appears to go after Telegram, Discord, and Steam user data. All the stolen data is converted into JSON strings and written to a txt file on the victim machine, before being exfiltrated to a hardcoded domain.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2022/04/05/inside-lightning-stealer/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1528 - Steal Application Access Token  
T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

Lightning Stealer Targets Over 30 Browsers
Cyble Research Labs have written an analysis of a new infostealer malware. Named Lightning Stealer, this malware targets over 30 browsers to steal crypto wallets, telegram data, and discord tokens.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Salfram Crypter Campaigns
Several email campaigns have been observed by Cisco Talos, all sharing one commonality: the use of a crypter, dubbed Salfram, on the first stage payloads.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Cisco Talos reports on a series of email campaigns distributing various malware families, all encrypted with the same crypter, named Salfram. The initial emails in each campaign are sent via business' website contact forms, increasing the chance it will be opened by the recipient. The content of the message claims that there are images hosted on the website that violate copyright and request the recipient review a document hosted at a provided link for more information. To send the form submissions, the operators leveraged proxy servers and automated scripting to generate and submit the lure. With regard to the links in the emails, most point to a document hosted on Google Drive. The document is a macro-emedded file that, if downloaded and executed, will begin infecting the system. Some infection chains led to the installation of various payloads, while others only delivered a single malicious payload. Regardless of the full infection chain and malware family in use, the initial payload leveraged the Salfram crypter to obfuscate its content. The crypter seems to have evolved over the course of the campaigns. Some differences include the actual code used for similar function calls. However, many similarities can be seen, such as the use of a large number of jumps and fake API calls. Ultimately, the payload is unpacked and run on the system. The researchers note that the crypter is quite advanced outside its inclusion of a string in the DOS stub that is highly trackable. For more information, see the Talos blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2020/09/salfram-robbing-place-without-removing.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Steam Phishing Campaign using Free Discord Nitro Lure
The promise of free Discord Nitro subscriptions has been used in phishing campaigns before in an attempt to steal Discord credentials. More recently, Malwarebytes has observed the same lure being used in a campaign targeting Steam credentials.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Discord users
  *  **Lure:** Free Discord Nitro subscription
  *  **Payload:** Phishing link via Discord
  *  **Compromised Data:** Steam credentials



# Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post analyzing yet another phishing campaign promising free Discord Nitro subscriptions as a lure. Similar to previous campaigns, the phishing link is distributed via direct messages within Discord. The message claims that the recipient can receive free Discord Nitro (premium) for a month by following the link. Unlike a previous campaign using this lure, instead of prompting users for their Discord credentials, the threat actor is targeting Steam credentials. A fake pop up window appears on the free Discord Nitro scam site and mimics the legitimate Steam login page. If credentials are entered, the victim is presented with an invalid login error while the data is exfiltrated to the attacker via a POST request to the same server. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68618202/Steam%20Phishing%20Campaign%20using%20Free%20Discord%20Nitro%20Lure%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635963461418&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/malwarebytes-news/2021/11/this-steam-phish-baits-you-with-free-discord-nitro/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Qakbot Upgrade and Activity
According to SANS ISC, a security researcher from malware-traffic-analysis.net conducted a sample Qakbot/Qbot malware infection in order to observe new behaviors. The researcher provided a full report on his findings.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

During a short, sample infection test, security researcher Brad Duncan was able to capture interesting information about new behaviors in the Qakbot malware. It appears, according to his research, the malware underwent a version update. During his research, malspam was observed in December 2020 with fake replies to email chains. In some of his examples, he found these may have been Qakbot generated replies for unsolicited spam. In the email, a ZIP archive with an Excel macro-enabled spreadsheet was discovered. The macros were intended to infect vulnerable Windows hosts with the malware. The templates used were the same used in previous campaigns. The infection took place using a Qakbot-typical HTTP GET request. The request searched for a URL with a .jpg file. The file was actually a DLL disguised as a Windows binary. During Wireshark analysis, Duncan observed web traffic with a destination of wellsfargo.com. This traffic was not generated with a web browser, as none had been opened. The user-agent string indicated the traffic my have been caused by Google Chrome. There was also web traffic attributed to Firefox. The belief is this traffic was related to a Qakbot module, though no modules were found on the "infected" machine. Some notable changes for this version included the Qakbot binary was changed from EXE to DLL, the malware creates other Windows Registry updates, and the directory for Qakbot artifacts has fewer files than previously seen. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://isc.sans.edu/forums/diary/Recent+Qakbot+Qbot+activity/26862/>

  * <https://twitter.com/lazyactivist192/status/1332363179729575938>
  * <https://twitter.com/_alex_il_/status/1333737189990158337>
  * <https://twitter.com/0verfl0w_/status/1331598884431421441>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Recent Zoom-Themed Phish
Cofense reports on yet another Zoom-themed phishing campaign using the video conferencing software as a ruse to steal Microsoft credentials.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense has published a blog post detailing the most recent in an extensive list of Zoom-themed phishing campaigns. This one uses a highly customized email to create a sense of legitimacy. The sender is spoofed to match the company domain, and mentions of both the recipient's first and last name and the company name are found throughout the email. Recipients are requested to click a link in order to see more details regarding the supposed meeting invite. The final destination of the link is hidden behind a MailChimp redirector URL. The landing page is a fake Microsoft login page hosted on a compromised WordPress site. Submitting credentials will ultimately result in their exfiltration to the attacker. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/zoom-themed-phish-in-use>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: UltimaSMS Scam Campaign
A large premium SMS scam campaign, dubbed "UltimaSMS," is being carried out via the Google Play Store. Avast reports on the fake applications and their functionality in a recent blog post.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** SMS Subscription Scam
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unknown
  *  **Associated** **Campaign** : UltimaSMS
  *  **Targets:** Android users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake apps in Google Play Store
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Premium SMS subscription enrollment



# Overview

Avast published a blog post analyzing a premium SMS scam campaign, dubbed "UltimaSMS," that has been active since at least May 2021. Google Play Store links to fake copies of legitimate applications are being shared via TikTok and Instagram. The types of applications vary and include custom keyboards, photo editors, games, and more. Once on the system, the fake app gathers system information to determine the location of the victim, which will determine the language and area code that should be used. Upon opening the app, users are presented with a location-specific prompt requesting a phone number. Entering this information results in the user being enrolled in monthly premium SMS services, with the charge maxed out to the limit of the country they are located in. The app either attempts to enroll them in further subscriptions or becomes non-functional. For more information, see the Avast blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616701/UltimaSMS%20Scam%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635257639416&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Install security updates (M1001).
  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).
  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blog.avast.com/premium-sms-scam-apps-on-play-store-avast>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**

T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application

T1475 - Deliver Malicious App via Authorized App Store

 **Execution - TA0041**

T1204.002 – User Execution: Malicious File

 **Discovery - TA0032**

T1422 – System Network Configuration Discovery

 **Impact - TA0034**

T1448 – Carrier Billing Fraud

UltimaSMS Scam Campaign
A large premium SMS scam campaign, dubbed "UltimaSMS," is being carried out via the Google Play Store. Avast reports on the fake applications and their functionality in a recent blog post.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** SMS Subscription Scam
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unknown
  *  **Associated** **Campaign** : UltimaSMS
  *  **Targets:** Android users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake apps in Google Play Store
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Premium SMS subscription enrollment



# Overview

Avast published a blog post analyzing a premium SMS scam campaign, dubbed "UltimaSMS," that has been active since at least May 2021. Google Play Store links to fake copies of legitimate applications are being shared via TikTok and Instagram. The types of applications vary and include custom keyboards, photo editors, games, and more. Once on the system, the fake app gathers system information to determine the location of the victim, which will determine the language and area code that should be used. Upon opening the app, users are presented with a location-specific prompt requesting a phone number. Entering this information results in the user being enrolled in monthly premium SMS services, with the charge maxed out to the limit of the country they are located in. The app either attempts to enroll them in further subscriptions or becomes non-functional. For more information, see the Avast blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616701/UltimaSMS%20Scam%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635257639416&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Install security updates (M1001).
  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).
  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blog.avast.com/premium-sms-scam-apps-on-play-store-avast>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**

T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application

T1475 - Deliver Malicious App via Authorized App Store

 **Execution - TA0041**

T1204.002 – User Execution: Malicious File

 **Discovery - TA0032**

T1422 – System Network Configuration Discovery

 **Impact - TA0034**

T1448 – Carrier Billing Fraud

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Anglicare Sydney - Ransomware Attack and Data Exfiltration
Breach / Leak Notification: The Sydney Anglican Diocese has reported a ransomware attack that affected Anglicare Sydney. Approximately 17GB of data was transmitted to a remote location during the attack.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Anglicare Sydney - Ransomware Attack and Data Exfiltration
Breach / Leak Notification: The Sydney Anglican Diocese has reported a ransomware attack that affected Anglicare Sydney. Approximately 17GB of data was transmitted to a remote location during the attack.

# Threat Type

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

  
"The cyber attack Anglicare Sydney has experienced is part of increased illegal cyber activity targeting the Australian health and aged care sectors alongside other sectors seeking to obtain funds via ransomware activity. Anglicare Sydney had an incident response plan in place for this type of scenario whereby we could remediate with off-site backup systems and would not entertain engaging with cyber criminals. Once the cyber attack was detected, Anglicare Sydney immediately embarked on remediation and investigation including the engagement of cyber security experts. A formal forensic investigation by third parties is still ongoing. At this stage, there is no current evidence that data has been stolen. We have identified 17GB of data transmission to a remote location and this forms part of the forensic investigation in progress. It is therefore premature to speculate on the impact."

# Reference

  * <https://www.anglicare.org.au/about-us/media-releases/statement-from-anglicare-sydney-19-september-2020/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Scans Targeting WordPress Themes That Use Epsilon Framework
A report from Wordfence's Threat Intelligence team notes a large number of scans looking for vulnerable versions of WordPress themes which use the Epsilon Framework.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability, Scans




# Overview

  
Scans targeting WordPress themes that use the Epsilon Framework have been reported by Wordfence. The report provides an estimation that the themes may be installed on more than 150,000 sites. The Wordfence Threat Intelligence team report that there have been greater than 7.5 million attacks targeting in excess of 1.5 million sites. It is important to note that Wordfence also mentions that the vast majority of these attacks are probing for vulnerable instances of the themes, rather than attempts to exploit the vulnerabilities. The probes are reported to have sourced from approximately 18,000 unique IP addresses. It appears that the vulnerabilities in question are those reported by NinTechNet at the beginning of October. The vulnerabilities could potentially allow an unauthenticated remote attacker to carry out function injections. Further information is available from the links in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * None Provided.




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.wordfence.com/blog/2020/11/large-scale-attacks-target-epsilon-framework-themes/>

  * <https://blog.nintechnet.com/unauthenticated-function-injection-vulnerability-fixed-in-15-wordpress-themes/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: El Salvador and Pegasus Spyware
A report has been published that is the result of an investigation by Citizen Lab and a number of collaborators that details attacks that infected the phones of journalists and members of civil society in El Salvador with NSO’s Pegasus spyware.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Journalists and members of civil society in El Salvador.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Pegasus
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** KISMET, and FORCEDENTRY.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A series of attacks that ran from July 2020 through to November 2021 targeted the phones of a number of journalists and members of civil society in El Salvador. The malware delivered in these attacks was the Pegasus spyware from NSO. Citizen Lab reports that the timing of the attacks coincided with media organizations reporting on sensitive issues related to the Salvadoran government. In total, thirty-seven devices were found to be infected. The report notes that at least two zero-click exploits, KISMET and FORCEDENTRY, were used as the infection vector and were delivered in messages which contain either an attachment or a one-click malicious link. Citizen Lab identified one actor they have named TOROGOZ whose activities strongly suggest that they are a Pegasus customer located in El Salvador. Further information can be found in the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057202/El%20Salvador%20and%20Pegasus%20Spyware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642643420711&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).

  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://citizenlab.ca/2022/01/project-torogoz-extensive-hacking-media-civil-society-el-salvador-pegasus-spyware/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1456 - Drive-by Compromise  
T1477 - Exploit via Radio Interfaces  
  
 **Persistence - TA0028**  
T1400 - Modify System Partition  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0029**  
T1404 - Exploit OS Vulnerability  
  
 **Discovery - TA0032**  
T1422 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1426 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0035**  
T1409 - Access Stored Application Data  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages  
T1429 - Capture Audio  
T1430 - Location Tracking  
T1432 - Access Contact List  
T1433 - Access Call Log  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0037**  
T1438 - Alternate Network Mediums

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Updated ReverseRat Seen in New Campaign and Drops NightFury
Black Lotus Labs, the security threat intelligence of Lumen Technologies, discovered an updated version of the remote access trojan they discovered in June 2021 they named ReverseRat. New capabilities include using the webcam to take a picture of the victim's environment and the ability to steal files from USB devices. While it recorded the IP address of the victim machine in the past, it has changed from using a third-party site to querying the network interface.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** RAT
  *  **Targets:** Government and Energy Sector Organizations in South and Central Asia
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing email with attached maldoc or malicious link, Initial Access (T1566.001, T1566.002), Execution (T1204.002), DLL Side-Loading, Privilege Escalation (T1574.002)
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** System Information Gathering, Discovery (T1082), Command and control via encrypted channel (T1573), Collection (T1005, T1025), Exfiltration (T1041)
  *  **Additional TTPs:**



# Overview

ReverseRat, first discovered in June 2021 by Black Lotus Labs, has now been enhanced by adding new capabilities as well as slightly changing some of it's methods behind the scenes. New features include making use of the webcam to take a picture of it's environment and also adding the ability to steal files from USB devices. This new version of ReverseRat uses a new version of the preBotHta loader file which drops a new agent called NightFury which is sideloaded with a legitimate Microsoft binary "charmap.exe". NightFury searches the computer for document files and sends them packaged up to a C2 host along with system information about the victim machine. Most targets from this campaign were in Afghanistan. A few targets were in Jordan, India, and Iran. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [UpdatedReverseRatSeeninNewCampaignandDropsNightFury-IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/59540969/UpdatedReverseRatSeeninNewCampaignandDropsNightFury-IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1629038713326&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blog.lumen.com/reverserat-reemerges-with-a-nightfury-new-campaign-and-new-developments-same-familiar-side-actor/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Bread - Android Billing Fraud Malware
A post on the Google Security blog from researchers in Google's Android Security & Privacy team looks at a malware family they refer to as "Bread". The malware is used for billing fraud.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Android, Billing Fraud




# Overview

Google's Android Security & Privacy team has published a report on an Android billing fraud malware family they call Bread, which is also known as Joker. The team has been tracking Bread since early 2017 and notably, Google Play Protect removed more than 1,700 Bread apps before they could be downloaded. The highest number of Bread apps that were uploaded to the Play store in a single day was 23. The researchers state that Bread has used "just about every cloaking and obfuscation technique under the sun" to avoid detection. The techniques include the use of custom encryption algorithms as well as AES, Blowfish, DES, XOR, and combinations of them, splitting of stings, the use of delimiters in strings, strings scattered throughout the code, and packing. Packers that have been used by Bread authors include AliProtect, Qihoo360, and SecShell. Bread also has the ability to solve basic captchas. Bread is used for billing fraud, which was initially carried out using SMS, but as Google's policies changed which restricted the SEND_SMS permissions, the Bread authors switched to using WAP billing. Further details are available from the blog post linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://security.googleblog.com/2020/01/pha-family-highlights-bread-and-friends.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Apache Struts 2 RCE Vulnerability
The Apache Software Foundation has published an advisory that addresses a vulnerability in Struts 2, which, in some cases, could allow for the remote execution of arbitrary code.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

An advisory from the Apache Software Foundation addresses a vulnerability in Struts 2 that could allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code. The vulnerability is caused by a failure to properly sanitize user-provided input in certain tags. The vulnerability can be exploited if forced Object-Graph Navigation Language (OGNL) evaluation using the %{...} syntax has been applied. A remote attacker could exploit the vulnerability by sending a maliciously crafted request to the application, potentially leading to arbitrary code execution. Versions of Strut 2 2.0.0 through 2.5.25 are affected. A workaround, and an update (version 2.5.26), have been published to address the vulnerability. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-17530




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/WW/S2-061#space-menu-link-content>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Ryuk Flips the Script in Five Hours
The threat actors behind Ryuk have updated tactics from phishing emails to a domain wide ransomware attack inside 5 hours. The DFIR Report posted an analysis and case summary regarding the sudden change in tactics.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, Phishing




# Overview

Using tools such as Cobalt Strike, AdFind, WMI, and PowerShell, the actors behind Ryuk took their actions from a phishing email to a full-blown, domain-wide ransomware attack in just 5 hours. Using Bazar as an entry point via phishing email, the actors were able to accomplish their mission faster than previously observed. As with previous attacks, once Bazar was downloaded, it began injecting into explorer.exe or svchost.exe and spawning command shells. The domain was then mapped using a lower-level privileged user with a slow and methodical approach. It was from this point the Zerologon vulnerability (CVE-2020-1472) was used to reset the password of the primary domain controller. Lateral movement was done via SMB file transfers and WMI executions of Cobalt Strike beaconing. More domain discovery was accomplished and privilege escalation was completed. Additional Cobalt Strike beacons were deployed, and further domain recon was performed using AdFind. At just 4 hours into the attack, the actors were able to pivot from the primary domain controller to RDP into the backup server. This was the target for the deployment of ransomware, followed by servers and, finally, workstations. Execution of the ransomware occurred on the primary domain controller and completed their attack at the 5 hour mark. Further details can be found within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://thedfirreport.com/2020/10/18/ryuk-in-5-hours/>

Execution of the ransomware occurred on the primary domain controller and completed their attack at the 5 hour mark. Further details can be found within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://thedfirreport.com/2020/10/18/ryuk-in-5-hours/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: STIBNITE ICS Threat Activity Group
STIBNITE is an ICS threat activity group identified by Dragos. It has targeted wind generation and government organizations in Azerbaijan.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT, Spear Phishing




# Overview

Dragos published a blog post providing details on a recently discovered threat activity group dubbed "STIBNITE." This group is responsible for multiple campaigns against the Azeri government and wind generation entities from late 2019 through 2020. Their initial access is gained through spoofed Azeri government sites designed for credential theft or through the use of malicious Microsoft Office documents attached to spear phishing emails. After access is obtained, the group delivers PoetRAT for post-exploitation activity, which allows for file exfiltration, taking screenshots, and command execution. Additionally, STIBNITE uses PypyKatz, a Python-based implementation of Mimikatz, and LaZagne for credential harvesting, which can allow for further lateral movement. They have also leveraged open-source web browser credential theft tools. Dragos notes that while the group has only focused on it infrastructure so far, the gathered data could allow for the compromise of OT infrastructure. For more information, see the Dragos blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.dragos.com/blog/industry-news/new-ics-threat-activity-group-stibnite/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Bulletproof Hosting Provider Planetary Reef
PhishLabs has published a paper on a threat actor group they have dubbed as "Planetary Reef" that appear to be setting themselves up as a bulletproof hosting provider.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing



# Overview

PhishLabs' report identifies a threat actor group, "Planetary Reef," that has leased IP addresses from a reseller and is setting themselves up as a bulletproof hosting site. A number of legitimate looking domains have been set up on these IPs to be used as phishing sites. To quickly set up phishing sites, Planetary Reef is using dynamic DNS services and domains registered through well-known registrars. As proof of the group's bulletproof hosting intentions, PhishLabs points out that the group allows their customers leniency in the types of illicit material their customers upload and distribute. They also provide hosting services to another group known for attacking large social media sites. Lastly, they have connections to other groups that are known for their phishing-for-hire services. For additional information, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

Tell me everything you know the following threat: Multiple GRUB2 Vulnerabilities Addressed
Multiple vulnerabilities in GRUB2 have been disclosed. Updates which address the vulnerabilities are available for the major Linux distributions.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Multiple vulnerabilities in GRUB2 that could allow for a bypassing of the UEFI Secure Boot restrictions have been disclosed. The most serious of the vulnerabilities could allow an attacker with physical access, or an authenticated remote attacker with administrative privileges, to potentially execute arbitrary code on an affected system. For most users, the updates which address the vulnerabilities will be provided by operating system vendor. For example, updates for the Debian, Red Hat, SuSE. and Ubuntu Linux distributions are already available. Further details are available from the links in the Reference section below.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Agrius Evolving Wiper to Functional Ransomware
A new threat group, tracked as Agrius by SentinelLabs, has been observed targeting Israel since 2020. SentinelLabs breaks down this group and how they are evolving to wiper activity disguised as ransomware.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

A new threat group, tracked by SentinelLabs as Agrius, has been observed targeting Israeli networks since at least 2020. Agrius started engaging in espionage activity but moved to wiper (Apostle) activity disguised as a ransomware attack. Using DEADWOOD (aka Detbosit), the wiper has unconfirmed links to an Iranian threat group. A new wiper is also deployed along with a custom .NET backdoor called 'IPsec Helper'. Intrusions by Agrius have shown Apostle to be a fully functioning ransomware. The group uses anonymizing VPNs to gain access to public-facing applications of its targets. Once on a targeted system, the group deploys webshell variations of ASPXSpy. The webshells are used to tunnel RDP traffic using compromised accounts for lateral movement. Publicly-available tools are used to harvest credentials as well. Custom malware called Apostle is deployed. This is a backdoor and wiper written in .NET and, to date, has only been seen used by Agrius. Additionally, DEADWOOD is deployed and has been linked, tentatively, to Iran. SentinelLabs assess with high confidence that, based on infrastructure, TTPs, the use of DEADWOOD, and other indicators, this activity is indeed Iranian-based activity. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/from-wiper-to-ransomware-the-evolution-of-agrius/>

  * <https://assets.sentinelone.com/sentinellabs/evol-agrius>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Harvester APT Targeting South Asia in Espionage Campaign
Harvester is a new nation-state actor observed by Symantec deploying a custom toolset in espionage campaigns in South Asia.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Harvester
  *  ** **Associated Payloads:**** Graphon, Cobalt Strike Beacon, Metasploit
  *  **Targets:** South Asian telecom, government, and IT organizations
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Espionage



# Overview

Symantec published a blog post analyzing a new threat actor, believed to be nation-state-backed, carrying out espionage campaigns in South Asia. The group is specifically targeting telecommunications, IT, and government organizations with a specific focus on Afghanistan. The initial infection vector is unknown but Symantec researchers identified the post-compromise infection chain. A custom downloader that leverages Microsoft Azure infrastructure for C2 communication with the ultimate purpose of installing the Graphon backdoor. This backdoor also abuses legitimate Microsoft Azure endpoints for C2 capabilities. It allows the attackers to execute Windows commands remotely. The threat group's toolset also includes a custom screenshot tool, a Cobalt Strike Beacon configured to use CloudFront infrastructure for C2, and Metasploit. Based on the toolset and observed activity, the group's motivation is espionage, and Symantec believes the group is a nation-state-backed, advanced persistent threat (APT). For more information, see the Symantec blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130475/Harvester%20APT%20Targeting%20South%20Asia%20in%20Espionage%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634561605124&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/harvester-new-apt-attacks-asia>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
T1560 - Archive Collected Data  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1102 - Web Service

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: VMware Security Advisory VMSA-2020-0021
VMware has released a security advisory, VMSA-2020-0021, identifying issues in VMware Horizon DaaS.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

VMware has released security advisory VMSA-2020-0021 that identifies a vulnerability (CVE-2020-3977) in VMware Horizon DaaS. Due to the way Horizon DaaS handled first-factor authentication it caused a broken authentication vulnerability. If successfully exploited, an attacker could potentially bypass two-factor authentication. This vulnerability does require that the attacker has a legitimate account on Horizon DaaS. For full details as to what versions are affected and patch availability, please see the link in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/30769750/VMware%20Security%20Advisory%20VMSA-2020-0021%20CVEs.txt?version=2&modificationDate=1600863900833&api=v2)

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2020-0021.html>
