instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Digital-Only Banks Targeted In New Phishing Campaign
Digital-only banks are becoming more prevalent, and with this, they are becoming targets for scams and fraud. This blog post on Bushido Token Threat Intel explores one campaign targeting a bank in the UK.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Digital-Only Banks Targeted In New Phishing Campaign
Digital-only banks are becoming more prevalent, and with this, they are becoming targets for scams and fraud. This blog post on Bushido Token Threat Intel explores one campaign targeting a bank in the UK.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Monzo Customers
  *  **Lure:** Monzo Login Page
  *  **Compromised Data:** Banking Credentials
  *  **Post-compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

Threat actors are targeting digital only banks as they are becoming more and more common. Bushido Token Threat Intel has published a blog post exploring one campaign targeting the online bank Monzo. The attack targets the mechanism by which a customer verifies their device for use with the bank - using a "golden link" which allows for the first login. The attack follows common phishing patterns, with the page copying Monzo's pages to get the users to enter their credentials and PIN. Along with the victim's name and phone number, the attacker will be able to access the compromised account. Upon exploration of the infrastructure behind the phishing site, the researcher discovered sites also targeting the bank Revolut. There was evidence that this attack was orchestrated by the threat actor "Cazanova", who offers phishing as a service. For more information, please see the link in the reference section

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058973/Digital-Only%20Banks%20Targeted%20In%20New%20Phishing%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645111572603&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Proactively reset accounts that are known to be part of breached credentials either immediately, or after detecting bruteforce attempts (M1018).



# References

  * <https://blog.bushidotoken.net/2022/02/mobile-banking-phishing-campaign.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.002 - GUI Input Capture

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Mirai Variant Exploiting Realtek SDK Vulnerability
A posting on the SAM blog reports that a Mirai variant is exploiting a recently disclosed vulnerability in the Realtek SDK that is used in devices from more than sixty-five vendors.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Botnet
  *  **Targets:** Mainly domestic devices such as routers
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Mirai
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Vulnerability in the device web interface
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See Mitre ATT&CK Framework below



# Overview

According to SAM, within two days of vulnerabilities in a Realtek SDK being disclosed, an attacker had created a Mirai variant that exploited one of the vulnerabilities. The vulnerability (CVE-2021-35395) can be exploited, without authentication, through the web interface of an affected device. Successfully exploited, an attacker can execute arbitrary code with the highest level of privilege. The SAM report notes that two weeks prior, the same attacker weaponised another vulnerability (CVE-2021-20090) within two days of disclosure. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/62358010/Mirai%20Variant%20Exploiting%20Realtek%20SDK%20Vulnerability%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1629956853387&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://securingsam.com/realtek-vulnerabilities-weaponized/>



# Mitre ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Analysis of Derusbi - Used By APT19
Cyber Geeks presents an analysis of a backdoor called Derusbi, which is associated with APT19 (aka Codoso, C0d0so, Sunshop Group).

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor, APT



# Overview

Cyber Geeks presents a paper that analyzes a backdoor called Derusbi. The malware attempts to create a file in the System32 directory. If successful, the malware is running with administrative rights and will register itself as a service for persistence. Otherwise, it gains persistence through the use of the "Run" registry key. After gathering information about the system and the user, the data is sent to its command and control server. The information gathered includes "username, hostname, IP address of the host, the CPU architecture, the default language for the local system, the amount of physical memory, the amount of physical memory currently available, the processor name, the width and the height of the screen of the primary display monitor." The information is encrypted with a randomly chosen one-byte key using an XOR operation. At the time of the article, the command and control server appeared to have been sinkholed, so some interaction between the malware and its server was not available for observation. For full technical details of Derusbi's actions on a victim system, please review the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35719061/Analysis%20of%20Derusbi%20-%20Used%20By%20APT19%20IoCs.txt?version=2&modificationDate=1609261278778&api=v2)



# Protection

## Yara Rule

  * Yara rules can be found here: [ Yara.txt](/download/attachments/35719061/Analysis%20of%20Derusbi%20-%20Used%20By%20APT19%20Yara.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1609261059572&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cybergeeks.tech/analyzing-apt19-malware-using-a-step-by-step-method/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Zero-days Patched by Apple
Apple has patched three zero-day exploits being actively employed in the wild, reports Bleeping Computer.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Three zero-day exploits have been observed in the wild and have since been patched by Apple. The vulnerabilities affect iPhone (6s and later), iPad (Air 2 and later), and iPod (7th generation) devices. The first vulnerability (CVE-2020-27930) is a remote code execution bug that triggers a memory corruption when processing certain maliciously-crafted fonts. The second vulnerability (CVE-2020-27950) is a kernel memory leak. This leak is caused by a memory initialization issue, which could allow for malicious applications to gain kernel access. The third vulnerability (CVE-2020-27932) is a kernel privilege escalation using type confusion, thus making it possible for malicious applications to execute arbitrary kernel privilege code. Project Zero brought the bugs to the Apple Security team, who then issued a patch for each of the vulnerabilities. For more information, see the references below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/32147613/Zero-days%20Patched%20by%20Apple%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1604675590092&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/apple-patches-three-actively-exploited-ios-zero-days/>

  * [https://twitter.com/benhawkes/status/1324422885830610944](https://twitter\[.\]com/benhawkes/status/1324422885830610944)

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: ModPipe Backdoor Attacking Hospitality Sector
ESET researchers have discovered a modular backdoor that gives access to sensitive information stored on devices running ORACLE MICROS Restaurant Enterprise Series (RES) 3700 Point-of-Sale system. This software is used by hundreds of thousands of hospitality-type establishments.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: ModPipe Backdoor Attacking Hospitality Sector
ESET researchers have discovered a modular backdoor that gives access to sensitive information stored on devices running ORACLE MICROS Restaurant Enterprise Series (RES) 3700 Point-of-Sale system. This software is used by hundreds of thousands of hospitality-type establishments.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor




# Overview

ModPipe is a modular backdoor discovered by ESET researchers that provides threat actors access to RES PoS systems worldwide. A downloadable module provides an algorithm that gathers database passwords which are decrypted from values in the Windows Registry. Using tactics such as these shows a thorough knowledge of the software targeted. This method is less noisy than other, more simple solutions such as keylogging, and shows a level of sophistication not seen by less experienced threat actors. Typically, only the customer names would be sent in the clear; however, access to databases allows the attacker to access sensitive data such as credit card numbers and expiration dates even with encryption employed. It is hypothesized by researchers that the modules deployed contain the ability to decrypt the most sensitive data contained within the user's database. Distribution methodology is also unknown as of this writing. 

The architecture of the ModPipe backdoor consists of basic components and downloadable modules including the initial dropper (used for downloadable modules), persistent loader (achieved through process injection), main module (used for managing C2 communication), networking module (used for sending requests to the C2 server and parsing payload from C2 server), and downloadable modules. The downloadable modules have been known since the end of 2019 when its basic components were analyzed. These modules have been observed in the wild by researchers and they have provided a complete list of the modules in the report (located in the References section) below. We've included details on three specific modules here.

## GetMicInfo

This component appears to target data in the MICROS POS to include passwords which are tied to two separate database usernames stored by the manufacturer. This data is part of the encrypted data exfiltrated to the attacker. This module can intercept and decrypt the passwords using a custom algorithm. Speculation exists in how the attackers created the algorithm, which could have been reverse engineering the implementation of the RES system, information gained which describes the encryption and decryption, or the actors could have bought the code on the dark web underground markets. 

## ModScan 2.20

This module is used to collect information about the environment on which the POS is installed. The module is injected into a specified process by the C2 via an InstallMod command.

## ProcList

This module collects, as expected, processes running on the target system, process ID, number of threads, token owner, token domain, process creation time, and command line. 

Further technical information can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2020/11/12/hungry-data-modpipe-backdoor-hits-pos-software-hospitality-sector/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Kubernetes Targeted By TeamTNT
Kubernetes, a container orchestration platform, has been targeted by TeamTNT, according to a report from Trend Micro.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Worm




# Overview

Widely adopted applications are often at most risk for attack. Kubernetes is one such application. Used for the deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications, Kubernetes is the most widely adopted of these platforms. TeamTNT has been actively scanning for open Kubernetes cluster for some time. According to the report, nearly 50,000 IPs have been compromised as a result of this targeting and the subsequent attacks by TeamTNT. Some of the IPs were targeted repeatedly with success in exploiting these IPs. Most of the activity covered in the report occurred between March and May 2021. According to ISP lists, most of the targeted nodes/IPs were located in China and the US. Other countries were targeted but with 71% coming from China and the US, it can be assumed these countries were the main targets of the attacks. Initially, the bash history is disabled and environment variables are set for C2 server communication. The script used to disable bash history is also used to install two free, open-source tools - masscan and Zgrab. Also installed are a crypto miner and XMRig Monero miner. Additionally, an IRC bot is installed, similar to Kaiten. Using Masscan, the threat actor checks for any host with port 10250 open. This port is part of the Kubelet API and is open by default. The Kubelet server lists running pods, thus giving the attacker a target of opportunity. The API is then set to update the package index of the container, instal bash, wget, and curl, download a shell script, and begin the mining process for Monero cryptocurrency. The pwn function within the script subsequently attempts to find new targets in much the same way a worm would behave. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/e/teamtnt-targets-kubernetes--nearly-50-000-ips-compromised.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Critical GitLab Vulnerability Exploited In The Wild
GitLab have published details on a critical vulnerability which would allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code. This is patched, but research shows a large number of unpatched instances accessible online.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Vulnerability
  *  **Targets:** GitLab Instances
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Public Facing Application
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown 



# Overview

GitLab published a security release on April 14, 2021, to address a critical remote code execution vulnerability in the service's web interface. The vulnerability was originally identified by GitLab as an authenticated vulnerability caused by passing user-supplied photos to the service's embedded version of ExifTool. ExifTool's mishandling of the files could allow a remote attacker to run arbitrary commands as the git user. Since being published, the vulnerability has been upgraded to critical, as it has become clear that authentication is not required to exploit it. There have since been multiple exploits for CVE-2021-22205 published, and it is being actively exploited in the wild. Patches for the GitLab vulnerability have been available for over six months. However, an examination of GitLab instances that are accessible via the internet indicates that a significant proportion are still susceptible. GitLab users should update to the most recent version as soon as possible. Furthermore, GitLab should ideally not be an internet-facing service. Consider putting your GitLab behind a VPN if you need to access it from the internet. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/70221996/Critical%20GitLab%20Vulnerability%20Exploited%20In%20The%20Wild%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636386402028&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Web Application Firewalls may be used to limit exposure of applications to prevent exploit traffic from reaching the application (M1050).



# References

  * <https://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2021/11/01/gitlab-unauthenticated-remote-code-execution-cve-2021-22205-exploited-in-the-wild/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.004 - Exploits  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Custom PowerShell RAT Targeting Germany in New Campaign
Malwarebytes Labs has published a report on a new campaign targeting Germans seeking information about the Ukraine crisis. The final payload of this campaign is a custom PowerShell RAT.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Custom PowerShell RAT Targeting Germany in New Campaign
Malwarebytes Labs has published a report on a new campaign targeting Germans seeking information about the Ukraine crisis. The final payload of this campaign is a custom PowerShell RAT.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Remote Access Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unnamed PowerShell RAT
  *  **Targets:** German Citizens
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing Site
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

Malwarebytes Labs has analyzed a new custom PowerShell RAT being used to target German citizens. The attack starts on an expired Germain domain that was a legitimate collaboration platform. The attackers registered this domain and used it to host a fake version of the local government site. The site encourages the user to download a file that claims to contain information on the war in Ukraine but is really a Microsoft HTML help file. Upon execution, the users will receive an error message, but a Base64 encoded PowerShell command is executed in the background. It downloads two files which are executed as the final payload, which is the PowerShell RAT. This RAT can download and upload files, execute PowerShell scripts, and execute commands. The C2 domain is another Germain domain to avoid suspicion. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2022/05/custom-powershell-rat-targets-germans-seeking-information-about-the-ukraine-crisis/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1222 - File and Directory Permissions Modification  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Delta Plus Ransomware
While investigating smaller ransomware actors, McAfee researchers uncovered an actor distributing a ransomware payload dubbed "Delta Plus."

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Delta Plus
  *  **RaaS Operation:** No
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake application installers
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encryption, Data Theft



# Overview

McAfee published a blog post analyzing the Delta Plus ransomware as a part of an investigation into small ransomware actors. The ransomware was discovered due to a hit on a Babuk payload signature. The reason it was detected as Babuk is because it was based on leaked Babuk source code. The Bitcoin address, actor email addresses, and ransomware name were edited for the actor's purpose, but the payload remained the same. McAfee notes that prior to leveraged leaked Babuk code, the actor attempted to write their own ransomware but it was simple and easy to analyze. Investigating domains contacted by the payload led to the discovery of an open directory containing additional tools, such as scripts for defense evasion and privilege escalation. Further pivoting on the network infrastructure led to what is likely the initial infection vector, fake Flash and AnyDesk installers, along with an exfiltration tool and other payloads. For more information, see the McAfee blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130649/Delta%20Plus%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634655653585&api=v2)

            author = “TS @ McAfee Enterprise ATR”

            rule_version = “v2”

            $pattern2 = {004163725363683253766300004163726F6E69734167656E74000000004341534144324457656253766300000043414152435570646174655376630000730071}  
            $pattern3 = {FFB0154000C78584FDFFFFB8154000C78588FDFFFFC0154000C7858CFDFFFFC8154000C78590FDFFFFD0154000C78594FDFFFFD8154  
            000C78598FDFFFFE0154000C7859CFDFFFFE8154000C785A0FDFFFFF0154000C785A4FDFFFFF8154000C785A8FDFFFF00164000C785ACFDFFFF081640  
            00C785B0FDFFFF10164000C785B4FDFFFF18164000C785B8FDFFFF20164000C785BCFDFFFF28164000C785C0FDFFFF30164000C785C4FDFFFF3816400

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Delta Plus Ransomware
While investigating smaller ransomware actors, McAfee researchers uncovered an actor distributing a ransomware payload dubbed "Delta Plus."
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Delta Plus
  *  **RaaS Operation:** No
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake application installers
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encryption, Data Theft



# Overview

McAfee published a blog post analyzing the Delta Plus ransomware as a part of an investigation into small ransomware actors. The ransomware was discovered due to a hit on a Babuk payload signature. The reason it was detected as Babuk is because it was based on leaked Babuk source code. The Bitcoin address, actor email addresses, and ransomware name were edited for the actor's purpose, but the payload remained the same. McAfee notes that prior to leveraged leaked Babuk code, the actor attempted to write their own ransomware but it was simple and easy to analyze. Investigating domains contacted by the payload led to the discovery of an open directory containing additional tools, such as scripts for defense evasion and privilege escalation. Further pivoting on the network infrastructure led to what is likely the initial infection vector, fake Flash and AnyDesk installers, along with an exfiltration tool and other payloads. For more information, see the McAfee blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130649/Delta%20Plus%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634655653585&api=v2)

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Magecart Group 8 Infrastructure
A brief blog post from Malwarebytes provides an overview and indicators of compromise associated with Magecart Group 8 infrastructure.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Skimmer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Magecart Group 8
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Magecart Skimming Code
  *  **Targets:** Retail customers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post analyzing infrastructure tied to Magecart Group 8. This group is believed to be one of the oldest digital skimming groups. Much of the discovery came when researching the new "checkcheck" skimmer, which leverages a string swapping function used by other Magecart Group 8 skimmers. The researchers uncovered two large pieces of infrastructure that they've tied to the group. The first set of infrastructure is hosted on IP addresses owned by Flowspec, a bulletproof hosting providers. Many of these domains were also tied to OVH IP addresses. The second part of the infrastructure is owned by Crex Fex Pex, another bulletproof hosting provider. While investigating this infrastructure, they also found use of ICME as a hosting provider. Many skimming artifacts were found across the infrastructure, including webshells, panels, and other tools. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64128015/Magecart%20Group%208%20Infrastructure%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1631901283933&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2021/09/the-many-tentacles-of-magecart-group-8/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Potential Russian Threats To US 2020 Election
Recorded Future has published a whitepaper on their predictions of Russian involvement in the US 2020 election based on past events.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * APT, Malware, Ransomware



# Overview

Recorded Future is predicting, based on Russian involvement in the US elections in 2016 and 2018, that we can expect similar involvement coming from Russian in the 2020 election. In 2016, three APT groups (APT28, APT29, and the Main Intelligence Directorate / Main Directorate Unit 74455, tracked as Sandworm) targeted the DNC, DCCC, and other election-related individuals and organizations. 2018 saw the DNC being targeted and mass dissemination of disinformation in order to destablize opinions on domestic social media being performed. The Senate, a political think tank, and a political non-profit organization were victims of spearphishing campaigns during this time. While Recorded Future has not discovered any direct intrusion activity by these state-sponsored APT groups, they have noted the groups developing malware that could potentially be used to target election-related targets. For more details, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/29429606/Potential%20Russian%20Threats%20To%20US%202020%20Election%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1599161641491&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://go.recordedfuture.com/hubfs/reports/cta-2020-0903.pdf>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: TroubleGrabber - Stealing Credentials Through Discord
Researchers at Netskope discovered Discord, a popular multi-platform communication app designed for gamers, being exploited by threat actors leveraging a new credential stealer named TroubleGrabber. TroubleGrabber uses Discord messages to pass information to the attackers, allowing them to steal sensitive credentials.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: TroubleGrabber - Stealing Credentials Through Discord
Researchers at Netskope discovered Discord, a popular multi-platform communication app designed for gamers, being exploited by threat actors leveraging a new credential stealer named TroubleGrabber. TroubleGrabber uses Discord messages to pass information to the attackers, allowing them to steal sensitive credentials.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Threat actors continue to exploit cloud applications with new and improved malware, as it was discovered by Researchers at Netskope, threat actors have been utilizing the credential stealer, TroubleGrabber, to support their malicious initiatives. According to the analyst, when launched, the malware automatically compromises the following: browser tokens, Discord webhook tokens, web browser credentials, and System information such as country, IP address, and hardware information; sending the all victim's stolen credentials in Discord message form to the attacker. While assessing the current developments of this new malware, researchers also discovered that “Itroublve”, the original creator of the TroubleGrabber malware, had created a YouTube tutorial on how to utilize TroubleGrabber effectively. For more information, see the blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.netskope.com/blog/here-comes-troublegrabber-stealing-credentials-through-discord>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Samsung S20 - RCE via Samsung Galaxy Store App
While researching Samsung S20 vulnerabilities, F-Secure researchers found a remote code execution vulnerability in the Samsung Galaxy Store application.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
F-Secure researchers attempting to exploit the Samsung S20 device discovered a remote code execution vulnerability in the Samsung Galaxy Store application. This vulnerability existed in the store's use of a WebView activity with a JavaScript interface. The WebView activity targeted by the researchers, "com.sec.android.app.samsungapps.slotpage.EditorialActivity," can be launched via a browsable intent link or NFC tag and would allow for the download or opening of an application from the Galaxy Store based on a provided package name. The vulnerability specifically results from the allowance of HTTP URLs which, in turn, results in plaintext traffic. If an attacker had control of a WiFi network and can convince a victim to scan a custom NFC tag with their device, they could intercept the traffic associated with this activity to inject malicious JavaScript and force the phone to install and launch an application of the attacker's choice from the Galaxy Store. An update to the Galaxy Store app, version 4.5.20.7, provides a fix for this by only allowing HTTPS URLs to be used in conjunction with this WebView activity. For more information, see the F-Secure blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://labs.f-secure.com/blog/samsung-s20-rce-via-samsung-galaxy-store-app/>

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Samsung S20 - RCE via Samsung Galaxy Store App
While researching Samsung S20 vulnerabilities, F-Secure researchers found a remote code execution vulnerability in the Samsung Galaxy Store application.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
F-Secure researchers attempting to exploit the Samsung S20 device discovered a remote code execution vulnerability in the Samsung Galaxy Store application. This vulnerability existed in the store's use of a WebView activity with a JavaScript interface. The WebView activity targeted by the researchers, "com.sec.android.app.samsungapps.slotpage.EditorialActivity," can be launched via a browsable intent link or NFC tag and would allow for the download or opening of an application from the Galaxy Store based on a provided package name. The vulnerability specifically results from the allowance of HTTP URLs which, in turn, results in plaintext traffic. If an attacker had control of a WiFi network and can convince a victim to scan a custom NFC tag with their device, they could intercept the traffic associated with this activity to inject malicious JavaScript and force the phone to install and launch an application of the attacker's choice from the Galaxy Store. An update to the Galaxy Store app, version 4.5.20.7, provides a fix for this by only allowing HTTPS URLs to be used in conjunction with this WebView activity. For more information, see the F-Secure blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://labs.f-secure.com/blog/samsung-s20-rce-via-samsung-galaxy-store-app/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Social Networks Account Stealer Hidden in Android Gaming Hacking Tool
DesiEsp is an open-source, game assistant tool for PUBG on Android. McAfee uncovered a version of this tool injected with malicious code to act as a stealer.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Social Networks Account Stealer Hidden in Android Gaming Hacking Tool
DesiEsp is an open-source, game assistant tool for PUBG on Android. McAfee uncovered a version of this tool injected with malicious code to act as a stealer.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Stealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Android Stealer 
  * **Targets:** Android PUBG users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake DesiEsp application via Telegram
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Credential theft



# Overview

McAfee published a blog post analyzing an Android stealer hiding in DesiEsp, an open-source, game assistant tool for PUBG. The malware is being distributed via Telegram, rather than the official app store. If a user downloads the application to their device, administrator privileges are requested. With these root permissions, the malware will attempt to steal credentials via two methods. First, it will use the root permissions to access the device's system and application databases to gather any stored credentials. Second, it will overlay an input box onto the login pages for the Facebook, Twitter,r Google, and PUBG mobile game applications. Any stolen account information is exfiltrated to the attacker over HTTP. For more information, see the McAfee blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130673/Social%20Networks%20Account%20Stealer%20Hidden%20in%20Android%20Gaming%20Hacking%20Tool%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634664616939&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Install security updates (M1001).
  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).
  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).



# References

  * <https://www.mcafee.com/blogs/other-blogs/mcafee-labs/social-networks-account-stealer-hidden-in-android-gaming-hacking-tool/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means

 **Execution - TA0041**  
T1204.002 – User Execution: Malicious File

 **Credential Access - TA0031**  
T1409 – Access Stored Application Data  
T1417 - Input Capture

 **Privilege Escalation - TA0029**  
T1401 – Device Administrator Permissions

 **Defense Evasion - TA0030**  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1508 - Suppress Application Icon

 **Exfiltration - TA0036**  
T1437 – Standard Application Layer Protocol

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: A New and Unusual RAT - Borat
Cyble Research Labs has published a report that provides an analysis of a new and unusual RAT they discovered which is named Borat.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** RAT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Borat
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and exfiltration of data, Encrypting of files, DDoS attacks.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A new and unusual RAT named Borat was discovered by Cyble Research Labs. Borat is unusual in that, aside from typical RAT functions, it also has DDoS and Ransomware features. These features can be compiled into the Borat binary using the dashboard and builder that are provided with Borat. The RAT also contains the decryptor used to decrypt the encrypted files after the ransom is paid. Borat also contains features such as the ability to play audio, swap the mouse buttons, and show or hide the desktop which are reportedly used to disturb the victim. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2022/03/31/deep-dive-analysis-borat-rat/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
T1123 - Audio Capture  
T1125 - Video Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1132 - Data Encoding  
T1219 - Remote Access Software  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1485 - Data Destruction  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service  
T1565 - Data Manipulation  
  


####  **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1029:** Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: MIRCOP ransomware - From Infection to Full Encryption in 15 Minutes
Cofense have published the details of a new Halloween-themed phishing email that is being used to spread MIRCOP ransomware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: MIRCOP ransomware - From Infection to Full Encryption in 15 Minutes
Cofense have published the details of a new Halloween-themed phishing email that is being used to spread MIRCOP ransomware.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Mid-Size Businesses
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** MIRCOP, Crypt888
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Exfiltration, Data Destruction



# Overview

The Cofense Phishing Defense Center intercepted and analyzed a Halloween-themed MIRCOP ransomware email that made its way into the mailbox of targets. Cofense has observed threat actors using phishing emails to deliver reconnaissance and data exfiltrating tools ahead of a final ransom attack. The infection URL in the phishing email downloads an MHT file whenever it is clicked. Web browsers frequently employ MHT file extensions to archive webpages. The target is provided with a blurred and seemingly stamped form after opening the file, however, the threat actor is leveraging the MHT file to connect to the malware payload hosted on a C2 server. The downloaded payload is a RAR file containing an EXE file. The program is a DotNETLoader that drops and runs the MIRCOP ransomware in memory using VBS scripts. The ransomware takes a screenshot of the home screen, locks files, changes the background, and looks for stored passwords. The ransomware, also known as Crypt888, encrypts user files and applications to hold them hostage until a payment is made and a decryption tool is provided. The quick transition from MHT payload to final encryption demonstrates that this group is unconcerned about being covert. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70221937/MIRCOP%20ransomware%20-%20From%20Infection%20to%20Full%20Encryption%20in%2015%20Minutes%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636124772513&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/spooky-ransomware-past-segs/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1491 - Defacement  
T1491.001 - Internal Defacement

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: HermeticWiper Is New Destructive Malware Affecting Ukraine
A new destructive piece of malware has been observed during the recent Ukraine crisis. Reports from Sentinel Labs and Symantec explore the malware's capabilities and the threat actor's tools and techniques. The malware is being called HermeticWiper by the security community.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Wiper
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** HermeticWiper
  *  **Targets:** Ukraine, Lithuania, Latvia
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Public-Facing Systems
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Destruction



# Overview

A new piece of malware has been discovered during the ongoing Ukraine crisis. This malware is being called HermeticWiper because of the stolen certificate used. It has been seen mainly in businesses in Ukraine but has also been reported in Lithuania and Latvia. In a report by Symantec, it is speculated that the malware is dropped onto victim systems via exploitation of public-facing vulnerable systems, such as a Microsoft Exchange server. The researchers also note that in some attacks, the threat actors deployed ransomware to distract from the ongoing wiper attack. Sentinel Labs has analyzed the wiper malware and published some of the technical details they found. The malware is a custom-written application and uses a benign partition management driver to carry out the destructive attack. It enumerates the hard disks available in the system and proceeds to corrupt the master boot record for each one. Once the wiper process is complete, the victim machine would be unable to boot and all data would be destroyed. For more information, please see the links in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/81133569/HermeticWiper%20Is%20New%20Destructive%20Malware%20Affecting%20Ukraine%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645742502295&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/hermetic-wiper-ukraine-under-attack/>
  * <https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/ukraine-wiper-malware-russia>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1569 - System Services  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
T1553.002 - Code Signing  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.002 - SMB/Windows Admin Shares  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1485 - Data Destruction

Apple has released security updates for Xcode, iOS, iPadOS, watchOS, tvOS, and Safari.

Apple has released security updates for Xcode, iOS, iPadOS, watchOS, tvOS, and Safari.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

Apple has published a number of security updates for their products, bringing versions up to Xcode 12.0, iOS 14.0, iPadOS 14.0, watchOS 7.0, tvOS 14.0, and Safari 14.0. iTunes for Windows was also updated to version 12.10.9, but details of this release are not currently available. instruction:
I have encountered the following information: DDoS Attacks Targeting Ukrainian Websites Analyzed
A Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack targeting Ukrainian government organizations and banks caused temporary outages from February 15-16th.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Ukrainian Financial and Government Organizations
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Katana bot (derivative of Mirai) 
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Botnet 
  * **Post-Compromise Actions:** DDoS
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Cado Security reports that between February 15-16th a number of Financial, Government, and Military websites fell victim to a Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack. Network traffic to bank sites - Privat Bank and Oschad Bank - was seen spiking as the the attack commenced along with customer reports of the websites being unavailable. Some Privat Bank customers in the Ukraine received SMS messages crafted by adversaries warning that ATMs would not work on February 15th. In addition, a BGP hijack against the Privat Bank's IP space caused traffic routing issues for users. The report also mentions other components to the attack such as DDoS attacks against .gov.ua DNS servers. The news outlet, tsn.ua, named zsu.gov.ua and mil.gov.ua as specific Ukrainian government victims. The Ukrainian Ministry of Defense also confirmed the attack via Twitter. The report calls out Mirai and derivative Katana as likely botnets used to launch the attack. It goes on to name exploited Avtech network cameras as the launch point for the attacks. Overall, Cado Security's report calls these attacks moderately impactful. They were not particularly successful but the combination of methods suggests there is a base level of sophistication coordinated by the adversary. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/81133648/DDoS%20Attacks%20Targeting%20Ukrainian%20Websites%20Analyzed%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645985381594&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root (M1026).
  * Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic (M1037).
  * Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038).
  * Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040).
  * Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses (M1047).
  * Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software (M1049).
  * Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques (M1056).



# References

  * <https://www.cadosecurity.com/technical-analysis-of-the-ddos-attacks-against-ukrainian-websites/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.005 - Botnet  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1498 - Network Denial of Service

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: FBI Alert for Disinformation Spreading on 2020 Election
The FBI and CISA have issued an alert (I-092220-PSA) for foreign threat actors disseminating disinformation on 2020 election results.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Alert




# Overview

The FBI and CISA have issued Alert I-092220-PSA in an effort to raise awareness of potential threats related to the spread of disinformation regarding results of the 2020 elections. In order to certify elections, state and local officials take several days to ensure the validity of votes cast for accuracy. Due to COVID-19, usage of mail-in ballots is expected to be higher than in previous years. As a result, the possibility exists for fraudulent ballots. This process could slow election results past election night and cause a delay in announcing election race winners. By disseminating disinformation, foreign threat actors could affect voter turnout, voter suppression, cyber attacks on the election infrastructure, ballot fraud as well as other tactics intended to interfere with the 2020 election results. With proper protective measures in place, these types of disasters can be avoided. The alert contains information on ensuring accuracy in the election process. Details can be found in the alert located within the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.ic3.gov/media/2020/200922.aspx>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: The Deployment of DirtyMoe Payload
DirtyMoe is a complex, modularized, malware, focused on carrying out cryptojacking and DDoS attacks. In this article, Avast focuses on DirtyMoe's deployment and how it does things differently based on the version of windows each victim is using.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Cryptojacker and DDoS
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** PurpleFox Exploit Kit
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Ads, Phishing, Network Exploits
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining, DDoS botnet attacks
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Avast has a series of articles regarding the DirtyMoe malware which is a complex and modularized malware. DirtyMoe focuses on carrying out cryptojacking and DDoS attacks. Most of the samples they captured were delivered onto victims' machines by the PurpleFox exploit kit. The article takes a deeper look at 2 MSI installer packages. The newest version consists of two parts where one is the MSI package itself and the other part is a separate CAB file that contains the malicious payloads. The registry is used to disable antispyware and file protection features. It's also used for a counter to track how many times the installer has run, a killswitch that will abort installation, and a flag to indicate a victim's computer has already been compromised. The malware will run on various versions of Windows including older versions such as NT, XP, and Vista. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [TheDeploymentofDirtyMoePayload-IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70221897/TheDeploymentofDirtyMoePayload-IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636059404233&api=v2)

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).

T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise

T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
The Deployment of DirtyMoe Payload
DirtyMoe is a complex, modularized, malware, focused on carrying out cryptojacking and DDoS attacks. In this article, Avast focuses on DirtyMoe's deployment and how it does things differently based on the version of windows each victim is using.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Cryptojacker and DDoS
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** PurpleFox Exploit Kit
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Ads, Phishing, Network Exploits
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining, DDoS botnet attacks
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Avast has a series of articles regarding the DirtyMoe malware which is a complex and modularized malware. DirtyMoe focuses on carrying out cryptojacking and DDoS attacks. Most of the samples they captured were delivered onto victims' machines by the PurpleFox exploit kit. The article takes a deeper look at 2 MSI installer packages. The newest version consists of two parts where one is the MSI package itself and the other part is a separate CAB file that contains the malicious payloads. The registry is used to disable antispyware and file protection features. It's also used for a counter to track how many times the installer has run, a killswitch that will abort installation, and a flag to indicate a victim's computer has already been compromised. The malware will run on various versions of Windows including older versions such as NT, XP, and Vista. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [TheDeploymentofDirtyMoePayload-IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70221897/TheDeploymentofDirtyMoePayload-IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636059404233&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: DirtyMoe Spreading Using Worm Modules
Avast has written an analysis of the DirtyMoe malware. This article focuses on the worm-like capability which allows it to spread without any user interaction.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Worm
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** DirtyMoe
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing/Trojanized installer
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Lateral Movement



# Overview

Avast researchers have been analyzing the DirtyMoe malware. This malware is deployed by either phishing campaigns or malvertising. Alternatively, it uses the PurpleFox exploit kit to exploit a machine and install the malware. Once installed, it can spread without any user interaction. The goal of this worm module is to look for and exploit several known vulnerabilities and install itself into the new machine. DirtyMoe generates targets using a pseudo-random IP generation algorithm, allowing it to expand to machines hidden behind NAT. The generated IPs are scanned for any known vulnerabilities. If the potential victim is deemed exploitable, an attack is prepared and launched. The majority of these infections have been in North America and Europe. The analysts also discovered one worming module in developments that exploited other vulnerabilities but were not yet armed for deployment. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/82641486/DirtyMoe%20Spreading%20Using%20Worm%20Modules%20IoCs.txt?version=2&modificationDate=1647623393539&api=v2)



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/martinchlumecky/dirtymoe-5/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1210 - Exploitation of Remote Services  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1019:** Threat Intelligence Program - A threat intelligence program helps an organization generate their own threat intelligence information and track trends to inform defensive priorities to mitigate risk.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: AridViper Trojan Named PyMICROPSIA
Unit 42 from Palo Alto has published their findings on the threat-group AridViper (aka Desert Falcon, Arid Viper, APT-C-23). This group has been known to target the Middle Eastern region. Their investigation uncovered a new information stealing Trojan that is quite similar to the MICROPSIA malware family.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: AridViper Trojan Named PyMICROPSIA
Unit 42 from Palo Alto has published their findings on the threat-group AridViper (aka Desert Falcon, Arid Viper, APT-C-23). This group has been known to target the Middle Eastern region. Their investigation uncovered a new information stealing Trojan that is quite similar to the MICROPSIA malware family.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan



# Overview

During a Unit 42 investigation, they discovered a new information stealing Trojan they named PyMICROPSIA. This Trojan was similar to the MICROPSIA malware family but is written in Python, thus the "Py" prefix. They believed this Trojan is being deployed by the threat group AridViper (aka Desert Falcon, Arid Viper, APT-C-23), a group known to target the Middle Eastern region. Besides hosting PyMICROPSIA on the attacker's infrastructure, two additional samples were found that provided persistence and keylogging capabilities to PyMICROPSIA. Some of PyMICROPSIA's capabilities include file uploading, downloading and executing additional payloads, browser credential theft, keylogging, collecting process and file listing information, process termination, audio recording, as well as others. PyInstaller was used on PyMICROPSIA to convert the Python-based code into a Windows executable. PyMICROPSIA uses HTTP POST commands when communicating with its command and control server. Based on code snippets, Unit 42 pointed out that AridViper may be branching out to other operating systems, other than Windows, based on checks in the codes for "posix" or "darwin".

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35718212/AridViper%20Trojan%20Named%20PyMICROPSIA%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1607981534292&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/pymicropsia/>
