instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Cisco Security Advisories April 7 2021
Cisco has published fifteen Security Advisories. Of the advisories, two are rated as Critical, four are rated as High, and nine are rated as Medium.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 For all advisories listed below, it is noted that Cisco's Product Security Incident Response Team (PSIRT) is "not aware of any public announcements or malicious use of the vulnerabilities" that are described in the advisories.

## Advisories Rated Critical

 **Cisco SD-WAN vManage Software Vulnerabilities**  
cisco-sa-vmanage-YuTVWqy  
Multiple vulnerabilities in CiscoSD-WAN vManage Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to execute arbitrary code or allow an authenticated, local attacker to gain escalated privileges on an affected system.  
CVE-2021-1137 CVE-2021-1479 CVE-2021-1480  
Base 9.8 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-vmanage-YuTVWqy>

 **Cisco Small Business RV110W, RV130, RV130W, and RV215W Routers Management Interface Remote Command Execution Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-rv-rce-q3rxHnvm  
A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of CiscoSmall Business RV110W, RV130, RV130W, and RV215W Routers could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on an affected device.  
CVE-2021-1459  
Base 9.8 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-rv-rce-q3rxHnvm>

## Advisories Rated High

 **Cisco Advanced Malware Protection for Endpoints Windows Connector, ClamAV for Windows, and Immunet DLL Hijacking Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-amp-imm-dll-tu79hvkO  
A vulnerability in the dynamic link library (DLL) loading mechanism in CiscoAdvanced Malware Protection (AMP) for Endpoints Windows Connector, ClamAV for Windows, and Immunet could allow an authenticated, local attacker to perform a DLL hijacking attack on an affected Windows system. To exploit this vulnerability, the attacker would need valid credentials on the system.  
CVE-2021-1386  
Base 7.0 CVSS:3.1/AV:L/AC:H/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-amp-imm-dll-tu79hvkO>

 **Cisco Small Business RV Series Routers Vulnerabilities**  
cisco-sa-sb-rv-bypass-inject-Rbhgvfdx  
Multiple vulnerabilities exist in the web-based management interface of CiscoSmall Business RV Series Routers. A remote attacker could execute arbitrary commands or bypass authentication and upload files on an affected device.  
CVE-2021-1472 CVE-2021-1473  
Base 7.3 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:L  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-sb-rv-bypass-inject-Rbhgvfdx>

 **Cisco Small Business RV Series Routers Link Layer Discovery Protocol Vulnerabilities**  
cisco-sa-rv-multi-lldp-u7e4chCe  
Multiple vulnerabilities exist in the Link Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP) implementation for CiscoSmall Business RV Series Routers. An unauthenticated, adjacent attacker could execute arbitrary code or cause an affected router to leak system memory or reload. A memory leak or device reload would cause a denial of service (DoS) condition on an affected device.  
CVE-2021-1251 CVE-2021-1308 CVE-2021-1309  
Base 8.8 CVSS:3.1/AV:A/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-rv-multi-lldp-u7e4chCe>

 **Cisco Unified Communications Products Remote Code Execution Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-cucm-rce-pqVYwyb  
A vulnerability in the SOAP API endpoint of CiscoUnified Communications Manager, CiscoUnified Communications Manager Session Management Edition, CiscoUnified Communications Manager IM & Presence Service, CiscoUnity Connection, and CiscoPrime License Manager could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on an affected device.  
CVE-2021-1362  
Base 8.8 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-cucm-rce-pqVYwyb>

## Advisories Rated Medium

 **Cisco IOS XR Software Command Injection Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-xr-cmdinj-vsKGherc  
A vulnerability in the CLI of CiscoIOS XR Software could allow an authenticated, local attacker to inject arbitrary commands that are executed with root privileges on the underlying Linux operating system (OS) of an affected device.  
CVE-2021-1485  
Base 6.6 CVSS:3.1/AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:H/A:L  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-xr-cmdinj-vsKGherc>

 **Cisco Webex Meetings for Android Avatar Modification Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-webex-andro-iac-f3UR8frB  
A vulnerability in CiscoWebex Meetings for Android could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to modify the avatar of another user.  
CVE-2021-1467  
Base 4.3 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-webex-andro-iac-f3UR8frB>

 **Cisco Webex Meetings HTML Injection Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-webex-VObwRKWV  
A vulnerability in certain web pages of CiscoWebex Meetings could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to modify a web page in the context of a user's browser.  
CVE-2021-1420  
Base 4.7 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:C/C:N/I:L/A:N  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-webex-VObwRKWV>

 **Cisco Umbrella Link and CSV Formula Injection Vulnerabilities**  
cisco-sa-umbrella-inject-gbZGHP5T  
Multiple vulnerabilities in the Admin audit log export feature and Scheduled Reports feature of CiscoUmbrella could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to perform formula and link injection attacks on an affected device.  
CVE-2021-1474 CVE-2021-1475  
Base 6.5 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:R/S:C/C:L/I:L/A:L  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-umbrella-inject-gbZGHP5T>

 **Cisco RV340, RV340W, RV345, and RV345P Dual WAN Gigabit VPN Routers Authenticated Remote Code Execution Vulnerabilities**  
cisco-sa-sb-rv34x-rce-8bfG2h6b  
Multiple vulnerabilities in the web-based management interface of CiscoRV340, RV340W, RV345, and RV345P Dual WAN Gigabit VPN Routers could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges equivalent to the web service process on an affected device.  
CVE-2021-1413 CVE-2021-1414 CVE-2021-1415  
Base 6.3 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:L  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-sb-rv34x-rce-8bfG2h6b>

 **Cisco Unified Intelligence Center Reflected Cross-Site Scripting Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-cuic-xss-U2WTsUg6  
A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of CiscoUnified Intelligence Center Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to conduct a cross-site scripting (XSS) attack against a user of the interface.  
CVE-2021-1463  
Base 6.1 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:C/C:L/I:L/A:N  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-cuic-xss-U2WTsUg6>

 **Cisco Unified Communications Products Cross-Site Scripting Vulnerabilities**  
cisco-sa-cucm-xss-Q4PZcNzJ  
Multiple vulnerabilities in the web-based management interface of CiscoUnified Communications Manager (Unified CM), CiscoUnified Communications Manager IM & Presence Service (Unified CM IM&P), CiscoUnified Communications Manager Session Management Edition (Unified CM SME), and CiscoUnity Connection could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to conduct a cross-site scripting (XSS) attack against an interface user.  
CVE-2021-1380 CVE-2021-1407 CVE-2021-1408 CVE-2021-1409  
Base 6.1 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:C/C:L/I:L/A:N  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-cucm-xss-Q4PZcNzJ>

 **Cisco Unified Communications Manager Self Care Portal Authorization Bypass Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-cucm-selfcare-VRWWWHgE  
A vulnerability in the Self Care Portal of CiscoUnified Communications Manager (Unified CM) and CiscoUnified Communications Manager Session Management Edition (Unified CM SME) could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to modify data on an affected system without proper authorization.  
CVE-2021-1399  
Base 4.3 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-cucm-selfcare-VRWWWHgE>

 **Cisco Unified Communications Manager Information Disclosure Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-cucm-inf-disc-wCxZNjL2  
A vulnerability in CiscoUnified Communications Manager (Unified CM) and CiscoUnified Communications Manager Session Management Edition (Unified CM SME) could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to access sensitive information on an affected device.  
CVE-2021-1406  
Base 4.9 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-cucm-inf-disc-wCxZNjL2>

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/44827491/Cisco%20Security%20Advisories%20April%207%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1617852337572&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * [https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/Search.x?publicationTypeIDs=1&firstPublishedStartDate=2021%2F04%2F07&firstPublishedEndDate=2021%2F04%2F07](https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/Search.x?publicationTypeIDs=1&firstPublishedStartDate=2021%2F04%2F07&firstPublishedEndDate=2021%2F04%2F07)

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Drupal Core Security Advisories - September 16 2020
Five Security Advisories have been published which provide updates to the Drupal core. The Drupal security team has rated one of the vulnerabilities as Critical, with the remaining vulnerabilities rated as Moderately critical.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Drupal Core Security Advisories - September 16 2020
Five Security Advisories have been published which provide updates to the Drupal core. The Drupal security team has rated one of the vulnerabilities as Critical, with the remaining vulnerabilities rated as Moderately critical.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
Five Security Advisories have been published which provide updates to the Drupal core. Successfully exploited, the vulnerabilities could allow remote attackers to conduct cross-site scripting and reflected cross-site scripting attacks, or bypass certain access controls. The Drupal security team has rated one of the vulnerabilities as Critical, with the remaining vulnerabilities rated as Moderately critical. Further information ca be obtained from the advisories linked below.

 **Drupal core - Critical - Cross-site scripting - SA-CORE-2020-009**  
CVE-2020-13668 - Drupal 8 and 9 have a reflected cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability under certain circumstances.  
<https://www.drupal.org/sa-core-2020-009>

 **Drupal core - Moderately critical - Cross-site scripting - SA-CORE-2020-007**  
CVE-2020-13666 - The Drupal AJAX API does not disable JSONP by default, which can lead to cross-site scripting.  
<https://www.drupal.org/sa-core-2020-007>

 **Drupal core - Moderately critical - Access bypass - SA-CORE-2020-008**  
CVE-2020-13667 - The experimental Workspaces module allows you to create multiple workspaces on your site in which draft content can be edited before being published to the live workspace. The Workspaces module doesn't sufficiently check access permissions when switching workspaces, leading to an access bypass vulnerability.  
<https://www.drupal.org/sa-core-2020-008>

 **Drupal core - Moderately critical - Cross-site scripting - SA-CORE-2020-010**  
CVE-2020-13669 - Drupal core's built-in CKEditor image caption functionality is vulnerable to XSS.  
<https://www.drupal.org/sa-core-2020-010>

 **Drupal core - Moderately critical - Information disclosure - SA-CORE-2020-011**  
CVE-2020-13670 - A vulnerability exists in the File module which allows an attacker to gain access to the file metadata of a permanent private file that they do not have access to by guessing the ID of the file.  
<https://www.drupal.org/sa-core-2020-011>

# CVEs

  * A list of the CVE numbers is available here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/30769477/Drupal%20Core%20Security%20Advisories%20-%20September%2016%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1600406585721&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.drupal.org/security>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Ryuk Using GrimAgent Backdoor
A report from Group-IB provides an analysis of a new addition to the Ryuk toolset, the GrimAgent backdoor.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

GrimAgent first appeared in August 2020 and is now being used by the Ryuk group as a prior stage to deploying their ransomware. While GrimAgent is qualified as a backdoor, according to Group-IB, it also exhibits bot-like behavior. Once deployed, it gathers information about the victim system which it sends to its C&C server and in turn, receives commands from the server. While researching GrimAgent, Group-IB located new GrimAgent variants which indicate it is being actively developed. The report's target audience is mainly reverse engineers, researchers, and blue teams. It provides an in-depth technical analysis of GrimAgent and is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.group-ib.com/grimagent>

  * <https://gibnc.group-ib.com/s/Group-IB_GrimAgent_analysis>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Middle Eastern Oil and Gas Supply Chain Entities Targeted
An spear-phishing email campaign has been targeting entities in the Middle East involved in the oil and gas supply chain. According to a Zscaler report, the final payload is the information stealing Azorult malware.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Zscaler has been tracking a campaign in which spear-phishing emails, purporting to be from the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company, were sent to a number of oil and gas supply chain companies and government entities in the Middle East. The campaign has been active since July 2020. The emails have a PDF attached that contains a link to an archive file hosted on a legitimate file sharing site. The archive file contains a .NET executable, which will kick off the multistage infection chain that results in the installation of the Azorult information stealing malware using the process hollowing technique. The third stage of the infection chain includes multiple checks for analysis or virtualized environments. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/targeted-attacks-oil-and-gas-supply-chain-industries-middle-east>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Iranian APT Identified Obtaining Voter Registration Data
US-CERT published alert AA20-304A to address Iranian APT activity targeting U.S. state governments in order to retrieve voter registration information.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * APT, Exploit, Espionage




# Overview

US-CERT published alert AA20-304A providing an overview of the attack chain associated with recent Iranian APT activity targeting U.S. state governments in order to retrieve voter registration information. The attackers began by performing vulnerability scans using the legitimate Acunetix web scanner. They queried election-related sites for PDF files and URLs containing the words “vote” or “voter” and “registration.” With target websites identified, the actors then attempted to use scripted CURL activity to obtain voter information from these sites. Other attempted methods of access included attempted exploitation of known vulnerabilities, directory traversal, Structured Query Language (SQL) injection, web shell uploads, and leveraging unique flaws in websites. At least one state fell victim to these attacks, and the obtained information was subsequently used in propaganda videos distributed by the APT. This points to the goal of using such information in election-related disinformation campaigns. Additional activity believed to be carried out by this actor was a voter intimidation campaign; this type of campaign could also leverage stolen voter registration data to increase effectiveness. For more information, see the US-CERT alert in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa20-304a>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Android Infostealer Seen in the Wild
Zimperium zLabs researchers discovered a new advanced android malware package posing as "System Update". The malware exfiltrates a wide range of data using methods to limit the amount of bandwidth used in order to avoid detection. The spyware mobile app is not found on the Google Play Store.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Infostealer, Spyware, RAT




# Overview

Zimperium zLabs researchers discovered a new advanced android malware package posing as "System Update". The malware ex-filtrates a wide range of data using methods to limit the amount of bandwidth used in order to avoid detection. The spyware mobile app is not found on the Google Play Store. Upon installation, it will send system information about the device, including the type of network connection, back to a command and control server. It can then be instructed to steal the contacts list, call logs, and SMS messages, collect photo or video thumbnails, or record phone calls. It will package the data into an encrypted zip file and, after uploading it, will delete it from the device. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.zimperium.com/new-advanced-android-malware-posing-as-system-update/>

I have encountered the following information: Joomla! Update Addresses Multiple Vulnerabilities
An updated version of Joomla! has been released that addresses seven vulnerabilities in the Joomla! core.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
A new version of Joomla! has been released that provides mitigation for seven vulnerabilities in the Joomla! core. All seven of the vulnerabilities have been rated as Low by the Joomla! security team; CVE numbers for the vulnerabilities are yet to be provided. The vulnerabilities are due to a failure to properly validate user provided input, a missing token check, improper handling of usernames and blacklist configuration, a failure to remove sensitive data, and a failure to respect access levels. If successfully exploited, the vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to carry out CSRF and SQL injection attacks and obtain sensitive data. Updating to the new version, 3.9.23, addresses the vulnerabilities. Further details, including affected versions, are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE numbers are not yet available.




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://developer.joomla.org/security-centre.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Russian GRU Conducting Global Brute Force Campaign
A joint advisory from CISA, the FBI, NCSC, and NSA, provides details of a global brute force campaign being conducted by the Russian General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU).

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Brute-force




# Overview

Beginning in mid-2019 and probably ongoing, the Russian General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU) has been conducting a brute force campaign. The private sector has typically attributed the GRU activity to the well-known names APT28 or Fancy Bear, though a number of other names including Group 74, Iron Twilight, Pawn Storm, Sednit, Snakemackerel, Sofacy, Strontium, Swallowtail, Tg-4127, Threat Group-4127, Tsar Team, are also associated. IBM X-Force tracks the activity under ITG05. While the campaign has principally targeted Europe and the U.S., it is global in nature. The targeted entities include defense contractors, energy companies, government and military organizations, higher education institutions, law firms, logistics companies, media companies, political consultants and party organizations, and think tanks. The attacks are carried out using a Kubernetes cluster. The primary service targeted in the attacks has been Microsoft Office 365 cloud services, though other service providers and on-premise email servers are also targeted. If credentials are obtained they are typically used to gain an initial foothold before attempts are made to escalate privileges and move laterally. The attackers are also known to exploit vulnerabilities such as CVE-2020-0688 and CVE-2020-17144 for remote code execution or to further lateral movement within an environment. To anonymize the attacks, they are usually routed through Tor or VPN services, including those provided by CactusVPN, IPVanish, NordVPN, ProtonVPN, Surfshark, and WorldVPN. In some cases, the attacks have come directly from the Kubernetes cluster. Once an organization has been compromised, the attackers will attempt to gain a persistent foothold and exfiltrate data. Further information is available from the advisory linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Detection

  * A Yara rule can be found here:



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://media.defense.gov/2021/Jul/01/2002753896/-1/-1/1/CSA_GRU_GLOBAL_BRUTE_FORCE_CAMPAIGN_UOO158036-21.PDF>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Lemon_Duck Cryptominer Targets Cloud Apps and Linux
Lemon_Duck is an advanced cryptominer that spreads across networks and leverages victim resources to turn a profit. Sophos reports on the most recent updates to the malware, which is been constantly evolving.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

Sophos has published their analysis of the most recent version of Lemon_Duck. The first change the researchers noticed was the use of COVID-19-themed emails to social engineer users. Attached to these emails is an Office document that leverages an RTF exploit for CVE-2017-8570 to install the malware. Once an initial foothold is gained, the malware contains code necessary to construct new emails and attachments on-the-fly that are then sent to recipients in the victim's contact list in order to compromise additional networks. For infection of and lateral movement to Windows hosts, Lemon_Duck contains exploit code for SMBGhost and EternalBlue, as well as Mimikatz. Alternatively, when infecting Linux hosts either SSH brute-force attacks are performed or Redis or Hadoop weaknesses are exploited. Cron jobs are used for persistence on Linux hosts. Lemon_Duck identifies and kills any other mining processes to maximize the resources available to its own cryptominer. Once running on the system, Lemon_Duck can perform its ultimate goal of mining cryptocurrency to turn a profit for its operators. For more information, see the Sophos blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2020/08/25/lemon_duck-cryptominer-targets-cloud-apps-linux/>

I have encountered the following information: Digital Point Database Exposed Data of 800,000 Users
Breach / Leak Notification: Researchers at WebsitePlanet discovered an unsecured Elasticsearch database containing Digital Point user records. Digital Point is a popular webmaster forum and marketplace for web related services.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

On July 1st, researchers at WebsitePlanet identified a public, open Elasticsearch database hosted by Digital Point, a webmaster forum and web related services marketplace. Among the data in the database was user emails, names, internal user IDs, and user posts. The researchers note that threats related to this data include domain hijacking and social engineering. Data related to over 800,000 unique users was included in the leaked database. Upon discovery, the researchers reported their findings to the company, which quickly removed public access to the database; however, the researchers never received any response to their reports. For more information, see WebsitePlanet's report and ZDNet's article in the Reference section.

# Reference

  * <https://www.websiteplanet.com/blog/digitalpoint-leak-report/>

  * <https://www.zdnet.com/article/webmaster-forum-database-exposed-data-of-800000-users/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Matryosh Botnet
The Moobot appears to have created a new botnet malware dubbed "Matryosh" by Netlab 360 researchers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Matryosh Botnet
The Moobot appears to have created a new botnet malware dubbed "Matryosh" by Netlab 360 researchers.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet, DDoS




# Overview

Netlab 360 published a blog post analyzing a new botnet malware named Matryosh. This malware does not have any embedded propagation capabilities and has the primary goal of carrying out DDoS attacks. Android-like devices are infected via the ADB interface using an initial payload that downloads and executes a shell script. This shell script, in turn, retrieves several versions of Matryosh payload designed for different architectures from the same remote server hosting the shell script. Upon execution, resources and functions are decrypted, revealing various attack methods and remote domains. To obtain its TOR proxy and C2 information, hardcoded remote domains are queried to identify data in their DNS TXT records. The first DNS TXT record provides a string used to obtain the subdomains used for generating the next domain list. The second DNS TXT record is from one of the domains in the aforementioned list and returns the TOR proxy addresses. Finally, the last TXT record provides the TOR C2 address. At this point C2 communication is fully established and the bot can receive instructions for getting group information, performing a heartbeat, or carrying out a DDos attack. Similarities in the C2 model, commands, and communication indicate an overlap with the Moobot group. For more information, see the Netlab blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/matryosh-botnet-is-spreading-en/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Phishing Campaign Using McAfee Lure
A posting to the ISC Incident Handlers Diary provides some information on a phishing campaign that is using McAfee antivirus expiration as the lure.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** McAfee Antivirus users.
  *  **Lure:** Fake McAfee Antivirus expiry. 
  * **Payload:** Landing page to collect credentials or billing details.
  *  **Compromised Data:** Credentials or billing details.
  *  **Post-compromise Actions:** Unspecified.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A campaign that is using the expiration of McAfee antivirus as a lure has been reported by the ISC Incident Handlers. The email claims the victim's antivirus has expired and offers a large discount on renewal, for a limited time. Clicking on the "Buy now" link in the email leads to a page that runs what is described as a pretty well-designed fake that informs the victim it has found multiple items of malware on their system. There is a continue button on the page but when it was observed the landing page it links to had been removed. The Incident Handlers speculate that it was probably used to collect credentials or billing details, which would be quite normal for this type of scam. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056515/Phishing%20Campaign%20Using%20McAfee%20Lure%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641268492075&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://isc.sans.edu/diary/rss/28208>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Foiled Ransomware Attempt Leads to Backup Theft
Breach/Leak Notification: A failed ransomware attack led to the theft of a company's backups. ZDNet reports on this attack in a story posted to their website.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Breach, Ransomware




# Overview

A company responsible for providing software to manage referees and game officials has suffered a data leak as a result of a failed ransomware attack. The company, ArbiterSports, is the official software provider for the NCAA and other leagues. Though the ransomware attempt was thwarted prior to the encryption of any files, the attackers still managed to make off with 540,000 member's data. These members are referees, league officials, and school representatives. The company released a statement: "We recently detected unauthorized access to certain devices in our network and an attempt to encrypt our systems. We immediately took measures to stop the access, launched an investigation, and a security firm was engaged. On July 15, 2020, findings from the investigation identified a backup copy of a database made for business continuity reasons that was obtained by the unauthorized party at some point in the prior few weeks. Although we were able to prevent devices from being encrypted, the unauthorized party demanded payment in exchange for deleting the files that were obtained. We reached an agreement and obtained confirmation that the unauthorized party deleted the files." Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.




# Reference

  * <https://www.zdnet.com/article/details-of-540000-sports-referees-taken-in-failed-ransomware-attack/>

  * <https://oag.ca.gov/system/files/Arbiter%20-%20California%20Notification.pdf>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Vulnerability in Welcart e-Commerce Plugin for WordPress
A report from Wordfence outlines a vulnerability its Threat Intelligence team discovered in an the Welcart e-Commerce plugin for WordPress.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Vulnerability in Welcart e-Commerce Plugin for WordPress
A report from Wordfence outlines a vulnerability its Threat Intelligence team discovered in an the Welcart e-Commerce plugin for WordPress.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability  





# Overview

  
A vulnerability was discovered in Collne Inc's Welcart e-Commerce plugin for WordPress by Wordfence's Threat Intelligence team. The vulnerability could allow an authenticated attacker to include a maliciously crafted string in the "usces_cookie" parameter, potentially resulting in the injection of a PHP object. In its report, Wordfence provides a CVSS 3.0 Base score of 7.5 for the vulnerability. Versions of Welcart e-Commerce plugin prior to 1.9.36 are reported as being vulnerable. The vendor has published an update which addresses the vulnerability. Further information is available from the links in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * None provided.  





# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.wordfence.com/blog/2020/11/object-injection-vulnerability-in-welcart-e-commerce-plugin/>

  * <https://wordpress.org/plugins/usc-e-shop/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Silver Sparrow - macOS Malware With No Current Payload
An unusual piece of macOS malware has been reported by Red Canary. The malware is named Silver Sparrow, has infected almost 30,000 systems but, as of yet, has no actual payload.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Silver Sparrow is macOS malware, two versions of which have been analysed by Red Canary. The first version surfaced in August 2020, the second version appearing a month later. Both versions contained Mach-O binaries. However, the Mach-O binary in the second version is compiled for the Intel x86_64 and M1 ARM64 architectures. Silver Sparrow has been distributed using malvertising with links that lead to malicious DMG or PKG installers. Between them, the two versions of Silver Sparrow are reported to have infected almost 30,000 systems. Once installed, Silver Sparrow contacts its C&C every hour. As of yet, no actual payload is known to have been delivered to the infected systems. Silver Sparrow can completely remove itself from infected systems. While the actual purpose of Silver Sparrow is unknown, and there is no current payload, the operators of Silver Sparrow could issue instructions to the malware at a time of their choosing. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://redcanary.com/blog/clipping-silver-sparrows-wings/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: North Carolina College Hit with Ransomware Attack
Breach/Leak Notification: A community college in North Carolina was hit with a ransomware attack on September 13, 2020. Databreaches.net details the attack in a blog post.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Breach, Ransomware




# Overview

  
"A North Carolina-based community college suffered a ransomware attack on September 13, 2020. The attack rendered the campus unable to conduct in-person classes until September 21, 2020. According to a spokesperson, "On Sunday, Sept. 13, 2020, GTCC had an unauthorized access to the college network. Campuses were shut down for Monday, Sept. 14, 2020 to limit the extent of the unauthorized access and determine its impact." The information stolen from the college has appeared on DoppelPaymer's leak site. For more information, please see the blog located within the Reference section below."

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.databreaches.net/nc-guilford-technical-community-college-hit-with-ransomware/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Bandook Used In New Wave of Campaigns
Check Point Research details a new wave of campaigns that are using variants of the thirteen year old backdoor Trojan called Bandook.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor, Trojan



# Overview

A wave of campaigns distributing distributing variants of Bandook are the subject of a new report by Check Point Research. Bandook is a thirteen year old backdoor Trojan. Bandook was used in a 2015 campaign called "Operation Manul” and in a 2017 campaign called "Dark Caracal“. Supposedly, these campaigns had been carried out by the Kazakh and the Lebanese governments. In 2020, Check Point has seen dozens of digitally signed variants of Bandook. The infection chain of the attack is constantly evolving, so Check Point selected one from July. This version starts with a ZIP file attachment that contains a weaponized Microsoft Word document. Upon opening, the malicious macros begin their work by dropping the second stage of the attack. There is an encrypted PowerShell script inside the Word document that downloads and executes the Bandook backdoor. The version of Bandook examined had only eleven commands as opposed to more than a hundred commands found in other versions of Bandook. Sectors targeted by this Bandook include government, financial, energy, food industry, healthcare, education, IT and legal institutions. Countries targeted include Singapore, Cyprus, Chile, Italy, USA, Turkey, Switzerland, Indonesia and Germany. For more details, check out the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35717212/Bandook%20Used%20In%20New%20Wave%20of%20Campaigns%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606767023646&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2020/bandook-signed-delivered/>

Sectors targeted by this Bandook include government, financial, energy, food industry, healthcare, education, IT and legal institutions. Countries targeted include Singapore, Cyprus, Chile, Italy, USA, Turkey, Switzerland, Indonesia and Germany. For more details, check out the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35717212/Bandook%20Used%20In%20New%20Wave%20of%20Campaigns%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606767023646&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2020/bandook-signed-delivered/>

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability

Google has released an update, version 90.0.4430.85, to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for five vulnerabilities. I have encountered the following information: COVID-19 Pharmaceuticals Continue to be Phishing Targets
SlashNext Threat Labs has observed an uptick in spear-phishing attacks targeting companies producing COVID-19 vaccines and therapeutic remedies.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

SlashNext Threat Labs has been following a rise in phishing emails targeting companies developing COVID-19 vaccines and therapy solutions. At present, SlashNext has documented more than 800 spear-phishing domains over the previous 60 days belonging to threat actors. All of the attacks seen by the researchers point to Office365 login pages with differing companies being used in the login field. The attempt to steal the account credentials leads to a theory about wanting to steal vaccine-related information for their own development and use. The fake pages are identical to the legitimate company pages. The researchers used the fake domains to check for recognition in VirusTotal with none being listed in the search engine. Further information can be found in the link located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: An Unknown PowerShell Dropper
An entry in the SANS InfoSec Handlers Diary Blog reports an obfuscated PowerShell dropper that includes an anti-VM detection feature. The file has a .jpg extension but is, in fact, a text file that contains Base64-encoded data.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

An entry in the InfoSec Handlers Diary Blog reports a PowerShell dropper that, at the time the entry was written, had zero detections on VirusTotal. The dropper was found in the form of a file with a .jpg extension. The file is actually a text file that contains contains Base64-encoded data. When the data is is deobfuscated, it shows the use of public proof-of-concept code named PoSHBypass, which is used to "bypass PowerShell's Constrained Language Mode, AMSI and ScriptBlock and Module logging". An alias is created from obfuscated code for PowerShell's Invoke-Expression cmdlet which is then used to decode and execute data that results in a DLL being injected into the PowerShell process. If a VM is detected by the injected DLL, the PowerShell process will be terminated and prevents execution of the final payload. Further decoding of data generates the final payload, Formbook, which is then executed. The tool used to obfuscate the code is named "Zephyrus Protector". Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://isc.sans.edu/forums/diary/PowerShell+Dropper+Delivering+Formbook/26806/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New Snake Keylogger Variant
FortiGuard Labs discovered a new variant of the Snake Keylogger when analyzing a malicious Excel file.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Snake Keylogger Variant
FortiGuard Labs discovered a new variant of the Snake Keylogger when analyzing a malicious Excel file.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Keylogger and Infostealer
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Snake
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Maldoc
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, Collection, and exfiltration of information.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

The Snake Keylogger appeared in late 2020 and since then it has become one of the more popular malware families in use by threat actors. A report from FortiGuard Labs provides an analysis of a recent variant of Snake that was discovered when analyzing a malicious Excel file. Malicious VBA code in the Excel file creates a BAT file that contains base64-encoded PowerShell code. When the BAT file is executed using Shell(), the PowerShell code is decoded and executed resulting in the downloading of an EXE file which is a downloader and installer for the Snake payload. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70221921/New%20Snake%20Keylogger%20Variant%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636092053200&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/deep-dive-into-a-fresh-variant-of-snake-keylogger-malware>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**

T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host

T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1497.003 - Time Based Evasion  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
T1562.004 - Disable or Modify System Firewall  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1552.001 - Credentials In Files  
T1552.002 - Credentials in Registry  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
T1614 - System Location Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
T1115 - Clipboard Data  
T1119 - Automated Collection  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1029 - Scheduled Transfer  
T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol  
T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1489 - Service Stop

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: APT28 Using Zebrocy in Malware Campaign
QuoIntelligence has been monitoring an APT28 campaign since August this year that is spreading Zebrocy Delphi malware. They indicated that the command and control servers were located in France and that the theme used in the emails was NATO based.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Info Stealer



# Overview

QuoIntelligence's latest report discloses an malware campaign that uses a NATO training as a theme. A specific governmental body in Azerbaijan was the primary target, although other NATO countries may have also been involved. The article stated that APT28 (IBM follows this group as ITG05, but it is also known as Sofacy, Sednit, Fancy Bear, and STRONTIUM) was behind the campaign. The main objective of the campaign was to infect victims with the Zebrocy malware. The malware comes in as what appears to be a valid JPG image. If a .jpg extension is added to the file name, the operating system will display the logo of the Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe which is the NATO’s Allied Command Operations in Belgium. Adding a .zip extension, though, proves that the file is really an archive file, no matter what the file headers indicate. If the file is opened by WinZip, an error is returned. For the archive to be extracted properly, WinRAR must be used. Within the archive are two files named "Course 5 – 16 October 2020", one with a .exe extension and the other with a .xls extension. The spreadsheet file is corrupted and appears to contain military information while the executable is actually the Zebrocy malware. When clicked, Zebrocy copies itself to a service directory using a different name and pads the new file with 160 bytes of random data to avoid hash-matching security applications. Data stolen from the victim system is sent by accessing a PHP page on the attacker's controlled system. For more technical details, please review the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://quointelligence.eu/2020/09/apt28-zebrocy-malware-campaign-nato-theme/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Google Play Apps That Delivered Out of Context Ads
In a blog posting, the White Ops Satori Threat Intelligence and Research Team reports on more than 240 apps the team located on the Google Play store which deliver out of context ads to users. They are were typically based on Nintendo (NES) emulators from legitimate sources, and were collectively downloaded more than 14 million times.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malicious Apps




# Overview

Malicious apps can make their way onto the Google Play store if they manage to bypass security protocols. A number of apps that used various versions of the Tencent Legu packer to hide their malicious code were discovered on the Play store by the White Ops Satori Threat Intelligence and Research Team. The number of apps discovered exceeded 240 and collectively the apps were downloaded some 14 million times and at peak, the apps generated some 15 million ad impressions, per day. The apps were mainly based on Nintendo (NES) emulators which the authors of the malicious apps obtained from legitimate sources. The ads delivered to the users were made to appear to come from applications and social media platforms such as Youtube and Chrome. The apps tracked the device's screen on and off times in an effort to deliver ads when the user was more likely to see them. Once an app had contacted its C&C server, an ad would be displayed around every 10 minutes. The C&C server located by the White Ops team was running on what appears to be a legitimate, but compromised server. The malicious apps discovered by White Ops have been removed from the Play store. Further details are available from the blog posting linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.whiteops.com/blog/somewhere-over-the-rainbowmix>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ICS Advisory ICSA-21-091-01
The ICS-CERT has published an advisory that affects Rockwell Automation's FactoryTalk AssetCentre.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information is available from the advisory which is summarized below.

 - Rockwell Automation FactoryTalk AssetCentre  
CVE-2021-27462 - A deserialization vulnerability exists in how the AosService.rem service in FactoryTalk AssetCentre verifies serialized data. This vulnerability may allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary commands in FactoryTalk AssetCentre.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-27466 - A deserialization vulnerability exists in how the ArchiveService.rem service in FactoryTalk AssetCentre verifies serialized data. This vulnerability may allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary commands in FactoryTalk AssetCentre.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-27470 - A deserialization vulnerability exists in how the LogService.rem service in FactoryTalk AssetCentre verifies serialized data. This vulnerability may allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary commands in FactoryTalk AssetCentre.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-27474 - FactoryTalk AssetCentre does not properly restrict all functions relating to IIS remoting services. This vulnerability may allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to modify sensitive data in FactoryTalk AssetCentre.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-27476 - A vulnerability exists in the SaveConfigFile function of the RACompare Service, which may allow for OS command injection. This vulnerability may allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary commands in FactoryTalk AssetCentre.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-27472 - A vulnerability exists in the RunSearch function of SearchService service, which may allow for the execution of remote unauthenticated arbitrary SQL statements.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-27468 - The AosService.rem service exposes functions lacking proper authentication. This vulnerability may allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary SQL statements.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-27464 - The ArchiveService.rem service exposes functions lacking proper authentication. This vulnerability may allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary SQL statements.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-27460 - FactoryTalk AssetCentre components contain .NET remoting endpoints that deserialize untrusted data without sufficiently verifying that the resulting data will be valid. This vulnerability may allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to gain full access to the FactoryTalk AssetCentre main server and all agent machines.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-091-01>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Ransomware Named Nokoyawa
Trend Micro has published a report that looks at a new piece of ransomware named Nokoyawa, and the similarities it has to the Hive ransomware.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Users in South America, primarily Argentina.
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Nokoyawa
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Possibly spearphishing emails.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** File encryption.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

In March, Trend Micro observed new ransomware that has been named Nokoyawa. In a report they have published, Trend Micro note that Nokoyawa may be connected to the Hive ransomware operators as there are significant similarities in the tools used and the order in which steps in the attack chain are carried out. Nokoyawa has been used in attacks targeting South America with Argentina appearing to be the primary target. The initial infection vector is uncertain but it is speculated that the delivery is similar to the manner Hive is distributed spearphishing emails. There is no evidence at this time to suggest that Nokoyawa uses the double extortion technique. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/82641153/New%20Ransomware%20Named%20Nokoyawa%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1647326677640&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/c/nokoyawa-ransomware-possibly-related-to-hive-.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.002 - Tool  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Owowa Malicious IIS Module
A campaign targeting South East Asian government organizations is leveraging IIS modules to install malware. Kaspersky has published their analysis of the payload, which they have named Owowa.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Stealer, RAT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Owowa
  *  **Targets:** Asian government organizations
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Credential theft, remote command execution



# Overview

Kaspersky published a blog post analyzing a malicious IIS module dubbed "Owowa." Not much is known about the infection chain or post-compromise actions, but a sample of the payload was found for analysis by researchers. The malicious module is capable of running on IIS servers that expose Exchange's Outlook Web Access (OWA). When loaded, it is capable of stealing credentials from the OWA login page as well as run commands issued by the attacker. It hooks an ISS event to inspect the content of HTTP requests, and when a successful OWA authentication attempt is observed, the credentials are encrypted and logged to a file on the system. This file can later be retrieved by the attacker. To issue commands, the attacker submits specific usernames to the OWA authentication page. Depending on what username is submitted, the malware will either exfiltrate the log file, delete the contents of the log file, or execute the contents of the password field via PowerShell, the results of which is sent back to the attacker. Victimology includes government organizations in Malaysia, Mongolia, Indonesia and the Philippines. The researchers were unable to attribute the activity to a known threat actor but provide their analysis of potential related personas and payloads based on PDB paths observed. For more information, see the Securelist blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056224/Owowa%20Malicious%20IIS%20Module%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639670484269&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://securelist.com/owowa-credential-stealer-and-remote-access/105219/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1129 - Shared Modules  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ICS-CERT Security Advisory - December 1st, 2020
ICS-CERT has released a security advisory addressing a vulnerability in Schneider Electric's EcoStruxure Operator Terminal Expert products.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




Overview



CVE-2020-7544 is an improper privilege management vulnerability affecting EcoStruxure Operator Terminal Expert Runtime 3.1 Service Pack 1A and prior installed on Windows PC using legacy BIOS or Harmony iPC (HMIG5U, HMIG5U2) using legacy BIOS. If successfully exploited, a local user with access to the Windows engineering workstation may be able to perform unauthorized command execution, potentially resulting in loss of availability, confidentiality, and integrity.

Schneider Electric has released an update to fix this issue. We recommend reviewing the advisories in the Reference section for patches and mitigation advice.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35717383/ICS-CERT%20Security%20Advisory%20-%20December%201st%2C%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606853337313&api=v2)  
  





# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-336-01>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Visa Provides PoS Malware IoCs Used in Attacks
A report from Visa's Payment Fraud Disruption team sheds light on the PoS malware that was used in recent, independent compromises of two North American merchants.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * PoS Malware




# Overview

Attackers are still compromising merchants using PoS malware, as a report from Visa's Payment Fraud Disruption (PFD) team indicates. The PFD team analyzed the malware involved in the independent compromises of two North American merchants. The malware used in the first compromise was a variant of TinyPOS. Phishing emails sent to employees of the merchant and the attackers succeeded in obtaining a number of sets of credentials, including one with administrative rights. The credentials were then used to access the the merchant's environment. The second compromise involved malware from a number of different families including, MMon (also known as Kaptoxa), PwnPOS, and RtPOS. The vector used by the attackers to gain a foothold in the merchant's systems is unknown. In both cases the attackers targeted track 1 and track 2 payment account data which was stored for later exfiltration. Further details can be found in the report linked in the Reference below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://usa.visa.com/dam/VCOM/global/support-legal/documents/new-pos-malware-samples.pdf>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Mirai Malware Variants Continue to Target Linux
The Crowdstrike research team assesses that Mirai malware variants targeting Linux are increasing. According to Crowdstrike, these Mirai variants continue to compromise systems to populate their botnets.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Targets:** Linux Devices
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Brute Force, vulnerability exploitation.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Various ****
  * **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below



# Overview

The Crowdstrike report details a number of capabilities of Mirai variants, but focuses on instances that are targeting 32-bit x86 Linux systems. There is a significant increase in Mirai variants that target Linux systems that enterprise environments use as servers and networking endpoints. Crowdstrike research indicates that threat actors are targeting the Linux x86 monoculture because it is easier to target these devices as the Mirai code does not have to be continually updated. Additionally, the targeting and compromise of Linux servers provide more computing “power” for the botnet. The researchers at Crowdstrike go on to point out that the Mirai variants still utilize brute force attacks to gain initial access, but also exploit new vulnerabilities like the recent vulnerability in Log4j. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * [https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/linux-mirai-malware-double-on-stronger-chips/?&web_view=true](https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/linux-mirai-malware-double-on-stronger-chips/?&web_view=true "Follow link")



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1110 - Brute Force  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation  
T1090 - Proxy

  
 **Mitigations:**

 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1036:** Account Use Policies - Configure features related to account use like login attempt lockouts, specific login times, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

The Crowdstrike research team assesses that Mirai malware variants targeting Linux are increasing. According to Crowdstrike, these Mirai variants continue to compromise systems to populate their botnets.

There is a significant increase in Mirai variants that target Linux systems that enterprise environments use as servers and networking endpoints. Crowdstrike research indicates that threat actors are targeting the Linux x86 monoculture because it is easier to target these devices as the Mirai code does not have to be continually updated. Additionally, the targeting and compromise of Linux servers provide more computing “power” for the botnet. The researchers at Crowdstrike go on to point out that the Mirai variants still utilize brute force attacks to gain initial access, but also exploit new vulnerabilities like the recent vulnerability in Log4j. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * [https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/linux-mirai-malware-double-on-stronger-chips/?&web_view=true](https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/linux-mirai-malware-double-on-stronger-chips/?&web_view=true "Follow link")



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1110 - Brute Force  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation  
T1090 - Proxy

  
 **Mitigations:**

 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1036:** Account Use Policies - Configure features related to account use like login attempt lockouts, specific login times, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: QNAP NAS Devices Being Exploited
Beginning on March 2, 360Netlab observed attacks that attempt to exploit vulnerabilities in QNAP NAS devices running firmware released prior to August 2020. If a device was successfully compromised, the attackers installed cryptomining software.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: QNAP NAS Devices Being Exploited
Beginning on March 2, 360Netlab observed attacks that attempt to exploit vulnerabilities in QNAP NAS devices running firmware released prior to August 2020. If a device was successfully compromised, the attackers installed cryptomining software.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability, Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

A report from 360Netlab provides details on attacks that attempt to exploit two vulnerabilities (CVE-2020-2506 and CVE-2020-2507) in QNAP NAS devices. If successfully exploited, the vulnerabilities could allow the attacker root privileges on the device. The reports notes that there are no publicly available proof of concept exploits for these vulnerabilities. In the case of the attack observed by 360Netlab, the attackers installed a cryptomining application, XMRig. The attackers disguise the mining pool they use through proxying and also hijack the device's "manaRequest.cgi" file so that lower than actual CPU utilization and temperatures are reported. The vulnerabilities were addressed by QNAP in an advisory (QSA-20-08), published on October 8th 2020. Further details are available from the links in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/qnap-nas-users-make-sure-you-check-your-system/>

  * <https://www.qnap.com.cn/en/security-advisory/qsa-20-08>
