instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Spectre Remote Access Trojan
Spectre is a remote access Trojan (RAT) being sold on the dark web. Yoroi has published their analysis of the payload and its evolution.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** RAT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Spectre
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious document with XLM macro 
  * **Post-Compromise Actions:** Remote code execution, data theft



# Overview

Yoroi published a blog post analyzing the most recent version of Spectre, a RAT being sold as part of a malware-as-a-service offering. While it has been in existence since 2017, most of its development has occurred in 2021, with multiple major evolutions between March and October. The infection chain begins with a document containing a malicious macro that writes a VBS script to the startup folder. This VBS script proceeds to download an executable from a remote server. The downloaded executable was determined to be a packer that decrypts and executes the Spectre payload in memory. After anti-analysis checks pass, strings and C2 configuration information are decoded. An initial check-in is then performed, at which point the C2 returns various commodity tools to be used by the RAT. The RAT provides a variety of capabilities, such as browser data theft, clipboard stealer, and file download and execution. Each version of Spectre has added additional C2 commands, expanding the functionality of the malware. The researchers highlight that the sellers of the malware-as-a-service are also providing C2 infrastructure as part of their offering. For more information, see the Yoroi blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616544/Spectre%20Remote%20Access%20Trojan%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635182012198&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://yoroi.company/research/spectre-v4-0-the-speed-of-malware-threats-after-the-pandemics/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1106 - Native API  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
T1560 - Archive Collected Data  
T1560.001 - Archive via Utility  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ICS-CERT Security Advisories - October 22nd, 2020
ICS-CERT has released two security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in B. Braun Melsungen AG products.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 

ICSMA-20-296-01 addresses three vulnerabilities in B. Braun OnlineSuite. These vulnerabilities include: relative path traversal, uncontrolled search path element, and improper neutralization of formula elements in a CSV file. Potential impacts, if successfully exploited, include privilege escalation, arbitrary file upload and download, and remote code execution. 

ICSMA-20-296-02, addresses eleven vulnerabilities in B. Braun SpaceCom, Battery Pack SP with Wi-Fi, and Data module compactplus. The vulnerabilities include, cross-site scripting, hard-coded credentials, XPath injection, and several other vulnerability types. Potential impacts, if successfully exploited, include: information disclosure, privilege escalation, arbitrary file upload, and remote code execution.

We recommend reviewing the advisories in the Reference section for patches and mitigation advice.

# CVEs

A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/32146363/ICS-CERT%20Security%20Advisories%20-%20October%2022nd%2C%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1603386860835&api=v2)

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsma-20-296-01>

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsma-20-296-02>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: File Share Phishing in the WFH Era
Throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, companies have been utilizing a work-from-home (WFH) business model. Cofense published a blog post detailing some file sharing phishing scams that have been observed.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: File Share Phishing in the WFH Era
Throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, companies have been utilizing a work-from-home (WFH) business model. Cofense published a blog post detailing some file sharing phishing scams that have been observed.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Working from home presents unique problems to companies. Sharing of files has become more commonplace, as has the digital signing of documents. Cofense has observed attempts to lure victims into clicking on attachments that are seemingly legitimate. The steps taken to portray themselves as trusted users remains mostly the same. Threat actors use spoofing to appear as though the actor works in some capacity for a company in question or simply compromising an existing account. Once the actor has an identity to which the victim can 'trust', the actor goes to the email phishing scam approach. In this case, the actor used a compromised account to send these emails to contacts in the compromised account's address book. This action can allow an actor to bypass SPF and/or DKIM checks. The body of the email follows other phishing schemes in its use of file sharing to lure victims into opening the email containing malicious attachments. Shared document links are contained within the email in the hopes a victim will click on the links. Should a victim click the link(s), they are taken to a site hosting Piktochart or other services, which are not commonly blocked by SEGs. The presentation contains a name that does not match that of the sender of the email. Should the user click the link for the presentation, they're taken to an Atlassian login page that looks remarkably like a legitimate Atlassian page. Missing from this page are the customer service links typically seen in this type of site. From here, users are asked to select the email provider of choice and login from there in order to view the files sent. Further details can be found in the blog post located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/beware-file-share-phish/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: ICS-CERT Advisories March 23 2021
The ICS-CERT has published four advisories that affect Weintek EasyWeb cMT, GE MU320E, GE Reason DR60, and Ovarro TBox.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information is available from the advisories, which are summarized below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-082-01 - Weintek EasyWeb cMT  
** CVE-2021-27446 - The Weintek cMT product line is vulnerable to Code Injection, which may allow an unauthenticated remote attacker to execute commands with root privileges on the operation system.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H

CVE-2021-27444 - The Weintek cMT product line is vulnerable to various improper access controls, which may allow an unauthenticated attacker to remotely access and download sensitive information and perform administrative actions on behalf of a legitimate administrator.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 9.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-27442 - The Weintek cMT product line is vulnerable to a cross-site scripting vulnerability, which could allow an unauthenticated remote attacker to inject malicious JavaScript code.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 9.4 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:L  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-082-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-082-02 - GE MU320E  
** CVE-2021-27452 - The software contains a hard-coded password that could allow an attacker to take control of the merging unit using these hard-coded credentials.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 9.8 - assigned; the CVSS vector string is AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H

CVE-2021-27448 - A miscommunication in the file system allows adversaries with access to the MU320E to escalate privileges.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - assigned; the CVSS vector string is AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H

CVE-2021-27450 - SSH server configuration file does not implement some best practices. This could lead to a weakening of the SSH protocol strength, which could lead to additional misconfiguration or be leveraged as part of a larger attack.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 3.8 - assigned; the CVSS vector string is AV:L/AC:H/PR:H/UI:R/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:L  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-082-02>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-082-03 - GE Reason DR60  
** CVE-2021-27440 - The software contains a hard-coded password it uses for its own inbound authentication or for outbound communication to external components.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 9.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H

CVE-2021-27438 - The software constructs all or part of a code segment using externally influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the syntax or behavior of the intended code segment.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H

CVE-2021-27454 - The software performs an operation at a privilege level higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-082-03>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-054-04 - Ovarro TBox  
** CVE-2021-22646 - The “ipk” package containing the configuration created by TWinSoft can be uploaded, extracted, and executed in the TBox, allowing malicious code execution.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.8 - assigned; the CVSS vector string is AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H

CVE-2021-22648 - The TBox proprietary Modbus file access functions allow attackers to read, alter, or delete the configuration file.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.8 - assigned; the CVSS vector string is AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H

CVE-2021-22642 - An attacker could use specially crafted invalid Modbus frames to crash the system.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - assigned; the CVSS vector string is AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H

CVE-2021-22640 - An attacker can decrypt the login password by communication capture and brute force attacks.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - assigned; the CVSS vector string is AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N

CVE-2021-22644 - TWinSoft uses the custom hardcoded user “TWinSoft” with a hardcoded key.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - assigned; the CVSS vector string is AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-054-04>

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/44826834/ICS-CERT%20Advisories%20March%2023%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1616564596967&api=v2)

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: The LockBit Exfiltration Tool - StealBit
A report from Cybereason details an exfiltration tool named StealBit that was developed and is maintained by, the LockBit ransomware group.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Exfiltration tool 
  * **Associated Threat Actors:** LockBit RaaS affiliates.
  *  **Associated Payloads:** StealBit
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

StealBit is a specialized exfiltration tool that was developed and is maintained by, the LockBit ransomware group. It is provided to affiliates of the LockBit ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) operation. It is used by the LockBit affiliates to exfiltrate data from systems prior to them being encrypted for double extortion purposes. Older versions of StealBit would not execute on systems located in former Soviet countries but the more recent versions will execute on systems regardless of their location. StealBit uses the Microsoft input/output (I/O) completion port threading model, interprocess communication (IPC) between multiple StealBit processes running on the same host, and parallelizes the exfiltration of multiple files to keep exfiltration time to a minimum. It has a GUI which supports dragging and dropping of files or folders that have been chosen for exfiltration. As Cybereason notes in the report StealBit is also incomplete as some advertised features were not present in some samples, and it also has bugs. For example, one sample failed to properly hide windows created by StealBit and does not compress the exfiltrated files.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056251/The%20LockBit%20Exfiltration%20Tool%20-%20StealBit%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639719166863&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.cybereason.com/blog/threat-analysis-report-inside-the-lockbit-arsenal-the-stealbit-exfiltration-tool>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1106 - Native API  
T1559 - Inter-Process Communication  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism  
T1548.002 - Bypass User Account Control  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
T1564.003 - Hidden Window  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1614 - System Location Discovery  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1030 - Data Transfer Size Limits  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: FreakOut Botnet
FreakOut is a botnet discovered by Checkpoint researchers that is exploiting new vulnerabilities to build its network.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: FreakOut Botnet
FreakOut is a botnet discovered by Checkpoint researchers that is exploiting new vulnerabilities to build its network.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet, Cryptomining




# Overview

Checkpoint has published a blog post detailing a botnet dubbed "FreakOut" exploiting new vulnerabilities to compromise victims. The three platforms targeted are TerraMaster TOS, Zend Framework, and Liferay Portal. The vulnerabilities in each of these devices allow for OS command injection, which the operators use to download and run a Python script. This polymorphic, obfuscated Python script is the main malware payload. Upon execution, it connects to the same server it was downloaded from (its C2 server), with various system information included in the request. With the connection in place, the victim host is joined to the botnet and the script is able to receive a variety of commands. These include commands that assist in spreading to other vulnerable systems, performing DDoS attacks, and opening a reverse shell. All of the command and control traffic occurs over IRC with specific IRC channels on the server being connected to based on the configuration used. More recent versions of the malware were seen downloading the XMRig miner in order to use the victim system for cryptomining. The blog post includes Checkpoint's findings regarding the actor behind the operation of this botnet. For more information, see the Checkpoint blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2021/freakout-leveraging-newest-vulnerabilities-for-creating-a-botnet/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Version of Chaos Ransomware
While Chaos ransomware has not been seen used in an attack, the ransomware builder is in active development. Qualys reports on the most recent version of the ransomware and its functionality.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Chaos
  *  **RaaS Operation:** No
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data encryption, data destruction



# Overview

Qualys published a blog post analyzing the most recent version of the Chaos ransomware. Its builder has been advertised for testing on dark web forums since June 2021 but has not yet been observed in attacks in the wild. The latest version's main update is to expand the size of files that will be encrypted to 2 MB. Upon execution, the ransomware searches all drives for target files. If the file is within the size limit, it is encrypted using AES. If it exceeds the 2 MB limit, the file is overwritten with random bytes, making it unrecoverable. A ransom note is dropped in each affected folder and the victim's wallpaper is modified. Additionally, the ransomware implements common techniques to make the recovery of files more challenging, such as deleting volume shadow copies and disabling Windows recovery mode. Qualys points out that due to the fact the malware will simply overwrite files bigger than 2 MB, the payload acts more like a wiper than ransomware, as even if the ransom is paid many files will remain unrecoverable. For more information, see the Qualys blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057133/New%20Version%20of%20Chaos%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642539148738&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise (M1053).



# References

  * <https://blog.qualys.com/vulnerabilities-threat-research/2022/01/17/the-chaos-ransomware-can-be-ravaging>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1485 - Data Destruction  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: APT34 Using New Backdoor In Campaign Against Jordan Government
Malwarebytes has published an analysis of a brand new backdoor called Saitama. This is being actively used in a campaign against the Jordan government by the threat group APT34.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: APT34 Using New Backdoor In Campaign Against Jordan Government
Malwarebytes has published an analysis of a brand new backdoor called Saitama. This is being actively used in a campaign against the Jordan government by the threat group APT34.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** APT34
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Saitama
  *  **Targets:** Jordan Government
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing Attachment
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Collection



# Overview

Malwarebytes Labs have been tracking the threat group APT34. They have recently observed this group using a new backdoor in a campaign against the Jordanian government. This backdoor is being called Saitama. Initial access is gained through a malicious email containing an excel file, pretending to be from the Government of Jordan. If the victim enables macros, the excel file performs the necessary actions to drop the Saitama backdoor onto the victim machine. The backdoor uses DNS for C2 communications, as well as long sleep times and compression to disguise the malicious traffic. The backdoor can execute predefined commands, and custom commands from the C2 server, and manipulate files on disk. Some of the predefined commands contain internal IP and domain names, showing that this is a highly targeted attack and that the attackers had some knowledge of the victim's internal infrastructure. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2022/05/apt34-targets-jordan-government-using-new-saitama-backdoor/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1560 - Archive Collected Data  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071.004 - DNS  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: PDF Malware Is Not Yet Dead
HP security shared an analysis of current trends regarding the use of packaging malicious malware in Microsoft Office documents. HP is reporting that almost half of the malware blocked by their security software is malicious Microsoft Office documents.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Snake Keylogger
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** PDF with embedded malicious Word file attached to an email. Exploits CVE-2017-11882.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:**
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below



# Overview

Reporting by HP research indicates that there is continuous use of malicious code packaged in Office documents. This is due to the fact that these documents are easily delivered through social engineering. HP conducted an analysis of a malware campaign detected by HP Wolf Security. The analysis indicates that the threat actor utilized PDFscontaining malicious embedded files that executed encrypted shellcode to exploit the vulnerability CVE-2017-11882. The payload in this campaign was the Snake keylogger. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://threatresearch.ext.hp.com/pdf-malware-is-not-yet-dead/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.005 - Exploits  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol  
T1048.003 - Exfiltration Over Unencrypted/Obfuscated Non-C2 Protocol  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: The Evolving Ryuk Ransomware
The Ryuk ransomware has been involved in a number of high profile attacks. According to a report from SentinelOne which looks at the evolvement of Ryuk since 2018, attacks involving Ryuk are continuing with approximately twenty organizations being attacked, per week.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

The Ryuk ransomware was developed from the Hermes ransomware framework which was sold on the black market. Part of the reason for Ryuk's success is the operators behind Ryuk leverage other toolkits, and are quick to take advantage of newly discovered vulnerabilities, for example, the recent Zerologon vulnerability (CVE-2020-1472). The current attacks typically involve Emotet, Trickbot, and Ryuk. The Zerologon vulnerability is not exploited from within the Ryuk payload but is instead exploited in the early stages of an attack. Changes which have occurred in Ryuk include, obfuscation of hardcoded strings, a significant improvement in the time taken to encrypt a local drive, and changes to the various evasion techniques it uses. More details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/an-inside-look-at-how-ryuk-evolved-its-encryption-and-evasion-techniques/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: An Accidental APT Attack
Positive Technologies disclosed the results of their investigation into a client's attack that resulted in the encryption of servers and employee workstations.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: An Accidental APT Attack
Positive Technologies disclosed the results of their investigation into a client's attack that resulted in the encryption of servers and employee workstations.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, Backdoor, Cyber espionage, APT



# Overview

In a disclosure by Positive Technologies, they described an attack on one of their client's network. The attack was from a well-known Asian APT group, APT27, known for their cyber espionage against governmental targets. The investigation was the result of a compromise of the client's network on which ransomware was installed and executed. It was discovered that the compromise had occurred in early 2018. A vulnerable server on the perimeter was the initial entry point using ChinaChopper and TwoFace web shells. Recon and lateral movement on the network was accomplished by NBTScan and PsExec. Mimikatz provided the necessary network credentials. SMBTouch was used to find systems vulnerable to EternalBlue exploitations. Interesting hosts were compromised using SysUpdate and HyperBro backdoors. Cryptocurrency mining software was installed and went unnoticed for over one and a half years. Rather than running the ransomware software at infection time, the threat-group merely ran the mining software and the backdoor access. They monitored for new account creation and captured the credentials. Two years later, they began deleting OS logs and terminated the Shadow Copy services. Using a compromised domain admin account, on April 29th, Polar ransomware was pushed to computers and executed. While Positive Technologies was on-site assisting the client, the attackers attempted to regain control of the network in May, but to no avail. For a full description of the attack, examine the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35717389/An%20Accidental%20APT%20Attack%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606853518145&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.ptsecurity.com/ww-en/analytics/pt-esc-threat-intelligence/incident-response-polar-ransomware-apt27/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Black Basta Ransomware Now Targeting ESXi Systems
The Uptycs research team has published details on new behavior seen from Black Basta ransomware. In this article. they describe how the ransomware is now targeting ESXi servers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Black Basta Ransomware Now Targeting ESXi Systems
The Uptycs research team has published details on new behavior seen from Black Basta ransomware. In this article. they describe how the ransomware is now targeting ESXi servers.

Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Ransomware
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Black Basta
* **Associated Payloads:** Black Basta
* **Targets:** ESXi Servers
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encryption
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

The Uptycs threat research team has been tracking the activities of the Black Basta ransomware group. The ransomware, which was first seen in April 2022, now appears to be infecting ESXi servers. Researchers were able to attribute this behavior to the group behind Black Basta due to the similarities in the encrypted file extension and the chat support link. In this example, the ransomware looks for the directory which stores the virtual machines on the server and encrypts the files present. Multithreading is used to speed up the encryption process, and the malware uses the fast 'chacha20' encryption algorithm. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://www.uptycs.com/blog/black-basta-ransomware-goes-cross-platform-now-targets-esxi-systems>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
 T1112 - Modify Registry  
   T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1082 - System Information Discovery  
 T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  

**Impact - TA0040**  
 T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
 T1489 - Service Stop  
 T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery  

#### Mitigations:

**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1030:**  Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1039:**  Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1053:**  Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Anubis Malware Being Distributed in the Wild
Infostealing malware, first observed in June 2020, has been deployed in the wild, according to Microsoft Security Intelligence.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Infostealer




# Overview

Microsoft Security Intelligence has reported on a new info-stealing malware first observed in the cybercriminal underground that is now being seen in the wild. The malware, called Anubis, uses forked code from Loki to steal vast amounts of data including system info, credentials, credit card details, and cryptocurrency wallets such as Bitcoin and Electrum. This malware should not be confused with the Android banking malware also named Anubis. At present, the new Anubis is being deployed in limited campaigns and contains only a handful of download URLs and C2 servers. This malware uses a text file to exfiltrate data from the victim. Further information will be passed as it is received. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

New Anubis Malware Being Distributed in the Wild

parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Infostealer




# Overview

Microsoft Security Intelligence has reported on a new info-stealing malware first observed in the cybercriminal underground that is now being seen in the wild. The malware, called Anubis, uses forked code from Loki to steal vast amounts of data including system info, credentials, credit card details, and cryptocurrency wallets such as Bitcoin and Electrum. This malware should not be confused with the Android banking malware also named Anubis. At present, the new Anubis is being deployed in limited campaigns and contains only a handful of download URLs and C2 servers. This malware uses a text file to exfiltrate data from the victim. Further information will be passed as it is received. 

# Indicators of Compromise

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Exposed Kubeflow Interfaces Used to Run Cryptomining Containers
A new campaign has been targeting exposed Kubeflow interfaces to install containers that carry out cryptocurrency mining according to a a report from a researcher at Cloud Security Research.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

In late May, Cloud Security Research observed an increase in deployments of TensorFlow pods on a number Kubernetes clusters. The deployments were simultaneous, which according to Cloud Security Research, indicates the targets were scanned prior and the attacks staged to execute at the same time. To carry out the attack, the attackers targeted exposed instances of Kubeflow's centralized dashboard. Two cryptomining pods were installed on each cluster. One being the Ethminer which uses the GPU for mining, the other being XMRIG which uses the CPU. Prior to the commencement of cryptomining, a pod was installed which provided the attacker's information on the environment such as CPU and GPU information. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Overlap Between Sunburst and Kazuar
A coding overlap between the Sunburst backdoor and Kazuar has led to the publication of a report by Kaspersky researchers.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Researchers with Kaspersky have discovered some overlap in code between Sunburst and Kazuar. The first noted overlap is in the sleeping algorithm. Both sets of malware delay C2 server communications in an effort to reduce network traffic. These delay calculations use the same mathematical formula. The delay for Kazuar is between two and four weeks for C2 communication attempts and the delay for Sunburst is between twelve and fourteen days before contacting its C2. These long delays are not common for APT malware. Both sets use the FNV-1a hashing throughout their respective codes with the difference being Sunburst's use of a modified FNV-1a algorithm. Additionally, both malwares use a similar victim identifier, which is typically a random number generated by a specific algorithm. There has been a significant number of changes to Kazuar beginning in November 2020. These changes have added some differences between the two malwares with the basic, above-noted code still containing similarities. More information can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/sunburst-backdoor-kazuar/99981/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Threat Actors Using Voter Registration Themes in Phishing Lures
Threat actors are constantly modifying their lures to match current events. Proofpoint has identified one such actor that pivoted from using COVID-19 lures to voter registration themes.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Proofpoint has published their analysis of a threat actor who is using voter registration lures after a history of using other phishing kits with different themes. The voter registration emails claim that the recipient's application could not be confirmed and provides a link to re-confirm the application. It appears to come from the Election Assistance Commission (EAC) but the phishing page the user is taken to impersonates ServiceArizona instead, despite being sent to users in multiple states. Analysis of the phishing kit reveals an email address that gathered data is sent to. By pivoting off of this email address, the researchers were able to find several more phishing kits used by the same actor. One used a generic PayPal theme, while another took advantage of the COVID-19 pandemic. The COVID-19 page appeared to target UK users instead of US users. Lastly, based on code similarity, a secondary voter registration page was identified. This one impersonated the EAC instead of ServiceArizona. Both of the pages attempted to gather personal information. In all cases, the phishing kits appeared to be hosted on compromised WordPress sites. For more information, see the Proofpoint blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/agile-threat-actors-pivot-covid-19-voter-registration-themes-phishing-lures>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Cisco Security Advisories - March 3rd, 2021
Cisco has published thirteen Security Advisories. Of the advisories, one is rated as High and twelve are rated as Medium.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 For all advisories listed below, it is noted that Cisco's Product Security Incident Response Team (PSIRT) is "not aware of any public announcements or malicious use of the vulnerabilities" that are described in the advisories.

## Advisories Rated High

 **Multiple Cisco Products Snort Ethernet Frame Decoder Denial of Service Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-snort-ethernet-dos-HGXgJH8n  
Multiple Cisco products are affected by a vulnerability in the Ethernet Frame Decoder of the Snort detection engine that could allow an unauthenticated, adjacent attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition.  
CVE-2021-1285  
Base 7.4 CVSS:3.0/AV:A/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-snort-ethernet-dos-HGXgJH8n>

## Advisories Rated Medium

 **Cisco Webex Meetings Unauthorized Distribution List Update Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-webex-distupd-N87eB6Z3  
A vulnerability in the distribution list feature of Cisco Webex Meetings could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to modify a distribution list that belongs to another user of their organization.  
CVE-2021-1410  
Base 4.3 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-webex-distupd-N87eB6Z3>

cisco-sa-vman-dir-trav-Bpwc5gtm  
A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of Cisco SD-WAN vManage Software could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to conduct a directory traversal attack and obtain read access to sensitive files on an affected system.

<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-vman-dir-trav-Bpwc5gtm>

 **Cisco SD-WAN vManage Authorization Bypass Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-vman-authorization-b-GUEpSLK  
A vulnerability in Cisco SD-WAN vManage Software could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to bypass authorization checking and gain restricted access to the configuration information of an affected system.  
CVE-2021-1464

 **Cisco ASR 5000 Series Software (StarOS) ipsecmgr Process Denial of Service Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-staros-ipsecmgr-dos-3gkHXwvS  
A vulnerability in the ipsecmgr process of Cisco ASR 5000 Series Software (StarOS) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition.  
CVE-2021-1424  
Base 5.3 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:L/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-staros-ipsecmgr-dos-3gkHXwvS>

 **Cisco SD-WAN vManage Information Disclosure Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-sdwanvman-infodis1-YuQScHB  
A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of Cisco SD-WAN vManage Software could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to read arbitrary files on the underlying filesystem of an affected system.  
CVE-2021-1232  
Base 6.5 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-sdwanvman-infodis1-YuQScHB>

 **Cisco SD-WAN vDaemon Buffer Overflow Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-sdwan-vdaemon-bo-RuzzEA2  
A vulnerability in the vDaemon service of Cisco SD-WAN vManage Software could allow an authenticated, local attacker to cause a buffer overflow on an affected system, resulting in a denial of service (DoS) condition.  
CVE-2021-1466  
Base 5.4 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:L/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-sdwan-vdaemon-bo-RuzzEA2>

 **Cisco SD-WAN Software Signature Verification Bypass Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-sdwan-sigverbypass-gPYXd6Mk  
A vulnerability in the Image Signature Verification feature of Cisco SD-WAN Software could allow an authenticated, remote attacker with Administrator-level credentials to install a malicious software patch on an affected device.  
CVE-2021-1461

 **Cisco SD-WAN vManage Software Privilege Escalation Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-sdwan-privesc-vman-kth3c82B  
A vulnerability in the CLI of Cisco SD-WAN vManage Software could allow an authenticated, local attacker to elevate privileges on an affected system. To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker would need to have a valid Administrator account on an affected system.  
CVE-2021-1462  
Base 4.4 CVSS:3.0/AV:L/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-sdwan-privesc-vman-kth3c82B>

 **Cisco SD-WAN vManage SQL Injection Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-sdw-sqlinj-HDJUeEAX  
A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of Cisco SD-WAN vManage Software could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to conduct SQL injection attacks on an affected system.  
CVE-2021-1470  
Base 4.9 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-sdw-sqlinj-HDJUeEAX>

 **Cisco Network Services Orchestrator Path Traversal Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-nso-path-trvsl-dZRQE8Lc  
A vulnerability in the API subsystem and in the web-management interface of Cisco Network Services Orchestrator (NSO) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to access sensitive data.  
CVE-2021-1132  
Base 5.3 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-nso-path-trvsl-dZRQE8Lc>

 **Cisco IP Phones Buffer Overflow and Denial of Service Vulnerabilities**  
cisco-sa-ipphone-rce-dos-U2PsSkz3  
Multiple vulnerabilities in the Cisco Discovery Protocol and Link Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP) implementations for Cisco IP Phone Series 68xx/78xx/88xx could allow an unauthenticated, adjacent attacker to execute code remotely or cause a reload of an affected IP phone.  
CVE-2021-1379  
Base 6.5 CVSS:3.1/AV:A/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-ipphone-rce-dos-U2PsSkz3>

 **Cisco Email Security Appliance and Content Security Management Appliance Information Disclosure Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-esa-sma-info-disclo-VOu2GHbZ  
A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of Cisco AsyncOS Software for Cisco Email Security Appliance (ESA) and Cisco Content Security Management Appliance (SMA) could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to access sensitive information on an affected device.  
CVE-2021-1425  
Base 4.3 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-esa-sma-info-disclo-VOu2GHbZ>

Base 4.9 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-sdwan-sigverbypass-gPYXd6Mk>

 **Cisco SD-WAN vManage Software Privilege Escalation Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-sdwan-privesc-vman-kth3c82B  
A vulnerability in the CLI of Cisco SD-WAN vManage Software could allow an authenticated, local attacker to elevate privileges on an affected system. To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker would need to have a valid Administrator account on an affected system.  
CVE-2021-1462  
Base 4.4 CVSS:3.0/AV:L/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-sdwan-privesc-vman-kth3c82B>

 **Cisco SD-WAN vManage SQL Injection Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-sdw-sqlinj-HDJUeEAX  
A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of Cisco SD-WAN vManage Software could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to conduct SQL injection attacks on an affected system.  
CVE-2021-1470  
Base 4.9 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-sdw-sqlinj-HDJUeEAX>

 **Cisco Network Services Orchestrator Path Traversal Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-nso-path-trvsl-dZRQE8Lc  
A vulnerability in the API subsystem and in the web-management interface of Cisco Network Services Orchestrator (NSO) could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to access sensitive data.  
CVE-2021-1132  
Base 5.3 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-nso-path-trvsl-dZRQE8Lc>

 **Cisco IP Phones Buffer Overflow and Denial of Service Vulnerabilities**  
cisco-sa-ipphone-rce-dos-U2PsSkz3  
Multiple vulnerabilities in the Cisco Discovery Protocol and Link Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP) implementations for Cisco IP Phone Series 68xx/78xx/88xx could allow an unauthenticated, adjacent attacker to execute code remotely or cause a reload of an affected IP phone.  
CVE-2021-1379  
Base 6.5 CVSS:3.1/AV:A/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-ipphone-rce-dos-U2PsSkz3>

 **Cisco Email Security Appliance and Content Security Management Appliance Information Disclosure Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-esa-sma-info-disclo-VOu2GHbZ  
A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of Cisco AsyncOS Software for Cisco Email Security Appliance (ESA) and Cisco Content Security Management Appliance (SMA) could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to access sensitive information on an affected device.  
CVE-2021-1425  
Base 4.3 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-esa-sma-info-disclo-VOu2GHbZ>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Operation Epic Manchago Maldocs Used for Infostealer Delivery
NVISO has detected malicious Excel documents delivering VBA-activated spreadsheets. In a blog post, researchers analyzed the campaign and the intricacies built into the maldocs discussed.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Operation Epic Manchago Maldocs Used for Infostealer Delivery
NVISO has detected malicious Excel documents delivering VBA-activated spreadsheets. In a blog post, researchers analyzed the campaign and the intricacies built into the maldocs discussed.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Infostealer




# Overview

NVISO detected malicious Excel documents in July 2020 that are able to deliver malware through VBA-activated spreadsheets. Unlike most malicious excel documents, these particular samples were created using EPPlus software. It is believed the campaign is being carried out by a single threat actor based on the number of samples provided to services such as VirusTotal. Additionally, delivery of payloads supports this theory. The lack of Office metadata led researchers to conclude the files were created in EPPlus as well as the uncompiled code contained within the spreadsheets. All of the sample maldocs contain a password protected VBA project. Efforts to recover the passwords were unsuccessful. A handful of samples were obtained and it was determined the VBA code will use either PowerShell or ActiveX to download the payload. These payloads are hosted on various websites. There is a common pattern to the second stage downloader. The stage 2 EXE loads a DLL. This DLL extracts and decodes steganography encoded images from the EXE. Finally, the DLL loads the stage 3 EXE. This is the final payload. These final stages included such malware as AgentTesla, Azorult, Formbook, Matiex, and njRAT. There does not appear to be a pattern in the targeting of victims. Further technical details can be found in the blog post contained within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.nviso.eu/2020/09/01/epic-manchego-atypical-maldoc-delivery-brings-flurry-of-infostealers/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: ICS-CERT Security Advisories - October 15th, 2020
ICS-CERT has released two security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in Advantech devices.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview



ICSA-20-289-01 addresses an external control of file name or path vulnerability in Advantech WebAccess/SCADA. If successfully exploit, an remote attacker may be able to execute code as an administrator on the target device.

ICSA-20-289-02 addresses an SQL Injection vulnerability in Advantech R-SeeNet applications. If successfully exploited, a remote attacker may be able to retrieve sensitive information from the R-SeeNet database.

Advantech has patch both vulnerabilities. We recommend reviewing the advisories for patches and mitigation advice.

# CVEs

A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/32146003/ICS-CERT%20Security%20Advisories%20-%20October%2015th%2C%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1602788830821&api=v2)

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-289-01>

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-289-02>

Of these, 1 is rated critical, 4 are rated high, 9 are rated as medium, and 5 are updates to previously released patches. The potential impact from successful exploitation of the most serious vulnerability is remote code execution. In addition, privilege escalation, accessing sensitive files, and other nefarious actions are possible.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Seedworm: Continues to Target Organizations in the Middle East
The Threat Hunter Team from Symantec began probing a new hacking tool they believe Seedworm, the Iranian cyber-espionage group, also known as MuddyWater, has been utilizing in recent attacks, known as PowGoop. Furthermore, supporting Iranian strategic interest, with the end goal of smuggling key data from prime targets in the Middle East.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Researchers at Symantec observed the latest addition to Seedworms attack arsenal, a new hacking tool called PowGoop. It was assessed, that Seedworm ulitizes the PowGoop malware as a downloader to reach out to other remote servers to download and execute additional PowerShell scripts. This has been highly effective for the group, due to PowGoops two components: a DLL loader and a PowerShell-based downloader. The PowGoop loader component is responsible for decrypting and running the PowerShell code that comprises the PowGoop downloader, allowing the threat group to siphon data off of networks. Analyst at Symantec also observed Seedworm exploiting several open-source tools like: Quarks PwDump, Chisel and Secure Sockets Funneling (SSF), to help with the movement and maneuverability of the data from one network to another. Furthermore, allowing the attackers to configure local and remote port forwarding as well as copy files to compromised machines. Although researchers are unable to assess a sustainable correlation between PowGoop and Seedworm, they’ve focused their rational on the presumption that; Seedworm is reconstructing their operational approach in terms of TTPs. For more details, please review the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: CISA Alert AA20-266A - LokiBot Malware
CISA, in conjunction with MS-ISAC, has issued Alert AA20-266A on the increase in LokiBot malware since July.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan, Info Stealer



# Overview

According to CISA and MS-ISAC (Multi-State Information Sharing & Analysis Center), LokiBot malware usage has been on the rise since July. LokiBot (aka Loki PWS) is a Trojan designed to steal information from its victims. This information can include items such as usernames, passwords, cryptocurrency wallets, and other credentials. Infection vectors can include spam emails, malicious websites, SMS, as well as other means of communication. Primary targeted operating systems are Windows and Android. LokiBot has been around and evolving since early 2016. For full details, list of mitigation techniques, and other references, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Protection

## Snort Rule

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: KryptoCibule Malware - Cryptominer and RAT
KryptoCibule is malware discovered by researchers from ESET that has the ability to mine cryptocurrency, hijack cryptocurrency transactions, and exfiltrate files from victim systems which are mainly related to cryptocurrency. It also has RAT functionality.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

Researchers from ESET have discovered a piece of malware which they have named KryptoCibule. The malware appears to have first emerged in December 2018, but until now, was undocumented. The primary functions of the malware are related to cryptocurrency. It can mine currency, hijack cryptocurrency transactions, and exfiltrate files related to cryptocurrency, and provides RAT functionality. It uses XMRig to mine Monero, and kawpowminer to mine Ethereum. Other, legitimate applications are also installed by KryptoCibule, these include the Apache httpd server, Buru SFTP server, Tor, and the Transmission torrent client, which are either bundled with the installer or downloaded at runtime. KryptoCibule mainly targets users in the Czech Republic and Slovakia. It is distributed in torrent files that purport to be cracked or pirated games and software. The torrents deliver a ZIP file, inside which is an executable file that masquerades as a legitimate InstallShield application. A number of anti-analysis and anti-detection techniques are implemented in KryptoCibule and specifically checks for three anti-virus products, Avast, AVG, and ESET, all of which are headquartered in either the Czech Republic or Slovakia. Infected systems are used to seed the malicious torrents, and the BitTorrent protocol is used for downloading updates to KryptoCibule and installing additional applications. The Transmission client, transmission-daemon, is managed through RPC on port 9091 and used the hardcoded credentials "superman:krypton". The SFTP server is also used to download additional components, and additionally, run as an onion service using port 9187 for exfiltrating data. Persistence for the malware is achieved using a scheduled task. Further details are available from the ESET report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2020/09/02/kryptocibule-multitasking-multicurrency-cryptostealer/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: A Technical Look at DreamBus Botnet
Zscaler's ThreatLabz has provided a technical analysis of the DreamBus Botnet. The malware, which exhibits worm-like behavior, has been in use since 2019.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet




# Overview

Exhibiting worm-like behavior, DreamBus is a Linux-based botnet. The botnet can spread by scanning private IP address ranges for vulnerable systems. The botnet uses implicit trust, application exploits, and weak passwords to gain a foothold into databases, cloud-based applications, and IT admin tools. The botnet is using XMRig to mine for Monero currency and appears to be operating out of Russia or Eastern Europe. The botnet uses an ELF binary to set up the environment, infecting systems, downloading new modules, and deploying XMRig. The ELF binary is packed using UPX and a modified header and footer. This obfuscation reduces file sizes and hides the malware code. Most of the C2 components are hosted through TOR or anonymous file sharing services that use HTTP as its transport protocol. The main component spreads through SSH and is downloaded over HTTP when the exploit is successful. The module contains seven shell scripts with each performing a different action. Persistence is achieved via x() functionality in the creation of a cron job. This script will download the latest version of the malware. Each time the exploit is successful, the malware attempts to authenticate with the username of the compromised system. The SSH module is a brute force shell script used to download and extract a TAR file. Further details on this malware and its associated modules can be found in the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 

# Recommendations

    * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
    * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
    * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
    * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
    * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.

# Reference

    * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/dreambus-botnet-technical-analysis>
