instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Emotet Chronicles
Kaspersky has published a report chronicling what is known about Emotet malware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Emotet Chronicles
Kaspersky has published a report chronicling what is known about Emotet malware.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan



# Overview

According to Kaspersky, Emotet was first discovered in June 2014 by Trend Micro. Emotet is a malware package designed to steal banking credentials. Initial targets were German and Austrian bank users. At that time, the infection vector was bank-related spam with either weaponized attachments or links to ZIP files with the loader install. November of that year saw additional modules added that could modify HTTP(s) traffic, collect Outlook email addresses, and steal credentials in Mail PassView, among others. December saw unresponsive command and control servers as attacks dropped off. The following January saw a public RSA key and encrypted embedded strings. Swiss bank clients were also added to the victim list. June 2015 saw the beginning of another shutdown of the command and control servers. December of 2016 saw a new outlook for Emotet with the ability to infect victims using the RIG-E and RIG-V exploit kits. In February 2017, it was discovered that Emotet had included a spam module in its tool set. Banking clients in Poland were added in April's spam emails. May saw a change in the spam attachment used in the attack. This was the first time a weaponized Microsoft Word document (or a link to one) required the victim to enable macros. It was also the first time that Emotet began installing the banking Trojan Qbot (or QakBot), although the number of installs were not numerous. June saw Emotet begin to use a network spreading technique to infect other systems on the local network. In July, Emotet changed from using GET requests to using POST requests. The list of brute-force passwords used significantly increased in August. IBM X-Force announced in November that Emotet was now spreading IcedID. In January of 2018, Emotet began installing the banking Trojan Panda (also known as Zeus Panda). In April, Emotet added a module to spread laterally over wireless networks. In June, Emotet began a relationship with Trickbot (also known as Trickster). The ability to access computers behind NAT and convert them into command and control proxies was added in July. Installing Ryuk by Emotet began in August. October saw a brief suspension of command and control servers as well as an update to the Outlook exfiltration module. Another suspension of command and control servers began in November with a resumption beginning in January of 2019. March saw modifications to the HTTP protocol used in command and control communication. In April, data exfiltration (topics, mailing lists, message contents) began showing up in Emotet spam emails. From May until August, command and control servers went down once more. In November and February, additional minor changes were made to the headers in the HTTP protocol. Infections declined in February, not to resume until July. After starting back up in July, public reports indicated that the links in the spam emails were replaced with benign images and memes instead of the malicious Emotet payload. In a few days, this issue was corrected and Emotet began flowing again. For full details on the Emotet history, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35717728/Emotet%20Chronicles%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1607375773201&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/the-chronicles-of-emotet/99660/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: APT41 Ransomware Attack Against Taiwanese Energy Company
Following the indictment of APT41 threat actors, Trend Micro has published a report regarding one of their attacks against a Taiwanese energy company.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: APT41 Ransomware Attack Against Taiwanese Energy Company
Following the indictment of APT41 threat actors, Trend Micro has published a report regarding one of their attacks against a Taiwanese energy company.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, APT




# Overview

Trend Micro has published their analysis of an APT41 attack targeting a Taiwanese energy company. Due to being unable to identify the initial infection vector, their focus is on the post-compromise activity. Once the threat actor gained access to the victim environment, they deployed CobaltStrike and subsequently performed reconnaissance using password dumpers and HTTP tunneling tools. Their ultimate goal was to obtain the headquarter's Active Directory server account username and password. About a month after the initial compromise, the attackers used their Active Directory access to copy the ransomware loader to domain members via SMB and the internal IIS Web Service. With the payload on the endpoints, a scheduled task is created via Active Directory that uses PowerShell to execute the loader. The ransomware family in use has been dubbed ColdLock. Trend Micro researchers were able to identify additional cyber espionage activities carried out by the group against a variety of industries based on overlapping indicators and C2 infrastructure. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/20/i/u-s--justice-department-charges-apt41-hackers-over-global-cyberattacks.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Scammers Using MalwareBytes Renewals for Phishing
MalwareBytes' Threat Intelligence Team has uncovered a scam using their brand as a lure for phishing. Using fake emails and phone calls, threat actors are targeting users of MalwareBytes' services and products for the scam.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

A series of fake renewal notices and offers to remove security services offered by MalwareBytes has led their analysts to a phishing campaign. Several reports indicate the receipt of an email stating the product for which the customer may or may not have a legitimate license for has been seen in the wild. The email states that a subscription service offered by the company has been renewed at a rate much higher than the actual rate the company charges for this product. The threat actors show a charge of between $300-500. A typical yearly subscription for the product is actually about $100. The scam uses these emails in the hopes the victim will call and try to get the charges reversed. Should victims call, they're pointed to a website wherein a technician will remotely connect to their computer and 'uninstall' the product in question. Once the product is 'removed', the promise of a refund is given. Instead, the actors ask the victim to download TeamViewer and to share their ID and password to connect to the victim machine. The actors then install a second program to achieve persistence. In the same way as a tech support scheme, the threat actors use notepad to concoct a note telling the victim of the risks of not continuing with the product. Using SysKey, the actors place a password known only to them is installed on the computer. Should this be the case, a VBS script is downloaded and placed in the Startup folder. Upon completion of these acts, the scammers attempt to have the victim restart their machine in order to complete the 'uninstall' process. After restart, a Windows license expiration is displayed with a button to click. This button opens many browser windows to give the appearance of a malware infection. The hope is that some of the victims will call the number and ask that their service be reinstated. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/cybercrime/2021/03/software-renewal-scammers-unmasked/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: IBM Publishes Eight Security Guardium Security Bulletins
IBM has published eight security bulletins covering Security Guardium. The bulletins cover issues such as OS command injection, kernel vulnerabilities, Java vulnerabilities, third-party vulnerabilities, cross-site scripting issues, and hard-coded credentials.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerabilities



# Overview

IBM has published eight security bulletins covering fifty-nine vulnerabilities patched in the current version of Security Guardium.   
  
Two bulletins deal with OS command injection vulnerabilities (CVE-2020-4180 and CVE-2020-4183). In the first bulletin, a remote authenticated attacker could potentially send a specially crafted request to the system that exploits this vulnerability. If successful, the execution of arbitrary commands may be possible. The second bulletin describes a cross-site scripting issue that could allow the attacker to embed arbitrary JavaScript code into the Web UI. This could potentially lead to credential disclosure.   
  
Guardium is also vulnerable to a kernel vulnerability that could lead to a denial of service condition. This is due to a race condition between mmget_not_zero()/get_task_mm() and core dumping. A specially crafted system call could lead to a system crash or sensitive information being leaked.   
  
Eleven vulnerabilities were patched in the IBM Java SDK. Results from successful exploitation includes low confidentiality impact, low integrity impact, no availability, or leaking of sensitive information.   
  
Forty-three vulnerabilities were disclosed in two bulletins identifying third-party product vulnerabilities. These products include Jackson Library, Jackson-databind, FasterXML Jackson-databind, Oracle products, Huawei products, and Apache Log4j.   
  
The next bulletin describes a cross-site scripting vulnerability that could potentially lead to credential disclosure if successfully exploited.   
  
The last bulletin describes a hard-coded credential use that was fixed.   
  
IBM has provided updates that address all of the issues listed above.

# CVEs

  * For a complete list of CVEs, click here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/29428709/IBM%20Publishes%20Eight%20Security%20Guardium%20Security%20Bulletins%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1599080547172&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review bulletins carefully for vulnerable systems versions and technical details

  * Apply update as soon as possible

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: FiveHands Ransomware
The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has issued a report on a new ransomware variant dubbed "FiveHands" and its usage in a recent campaign.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: FiveHands Ransomware
The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has issued a report on a new ransomware variant dubbed "FiveHands" and its usage in a recent campaign.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

CISA has issued a report on the FiveHands ransomware variant. Using publicly-available penetration testing and exploitation tools, FiveHands, and SombRAT, the threat actors were able to steal information, obfuscate files, and demand ransom from the victim. In addition to the pen testing tools, the actors used publicly-available tools to accomplish network discovery and credential access. Initially, the threat actor used a zero-day vulnerability in a VPN product to gain access to the victim network. Tools used in this attack included: SoftPerfect Network Scanner, FiveHands ransomware, PsExec.exe, ServeManager.exe, SombRAT, RoutherScan.exe, grabff.exe, rclone.exe, and s3browser-9-5-3.exe. As with most ransomware attacks, the attacker left a note behind detailing payment instructions as well as threats of continued actions against the company for non-compliance. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-126a>

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-126b>

Tell me everything you know the following threat: India's National Informatics Centre Compromised by Malware
Breach / Leak Notification: Multiple media articles are reporting that more than one hundred computers of India's National Informatics Centre have been compromised by malware.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

  
"In a major security breach, more than 100 computers of the National Informatics Centre (NIC), which is responsible for securing critical cyber infrastructure in the country and the Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology (MeitY), were found to be compromised, ThePrint has learnt... According to sources in the police, these computers contain crucial information and data on India’s security, citizens and important government functionaries, including the prime minister, national security advisor, the home minister, among others."

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New Targeting of National Oil Company’s Ongoing Development and Exploration Projects
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence has identified phishing emails targeting companies with an interest in the pipeline offshore Sarawak, Malaysia project led by Petroleum Authority of Thailand (PTT) Exploration and Production Public Co. Ltd’s (PTTEP). This activity has been connected to a previous credential harvesting campaign identified by X-Force in July 2020.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Targeting of National Oil Company’s Ongoing Development and Exploration Projects
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence has identified phishing emails targeting companies with an interest in the pipeline offshore Sarawak, Malaysia project led by Petroleum Authority of Thailand (PTT) Exploration and Production Public Co. Ltd’s (PTTEP). This activity has been connected to a previous credential harvesting campaign identified by X-Force in July 2020.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Credential Harvesting




# Overview

In mid-September 2020, IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence observed a wave of phishing emails targeting companies likely having an interest in the pipeline offshore Sarawak, Malaysia project led by Petroleum Authority of Thailand (PTT) Exploration and Production Public Co. Ltd’s (PTTEP). X-Force uncovered Domain Name System (DNS) Start of Authority (SOA) records associated with this activity that directly overlap with the DNS SOA record reported by X-Force in July 2020 “Years of Phishing Campaigns Deliver Credential Harvesting Malware to Exploit Worldwide Expansion of Major Saudi Arabian Energy Company”. The emails involved in this campaign deliver the AgentTesla credential harvesting malware. The full story, including indicators of compromise, is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# Indicators of Compromise

Indicators of compromise are available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more and see the indicators at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/9c339d47-8b17-4c7c-a4e1-5eb9770c3ca0>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Cisco Security Advisory - March 24th, 2021
Cisco published a security advisory addressing three vulnerabilities in the Cisco Jabber desktop and mobile client software.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview



CVE-2021-1411 and CVE-2021-1469 are arbitrary program execution vulnerabilities in Cisco Jabber for Windows. They results from improper validation of message content and, if successfully exploited, could allow an authenticated attacker to execute programs on the target system. CVE-2021-1417 is a information disclosure vulnerability in Cisco Jabber for Windows. It results from improper validation of message content and, if successfully exploited, could allow an authenticated attacker to access sensitive authentication information. CVE-2021-1471 is a certificate validation vulnerability in Cisco Jabber for Windows, Cisco Jabber for MacOS, and Cisco Jabber for mobile platforms that could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to intercept protected network traffic. CVE-2021-1418 is a denial of service (DoS)vulnerability in Cisco Jabber for Windows, Cisco Jabber for MacOS, and Cisco Jabber for mobile platforms that could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to cause a DoS condition.

Cisco has released patches to fix all of these vulnerabilities. We recommend reviewing the security advisory in the Reference section and applying any applicable patches as soon as possible.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-1411

  * CVE-2021-1417

  * CVE-2021-1418

  * CVE-2021-1469

  * CVE-2021-1471




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-cisco-jabber-PWrTATTC>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Verblecon - A New Loader
A report from Symantec looks at a new loader they describe as sophisticated being used in low-level attacks to install cryptominers and potentially steal Discord tokens.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Verblecon
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration, Cryptomining.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Symantec has reported a new loader named Verblecon they describe as complex and powerful and being used in low-level attacks. The attacks are described as unsophisticated and low-reward. No information is provided on how the malware is being distributed to victims which Symantec described as mostly non-enterprise systems. Verblecon itself is loaded as a server-side JAR file and is polymorphic making it appear different each time it is downloaded. When executed, Verblecon checks that it is not being debugged or run in a virtual machine or sandbox. It then collects information about the system and communicates it to a C&C server. A payload is then downloaded in the form of binary blobs which are decrypted, executed, and injected into dllhost.exe using com.sun.jna. The objective of that attacks appears to be cryptomining but may also involve attempts to steal Discord tokens. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/verblecon-sophisticated-malware-cryptocurrency-mining-discord>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.001 - Dynamic-link Library Injection  
T1112 - Modify Registry  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Shared Power Banks Used to Take Control of Phones
Yicai Global indicates that shared power banks, used to charge phones in public areas in China, may be infected with malware to either steal victim's data or take control of the device.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Shared Power Banks Used to Take Control of Phones
Yicai Global indicates that shared power banks, used to charge phones in public areas in China, may be infected with malware to either steal victim's data or take control of the device.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan



# Overview

Yicai Global announced in an article that charging stations in China may have been compromised by hackers. They indicate that the compromised station may install a Trojan on Android or iOS devices that are plugged in to recharge the device. One of China's larger shared power bank providers, Energy Monster, stated that their cables are configured only to supply power, not transfer data. Users are warned to take caution when using such public charging stations. When necessary, using your own cable that is known to not be configured to transfer data, is your best option, if possible. For more information, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.yicaiglobal.com/news/hackers-can-take-control-of-phones-via-shared-power-banks-ministry-says->

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Remcos RAT Delivered via Visual Basic
Remcos RAT is leveraging new tactics in recent campaigns. Malwarebytes published a blog post detailing the new behaviors being observed.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Remcos RAT Delivered via Visual Basic
Remcos RAT is leveraging new tactics in recent campaigns. Malwarebytes published a blog post detailing the new behaviors being observed.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type** : RAT

  *  **Associated Threat Actors** : Unknown

  *  **Associated Payloads** : Remcos ([S0332](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332/))

  *  **Initial Infection Vector** : Finance-themed malspam ([T1566.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/001/))

  *  **Post-Compromise Actions** : Remote control, steal sensitive information

  *  **Additional TTPs** : PowerShell Scripts ([T1059.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001/)) Visual Basic Scripts ([T1059.005](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/005/)), Registry Run Keys/Startup Folder ([T1547.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1547/001/)), communication with Non-Standard Port ([T1571](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1571)), payloads hosted on Archive.org ([T1102](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1102/)), payload injected into aspnet_compiler.exe ([T1055.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055/002/))




# Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post detailing the most recent tactics being used by the Remcos RAT. The threat actors are still leveraging ZIP and IMG attachments on financially-themed malspam emails as an initial infection vector. These archives, however, now contain a Visual Basic script instead of an executable file. This script kicks off an infection chain that involves multiple stages of PowerShell downloading and executing additional obfuscated VB scripts. The final script is responsible for injecting an embedded PE file into aspnet_compiler.exe. The executable is the Remcos RAT, which provides its operator with the ability to fully control the victim system and steal sensitive information. The various Visual Basic scripts were all hosted on the legitimate Archive.org to evade detection. Additionally, all samples of the final payload called back to an IP address and port, but no C2 communication was observed. For more information, see the Malwarebyes blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-analysis/2021/07/remcos-rat-delivered-via-visual-basic/>

Tell me everything you know the following threat: Fairfax County Public Schools Targeted in Ransomware Attack
Breach / Leak Notification: Fairfax County Public Schools (FCPS) issued a statement regarding the discovery of ransomware on some of its systems. A report from Bleeping Computer notes that the Maze ransomware operators have claimed responsibility for the attack and have posted data they allege is from FCPS.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

  
"FCPS recently learned that ransomware was placed on some of our technology systems. We are taking this matter very seriously and are working diligently to address the issue. We currently believe we may have been victimized by cyber criminals who have been connected to dozens of ransomware attacks in other school systems and corporations worldwide. We are coordinating with the FBI on the matter."

# Reference

  * <https://www.fcps.edu/blog/fcps-statement-ransomware-investigation>

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/fairfax-county-schools-hit-by-maze-ransomware-student-data-leaked/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Cuba Ransomware Updates Analyzed
Trend Micro has analyzed Cuba ransomware and published the analysis in a new article. Their research shows that the malware is being continually developed, with new variants being seen almost monthly.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Ransomware
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
* **Associated Payloads:** Cuba Ransomware (S0625)
* **Targets:** Unknown
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encryption, Data Theft
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Cuba ransomware was first detected in February 2020 and has regularly resurfaced since then with new updates. Trend Micro has reported that the threat group has started using a custom downloader called BUGHATCH to install the ransomware. The newest variant contains changes allowing the ransomware to terminate a wide range of processes relating to databases and storage. It is also optimized to speed up its execution and provide technical support to compliant victims who want to negotiate. The new variant has expanded its whitelisted directories and file extensions to avoid impacting the underlying operating system. Looking at the updated ransom note, it appears that the threat group are moving towards a double extortion model as it includes a specific threat that wasn't there in samples from March 2022. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/f/cuba-ransomware-group-s-new-variant-found-using-optimized-infect.html>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
   T1059.001 - PowerShell  
   T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
 T1106 - Native API  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1543 - Create or Modify System Process  
   T1543.003 - Windows Service  

**Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
 T1134 - Access Token Manipulation  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
   T1027.002 - Software Packing  
 T1036 - Masquerading  
   T1036.005 - Match Legitimate Name or Location  
 T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
   T1070.004 - File Deletion  
 T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
   T1564.003 - Hidden Window  
 T1620 - Reflective Code Loading  

**Credential Access - TA0006**  
 T1056 - Input Capture  
   T1056.001 - Keylogging  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1007 - System Service Discovery  
 T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
 T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  
 T1057 - Process Discovery  
 T1082 - System Information Discovery  
 T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
 T1135 - Network Share Discovery  
 T1614 - System Location Discovery  
   T1614.001 - System Language Discovery  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  

**Impact - TA0040**  
 T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
 T1489 - Service Stop  

#### Mitigations:

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1015:**  Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1029:**  Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
**M1030:**  Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1039:**  Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1041:**  Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1053:**  Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.

Breach / Leak Notifications: Hot wallets belonging to ETERBASE Exchange were compromised, and approximately $5.4 million was stolen.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

Breach, Compromise

# Overview

ETERBASE Exchange's hot wallets were compromised, they announced. Approximately 5.4 million dollars in assets were stolen as a result. As such, they have created new wallets and their addresses can be found in the links in the Reference section. The appropriate law enforcement agencies have been notified and a security audit begun. Upon completion of the audit, they will resume operations.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: QRadar SIEM Security Bulletin Addresses Apache ZooKeeper Information Disclosure Vulnerability
A Security Bulletin for IBM QRadar SIEM addresses an information disclosure vulnerability in the version of Apache ZooKeeper distributed with QRadar.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
A vulnerability, CVE-2019-0201, in the version of Apache ZooKeeper distributed with QRadar could potentially allow a remote attacker to obtain sensitive information. The vulnerability is caused by the failure of the getACL() command to check certain permissions and can be exploited using a specially-crafted request. Further details, including affected versions and updates, are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/30769839/QRadar%20SIEM%20Security%20Bulletin%20Addresses%20Apache%20ZooKeeper%20Information%20Disclosure%20Vulnerability%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1600833371696&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/6335235>

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
A vulnerability, CVE-2019-0201, in the version of Apache ZooKeeper distributed with QRadar could potentially allow a remote attacker to obtain sensitive information. The vulnerability is caused by the failure of the getACL() command to check certain permissions and can be exploited using a specially-crafted request. Further details, including affected versions and updates, are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/30769839/QRadar%20SIEM%20Security%20Bulletin%20Addresses%20Apache%20ZooKeeper%20Information%20Disclosure%20Vulnerability%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1600833371696&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/6335235>

I have encountered the following information: Active CVE-2020-0688 Exploit Affects Over 247,000 Microsoft Exchange Servers
A vulnerability, CVE-2020-0688, patched in February of 2020, is being actively exploited. This Microsoft Exchange Server remote code execution vulnerability could affect more than 247,000 unpatched systems on the Internet, BleepingComputer warns.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

BleepingComputer warns that over 247,000 Microsoft Exchange Servers on the Internet have not had the February update to address a remote code execution vulnerability, CVE-2020-0688. The issues resides in the Exchange Control Panel code, which is enabled by default, and could allow an attacker to gain control of the server if successfully exploited. In a survey of Exchange servers on the Internet, Rapid7 found 405,873 Exchange servers with 61% (247,986) still vulnerable to CVE-2020-0688. They also discovered 16,577 Exchange 2007 servers, which are no longer being supported by Microsoft, that were vulnerable as well. For more details, refer to the links in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/30771017/Active%20CVE-2020-0688%20Exploit%20Affects%20Over%20247%2C000%20Microsoft%20Exchange%20Servers%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1601476091435&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Features Of Hive Ransomware VMware Encryptor
Bleeping Computer has reported on an analysis of the new Hive ransomware encryptor for VMware ESXi Linux. They have switched to the Rust programming language and have added features to make it more evasive.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Hive Ransomware
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Hive VMware ESXi Linux encryptor.
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encryption and Extortion



# Overview

As Businesses become more reliant on virtual machines, threat actors have been targeting these in their ransomware operations. Bleeping Computer has reported on some developments in Hive ransomware's VMware ESXi Linux encryptor. Although this encryptor has been in use for some time, they have recently updated it with features seen previously in the BlackCat ransomware operation. The main change is the attempt to make ransom negotiations private. This works by making the negotiation URL something that is passed as a command-line argument when executed, meaning the URL is harder to discover by researchers who may be tracking ransomware on open source sandboxes such as VirusTotal. They have also switched to using the Rust programming language, making it more difficult to reverse engineer. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/hive-ransomware-ports-its-linux-vmware-esxi-encryptor-to-rust/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Same Group Developed Defray777, PyXie, and Vatet Malwares
The Defray777 ransomware, PyXie RAT, and Vatet loader all have something in common according to a report from Palo Alto's Unit 42. Analysis suggests that all three malwares were created and maintained by the threat group known as PyXie and GOLD DUPONT.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

The threat group known as as PyXie and GOLD DUPONT have, according to Palo Alto's Unit 42, been operating since at least 2018. The analysis carried out by Unit 42 suggests that the group developed and maintain the three malware families known as Defray777 ransomware, PyXie RAT, and Vatet loader. The group is reportedly financially motivated and known to have carried out ransomware attacks on organizations in the education, government, healthcare, and technology sectors. In some instances, the group obtained their initial foothold in a victim organization using the well known IcedID or Trickbot banking Trojans. The Vatet loader is used to deliver payloads including PyXie and Cobalt Strike. A version of PyXie Unit 42 refer to as PyXie Lite is used for reconnaissance and to exfiltrate potentially sensitive files from within a victim organization. And lastly, the Defray777 ransomware is executed and traces of the malwares are removed from the system. The group has also developed a Linux port of Defray777, which Unit 42 notes is the first time this has been observed in the world of targeted ransomware. The entire report from Palo Alto is spread over five URLs and provides a detailed technical analysis, as well as IoCs. All pages are linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/vatet-pyxie-defray777/>
  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/vatet-pyxie-defray777/2>
  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/vatet-pyxie-defray777/3>
  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/vatet-pyxie-defray777/4>
  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/vatet-pyxie-defray777/5>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: z0Miner Exploiting ElasticSearch and Jenkins Vulnerabilities
While investigating active botnet mining attacks, 360 Netlab discovered a change in the vulnerabilities exploited by z0Miner for spreading.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet, Cryptomining




# Overview

360 Netlab published a blog post about recent development in z0Miner, a malicious mining family that appeared on the scene last year. When it was initially discovered, the botnet was spreading by exploiting a WebLogic unauthorized remote command execution vulnerability. The most recent attacks, however, exploit remote command execution vulnerabilities in ElasticSearch and Jenkins, both vulnerabilities are from 2015. Regardless of the exact vulnerability exploited, it results in a .txt file being downloaded from a remote server and executed as a shell script. Once executed, competing mining processes are killed. Then cron tasks are created that will download and execute malicious scripts from Pastebin. Currently, the discovered Pastebin URLs point to a script with only an "exit" command, but these can easily be edited to include malicious commands. Lastly, the mining payloads are downloaded and executed. This includes a config file, the miner itself, and a shell script to execute the miner. Monero is the cryptocurrency being mined in this case. For more information, see the 360 Netlab blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/threat-alert-z0miner-is-spreading-quickly-by-exploiting-elasticsearch-and-jenkins-vulnerabilities/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: McAfee Security Bulletin - February 16th, 2021
McAfee has published a security bulletin addressing a critical privilege escalation vulnerability in Web Gateway.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: McAfee Security Bulletin - February 16th, 2021
McAfee has published a security bulletin addressing a critical privilege escalation vulnerability in Web Gateway.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

McAfee has published a security bulletin addressing a critical privilege escalation vulnerability in McAfee Web Gateway (MWG). This vulnerability, CVE-2021-23885, has been given a CVSSv3 base score of 9.0. In order to exploit the vulnerability, an attacker must have authenticated access to the MWG web interface. If successfully exploited, an improper neutralization of user input issue may allow the authenticated attacker to execute commands with elevated privileges. Proof of concept code that exploits the vulnerability is known to exist. McAfee has released an update to Web Gateway that fixes this issue. We recommend reviewing the security advisory linked to in the Reference section and applying any applicable updates as soon as possible.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-23885




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * [https://kc.mcafee.com/corporate/index?page=content&id=SB10349&](https://kc.mcafee.com/corporate/index?page=content&id=SB10349&)

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Skimmers Being Spread By Cloud Video Platform
Palo Alto has published a report analyzing a skimmer that is being hosted by a cloud video platform. When the video is used by a site, it becomes infected with the skimmer. The skimmer is currently affecting over 100 real estate websites.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Skimmers Being Spread By Cloud Video Platform
Palo Alto has published a report analyzing a skimmer that is being hosted by a cloud video platform. When the video is used by a site, it becomes infected with the skimmer. The skimmer is currently affecting over 100 real estate websites.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Skimmer
  *  **Targets:** Real Estate Sites
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown **  
**
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Supply Chain Attack
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Personal Information Theft
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Palo Alto researchers have discovered a skimmer attack that is affecting over 100 real estate sites. They have determined that the source of this attack was a supply chain attack, where the attackers have leveraged a cloud video platform to allow them to reach a greater number of victims. The attackers injected malicious JavaScript into a specific video hosted on the cloud platform. Any site importing this video will also be infected, without the attackers having to perform any further attacks. The researchers also observed the attackers modify the script and re-upload it, which was then propagated to all previously infected sites. This is far more efficient than manually updating the skimmer on each site. The researchers retrieved the code from a compromised site and found that it was highly obfuscated to deter manual code analysis. Furthermore, the script includes code to detect if the code is being debugged and stops if the browser console is open. The end goal of this script is to steal any entered personal details such as names, emails, phone numbers, and credit card details and send them to a collection server. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056799/Skimmers%20Being%20Spread%20By%20Cloud%20Video%20Platform%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641899384488&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021)
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 



# References

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/web-skimmer-video-distribution/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1584.006 - Web Services  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1195 - Supply Chain Compromise  
T1195.002 - Compromise Software Supply Chain  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.003 - Web Portal Capture

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Xen Security Advisories February 16 2021
Five security advisories have been published for Xen. The most serious vulnerability addressed in the advisories could potentially allow for privilege escalation..
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Five security advisories have been published for Xen. The most serious vulnerability addressed in the advisories could potentially allow for privilege escalation. Other potential impacts include denial or service conditions, that in some cases can affect the host system, and information disclosure. The advisories are summarized below, and further information is available from their links.

 **Xen Security Advisory CVE-2021-26930 / XSA-365**  
Linux: error handling issues in blkback's grant mapping   
Impact: A malicious or buggy frontend driver may be able to crash the corresponding backend driver, potentially affecting the entire domain running the backend driver. In configurations without driver domains or similar disaggregation, that is a host-wide denial of service. Privilege escalation and information leaks cannot be ruled out.  
<https://xenbits.xen.org/xsa/advisory-365.html>

 **Xen Security Advisory CVE-2021-26933 / XSA-364**  
arm: The cache may not be cleaned for newly allocated scrubbed pages  
Impact: A malicious guest may be able to read sensitive data from memory that previously belonged to another guest.  
<https://xenbits.xen.org/xsa/advisory-364.html>

 **Xen Security Advisory CVE-2021-26934 / XSA-363**  
Linux: display frontend "be-alloc" mode is unsupported  
Impact: Use of the feature may have unknown effects.  
<https://xenbits.xen.org/xsa/advisory-363.html>

 **Xen Security Advisory CVE-2021-26931 / XSA-362**  
Linux: backends treating grant mapping errors as bugs  
Impact: A malicious or buggy frontend driver may be able to crash the corresponding backend driver, potentially affecting the entire domain running the backend driver.  
<https://xenbits.xen.org/xsa/advisory-362.html>

 **Xen Security Advisory CVE-2021-26932 / XSA-361**  
Linux: grant mapping error handling issues  
Impact: A malicious or buggy frontend driver may be able to crash the corresponding backend driver, causing a denial of service potentially affecting the entire domain running the backend driver. A malicious or buggy frontend driver may be able to cause resource leaks in the domain running the corresponding backend driver, leading to a denial of service.  
<https://xenbits.xen.org/xsa/advisory-361.html>

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/40993508/Xen%20Security%20Advisories%20February%2016%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1613538069743&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://xenbits.xen.org/xsa/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Malware uses Windows Subsystem for Linux In New Attack Chain
Quickheal has published an analysis of malware using a new attack chain targeting the Windows Subsystem for Linux.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Windows Machines
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

Quickheal researchers have discovered a new attack chain that exploits the Windows Subsystem for Linux. The Windows Subsystem for Linux allows users to run Linux commands on a Windows computer. In the new attack chain, the attackers use Python 3 to write scripts that are converted into an ELF executable. The files act as a loader where the payload can be embedded in the sample or downloaded from a remote server. An actor can use this method to gain a foothold on a compromised machine. The ELF loader comes in two flavors: one that is entirely written in Python, and another that utilizes Python to call many Windows APIs and launches a PowerShell script to do additional tasks on the host machine. Lightweight payloads built by an open-source tool like Meterpreter were included in several of the examples. Another iteration of the "ELF to Windows" loader used PowerShell to inject and run the shellcode. One of these samples utilized Python to execute functions that terminated the antivirus software, established system persistence, and ran a PowerShell script every 20 seconds. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70221861/Malware%20uses%20Windows%20Subsystem%20for%20Linux%20In%20New%20Attack%20Chain%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636034597577&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).
  * When PowerShell is necessary, restrict PowerShell execution policy to administrators. Be aware that there are methods of bypassing the PowerShell execution policy, depending on environment configuration (M1026).



# References

  * <https://blogs.quickheal.com/stay-alert-malware-authors-deploy-elf-as-windows-loaders-to-exploit-wsl-feature/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.006 - Python

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Cryptominer Exploiting ProxyLogon
The ProxyLogon vulnerability affecting Microsoft Exchange has been exploited for a wide variety of purposes. A report by Sophos details the case of a cryptominer spreading via exploitation of this vulnerability.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptominer, Exploit




# Overview

Sophos has published a blog post analyzing a cryptominer spreading via the ProxyLogon exploit. The payload being distributed is itself hosted on a vulnerable Microsoft Exchange server. The infection chain begins with the attackers exploiting ProxyLogon in order to execute a PowerShell command. This PowerShell command downloads and executes a batch script masquerading as a ZIP archive. The batch script, in turn, uses certutil to download two files hosted on the same server, a base64-encoded executable and a .dat file. The decoded executable extracts the miner and its configuration from the .dat file, injects it into a system process, and then deletes the downloaded files, leaving the miner running in memory only. The miner in use is xmr-stack and is capable of mining Monero. The Monero blockchain indicates that the wallet has been receiving funds with fluctuations due to patching of servers followed by further infections on other servers. For more information, see the Sophos blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/04/13/compromised-exchange-server-hosting-cryptojacker-targeting-other-exchange-servers/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: OnePercent Group Ransomware IoCs
The FBI has issued a FLASH with coordination from DHS-CISA. The FBI has identified that the OnePercent Group has been using Cobalt Strike to distribute ransomware against US companies since November 2020.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: OnePercent Group Ransomware IoCs
The FBI has issued a FLASH with coordination from DHS-CISA. The FBI has identified that the OnePercent Group has been using Cobalt Strike to distribute ransomware against US companies since November 2020.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** US **** Companies
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Not Specified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing Emails with Malicious Zip Files
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Spoofed Phone Calls, Ransom Demands, 
  * **Additional TTPs:** N/A
  *  **Additional Tools Dropped:** Cobalt Strike, IcedID, AWS S3 Cloud, PowerShell, Rclone, Mimikatz, SharpKatz, BetterSafetyKatz, SharpSploit



# Overview

A group known as the OnePercent Group has gained unauthorized access to networks through phishing emails, reports the FBI and DHS-CISA. The phishing emails contain a malicious zip file attachment. The attachment is either a Microsoft Word document or Excel spreadsheet containing macros that allow for the installation of the IcedID banking Trojan. IcedID is then used to install and execute Cobalt Strike on the network for the purposes of lateral movement with PowerShell remoting. Rclone is used for data exfiltration. It has been observed the attacker remains on the victim network for about a month before deploying ransomware. Upon successful deployment, the victim receives phone calls from spoofed numbers with the callers demanding a ransom and are provided with an email address for further communications and negotiation. Other tools employed include AWS S3 cloud, Mimikatz, SharpKatz, BetterSafetyKatz, and SharpSploit. The attacker persistently threatens the release of the stolen data should the ransom not be paid. Further details can be found in the FLASH report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [.txt](/download/attachments/62357994/OnePercent%20Group%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=2&modificationDate=1630004870089&api=v2)



# Recommendations

The following recommendations are from the FBI FLASH report.

  * Back-up critical data offline.

  * Ensure administrators are not using “Admin Approval” mode.

  * Implement Microsoft LAPS, if possible.

  * Ensure copies of critical data are in the cloud or on an external hard drive or storage device. This information should not be accessible from the compromised network.

  * Secure your back-ups and ensure data is not accessible for modification or deletion from the system where the original data resides.

  * Keep computers, devices, and applications patched and up-to-date.

  * Consider adding an email banner to emails received from outside your organization.

  * Disable unused remote access/Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) ports and monitor remote access/RDP logs.

  * Audit user accounts with administrative privileges and configure access controls with least privilege in mind.

  * Implement network segmentation.

  * Use multi-factor authentication with strong passphrases.




# References

  * <https://www.ic3.gov/Media/News/2021/210823.pdf>



# Mitre ATT&CK Framework

 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1040 - Network Sniffing  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
  
 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1591 - Gather Victim Org Information  
T1592 - Gather Victim Host Information  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1595.001 - Scanning IP Blocks  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1072 - Software Deployment Tools  
T1129 - Shared Modules  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1072 - Software Deployment Tools  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Buer Loader Malware-as-a-Service
Ryuk actors appear to be adding a new malware-as-a-service offering to their toolset, the Beur loader. Sophos provides an analysis of this malware and its recent usage in Ryuk campaigns.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Loader




# Overview

Sophos has published a blog post analyzing the Beur loader and its recent appearance in Ryuk campaigns. This loader is offered as malware-as-a-service that offers payloads, C2 hosting, and technical support, as advertised in forum posts. A C2 panel provided by the service allows attackers to deliver files to endpoints and track their successful infections with details about each host. The specific infection chain that the Sophos article focuses on is that observed as part of Ryuk campaigns. The infection chain is relatively similar to those using Emotet or Trickbot's Bazar loader for access instead. A spear phishing email provides a link to a file hosted on a legitimate cloud storage platform, such as Google Docs or Constant Contact. If a user opens the downloaded file, a macro drops an executable on the system. This executable is the packed installer for the Beur loader payload. Once installed, if it passes anti-analysis and regional checks, the loader establishes communication with its C2 server. From this point the attacker can deliver further payloads to the victim system. The Ryuk operators used the loader to first deliver a Cobalt Strike beacon, which, in turn, was used deliver the final ransomware payload. Similar emails that appear to be a part of the same campaign were seen delivering Bazar or ZLoader instead, both of which have been used in Ryuk attacks in the past. For more information, see the Sophos blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2020/10/28/hacks-for-sale-inside-the-buer-loader-malware-as-a-service/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Doki - How it Prevents Another Cryptominer from Operating
Doki is a backdoor installed through exploiting the Docker API with the goal of mining cryptocurrency. While only recently discovered, the Doki malware can be traced to as early as June 2019, according to a report from Lacework that focuses on Doki's activities to prevent a cryptomining competitor, Kinsing, from operating on the same hosts.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

A report from Lacework looks at the Doki malware, a backdoor that is installed through exploiting the Docker API. Doki was first publicized in late July 2020. Since being reported, Lacework has traced samples of Doki back as early as June 2019. Doki is a backdoor used to install a cryptomining package. The Lacework report focuses on the techniques used by Doki in an effort to prevent a cryptomining competitor named Kinsing from being able to mine currency on the same host by attempting to block IP addresses used by Kinsing. Rather than blocking individual IP addresses, Doki typically blocks address ranges such as /22 and /24. The blocking of ranges, instead of single IP addresses may be due to Doki's operators being aware of activity from multiple addresses in the blocked ranges. Kinsing itself typically targets the Docker API, the F5 vulnerability CVE-2020-5092, Redis, and SaltStack. The operators behind other cryptomining operations also target Kinsing, though more typically by killing processes using "pkill". Further details are available from the article linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.    




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.lacework.com/doki-dukes-kinsing/>
