instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Agent Tesla and IcedID Being Distributed in New Malspam Campaigns
A report from Rewterz advises of two new malspam campaigns. One campaign is distributing the well known info-stealing malware, Agent Tesla. The other campaign is distributing the IcedID banking Trojan.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

A malspam campaign is targeting users in Italy according to a report from Rewterz. The emails pretend to be purchase orders and have an attached .DAT file. An executable file is contained within the .DAT file which, if executed, will result in the installation of Agent Tesla. The report also covers a second campaign which uses a document file contained in a zip archive to deliver the IcedID banking Trojan. The document uses an AutoOpen macro to download the next stage of the infection chain. According to the report, the domain that is hosting the second stage, appears to be generated randomly. The emails in this campaign contain very little text but purport to be related to an overdue payment. No information on the geographies being targeted in this campaign have been provided. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.rewterz.com/rewterz-news/rewterz-threat-alert-agent-tesla-and-icedid-banking-trojan-malspam-campaigns>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: FIN7 Recruiting Unsuspecting IT Specialists Via New Fake Company
The cybercriminal group known as FIN7 has been discovered by Gemini Advisory as using a fake company named “Bastion Secure”. Using this company they have posed as a legitimate cybersecurity software company in order to recruit IT specialists and pay them a lower wage in post-Soviet states than they would pay them if they were knowingly participating in the cybercriminal activity that FIN7 has them doing.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** APT, Ransomware, Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Unknown, REvil, Ryuk
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing Attachment (T1566.001)
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Ransomware Deployment
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.
  *  **Leak Site:** N/A



# Overview

Gemini Advisory, a Recorded Future Company, has discovered that the cybercriminal group known as FIN7 has created a fake company named “Bastion Secure”. Using this company they have posed as a legitimate cybersecurity software company in order to recruit IT specialists and pay them a lower wage in post-Soviet states than they would pay them if they were knowingly participating in the cybercriminal activity that FIN7 has them doing. A Gemini source who was offered a position as an IT specialist at Bastion Secure Ltd was able to analyze the tools provided by Bastion Secure and found they are components of the post-exploitation toolkits Carbanak and Lizar/Tirion, both having been previously attributed to the FIN7 group. Further information is available from the links in the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 
  * Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing (M1045). 
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://geminiadvisory.io/fin7-ransomware-bastion-secure/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: APT41 Back as Earth Baku and New Campaign
APT41 is back with a new name and cyberespionage campaign, according to a report from Trend Micro. Tracked by IBM as hive0088, this group is also known as Barium, Winnti, Wicked Panda, as well as other suspected names.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Cyberespionage




# Overview

APT41 has resurfaced as Earth Baku along with a new cyberespionage campaign. The campaign can be traced back as far as July 2020. Using attack vectors designed to exploit different infrastructures, the group is using SQL injection to upload malicious files, installing through InstallUtil.exe using a scheduled task, a possible malicious link file in an email attachment, and exploiting the ProxyLogon vulnerability (CVE-2021-26855) to upload the China Chopper web shell. In addition to the above, the campaign is using unidentified shellcode loaders named StealthVector and StealthMutant, as well as a backdoor called ScrambleCross. These tools, developed by Earth Baku, are used to facilitate targeted attacks on entities in specific industries within the Indo-Pacific region. Countries affected include India, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Vietnam. StealthVector is a shellcode loader designed to be configurable for the threat actor's needs including disabling Event Tracing for Windows allowing for stealth mode execution. StealthMutant uses AES-256-ECB for decryption, whereas an earlier version uses XOR. This allows StealthMutant to perform process hollowing for execution remotely. ScrambleCross is a newly discovered backdoor. Instructions are received from a C2 server that allows it to receive and change plug-ins. The researchers have yet to obtain a plug-in to study. In addition to the tools mentioned, both StealthVector and StealthMutant contain a payload for Cobalt Strike beacons. Further details can be found in the links located within the Reference section below as well as a MITRE ATT&CK framework table. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/h/apt41-resurfaces-as-earth-baku-with-new-cyberespionage-campaign.html>

  * <https://documents.trendmicro.com/assets/white_papers/wp-earth-baku-an-apt-group-targeting-indo-pacific-countries.pdf>



# Mitre ATT&CK Framework

 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1036.003 - Rename System Utilities  
T1218.004 - InstallUtil  
T1562.006 - Indicator Blocking  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1569.002 - Service Execution  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1071.004 - DNS  
T1090.004 - Domain Fronting  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment

output:

Microsoft released a security update for its Chromium-based Edge browser that addresses six CVE-numbered vulnerabilities.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

A security update for Microsoft's Chromium-based Edge browser has been released. Six CVE-numbered vulnerabilities are addressed in the update. The most serious of the vulnerabilities, if successfully exploited, could potentially allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on an affected system. Further details are available from the links in the Reference section below.

Tell me about the following threat: CISA Alert AA20-258A
Observations of the Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) cyber threat actors reveal the use of public information source and well-known TTPs, states CISA in a new alert (AA20-258A).

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: CISA Alert AA20-258A
Observations of the Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) cyber threat actors reveal the use of public information source and well-known TTPs, states CISA in a new alert (AA20-258A).

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability, Cyber Threat




# Overview

The Cybersecurity and Information Security Agency has issued an alert detailing the suspected actions of Chinese Ministry of State Security-affiliated cyber threat actors. These actors are using publicly available information and well-known TTPs in order to target U.S. government agencies. Additionally, the actors use easily obtained exploit kits to infiltrate target networks. In addition to the targeting of the U.S. Government, the actors have also been observed targeting various other industries including high-tech manufacturing, medical devices, civil and industrial engineering, business, education, gaming software, and others. Through the use of open-source tools, it is suspected the actors have low-complexity capabilities. The actors have been mostly successful in the infiltration of networks that are misconfigured or have a weak password management profile. Further information can be found in the alert listed within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/30769168/CISA%20Alert%20AA20-258A%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1600107390523&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa20-258a>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: An Analysis of the YourCyanide Ransomware
Trend Micro has published an analysis of the YourCyanide ransomware, a variant of the ransomware family that began with GonnaCope which first appeared in April 2022.
output:
Summary
=======



Attack Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Ransomware
* **Malware Family/Families:** YourCyanide
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious LNK file
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Encrypt Data
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

The YourCyanide ransomware is a variant of a ransomware family that started with GonnaCope in April 2022 and is still under development. Three variants were released in May, Kekpop, Kekware, and YourCyanide. Trend Micro has published an analysis of YourCyanide that describes it as sophisticated. Its download routine includes the utilizing of Discord, Microsoft document links, and Pastebin. The first stage of the infection chain is an LNK file that contains PowerShell code that downloads and executes a file from Discord that in turn creates and executes a CMD file. The CMD file downloads and executes a heavily obfuscated CMD script from Pastebin. This file carries out a number of operations including creating a registry entry for persistence, attempting to add a user to the Administrators group, disabling Task Manager, terminating certain services and security applications, and enabling RDP. It also checks the machine for certain usernames used by malware researchers and sandbox systems that are to be avoided. YourCyanide can also move laterally by sending emails containing itself as an attachment and copying itself to other drives and directories. Several other files are also downloaded and executed throughout the attack. Of note, is that files are not encrypted and instead are just renamed. A ransom note is left on the system and the report also notes that all users in the compromised network may be messaged with a warning. Collected data and system information are exfiltrated using Telegram. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/f/yourcyanide-a-cmd-based-ransomware.html>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Resource Development - TA0042**  
 T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
   T1587.001 - Malware  
 T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
   T1608.001 - Upload Malware  

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
   T1059.001 - PowerShell  
   T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
 T1204 - User Execution  
   T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
   T1204.002 - Malicious File  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
   T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
 T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
   T1070.004 - File Deletion  
 T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
 T1222 - File and Directory Permissions Modification  
 T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
   T1497.001 - System Checks  
 T1562 - Impair Defenses  
   T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
   T1562.004 - Disable or Modify System Firewall  
 T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
   T1564.001 - Hidden Files and Directories  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1082 - System Information Discovery  

**Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
 T1534 - Internal Spearphishing  
 T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer  

**Collection - TA0009**  
 T1005 - Data from Local System  
 T1074 - Data Staged  
   T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
 T1560 - Archive Collected Data  

**Exfiltration - TA0010**  
 T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service  

**Impact - TA0040**  
 T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery  

**Mitigations:**

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1025:**  Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1029:**  Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1039:**  Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1041:**  Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1043:**  Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
**M1044:**  Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1053:**  Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Malicious Excel File Uses VBA and Excel4 Macros to Deliver Qakbot
An entry in the ISC Incident Handler's Diary provides an analysis of a malicious Excel file that uses both VBA and Excel4 macros.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Malicious Excel File Uses VBA and Excel4 Macros to Deliver Qakbot
An entry in the ISC Incident Handler's Diary provides an analysis of a malicious Excel file that uses both VBA and Excel4 macros.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Qakbot
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Excel file.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unspecified
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

There is nothing new in malicious Excel files using either VBA or Excel4 macros to deliver malware. It is a little unusual however to see both macros being used on the same Excel file. An analysis of a malicious Excel file that uses both macros has been published on the ISC Incident Handlers Diary. VBA code in the Excel file creates a new sheet and also injects the Excel4 macro which is used to download a payload named Xertis.dll which is in this case, the Qakbot Trojan. Further information is available from the link in the reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64128738/Malicious%20Excel%20File%20Uses%20VBA%20and%20Excel4%20Macros%20to%20Deliver%20Qakbot%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632803783139&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://isc.sans.edu/diary/rss/27864>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Targeting of Comm Apps Continues
The targeting of communication applications such as Zoom, Slack, and Discord continues as the COVID-19 pandemic rages on. Trend Micro posted a blog about the continuance of attacks on the Work-from-From home crowd.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

Given the continuing battle against COVID-19, threat actors have consistently attacked communication platforms used by the work-from-home crowd. Zoom attacks have been the most popular with the platform being the most used since the start of the pandemic. WFH users rely on the platform for meetings, collaboration, and communication with closing of many office spaces in an effort to prevent the spread of the virus. Known as "Zoombombing," pranksters will crash a meeting and perform actions not deemed appropriate for the setting. These actions can include but are not limited to displaying pornographic images and videos or being disruptive to the environment. This type of behavior is typically harmless, however, some threat actors have taken to using fake Zoom installers in an effort to implant malware onto unsuspecting victim's computers. Bots such as Devil Shadow Botnet and backdoors have been found within these installers. These fake applications can cause the user's machine to perform unintended actions or allow backdoor access to the machine. Additionally, they execute operator commands, add or delete files, log keystrokes, and gather information from a victim system. One such malware, ZAPIZ, comes bundled with a legitimate Zoom installer, however, the malicious application included will perform a variety of actions. A sextortion email based on a supposed Zoom recording was also observed. Slack and Discord face similar issues with actors using tactics to disrupt communications. A ransomware variant (Crypren) encrypts files of various types. Utilizing Slack's Webhooks, the encryption of the victim's files is reported back to the C2 server. This is a yet unseen tactic in the ransomware world. Discord is being exploited through the use of spam campaigns that contain AveMaria or AgentTesla malwares. These emails typically resemble postal delivery notifications or invoices as attachments. Additionally, the emails contain embedded links to a Discord URL. Further information can be found in the links located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/vinfo/us/security/news/cybercrime-and-digital-threats/malicious-actors-target-comm-apps-such-as-zoom-slack-discord>

  * [https://blog.trendmicro.com/trendlabs-security-intelligence/backdoor-devil-shadow-botnet-hidden-in-fake-zoom-installers/](https://blog.trendmicro.com/trendlabs-security-intelligence/backdoor-devil-shadow-botnet-hidden-in-fake-zoom-installers/?_ga=2.36779232.1957473346.1605543013-1783250011.1605543013)

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Targeting of Comm Apps Continues
The targeting of communication applications such as Zoom, Slack, and Discord continues as the COVID-19 pandemic rages on. Trend Micro posted a blog about the continuance of attacks on the Work-from-From home crowd.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

Given the continuing battle against COVID-19, threat actors have consistently attacked communication platforms used by the work-from-home crowd. Zoom attacks have been the most popular with the platform being the most used since the start of the pandemic. WFH users rely on the platform for meetings, collaboration, and communication with closing of many office spaces in an effort to prevent the spread of the virus. Known as "Zoombombing," pranksters will crash a meeting and perform actions not deemed appropriate for the setting. These actions can include but are not limited to displaying pornographic images and videos or being disruptive to the environment. This type of behavior is typically harmless, however, some threat actors have taken to using fake Zoom installers in an effort to implant malware onto unsuspecting victim's computers. Bots such as Devil Shadow Botnet and backdoors have been found within these installers. These fake applications can cause the user's machine to perform unintended actions or allow backdoor access to the machine. Additionally, they execute operator commands, add or delete files, log keystrokes, and gather information from a victim system. One such malware, ZAPIZ, comes bundled with a legitimate Zoom installer, however, the malicious application included will perform a variety of actions. A sextortion email based on a supposed Zoom recording was also observed. Slack and Discord face similar issues with actors using tactics to disrupt communications. A ransomware variant (Crypren) encrypts files of various types. Utilizing Slack's Webhooks, the encryption of the victim's files is reported back to the C2 server. This is a yet unseen tactic in the ransomware world. Discord is being exploited through the use of spam campaigns that contain AveMaria or AgentTesla malwares. These emails typically resemble postal delivery notifications or invoices as attachments. Additionally, the emails contain embedded links to a Discord URL. Further information can be found in the links located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/vinfo/us/security/news/cybercrime-and-digital-threats/malicious-actors-target-comm-apps-such-as-zoom-slack-discord>

  * [https://blog.trendmicro.com/trendlabs-security-intelligence/backdoor-devil-shadow-botnet-hidden-in-fake-zoom-installers/](https://blog.trendmicro.com/trendlabs-security-intelligence/backdoor-devil-shadow-botnet-hidden-in-fake-zoom-installers/?_ga=2.36779232.1957473346.1605543013-1783250011.1605543013)

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: The Warsaw Banking Trojan and Horus Eyes RAT
A posting on the Seguranca-Informática blog provides an analysis of a Latin American banking Trojan named Warsaw, and its second stage payload, the Horus Eyes RAT.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: The Warsaw Banking Trojan and Horus Eyes RAT
A posting on the Seguranca-Informática blog provides an analysis of a Latin American banking Trojan named Warsaw, and its second stage payload, the Horus Eyes RAT.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Banking Trojan, RAT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Warsaw banking Trojan, Horus Eyes RAT
  *  **Targets:** Latin American bank customers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Downloaded executable file, Execution (TA0002, T1204, T1204.001, T1204.002)
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions: Persistence** (TA0003, T1547, T1547.001, T1037.001, T1037.002, T1037.003, T1037.004, T1037.005), **Privilege Escalation** (TA0004, T1055, T1547.001, T1037.001, T1037.002, T1037.003, T1037.004, T1037.005), **Defense Evasion** (TA0005, T1036, T1497, T1562.001, T1055, T1027, T1027.002, T1070.006), **Credential Access** (TA0006, T1003, T1003.001, T1003.002, T1003.003, T1003.005, T1003.006), **Discovery** (TA0007, T1518.001, T1497, T1057, T1018, T1082, T1033, T1040), **Lateral Movement** (TA0008, T1021, T1021.001, T1021.002, T1021.003, T1021.004, T1021.005, T1021.006), **Collection** (TA0009, T1560, T1025, T1039, T1056, T1056.001, T1056.002, T1056.003), **Exfiltration** (TA0010, T1011, T1011.001, T1020, T1029, T1030, T1041, T1048), **Command and Control** (TA0011, T1573, T1095, T1071, T1001.003, T1008)



# Overview

According to a posting on the Seguranca-Informática blog, Warsaw is a new .NET banking Trojan developed in and targeting Latin America. The infection chain begins with a victim downloading an executable file that contains the Warsaw Trojan. Additionally, it downloads and installs a second-stage payload, a customized variant Horus Eyes RAT (source-code available on Github) that provides typical RAT features including the ability to steal credentials. Once installed, Warsaw sends a basic profile of the system to a Telegram bot which notifies the malware's operators that a system has been infected. From that point, the operators can then take control of the system using the Horus Eyes RAT. Horus Eyes connects to the operator's AWS instance using a hard-coded ngrok TCP URL. Few details of the operation on the banking Trojan are provided, however, it is noted that foreground windows are captured by matching the substring “santander”. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/59540820/The%20Warsaw%20Banking%20Trojan%20and%20Horus%20Eyes%20RAT%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1628747380922&api=v2)



# Detection

  * A list of Yara rules can be found here: [ Yara Rules.txt](/download/attachments/59540820/The%20Warsaw%20Banking%20Trojan%20and%20Horus%20Eyes%20RAT%20Yara%20Rules.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1628747396273&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://seguranca-informatica.pt/the-clandestine-horus-eyes-rat-from-the-underground-to-criminals-arsenal/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Emotet Adopts Political and Elections Lures
Continuing their use of current events to social engineer victims, Emotet has pivoted to using political and elections lures. Proofpoint reports on samples from this recent campaign.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Proofpoint identified an Emotet campaign using political and election themes to social engineer recipients. With the U.S. presidential election coming up, users may be more susceptible to this type of messaging. The email body contains text directly copied from the Democratic National Committee's website. Added to the end of the text is a request to open an attached Word document. As is common with Emotet infection chains, this Word document uses malicious macros to download and install Emotet. This campaign is distributing Qbot and Trickbot as secondary payloads. Along with the subject and filename of "Team Blue Take Action," researchers also observed volunteer-themed and other subject and filenames. For more information, see the Proofpoint blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/emotet-makes-timely-adoption-political-and-elections-lures>

I have encountered the following information: IBM QRadar SIEM Security Bulletins - May 2021
IBM has published eight security bulletins that apply to QRadar SIEM. In total, seventeen vulnerabilities are addressed in the bulletins.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 The potential impacts from successful exploitation of the vulnerabilities includes a remote attacker being able to cause denial of service conditions, obtain sensitive data (including session credentials), and execute arbitrary commands or code. The vulnerabilities are present in QRadar versions 7.3.0 to 7.3.3 Patch 7, and 7.4.0 to 7.4.2 Patch 2. We recommend updating to the latest fixed versions at the earliest opportunity. instruction:
I have encountered the following information: NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR21-048G - AppleJeus: Ants2Whale
A Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency malware analysis report, AR21-048G, has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System. The report provides information on the malicious program Ants2Whale, which is associated with AppleJeus, the cyber threat to cryptocurrency posed by North Korea.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

From the Malware Analysis Report (AR21-048G)  
MAR-10322463-7.v1 - AppleJeus: Ants2Whale

This Malware Analysis Report (MAR) is the result of analytic efforts among the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA), and the Department of Treasury (Treasury) to highlight the cyber threat to cryptocurrency posed by North Korea, formally known as the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea (DPRK), and provide mitigation recommendations. Working with U.S. government partners, FBI, CISA, and Treasury assess that Lazarus Group—which these agencies attribute to North Korean state-sponsored advanced persistent threat (APT) actors—is targeting individuals and companies, including cryptocurrency exchanges and financial service companies, through the dissemination of cryptocurrency trading applications that have been modified to include malware that facilitates theft of cryptocurrency.

This MAR highlights this cyber threat posed by North Korea and provides detailed indicators of compromise (IOCs) used by the North Korean government. The U.S. Government refers to malicious cyber activity by the North Korean government as HIDDEN COBRA. For more information on other versions of AppleJeus and recommended steps to mitigate this threat, see Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA21-048A: AppleJeus: Analysis of North Korea's Cryptocurrency Malware at <https://www.us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/AA21-048A>.

There have been multiple versions of AppleJeus malware discovered since its initial discovery in August 2018. In most versions, the malware appears to be from a legitimate-looking cryptocurrency trading company and website, whereby an unsuspecting individual downloads a third-party application from a website that appears legitimate.

The U.S. Government has identified AppleJeus malware version—Ants2Whale—and associated IOCs used by the North Korean government in AppleJeus operations.

Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR21-048G - AppleJeus- Ants2Whale IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/40993596/NCAS%20Malware%20Analysis%20Report%20AR21-048G%20-%20AppleJeus-%20Ants2Whale%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1613626715733&api=v2)
  * IoCs can also be download in STIX format from CISA: <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/sites/default/files/publications/MAR-10322463-7.v1.WHITE_stix.xml>



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-048g>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: NCAS Alert AA21-200A - TTPs of Indicted APT40 Actors
Alert AA21-200A has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System and provides information on APT40’s tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) and indicators of compromise (IOCs).

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

 **From Alert AA21-200A**  
 **Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures of Indicted APT40 Actors Associated with China’s MSS Hainan State Security Department**

This Joint Cybersecurity Advisory was written by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) to provide information on a Chinese Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) group known in open-source reporting as APT40. This advisory provides APT40’s tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) and indicators of compromise (IOCs) to help cybersecurity practitioners identify and remediate APT40 intrusions and established footholds.

APT40—aka BRONZE MOHAWK, FEVERDREAM, G0065, Gadolinium, GreenCrash, Hellsing, Kryptonite Panda, Leviathan, MUDCARP, Periscope, Temp.Periscope, and Temp.Jumper—is located in Haikou, Hainan Province, People’s Republic of China (PRC), and has been active since at least 2009. APT40 has targeted governmental organizations, companies, and universities in a wide range of industries—including biomedical, robotics, and maritime research—across the United States, Canada, Europe, the Middle East, and the South China Sea area, as well as industries included in China’s Belt and Road Initiative.

On July 19, 2021, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) unsealed an indictment against four APT40 cyber actors for their illicit computer network exploitation (CNE) activities via front company Hainan Xiandun Technology Development Company (Hainan Xiandun). Hainan Xiandun employee Wu Shurong cooperated with and carried out orders from PRC Ministry of State Security (MSS) Hainan State Security Department (HSSD) intelligence officers Ding Xiaoyang, Zhu Yunmin, and Cheng Qingmin to conduct CNE. Wu’s CNE activities resulted in the theft of trade secrets, intellectual property, and other high-value information from companies and organizations in the United States and abroad, as well as from multiple foreign governments. These MSS-affiliated actors targeted victims in the following industries: academia, aerospace/aviation, biomedical, defense industrial base, education, government, healthcare, manufacturing, maritime, research institutes, and transportation (rail and shipping).

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 
  * IoCs can also be download in STIX format from CISA: <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/sites/default/files/publications/AA21-200A.stix.xml>



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa21-200a>

This Joint Cybersecurity Advisory was written by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) to provide information on a Chinese Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) group known in open-source reporting as APT40. This advisory provides APT40’s tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) and indicators of compromise (IOCs) to help cybersecurity practitioners identify and remediate APT40 intrusions and established footholds.

APT40—aka BRONZE MOHAWK, FEVERDREAM, G0065, Gadolinium, GreenCrash, Hellsing, Kryptonite Panda, Leviathan, MUDCARP, Periscope, Temp.Periscope, and Temp.Jumper—is located in Haikou, Hainan Province, People’s Republic of China (PRC), and has been active since at least 2009. APT40 has targeted governmental organizations, companies, and universities in a wide range of industries—including biomedical, robotics, and maritime research—across the United States, Canada, Europe, the Middle East, and the South China Sea area, as well as industries included in China’s Belt and Road Initiative.

On July 19, 2021, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) unsealed an indictment against four APT40 cyber actors for their illicit computer network exploitation (CNE) activities via front company Hainan Xiandun Technology Development Company (Hainan Xiandun). Hainan Xiandun employee Wu Shurong cooperated with and carried out orders from PRC Ministry of State Security (MSS) Hainan State Security Department (HSSD) intelligence officers Ding Xiaoyang, Zhu Yunmin, and Cheng Qingmin to conduct CNE. Wu’s CNE activities resulted in the theft of trade secrets, intellectual property, and other high-value information from companies and organizations in the United States and abroad, as well as from multiple foreign governments. These MSS-affiliated actors targeted victims in the following industries: academia, aerospace/aviation, biomedical, defense industrial base, education, government, healthcare, manufacturing, maritime, research institutes, and transportation (rail and shipping).

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 
  * IoCs can also be download in STIX format from CISA: <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/sites/default/files/publications/AA21-200A.stix.xml>



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa21-200a>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Credential Stealing Malware Uses AHK
A credential stealing campaign that mainly uses AHK, an open-source scripting language, has been reported by Trend Micro. The campaign began in early 2020 and has mainly targeted the customers of Canadian and U.S. banks.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Trend Micro discovered a credential stealing campaign that began in early 2020. The campaign has mainly targeted the customers of Canadian and U.S. banks. A malicious Excel file is used to kick off the infection chain by using a VBA AutoOpen macro to drop an AHK script compiler and an AHK script file. AHK is an open-source scripting language that runs on Windows. When the compiler is executed, it runs the script which is a client for downloading and executing further AHK payloads. It is also used for creating persistence by creating an autorun link in the startup folder and profiling the victim system. Commands issued to the malware by its C&C server are downloaded as individual scripts for each task. This means there is no single, large payload on the victim system and allows the operator to create custom commands for victims as required. The malware's primary function is to steal credentials from victims' browsers. The browsers it targets include Edge, Internet Explorer, Chrome, Firefox, and Opera. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/20/l/stealth-credential-stealer-targets-us-canadian-bank-customers.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: PHP Malware Used in Lucky Visitor Scam
Vulnerabilities in content management systems allow attackers to upload malicious code for a variety of purposes. One such case observed by JPCERT/CC involves redirecting users to scam sites or executing various commands.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

JPCERT/CC published a blog post analyzing the use of malicious PHP code injected into vulnerable CMS sites to redirect users to scam sites or execute code. When a user visits one of these compromised CMS sites, an attacker server evaluates the next stage of the attack. Based on the UserAgent, referrer, Accept-Language header, and a UID in the URL path, the malware determines whether the victim should be redirected. If so, they are sent to a scam site, often a "lucky visitor" scam claiming that the recipient has the chance to win a prize. If the criteria for redirection isn't met, a non-malicious page is displayed on the attacker server. The same behavior occurs if a previously observed IP address tries to re-access the server. Additionally, the PHP malware has the capability to issue commands for updating the sitemap.xml, create new pages on the server, create a robots.txt file, or run PHP code via an eval function. For more information, see the JPCERT/CC blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.jpcert.or.jp/en/2021/06/php_malware.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Spear-Phishing Campaign Targets High-Ranking Israeli and US Individuals
Check Point Research has published an article on a new spear-phishing campaign targeting high-profile officials in Israel and the US. The attack involves new techniques involving a false URL shortening site owned by the attackers.
output:
Summary
=======



Attack Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Phishing
* **Target:** Israeli and US Officials
* **Lure:** Hijacked Email Threads
* **Payload:** Credential Stealer Site
* **Compromised Data:** Inbox Credentials
* **Post-compromise Actions:** Unknown
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

Check Point Research has uncovered a phishing campaign against high-profile individuals in the United States and Israel. Rather than sending a malicious attachment or link, the attackers establish a dialogue with their targets using email thread hijacking. The emails come from the compromised account, or from a newly registered account that is formatted to trick victims into believing that it is coming from the legitimate domain. The attackers eventually send a link to a document, which takes the victim to a fake URL shortening site called 'Litby' - a 'bitly' impersonation. The website doesn't have any functionality, but it will redirect victims depending on the full URL they accessed. Each URL path seems specifically tailored for its target, including a personalized final phishing page. The campaign appears to attempt to gain access to the victim's inboxes, focusing on Yahoo inboxes. To get past 2FA, the page asks for the code just as the legitimate site would, and then grants an attacker full access to the victim's inbox. It is speculated that this activity could be connected to an Iranian-backed entity. This is reinforced by the use of a domain that has previously been used by the Iranian APT Phosphorus. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://research.checkpoint.com/2022/check-point-research-exposes-an-iranian-phishing-campaign-targeting-former-israeli-foreign-minister-former-us-ambassador-idf-general-and-defense-industry-executives/>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

#### Tactics and Techniques:

**Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
   T1589.002 - Email Addresses  
   T1589.003 - Employee Names  

**Resource Development - TA0042**  
   T1583.001 - Domains  
   T1586.002 - Email Accounts  

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
   T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  

**Execution - TA0002**  
   T1204.001 - Malicious Link  

**Credential Access - TA0006**  
 T1056 - Input Capture  
   T1056.003 - Web Portal Capture  

#### Mitigations:

**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Cyberpunk 2077 Release Hoax is Actually Data Theft Attempt
A joint analysis effort by Kaspersky and other researchers has revealed a scheme to steal information from users eagerly awaiting the release of a new game.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Cyberpunk 2077 Release Hoax is Actually Data Theft Attempt
A joint analysis effort by Kaspersky and other researchers has revealed a scheme to steal information from users eagerly awaiting the release of a new game.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

With the much anticipated impending release of the PC game Cyberpunk 2077 comes a scam being perpetrated against impatient users. The scam involves the download of a fake installer, which is used to steal data through a series of redirects and phishing pages. When the user visits one of the fake sites, they are presented with the option to download a copy of the game, which, in actuality, is an executable that masquerades as the real game installer. This executable contains legitimate looking splash screens and buttons. Though some buttons are unusable, it's a convincing enough fake that users are clicking on the install link. Once the install link is clicked, a window is displayed that shows the "game" being downloaded and unpacked. The program doesn't actually perform an install action; instead, the program only emulates the install process. From here, the user is presented with the option of entering a license key. Since the game is not yet released, the actors decided to include a link in the installer, which will allow the victim to obtain a key. The link takes the victim to another site that leads to a survey or giveaway entry. A new prompt is displayed asking a set of questions, such as requests for phone number and email addresses. This information, it is hypothesized, is the target data set of the threat actors. The site does provide a key, which has been hard coded into the installer' however, the game will not start as a DLL is missing from the installation. The user would have to click the download button again. They are taken to a dead end site with another survey. More information can be found in the link in the Reference section below. 

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.




# Reference

  * <https://www.kaspersky.com/blog/cyberpunk-2077-scam/37907/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Android Trojans Stealing Facebook Logins
Researchers with Doctor Web uncovered several Android apps on the Google Play store that were Trojanized in order to steal Facebook login credentials.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan




# Overview

Doctor Web published a blog post analyzing a series of Trojanized Android applications designed to steal Facebook login credentials. In total, ten apps were discovered with nine of those present in the Google Play store. The types of apps varied from photo editing tools to device performance utilities and more. All of the apps included legitimate code, allowing them to function as expected and thus decrease the chances of a user getting suspicious. Malicious code was injected into the app, however, to encourage the users to login to the app using Facebook in order to gain full functionality and remove ads. If a user opts to log in to Facebook, the legitimate Facebook login page is loaded, but JavaScript is used to capture and exfiltrate any submitted credentials and cookies. Doctor Web reported their findings to the Google Play store, but at the time of writing some of the apps remain active. For more information, see the Doctor Web blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://news.drweb.com/show/?i=14244>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: WIRTE Phishing Campaign Targets The Middle East
SecureList has discovered a new phishing campaign targeting organizations in the Middle East. This has been attributed to the group known as WIRTE.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: WIRTE Phishing Campaign Targets The Middle East
SecureList has discovered a new phishing campaign targeting organizations in the Middle East. This has been attributed to the group known as WIRTE.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** WIRTE
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Ferocious Dropper, LitePower
  *  **Targets:** Financial institutions, Law firms, Military organizations, and Technology companies mainly in the Middle East. **  
**
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

SecureList researchers have published details of a phishing campaign that is targeting businesses in the middle east. This has been attributed to the lesser-known WIRTE group, which uses relatively simple TTPs to remain undetected for a long time. The campaign starts with spearphishing emails with an attached office document (either Word or Excel). The office documents contain malicious macros to allow the next stage of the attack to continue. Once the user has enabled macros on the document, the macros perform several activities. firstly, the documents perform checks to confirm that it is not running in a sandbox. If these tests pass, the document establishes persistence using the registry and then downloads the next stage of the attack, which is an implant called LitePower. This implant establishes communication with the C2 server and can accept and execute commands sent by the attacker. It can also download and execute further malware at the attacker's discretion. The researchers were able to discover multiple C2 domains used by this malware, with some being hidden behind CloudFlare to conceal the true source domain. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155397/WIRTE%20Phishing%20Campaign%20Targets%20The%20Middle%20East%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638275886794&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction (M1017).
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://securelist.com/wirtes-campaign-in-the-middle-east-living-off-the-land-since-at-least-2019/105044/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** WIRTE
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Ferocious Dropper, LitePower
  *  **Targets:** Financial institutions, Law firms, Military organizations, and Technology companies mainly in the Middle East. **  
**
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

SecureList researchers have published details of a phishing campaign that is targeting businesses in the middle east. This has been attributed to the lesser-known WIRTE group, which uses relatively simple TTPs to remain undetected for a long time. The campaign starts with spearphishing emails with an attached office document (either Word or Excel). The office documents contain malicious macros to allow the next stage of the attack to continue. Once the user has enabled macros on the document, the macros perform several activities. firstly, the documents perform checks to confirm that it is not running in a sandbox. If these tests pass, the document establishes persistence using the registry and then downloads the next stage of the attack, which is an implant called LitePower. This implant establishes communication with the C2 server and can accept and execute commands sent by the attacker. It can also download and execute further malware at the attacker's discretion. The researchers were able to discover multiple C2 domains used by this malware, with some being hidden behind CloudFlare to conceal the true source domain. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155397/WIRTE%20Phishing%20Campaign%20Targets%20The%20Middle%20East%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638275886794&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction (M1017).
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://securelist.com/wirtes-campaign-in-the-middle-east-living-off-the-land-since-at-least-2019/105044/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

I have encountered the following information: South Eastern Asian Government Institutions Targeted By Chinese APT Group
Bitdefender has published a whitepaper on their monitoring of a Chinese APT group that has been targeting South Eastern Asian government institutions since late 2018.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT, Backdoor



# Overview

In a recently published whitepaper, Bitdefender dissects the antics of a Chinese APT group's attacks on South Eastern Asian Government institutions. The paper indicates that these attacks have been going on since at least late 2018. Although proof was not found, Bitdefender suspects that social engineering via spam may be the source of infection. Chinoxy backdoor is first loaded and gains persistence on the infected system. Chinoxy then deploys additional modules, including in some cases, an open source Chinese RAT called PcShare. Lateral movement was also observed to some extent through the uses of credentials. How the credentials were obtained is unknown. System information is gathered through the use of a number of Windows command line tools such as tasklist.exe, ipconfig.exe, among others. Data gathered is sent back to the command and control servers on a daily basis. For a detailed timeline and tool description, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here:

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.bitdefender.com/files/News/CaseStudies/study/379/Bitdefender-Whitepaper-Chinese-APT.pdf>

Breach/Leak Notification: A Bangkok-based hospital suffered a ransomware attack, as reported by the Bangkok Post.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Bangkok Hospital Suffers Ransomware Attack
Breach/Leak Notification: A Bangkok-based hospital suffered a ransomware attack, as reported by the Bangkok Post.

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware, Breach




# Overview

  
Saraburi Hospital suffered a ransomware attack, which, so far, has not resulted in a ransom demand. Dr Anant Kamolnet, director of Saraburi Hospital in Muang district of Saraburi province, said that the "computer system crashed due to a ransomware attack." Patients frequenting the hospital have been advised to bring "welfare cards, copies of referrals, ID cards, medicinal allergy cards, old prescriptions and drugs for reference if visiting the hospital." This lends credibility to the encryption of hospital files. There were initial reports of a 200,000 (about 63 billion baht) Bitcoin demand though that has been debunked by the hospital management. Refer to the article located within the Reference section below for more details. 

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.




# Reference

  * <https://www.bangkokpost.com/thailand/general/1982423/ransomware-attack-on-saraburi-hospital>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: ESXi VMs Targeted by New REvil Linux Ransomware
A new ransomware from REvil is being used to target Linux ESXi virtual machines. Bleeping Computer and other researchers have written about this new malware in a blog and on researchers' Twitter accounts.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: ESXi VMs Targeted by New REvil Linux Ransomware
A new ransomware from REvil is being used to target Linux ESXi virtual machines. Bleeping Computer and other researchers have written about this new malware in a blog and on researchers' Twitter accounts.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

REvil's ransomware operation has released a Linux encryptor for the purpose of encrypting Vmware ESXi virtual machines. By using the current move to virtual machines for backups, the authors of the malware have targeted these systems by releasing the Linux tool in the wild. The group confirmed the addition of the Linux version in May 2021. The executable is an ELF64 file and includes the same options utilized by the Windows version of the executable. Upon execution, the actor is able to specify a path to encrypt as well as enable a silent mode. When the ESXi server is infected and the malware executed, the esxcli command line tool is used to list all ESXi devices and terminate them by closing the VMDK files. If the VM is not closed properly, the files may become corrupted. In targeting machines in this manner, REvil can perform encryption on a number of machines with one command. Other ransomware operators such as Babuk, RansomExx/Defray, Maspinoza, GoGoogle, DarkSide, and HelloKitty have also created similar tools for the purposes of targeting ESXi machines. Further information can be found in the article and twitter links located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/revil-ransomwares-new-linux-encryptor-targets-esxi-virtual-machines/>

  * [https://twitter.com/malwrhunterteam/status/1409577829289934851](https://twitter\[.\]com/malwrhunterteam/status/1409577829289934851)
  * <https://otx.alienvault.com/pulse/60da2c80aa5400db8f1561d5>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Evasive URLs Using Userinfo Subcomponent
Continuing on their research into evasive URLs in spam emails, SpiderLabs reports on URLs leveraging the Userinfo subcomponent to evade detection.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Spiderlabs identified a spam campaign leveraging evasive URLs to avoid detection and eventually install Lokibot. The initial email has a PowerPoint Add-in attachment containing a malicious macro. Closing the file leads to the execution of the macro. The macro, in turn, downloads and executes obfuscated VBScript code from a remote URL using MSHTA. Notably, the URL makes use of a rarely used subcomponent of URLs called "Userinfo." When used in combination with a website that does not support the Userinfo subcomponent, it is completely ignored, allowing attackers to insert random content into the URL without changing the destination. In this case, the Userinfo was appended to a j.mp shortened URL that redirects to the VBScript code hosted on Pastebin. The VBScript writes a Powershell downloader to a Registry Run key for persistence and execution. The PowerShell downloads and executes two binaries from other Pastebin URLs using the same evasion technique as the other URLs. The first executed binary is a DLL that bypasses the AMSI, while the second binary is a DLL injector used to load an obfuscated Lokibot payload hosted on Pastebin into the legitimate notepad.exe process. For more information, see the Trustwave blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trustwave.com/en-us/resources/blogs/spiderlabs-blog/evasive-urls-in-spam-part-2/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Some 1,904 Magento Stores Infected with Skimmer in Four Days
A report from Sansec notes that over a four day period, September 11 through 14, some 1904 Magento stores were infected with skimmers. The stores were compromised in an automated attack.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Skimmer




# Overview

An automated campaign targeting Magento stores, from September 11th through to the 14th, infected 1,904 stores with skimmers. At least some of the stores were running an outdated version of Magento that reached end of support in June 2020. According to the report, while Sansec researchers are still investigating the vector used to compromise the stores, it is speculated that the campaign may be using a 0-day remote code execution exploit that was recently offered for sale. It appears that after a store was compromised, the Magento admin panel and Magento Connect were used to download and install files. The code to load the skimmer was injected in prototype.js which is a legitimate Magento file. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://sansec.io/research/largest-magento-hack-to-date>

Tell me about the following threat: Gamaredon APT Targeting Ukraine with New Variants
The Gamaredon APT actors continue to target the Ukrainian military. A recent report from Cyble provides an analysis of their infection chain along with indicators of compromise.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Gamaredon APT Targeting Ukraine with New Variants
The Gamaredon APT actors continue to target the Ukrainian military. A recent report from Cyble provides an analysis of their infection chain along with indicators of compromise.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

Cyble has published a blog post regarding recent Gamaredon APT activity. The group is continuing their traditional targeting of the Ukrainian military in order to obtain intelligence for pro-Russian agendas. The infection chain is basically the same as previous TTPs for the group but with previously unseen malware samples. The target receives a spear phishing email originating from Russia with a malicious document attached. This document leverages a template injection technique to download secondary payload from a remote server. This payload then provides the capabilities required by the attackers to carry out their espionage activities. As mentioned, the TTPs have remained mostly the same compared to the previously identified COVID-19-themed campaign. The subjects and email headers have changed slightly to accommodate newer, more relevant themes. For more information, see the Cyble blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
