instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Adobe Security Updates March 2021
Adobe has released three security updates. The updates are for Framemaker, Creative Cloud Desktop Application, and Connect. Each of the updates address at least one vulnerability rated by Adobe as Critical.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 The potential impact of successful exploitation of the most serious vulnerabilities is the remote execution of arbitrary code. Further details are available from the links below.

 **APSB21-14 Security Updates Available for Adobe Framemaker**  
Adobe has released a security update for Adobe Framemaker. This update addresses a critical vulnerability. Successful exploitation could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of the current user.  
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/framemaker/apsb21-14.html>

 **APSB21-18 Security update available for Adobe Creative Cloud Desktop Application**  
Adobe has released a security update for the Creative Cloud Desktop Application for Windows. This update resolves multiple critical vulnerabilities that could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of current user.  
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/creative-cloud/apsb21-18.html>

 **APSB21-19 Security updates available for Adobe Connect**  
Adobe has released a security update for Adobe Connect. This update resolves a critical and an important vulnerability. Successful exploitation could lead to arbitrary JavaScript execution within the context of the victim's browser.   
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/connect/apsb21-19.html>

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-21056, CVE-2021-21068, CVE-2021-21078, CVE-2021-21069, CVE-2021-21085, CVE-2021-21079, CVE-2021-21080, CVE-2021-21081 




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://helpx.adobe.com/security.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Unexpected Sign-In Attempt Phishing
Several companies across the US, England, and Scotland are reporting a targeted phishing campaign attempting to obtain corporate email account credentials. Cofense reports on their analysis of this campaign.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Unexpected Sign-In Attempt Phishing
Several companies across the US, England, and Scotland are reporting a targeted phishing campaign attempting to obtain corporate email account credentials. Cofense reports on their analysis of this campaign.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense has published their analysis of a phishing campaign seen targeting organizations in English-speaking countries. The phishing emails are customized using the organization's name in various aspects to appear more legitimate. It is used in the "From" field as part of the sender address, the subject line and in various parts of the email body. The email claims that there was a sign in attempt from a suspicious location and points to an attached file that can be used to review that activity. Opening the attached HTML file leads to a fake sign in page for the company's mail portal, requesting their email address and password. Cofense notes that the images and CSS styles are pulled from a remote website. Entering the credentials results in a POST request to an attacker-controlled URL. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/101-credential-phishing-for-observant-employees/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Threat Actors Leverage Asterisk Servers for Monetary Gain
Researchers at Check Point recently discovered one of the most intricate methods of exploitation conducted by threat actors. As surges of cyber fraud attacks worldwide surface, the targeting of VoIP and Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) servers to make outgoing phone calls and generate profits has also appeared.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Threat Actors Leverage Asterisk Servers for Monetary Gain
Researchers at Check Point recently discovered one of the most intricate methods of exploitation conducted by threat actors. As surges of cyber fraud attacks worldwide surface, the targeting of VoIP and Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) servers to make outgoing phone calls and generate profits has also appeared.

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware 




# Overview

Analysts at Check Point Research assessed a unique campaign operation being conducted in the Middle East originally and have seen the campaigns influence spread worldwide, with 60 countries falling victim.  According to analysts, they believe the threat actors are located in Gaza and exploit the open-source user interface Sangoma PB to gain C2 of Asterisk VoIP phone systems, specifically the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) servers. Asterisk is a well-known VoIP PBX (private branch exchange) system provider used for telecommunication services. PBX is initially used to establish and control phone calls between telecommunication endpoints like standard telephone sets and services/devices on VoIP networks. Researchers at Check Point also discovered Pastebin being leveraged in the campaign Pastebin to download password-protected web shells, leading them to believe it could be the work of an uploader known as INJ3CTOR3. Furthermore, researchers uncovered how threat actors have been able to generate monetary gain for themselves. By exploiting the desired VoIP server, threat actors have the ability to make calls to International Premium Rate Numbers, numbers used by businesses to offer phone-based purchases or services. When an IPRN is called, the victims making the calls to IPRNs will pay a fee meaning, more calls, more money for the threat actor. It was also assessed that threat actors began selling and bidding the compromised VoIP services, which generated them hundreds of thousands of dollars in profit, along with the added benefit of eavesdropping on phone calls. For more information, see the blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2020/inj3ctor3-operation-leveraging-asterisk-servers-for-monetization/>

  * <https://wiki.freepbx.org/display/FOP/2019-11-20+Remote+Admin+Authentication+Bypass>
  * <https://github.com/FreePBX/framework/commit/4e4675d9a8c0cb5ff8891aa1b51889a8b845502f>
  * <https://packetstormsecurity.com/files/author/12734/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: BazarBackdoor Delivered via Nested Archives
In an effort to evade detection by email security gateways, threat actors are leveraging nested archives. Cofense reports on one campaign implementing this technique to deliver the BazarBackdoor.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor




Overview

Cofense published a blog post analyzing a campaign leveraging nested archives to deliver the BazarBackdoor. Some email security gateways (SEGs) will be unable to identify nested archives as malicious due to limitations of how many layers of compression can be analyzed. In this case, the body of the email simply mentioned a proposed event for Environmental Day with references to the attached RAR and ZIP files. Both of these archives contained two additional layers of compression with the same format. Decompression eventually leads to an obfuscated JavaScript file that downloads a payload with a PNG extension over HTTP. Although it masquerades as a PNG, in reality the file is a BazarBackdoor executable. Once on the system, BazarBackdoor provides its operators with the ability to establish a foothold and deploy additional malware. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/nested-files-evade-segs/>

I have encountered the following information: Chrome Browser Update - May 10 2021
Google has released an update to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for nineteen vulnerabilities. Of the fifteen CVE-numbered vulnerabilities noted in the advisory, Google has rated thirteen of them as High, and two as Medium.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Google has released an update, version 90.0.4430.212, to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for nineteen vulnerabilities. Of the fifteen CVE-numbered vulnerabilities noted in the advisory, Google has rated thirteen of them as High, and two as Medium. Successful exploitation of the most serious vulnerabilities could potentially allow for the remote execution of arbitrary code. Further information is available from the release notes which are linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Satori Botnet Targeting Vantage Velocity Field Unit RCE Vulnerability
Palo Alto discovered a Mirai botnet variant, Satori, exploiting a Vantage Velocity field unit RCE vulnerability in order to spread itself.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet




# Overview

Palo Alto published a blog post analyzing Satori, a Mirai botnet variant, and its exploitation of a Vantage Velocity field unit RCE vulnerability. This vulnerability, CVE-2020-9020, was discovered in 2020 and is rated as critical due to a low attack complexity resulting in remote code execution. The exploit attempt observed by Palo Alto researchers tries to call wget on the target host in order to download a file from a remote server and subsequently executes it. The same server hosting this malware is believed to be the C2 server for the Satori botnet. Once on the system, the malware spawns and detaches multiple child processes. A brute force attack is performed against port 23 on random hosts, and multiple hardcoded commands are executed to spread the botnet infection to new victim devices. A patch for this vulnerability has been released by Vantage Velocity and should be applied as soon as possible. For more information, see the Palo Alto blog post in the Reference section.  


# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/satori-mirai-botnet-variant-targeting-vantage-velocity-field-unit-rce-vulnerability/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Malware That Prevents Access to Pirate Sites
A piece of malware that prevents access to well-known software piracy sites is the subject of a report from Sophos.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Malware That Prevents Access to Pirate Sites
A piece of malware that prevents access to well-known software piracy sites is the subject of a report from Sophos.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

A piece of malware that prevents access to well-known software piracy sites is being distributed through Discord file sharing and BitTorrent files. The versions delivered through Discord are typically a single executable file. The versions being distributed through torrent files are compressed archives containing multiple files, similar to how pirated software is typically packaged. The files are usually named as games and software packages, again, typically in the manner pirated software is named. When executed, the malware attempts to modify the system's HOSTS file. Administrative rights are required to edit the HOSTS file. If the user running the malware does not have administrative rights, the malware will ask to run with additional privileges. The HOSTS file is modified to point a large number of domains associated with software piracy to 127.0.0.1 which will prevent the victim from accessing the sites. Another payload is downloaded but this appears to simply add more domains to the HOSTS file. When executed, the malware delivers an error claiming it cannot run due to a missing DLL. This is a fake message as it is delivered whether or not the DLL exists on the system. The executables are signed with bogus certificates. It appears the malware has a kill switch as it looks for two files on the system and if they are found, it exits. The malware has no persistence mechanism. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/06/17/vigilante-antipiracy-malware/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Android Malware TeaBot Targets Banks in Europe
Cleafy provides a report on a new Android-based banking Trojan dubbed TeaBot. This Trojan does not appear to be related to any other banking Trojan families.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Android Malware TeaBot Targets Banks in Europe
Cleafy provides a report on a new Android-based banking Trojan dubbed TeaBot. This Trojan does not appear to be related to any other banking Trojan families.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan




# Overview

TeaBot (aka Anatsa) is a Trojan banking app in the Android landscape. Upon analysis by the researchers, this Trojan does not appear to be related to any other banking Trojan family. TeaBot is used to steal credentials and SMS messages for fraudulent actions against more than 60 banks. Interestingly, the trojan allows for a "livestream" view of the victim device as well as providing the ability for interacting through Accessibility Services. Injections were first observed in March 2021 against Italian banks. In May 2021, injections were seen against Belgium and Netherlands-based banks. At present, the trojan appears to be in early development. Other capabilities seen include key logging, stealing Google Authentication codes, and full remote control over an Android device. Anti-analysis techniques are implemented, such as junk code, a dynamic 2nd stage, and partially encrypted network communications using an XOR algorithm. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
  * Only install applications from trusted App Stores.



# Reference

  * <https://www.cleafy.com/documents/teabot>
